Diagnosis: Physical examination; review of medical and family history; abdominal ultrasound (most common); abdominal CT scan; abdominal MRI.
Treatments: Frequent health checkups and imaging (medical monitoring or watchful waiting); Surgery (endovascular repair; open surgery)
Tests: Abdominal ultrasound; Abdominal CT scan; Abdominal MRI; Chest X-ray

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves detailed description of seizures by the healthcare professional; physical exam; electroencephalography (EEG), which may be triggered by hyperventilation; brain scans (MRI) to rule out other conditions.  Changes in brainwave patterns during an EEG are key to diagnosis.
Treatments: Antiseizure medication; Ketogenic diet; Modified Atkins diet; Glycemic index diet
Tests: Electroencephalography (EEG); Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)

Diagnosis: Acanthosis nigricans is detected during a skin exam; a skin biopsy may be performed for microscopic examination; other tests may be needed to determine the underlying cause.
Treatments: Skin creams; special soaps; medications; laser therapy; weight loss (if obesity is a cause); discontinuation of medications or supplements (if implicated); surgery to remove tumor (if cancerous tumor is the cause)
Tests: Skin biopsy; Other tests to determine underlying cause (unspecified)

Diagnosis: Achalasia is diagnosed through a combination of clinical symptoms and diagnostic testing.  Diagnostic tests are used to confirm the diagnosis and differentiate achalasia from other conditions with similar symptoms.  Esophageal manometry is the most helpful test to determine the type of swallowing condition.
Treatments: Pneumatic dilation; OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) injection; Heller myotomy; Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM); Fundoplication; Medication (nitroglycerin; nifedipine)
Tests: Esophageal manometry; X-rays of the upper digestive system (barium swallow); Upper endoscopy; Functional luminal imaging probe (FLIP) technology

Diagnosis: Physical exam to assess pain, tenderness, swelling, and foot/ankle movement; Imaging tests may be used to rule out other conditions and visualize the tendon.
Treatments: Self-care (RICE); Pain medications; Nitroglycerin patch; Physical therapy (exercises, orthotic devices); Extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT); Platelet-rich plasma (PRP) injections; Ultrasound-guided tenotomy; Ultrasound-guided tendon scraping; Surgery
Tests: X-rays; Ultrasound; MRI
Medications_Drugs: Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Prescription medications for inflammation and pain relief; Nitroglycerin patch

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing tenderness, swelling, and a palpable gap in the tendon;  evaluation of plantar flexion by squeezing the calf muscle; ultrasound or MRI scan if the extent of the rupture is unclear.
Treatments: Nonsurgical treatment (rest, ice, over-the-counter pain relievers, immobilization with a walking boot or cast); Surgery (incision and stitching of the tendon, possibly reinforced with other tendons; minimally invasive options available) ; Physical therapy (including functional rehabilitation).
Tests: Physical examination; Ultrasound; MRI scan

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing knee swelling, tenderness, and range of motion; diagnosis often made based on physical exam alone, but further tests may be needed to rule out other causes and determine injury severity.
Treatments: Rehabilitative therapy (including exercises, bracing, and crutches); Surgery (ACL reconstruction using a tendon graft)
Tests: X-rays; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Ultrasound

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of acne is primarily clinical, based on the presence of comedones (blackheads and whiteheads), papules, pustules, nodules, and cysts.  Severity is assessed based on the number and type of lesions.
Treatments: Topical medications; Oral medications; Light therapy; Chemical peel; Drainage and extraction; Steroid injection
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: tretinoin (Avita, Retin-A); adapalene (Differin); tazarotene (Tazorac, Avage); clindamycin with benzoyl peroxide (Benzaclin, Duac); erythromycin with benzoyl peroxide (Benzamycin); azelaic acid (Azelex, Finacea); salicylic acid; dapsone (Aczone); minocycline; doxycycline; erythromycin; azithromycin; Ortho Tri-Cyclen 21; Yaz; spironolactone (Aldactone); isotretinoin (Amnesteem, Claravis); benzoyl peroxide

Diagnosis: A thorough physical exam, including an ear exam;  Symptoms assessment; Hearing test (audiometry); Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with contrast dye; CT scan (if MRI unavailable or contraindicated).  Early diagnosis is difficult due to slow symptom onset and overlap with other ear conditions.
Treatments: Monitoring; Surgery; Stereotactic radiosurgery (Gamma Knife, CyberKnife); Fractionated stereotactic radiotherapy (SRT); Proton beam therapy; Supportive therapy (balance therapy, physical therapy, occupational therapy, hearing assistance, cochlear implants).
Tests: Hearing test (audiometry); Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with contrast dye; CT scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing health history and physical examination;  high IGF-1 level in blood test suggests high growth hormone, a clue for acromegaly; growth hormone suppression test measures growth hormone levels before and after glucose intake (low levels after glucose in non-acromegaly patients); imaging tests (MRI) pinpoint pituitary tumors; X-rays of hands and feet check for bone growth.
Treatments: Surgery to remove pituitary tumor; Medication to lower hormone levels; Radiation to shrink tumor
Tests: IGF-1 measurement; Growth hormone suppression test; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); X-rays of hands and feet
Medications_Drugs: octreotide (Mycapssa, Sandostatin); lanreotide (Somatuline Depot); cabergoline; bromocriptine (Cycloset, Parlodel); pegvisomant (Somavert)

Diagnosis: Visual examination by a healthcare provider; Skin biopsy if there is doubt.
Treatments: Observation (may disappear on its own); Medicated cream or gel; Freezing (cryotherapy); Scraping (curettage); Electrosurgery; Laser therapy; Photodynamic therapy
Tests: Skin biopsy

Diagnosis: Acute coronary syndrome is usually diagnosed in a hospital using a combination of patient symptoms, medical history, and diagnostic tests such as electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG), blood tests to check for heart proteins, and potentially coronary angiogram, echocardiogram, myocardial perfusion imaging, or CT angiogram to assess blood flow and artery blockages.  The tests help classify the condition as a heart attack or unstable angina.
Treatments: Medicine; Angioplasty and stenting; Coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG)
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Blood tests; Coronary angiogram; Echocardiogram; Myocardial perfusion imaging; CT angiogram; Exercise stress test
Medications_Drugs: Nitroglycerin; Aspirin; Clopidogrel (Plavix); Prasugrel (Effient); Metoprolol (Lopressor, Toprol-XL); Nadolol; Lisinopril (Qbrelis, Zestril); Benazepril (Lotensin); Irbesartan (Avapro); Losartan (Cozaar); Atorvastatin (Lipitor, Atorvaliq); Simvastatin (Zocor, Flolipid); Ezetimibe (Zetia); Clot busters (Thrombolytics)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a thorough medical history and physical exam focusing on weakness, poor muscle tone, and decreased reflexes.  Further investigation may include nervous system examination; MRI of the brain and spinal cord; lab tests on cerebrospinal fluid, respiratory fluid, blood, and stool; and nerve conduction studies.  Differential diagnosis from other neurological conditions like Guillain-Barre syndrome is crucial.
Treatments: Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Immunoglobulin treatment; Corticosteroids; Antiviral drugs; Plasma exchange; Nerve and muscle transfer surgeries (in some cases)
Tests: Nervous system examination; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Lab tests (cerebrospinal fluid, respiratory fluid, blood, stool); Nerve conduction studies; Electromyography (EMG); Lumbar puncture (spinal tap)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of acute kidney injury involves assessing blood tests (showing elevated urea and creatinine levels); urine output measurements (over 24 hours); urine tests (urinalysis); imaging tests (ultrasound and CT scans); and potentially a kidney biopsy (tissue sample for lab testing).  The diagnosis relies on identifying these factors to determine the extent of kidney function impairment and underlying cause.
Treatments: Treating the underlying cause; Intravenous (IV) fluids; Diuretics; Potassium binders (sodium zirconium cyclosilicate (Lokelma); patiromer (Veltassa)); Calcium infusions; Hemodialysis; Special diet
Tests: Blood tests; Urine output measures; Urine tests (urinalysis); Imaging tests (ultrasound; CT scan); Kidney biopsy

Diagnosis: Assessment of liver function through blood tests (including prothrombin time to assess clotting); imaging tests such as ultrasound, CT scan, and MRI to visualize the liver and identify potential causes like Budd-Chiari syndrome or tumors; liver biopsy to examine liver tissue and determine the cause of failure.
Treatments: Treatment of underlying cause (e.g., reversing poisoning); Medications to manage complications (e.g., cerebral edema, infections, bleeding); Nutritional support; Liver transplant; Artificial hepatic assist devices (e.g., extracorporeal liver support system/high-volume plasma exchange); Hepatocyte transplantation; Auxiliary liver transplantation; Xenotransplantation (experimental).
Tests: Blood tests; Prothrombin time test; Ultrasound; Abdominal CT scan; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Liver biopsy (including transjugular liver biopsy)
Medications_Drugs: Acetylcysteine; Medications to reduce cerebral edema; Medications to treat infections; Medications to reduce bleeding risk; Nutritional supplements.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of acute lymphocytic leukemia involves blood tests revealing abnormal white blood cell counts and the presence of blast cells; bone marrow aspiration and biopsy to identify leukemia cells, classify them by type (B or T lymphocytes), and analyze genetic changes; imaging tests (X-ray, CT scan, ultrasound) to assess cancer spread; and spinal fluid test (lumbar puncture) to check for central nervous system involvement.  The seriousness is determined by lymphocyte type (B or T cells), genetic changes, age, and lab test results.  There are no stages.
Treatments: Induction therapy; Consolidation therapy; Maintenance therapy; Preventive treatment to the spinal cord; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Radiation therapy; Bone marrow transplant (stem cell transplant); CAR-T cell therapy; Clinical trials
Tests: Blood tests; Bone marrow aspiration; Bone marrow biopsy; X-ray; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Ultrasound scan; Lumbar puncture (spinal tap)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with an exam checking for bruising, bleeding, infection, and swollen lymph nodes.  Further diagnosis involves blood tests (complete blood count to assess blood cell counts and identify myeloblasts), bone marrow aspiration and biopsy (to examine bone marrow cells for DNA changes), and sometimes a lumbar puncture (if spread to the brain and spinal cord is suspected). Imaging tests (CT, MRI, PET) may be used to assess for spread to other parts of the body.  Genetic testing is used to determine the AML subtype.
Treatments: Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Bone marrow transplant; Clinical trials
Tests: Complete blood count; Blood test for myeloblasts; Bone marrow aspiration; Bone marrow biopsy; Lumbar puncture; CT scan; MRI scan; PET scan; Genetic testing

Diagnosis: Physical exam including palpation for tenderness in the nose and face; inspection of the nasal passages; nasal endoscopy; CT scan (not usually for simple cases, but may help rule out other causes); nasal and sinus samples (rarely used, but may be necessary if condition worsens or doesn't improve with treatment).
Treatments: Self-care; saline nasal spray; nasal corticosteroids; decongestants; allergy medications (for allergy-induced sinusitis); pain relievers; antibiotics (for severe, worsening, or persistent symptoms); immunotherapy (for allergy-related sinusitis); nasal lavage (neti pot or squeeze bottle).
Tests: Nasal endoscopy; CT scan; Nasal and sinus samples
Medications_Drugs: fluticasone; budesonide; mometasone; beclomethasone; acetaminophen; ibuprofen; aspirin

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing medical history and symptoms, followed by tests to check for Addison's disease or secondary adrenal insufficiency.  Diagnostic criteria aren't explicitly listed but are implied through the diagnostic tests described.
Treatments: Corticosteroid medication replacement; Increased sodium intake in diet; Corticosteroid injections in case of emergency; Medical alert card and bracelet; Action plan; Regular follow-up with healthcare professional; Yearly checkups
Tests: Blood test (measuring sodium, potassium, cortisol, ACTH, and Addison's disease-related antibodies); ACTH stimulation test; Insulin-induced hypoglycemia test; CT scan of the stomach area; MRI of the pituitary gland
Medications_Drugs: Hydrocortisone (Cortef); Prednisone (Rayos, Prednisone Intensol); Methylprednisolone (Medrol); Fludrocortisone acetate

Diagnosis: Adenomyosis diagnosis is challenging due to similar symptoms with other uterine conditions like fibroids, endometriosis, and endometrial polyps. Diagnosis often involves ruling out other conditions.  Suspicion arises from signs and symptoms, pelvic exam revealing an enlarged, tender uterus, ultrasound, and MRI.  While pelvic imaging can detect signs, confirmation typically requires examination of the uterus post-hysterectomy; endometrial biopsy may rule out other conditions but won't confirm adenomyosis.
Treatments: Anti-inflammatory drugs; Hormone medications (combined estrogen-progestin birth control pills, hormone-containing patches, vaginal rings, progestin-only contraception, continuous-use birth control pills); Hysterectomy
Tests: Pelvic exam; Ultrasound; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Endometrial biopsy

Diagnosis: A mental health professional assesses major life stressors, symptoms, and their impact on daily life through a clinical interview focusing on medical, mental health, and social history.  Key diagnostic criteria include onset of emotional or behavioral symptoms within three months of a specific stressful event; disproportionate stress response to the event; symptoms not attributable to another mental health condition or typical grieving.
Treatments: Talk therapy (individual, group, or family); Medications (antidepressants; anti-anxiety drugs)
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a pelvic exam to palpate pelvic organs.  Imaging tests (ultrasound, CT scan, MRI) visualize the location and size of the mass. Blood tests may include a pregnancy test, infection tests, and tumor marker tests (e.g., CA-125).
Treatments: No treatment (for small cysts); Surgery to remove the tumor or mass
Tests: Pelvic exam; Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI; Pregnancy test; Blood tests for infection; CA-125 test

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam, review of health and family history, and blood and urine tests to assess hormone levels (cortisol, aldosterone, androgens).  Imaging tests (CT, MRI, PET scans) are used to visualize adrenal growths and assess metastasis.  In some cases, surgical removal of the adrenal gland followed by pathological examination is necessary for diagnosis.
Treatments: Surgery (adrenalectomy); Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Mitotane (Lysodren); Immunotherapy
Tests: Blood tests; Urine tests; CT scan; MRI scan; PET scan; Surgical removal of adrenal gland with pathological examination

Diagnosis: Review of symptoms and medical/family history; physical examination; blood testing to check for high levels of very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) and to evaluate adrenal gland function; genetic testing for ALD-causing defects/mutations; MRI to detect brain abnormalities; vision screening (to monitor disease progression in males with no other symptoms); skin biopsy and fibroblast cell culture (in some cases).
Treatments: Stem cell transplantation; Adrenal insufficiency treatment (corticosteroid replacement therapy); Medications to relieve symptoms (stiffness, seizures); Physical therapy; Gene therapy (in clinical trials).
Tests: Blood testing; Genetic testing; MRI; Vision screening; Skin biopsy; Fibroblast cell culture

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam to rule out other conditions; information gathering about medical history, personal history, and symptom history; and the use of ADHD rating scales or psychological tests to evaluate symptoms.  No single test confirms the diagnosis. Core symptoms must begin before age 12 and continue into adulthood to be considered ADHD.
Treatments: Medication; education; skills training; psychological counseling; psychotherapy; cognitive behavioral therapy; marital counseling; family therapy
Tests: Physical exam; ADHD rating scales; psychological tests

Diagnosis: No single test identifies adult Still disease.  Diagnosis is based on symptoms and ruling out other conditions with similar symptoms through blood tests and imaging.
Treatments: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs); Steroids; Methotrexate; Biologic response modifiers; Exercise
Tests: Antinuclear antibody (ANA) test; C-reactive protein test; CT scan; Echocardiogram; Ferritin test; Sed rate (erythrocyte sedimentation rate); Ultrasound; X-ray
Medications_Drugs: ibuprofen; naproxen sodium; prednisone; methotrexate (Trexall); anakinra (Kineret); canakinumab (Ilaris); tocilizumab (Actemra); etanercept (Enbrel); infliximab (Remicade); adalimumab (Humira); rituximab (Rituxan)

Diagnosis: Visual inspection by a doctor; Skin biopsy to distinguish age spots from other conditions, such as lentigo maligna.
Treatments: Prescription bleaching creams (hydroquinone) alone or with retinoids (tretinoin) and a mild steroid; Laser and intense pulsed light therapies; Freezing (cryotherapy); Dermabrasion; Microdermabrasion; Chemical peel; Over-the-counter fade creams containing hydroquinone, glycolic acid, or kojic acid; Makeup to conceal spots.
Tests: Skin biopsy

Diagnosis: Based on symptoms; in-depth interview with a healthcare or mental health provider; physical exam to rule out other conditions.
Treatments: Psychotherapy (cognitive behavioral therapy); Exposure therapy; Intensive outpatient program; Residential program; Medications (antidepressants; anti-anxiety medications)
Tests: Physical exam

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of airplane ear (ear barotrauma) is based on medical history and an examination of the ear with an otoscope.
Treatments: Time; Decongestant nasal sprays; Oral decongestants; Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (ibuprofen, naproxen sodium); Acetaminophen; Valsalva maneuver; Myringotomy (rarely needed)
Tests: Otoscopic examination
Medications_Drugs: Decongestant nasal sprays; Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Acetaminophen

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing skin and hair pigmentation; Thorough eye exam by an ophthalmologist, including retinal assessment; Comparison of pigmentation to family members; Review of medical history (including bleeding, bruising, infections); Genetic testing to determine type of albinism and genetic risk.
Treatments: Eye care (annual eye exams, prescription lenses, possible eye muscle surgery for nystagmus or strabismus); Skin care and skin cancer prevention (annual skin exams); Specialized care for Hermansky-Pudlak or Chediak-Higashi syndromes.
Tests: Physical exam; Eye exam; Genetic testing

Diagnosis: Physical exam; Skin test to identify potential allergies to ingredients in alcoholic beverages; Blood test to measure immunoglobulin E antibodies, though test accuracy is noted to be inconsistent.
Treatments: Avoidance of alcohol or specific problematic beverages/ingredients; Over-the-counter or prescription antihistamines for minor reactions.
Tests: Skin test; Blood test

Diagnosis: Assessment of visible signs and symptoms; blood and urine tests to check blood alcohol levels and identify other signs of alcohol toxicity, such as low blood sugar.
Treatments: Monitoring to prevent breathing or choking problems; Oxygen therapy; Fluids given through a vein to prevent dehydration; Use of vitamins and glucose to prevent serious complications; Hemodialysis (for methanol or isopropyl alcohol ingestion)
Tests: Blood test; Urine test

Diagnosis: Assessment of drinking habits through questions; Physical exam to identify physical signs of alcohol-related complications; Review of lab test results (though no specific test diagnoses alcohol use disorder, patterns may suggest it); Psychological evaluation including questions about symptoms, thoughts, feelings, and behavior patterns; potentially questionnaires.
Treatments: Brief intervention; Individual or group counseling; Outpatient program; Residential inpatient stay; Detoxification (medically managed withdrawal); Learning new skills and treatment planning (goal setting, behavior change techniques, self-help manuals, counseling, follow-up care); Psychological counseling (individual, group, couples, or family therapy); Oral medications; Injected medication; Aftercare programs; Support groups; Treatment for co-occurring mental health disorders; Medical treatment for alcohol-related health problems.
Tests: Lab tests; Imaging tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam, assessment of alcohol use history, liver function tests, blood tests, and imaging studies such as ultrasound, CT, or MRI scans. A liver biopsy may be performed if other tests are inconclusive or if other causes of hepatitis are suspected.
Treatments: Quitting alcohol consumption; Special diet to address malnutrition; Medications to reduce liver swelling (inflammation);  Counseling; Alcoholics Anonymous or other support groups; Outpatient or live-in treatment program; Liver transplant (in severe cases and with stringent criteria)
Tests: Liver function tests; Blood tests; Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI scan; Liver biopsy

Diagnosis: Detailed questioning about symptoms; Physical exam; Detailed symptom and trigger diary (including food diary for food allergies); Skin prick test; Intradermal skin test; Specific IgE (sIgE) blood testing (also known as RAST or ImmunoCAP testing).  If other causes are suspected, additional tests may be necessary.
Treatments: Avoidance of triggers; Medications (pills, liquids, nasal sprays, eye drops); Immunotherapy (shots or sublingual tablets); Emergency epinephrine (e.g., Auvi-Q, EpiPen)
Tests: Skin prick test; Intradermal skin test; Specific IgE (sIgE) blood test (RAST or ImmunoCAP test)
Medications_Drugs: Epinephrine (e.g., Auvi-Q, EpiPen); Antihistamines (mentioned as affecting skin test results, but specific names not listed)

Diagnosis: Alpha-gal syndrome is diagnosed based on patient history (tick bites, location of tick exposure, symptoms, time elapsed between red meat consumption and symptom onset) and medical tests.  A key diagnostic criterion is the presence of alpha-gal antibodies.  A physical exam may also be conducted.
Treatments: Avoiding foods containing red meat or mammal-derived products (beef, pork, lamb, organ meats, gelatin); Epinephrine auto-injector for serious reactions
Tests: Blood test to measure alpha-gal antibodies; Skin test to assess reactivity to red meat

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves patient symptom description (with family input), memory and thinking skills tests, blood and imaging tests to rule out other causes and identify Alzheimer's-related brain proteins (plaques and tangles).  Biomarker tests, including amyloid and tau protein measurements in blood or cerebrospinal fluid, and PET scans (amyloid and tau PET, FDG PET) are increasingly used to detect the presence and stage of the disease.
Treatments: Medications
Tests: Physical and neurological exam; Blood tests (including beta-amyloid and tau protein levels); Mental status and neuropsychological testing; Brain imaging (MRI, CT, FDG PET, Amyloid PET, Tau PET)
Medications_Drugs: donepezil (Aricept, Adlarity); galantamine; rivastigmine transdermal patch (Exelon); memantine (Namenda)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with imaging tests (X-ray, CT, and MRI scans) to determine the tumor's extent; a tissue or cell sample is then sent to a lab for testing to confirm the diagnosis.  The tumor may be incidentally found on routine dental X-rays.
Treatments: Surgery to remove the tumor; Surgery to repair the jaw; Radiation therapy; Prosthetics; Supportive care (including dietitian, speech and language therapy, and physical therapy)
Tests: X-ray; CT scan; MRI scan; Tissue biopsy

Diagnosis: Pelvic exam to check for reproductive organ problems; Breast and genital exam (if never had a period) to assess puberty changes; Blood tests to identify hormonal imbalances; Imaging tests (ultrasound, MRI) to detect structural abnormalities; Hysteroscopy to visualize the uterus if other tests are inconclusive.
Treatments: Birth control pills (combination and minipill); Hormone therapies; Medications for thyroid or pituitary disorders; Surgery for tumors or structural blockages.
Tests: Pregnancy test; Thyroid function test (TSH); Ovary function test (FSH); Prolactin test; Male hormone test; Ultrasound; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Hysteroscopy

Diagnosis: A comprehensive evaluation including detailed medical history from the patient and/or family/caregiver focusing on type and onset of memory loss, potential triggers (head injury, stroke, surgery), family history, substance use, and associated symptoms; physical exam, potentially including neurological exam; cognitive tests assessing thinking, judgment, and memory; imaging tests (MRI, CT scan) to rule out brain damage; blood tests to check for infection, nutritional deficiencies, etc.; EEG to detect seizure activity.
Treatments: Occupational therapy for memory training and compensatory strategies; Technological assistance (smartphones, tablets, etc.) and low-tech memory aids (notebooks, calendars);  Treatment of underlying conditions (e.g., thiamine replacement for Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome; cholinesterase inhibitors for Alzheimer's disease).
Tests: MRI; CT scan; Blood tests; EEG; Cognitive tests; Neurological exam

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of ampullary cancer involves visualizing the ampulla of Vater using endoscopy, often with endoscopic ultrasound to obtain images;  Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) may be used to highlight bile ducts and identify blockages;  Biopsy of tissue samples is crucial for confirming the diagnosis and determining cancer characteristics.
Treatments: Surgery (Whipple procedure, endoscopic surgery for small cancers, stent placement); Combined chemotherapy and radiation; Chemotherapy alone; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy; Palliative care
Tests: Endoscopy; Endoscopic ultrasound; Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP); Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography; CT scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Amyloidosis is diagnosed through laboratory tests (blood and urine analysis for abnormal proteins; thyroid and kidney function tests), biopsy (of subcutaneous fat, bone marrow, or affected organs like liver or kidney to identify amyloid type), and imaging tests (Echocardiogram, MRI, Nuclear imaging) to assess organ damage.  The diagnosis can be challenging because symptoms mimic other conditions.
Treatments: Treatment of underlying conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, tuberculosis); Chemotherapy; Heart medications; Drugs that increase urination; Targeted therapies; Autologous blood stem cell transplant; Dialysis; Organ transplant
Tests: Blood and urine analysis; Thyroid and kidney function tests; Biopsy (subcutaneous fat, bone marrow, affected organs); Echocardiogram; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Nuclear imaging
Medications_Drugs: patisiran (Onpattro); inotersen (Tegsedi); tafamidis (Vyndamax, Vyndaqel); diflunisal; Blood thinners (type unspecified);  Heart rate control medications (type unspecified)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis can be challenging due to similar symptoms to other diseases.  Diagnosis involves ruling out other conditions using various tests such as EMG, nerve conduction studies, MRI, blood and urine tests (including serum neurofilament light levels), spinal tap, muscle biopsy, and nerve biopsy.  High serum neurofilament light levels in blood samples suggest ALS.
Treatments: Medications; Breathing care (including mechanical ventilation and tracheostomy); Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Speech therapy; Nutritional support; Psychological and social support
Tests: Electromyogram (EMG); Nerve conduction study; MRI; Blood and urine tests; Serum neurofilament light level test; Spinal tap (lumbar puncture); Muscle biopsy; Nerve biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a digital rectal exam to palpate for growths; anoscopy using an anoscope to visually examine the anal canal; imaging tests such as ultrasound, X-ray, MRI, CT scan, and PET scan to determine location and size; and biopsy to obtain a tissue sample for lab analysis to confirm cancer and determine cancer cell characteristics.  Staging tests, often including imaging, are used to determine the extent of cancer spread.
Treatments: Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy; Surgery (including surgery for very small cancers and abdominoperineal resection - APR); Immunotherapy; Palliative care
Tests: Digital rectal exam; Anoscopy; Ultrasound; X-ray; MRI; CT scan; PET scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Physical exam with visual inspection of the anal region;  A recent fissure appears as a fresh tear, while a chronic fissure (lasting over 8 weeks) shows a deeper tear and may have growths; Location may indicate underlying conditions like Crohn's disease.
Treatments: Home treatment (increased fiber and fluids, warm water soaks); Externally applied nitroglycerin; Topical anesthetic creams (lidocaine); OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) injection; Blood pressure medications (nifedipine or diltiazem); Surgery (lateral internal sphincterotomy)
Tests: Anoscopy; Flexible sigmoidoscopy; Colonoscopy

Diagnosis: Physical exam to assess the area around and inside the anus, identifying the external opening;  imaging tests to identify the fistula's internal opening and complete path.
Treatments: Fistulotomy; Endorectal advancement flap; Ligation of the intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT); Seton placement; Fibrin glue and collagen plug; Ostomy and stoma; Muscle flap
Tests: MRI; Endoscopic ultrasound; Fistulography; Examination under anesthesia; Fistula probe; Anoscope; Flexible sigmoidoscopy; Colonoscopy; Injected dye solution

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on patient symptoms, medical history, personal habits, and physical exam (including rectal exam).  A pinworm test may be done if suspected. If the cause is unclear or treatment ineffective, referral to a dermatologist or proctologist may occur.
Treatments: Anti-itch cream; Treatment of infection; Fecal incontinence treatment; Oral antihistamine;  Zinc oxide ointment; Petroleum jelly; Hydrocortisone 1% cream; Dietary changes (reducing irritants like tea, coffee, cola, alcohol, citrus fruits, pepper, dairy products, spicy foods, tomato sauce and tomatoes); Increased fiber intake (vegetables, whole grains, noncitrus fruits, beans, nuts, seeds, fiber supplements like psyllium or methylcellulose); Colonoscopy (mentioned as an associated procedure, but not explicitly as a diagnostic test in this context);  Careful washing routine to keep the area clean, cool, and dry;  Applying a moist, room-temperature compress; Lukewarm oatmeal bath.
Tests: Pinworm test
Medications_Drugs: Oral antihistamine; Hydrocortisone 1% cream;  Psyllium (Metamucil); Methylcellulose (Citrucel)

Diagnosis: Provider questions about previous allergic reactions (foods, medications, latex, insect stings); blood test to measure tryptase levels (elevated up to 3 hours post-anaphylaxis); allergy skin or blood tests to identify triggers; ruling out other conditions with similar symptoms.
Treatments: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR); Epinephrine; Oxygen; Intravenous antihistamines; Intravenous cortisone; Beta-agonist (e.g., albuterol); Allergy shots (immunotherapy for insect sting anaphylaxis);  Hemodialysis
Tests: Blood test (tryptase); Allergy skin tests; Allergy blood tests; Creatinine test; Urinalysis

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing medical and family history, performing a physical exam, and ordering blood tests, including a complete blood count (CBC) to measure hematocrit and hemoglobin levels;  a test to assess red blood cell size, shape, and color; and, in some cases, bone marrow study.
Treatments: Iron supplements; Dietary changes; Blood transfusion; Erythropoietin injections; Medications; Chemotherapy; Bone marrow transplant; Vitamin B12 shots; Folic acid supplements;  Oxygen therapy; Pain relievers; Intravenous fluids;  Hydroxyurea (Droxia, Hydrea, Siklos); Splenectomy
Tests: Complete blood count (CBC); Red blood cell size, shape, and color assessment; Bone marrow study
Medications_Drugs: Hydroxyurea (Droxia, Hydrea, Siklos);  Iron supplements; Folic acid supplements; Erythropoietin

Diagnosis: Developmental delays, little to no speech, seizures, movement and balance problems, and small head size may suggest Angelman syndrome;  diagnosis is confirmed through genetic testing that identifies specific chromosomal changes or gene mutations.  Differential diagnosis is necessary as symptoms overlap with other syndromes.
Treatments: Anti-seizure medication; Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Communication and speech therapy (including sign language and picture communication); Behavior therapy; Sleep training; Diet changes; Medications to address feeding issues and constipation; Cognitive behavioral therapy
Tests: Blood test (DNA methylation test to screen for gene changes); Chromosomal microarray (CMA) to detect missing chromosome parts; UBE3A gene sequencing (if DNA methylation test results are typical); Electroencephalogram (EEG) to assess brain electrical activity
Medications_Drugs: Anti-seizure medication; Medications to address feeding issues and constipation

Diagnosis: Physical examination and patient history review focusing on symptoms and risk factors (including family history of heart disease);  Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) to assess heart electrical activity.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (healthy diet, exercise); Medicines; Angioplasty and stenting; Coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG); Enhanced external counterpulsation (EECP)
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Chest X-ray; Blood tests (cardiac enzymes); Stress test; Echocardiogram; Nuclear stress test; Cardiac computed tomography (CT); Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Coronary angiogram
Medications_Drugs: Nitroglycerin (Nitrostat); Aspirin; Clopidogrel (Plavix); Prasugrel (Effient); Ticagrelor (Brilinta); Beta blockers; Statins; Calcium channel blockers; Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors; Angiotensin 2 receptor blockers (ARBs); Ranolazine

Diagnosis: Angiosarcoma diagnosis involves a physical exam; tissue biopsy to detect cancer cells; and imaging tests such as MRI, CT, and PET scans to determine the extent of the cancer.
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Targeted drug therapy; Immunotherapy
Tests: Physical exam; Biopsy; MRI; CT; Positron emission tomography (PET)

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing spinal range of motion and pain reproduction; Imaging tests (X-rays and MRI) to detect changes in joints and bones, with MRI being more sensitive for early detection of nonradiographic axial spondyloarthritis; Blood tests for markers of inflammation (though not specific to ankylosing spondylitis) and HLA-B27 gene (though not definitive).
Treatments: Medications; Physical therapy; Surgery
Tests: X-rays; MRI; Blood tests for inflammation markers; HLA-B27 gene test
Medications_Drugs: Naproxen sodium (Aleve); Ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB); Adalimumab (Humira); Certolizumab pegol (Cimzia); Etanercept (Enbrel); Golimumab (Simponi); Infliximab (Remicade); Secukinumab (Cosentyx); Ixekizumab (Taltz); Tofacitinib (Xeljanz); Upadacitinib (Rinvoq)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam (measuring height and weight, checking vital signs, skin and nails, heart and lungs, and stomach area); lab tests (complete blood count, electrolyte and protein checks, liver, kidney, and thyroid function tests, urinalysis); and a mental health evaluation assessing thoughts, feelings, and eating habits.  X-rays may be used to check bone density, stress fractures, broken bones, pneumonia, or heart problems; electrocardiogram may be used to check for heart issues.
Treatments: Hospital stays; Day treatment programs; Residential treatment programs; Specialized eating disorder programs; Nasogastric tube feeding (in severe cases); Family-based therapy (FBT for teenagers); Nutritional counseling; Psychotherapy; Medical monitoring of vital signs, hydration, and electrolytes;  Supplements (e.g., vitamin D, as recommended by a healthcare professional)
Tests: Physical exam; Complete blood count (CBC); Electrolyte and protein blood tests; Liver function tests; Kidney function tests; Thyroid function tests; Urinalysis; X-ray; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Bone density test

Diagnosis: Review of medical history; general medical exam; pelvic exam; questionnaire about sexual experiences, partners, feelings about sexual experiences, types of stimulation/sexual activity; interview with patient and potentially partner.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes; education about female sexual anatomy; directed masturbation; sensate focus exercises; changes in sexual positions; sexual enhancement devices (vibrators, air-pulsating devices, suction devices); cognitive behavioral therapy; hormone replacement therapy (estrogen therapy; testosterone therapy).
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Pelvic exam to observe tissue bulge in vagina; assessment of prolapse worsening with bearing down; evaluation of pelvic floor muscle strength by asking patient to stop urine stream; review of medical, surgical, and pregnancy history; bladder and urine tests to assess bladder emptying and check for infection.
Treatments: Pelvic floor muscle exercises (Kegel exercises); Pessary; Surgery (vaginal, laparoscopic, robotic-assisted laparoscopic, open); Hysterectomy (if prolapse is linked with prolapsed uterus)
Tests: Pelvic exam; Urinalysis; Tests to assess bladder emptying

Diagnosis: Physician inquires about occupation and potential anthrax exposure; rules out other conditions like influenza or pneumonia; further testing may include skin testing of lesions or biopsies; blood tests; chest X-ray or CT scan (for inhalation anthrax); stool testing (for gastrointestinal anthrax); spinal tap (for suspected systemic anthrax).
Treatments: Antibiotics; Antitoxin; Surgical removal of infected tissue (in some injection anthrax cases); Intensive supportive care (including ventilators, fluids, and vasopressors).
Tests: Skin testing; Biopsy; Blood tests; Chest X-ray; CT scan; Stool testing; Spinal tap (lumbar puncture)
Medications_Drugs: Raxibacumab; Obiltoxaximab; Anthrax immunoglobulin; Antibiotics (specific antibiotic choice depends on various factors).

Diagnosis: The doctor will ask about health history, including recent antibiotic use; if *C. difficile* infection is suspected, a stool sample will be tested for the bacterium.
Treatments: For mild diarrhea, discontinuation of antibiotics or allowing symptoms to resolve; for *C. difficile* infection, stopping current antibiotics and prescribing targeted antibiotics; avoiding stomach-acid-suppressing drugs; oral rehydration solution; bland diet avoiding dairy, fatty, and spicy foods;  loperamide (Imodium A-D) may be recommended for mild cases (but not for *C. difficile* infection); probiotics may be considered, but their effectiveness isn't conclusive.
Tests: Stool test for *C. difficile*
Medications_Drugs: Loperamide (Imodium A-D); Antibiotics targeted to kill *C. difficile* (specific antibiotics not named)

Diagnosis: Antiphospholipid syndrome is diagnosed by the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies in the blood on at least two occasions, 12 or more weeks apart.  A diagnosis is only made when these antibodies cause health problems, such as blood clots or pregnancy loss.
Treatments: Blood-thinning medications;  Heparin; Warfarin; Aspirin; Hydroxychloroquine; Rituximab; Statins (more study needed)
Tests: Blood tests to check for clotting and the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies
Medications_Drugs: Heparin; Warfarin (Jantoven); Aspirin; Hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil); Rituximab (Rituxan); Statins

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is usually based on a mental health exam assessing thoughts, feelings, relationships, behavior patterns, and family history; symptom evaluation; personal and medical history;  a key factor is how the person relates to others, with information from family and friends being helpful;  a medical exam helps rule out other medical conditions; diagnosis is typically not made before age 18.
Treatments: Talk therapy (psychotherapy), including anger and violence management, treatment for substance use, and treatment for other mental health conditions; Cognitive behavioral therapy
Tests: Complete blood count (CBC); Medical exam

Diagnosis: Psychological evaluation to discuss thoughts, feelings, and behaviors; Comparison of symptoms to DSM-5 criteria; Consideration of co-occurring mental health problems (e.g., depression, substance misuse).
Treatments: Psychotherapy (including Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and exposure therapy); Medications; Lifestyle changes (physical activity, stress management techniques, sleep hygiene, healthy diet); Alternative medicine (herbal remedies, but further research needed).
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: Certain antidepressants; Buspirone; Benzodiazepines (sedatives); Beta blockers.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis can be challenging due to similar symptoms to other conditions.  Key indicators include sudden tearing or ripping chest pain; blood pressure difference between arms; and widening of the aorta on chest X-ray.
Treatments: Surgery; Medications
Tests: Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE); Computerized tomography (CT) scan of the chest; Magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA)

Diagnosis: Physical examination, including auscultation for heart murmurs; review of symptoms and medical history.  Further evaluation by a cardiologist may be necessary if a murmur is detected.
Treatments: Regular health checkups; Lifestyle changes; Medications; Surgery (open-heart, minimally invasive); Catheter-based procedures; Aortic valve repair (including separating fused flaps, adding support, reshaping tissue, patching holes); Aortic valve replacement (mechanical valve replacement; biological valve replacement; Ross procedure); Balloon valvuloplasty; Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR).
Tests: Echocardiogram (standard and transesophageal); Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Chest X-ray; Cardiac MRI; Cardiac computerized tomography (CT) scan; Exercise tests or stress tests; Cardiac catheterization (less frequently used for diagnosis, more often for severity assessment).

Diagnosis: Physical examination including listening for heart murmurs; review of symptoms and medical/family history; blood pressure check.  Referral to a cardiologist may occur.
Treatments: Regular health checkups; regular echocardiograms; heart-healthy lifestyle changes; medications to treat symptoms, reduce complications, and lower blood pressure; Aortic valve repair; Aortic valve replacement (biological or mechanical); Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR); Ross procedure
Tests: Echocardiogram (including transesophageal echocardiogram); Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Chest X-ray; CT scan of the heart; Exercise tests or stress tests; Cardiac MRI; Cardiac catheterization

Diagnosis: Physical examination, including auscultation for heart murmurs; review of symptoms and medical history.
Treatments: Regular health checkups; Medications to treat symptoms or reduce complications; Heart-healthy lifestyle changes; Surgery to fix or replace the valve (including biological valve replacement, mechanical valve replacement, transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR), balloon valvuloplasty, aortic valve replacement, and the Ross procedure).
Tests: Echocardiogram (standard and transesophageal); Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Chest X-ray; Exercise tests or stress tests; Cardiac computerized tomography (CT) scan; Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan; Cardiac catheterization (less frequently used for diagnosis).

Diagnosis: Physical and neurological exams assessing strength, feeling, reflexes, heart and neck vessels; MRI or CT scan to identify the cause; comprehensive language assessment by a speech-language pathologist evaluating naming, conversation, word understanding and use, question answering, repetition, instruction following, and reading/writing abilities.
Treatments: Speech and language therapy; medications (under investigation); brain stimulation (transcranial magnetic stimulation and transcranial direct current stimulation)
Tests: MRI; CT scan; comprehensive language assessment
Medications_Drugs: memantine (Namenda); donepezil (Aricept, Adlarity); galantamine (Razadyne ER); piracetam

Diagnosis: Aplastic anemia is diagnosed through blood tests showing low levels of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets; and a bone marrow biopsy revealing fewer blood cells than normal in the bone marrow.  A bone marrow biopsy is required to confirm the diagnosis. Further tests may be needed to determine the cause.
Treatments: Observation; Blood transfusions; Immunosuppressant medications; Stem cell transplant; Bone marrow stimulants; Antibiotics; Antivirals
Tests: Blood tests; Bone marrow biopsy; Bone marrow aspiration
Medications_Drugs: Cyclosporine; Antithymocyte globulin; Methylprednisolone; Sargramostim; Filgrastim; Pegfilgrastim; Epoetin alfa; Eltrombopag

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a history of symptoms, abdominal examination (checking for pain upon release of pressure, abdominal stiffness, guarding), digital rectal exam, and potentially a pelvic exam.  A high white blood cell count may suggest infection.
Treatments: Appendectomy (open or laparoscopic surgery); Abscess drainage; Antibiotics
Tests: Physical exam; Blood test; Urine test (urinalysis); Abdominal X-ray; Abdominal ultrasound; CT scan; MRI

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on physical exams, chest X-rays, and oxygen levels;  other diseases and conditions, such as heart problems causing similar symptoms, must be ruled out.
Treatments: Extra oxygen; Mechanical ventilation; Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO); Prone positioning; Fluid management;  Treatment for infections; Pain management; Blood clot prevention; Gastric acid reflux reduction; Anxiety management; Lung transplant
Tests: Chest X-ray; CT scan; Arterial blood gas test;  Electrocardiogram (ECG); Echocardiogram;  Airway secretion tests (if lung infection suspected)

Diagnosis: Physical examination including listening to the heart; review of symptoms and family history; consultation with a cardiologist if needed.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (healthy diet, exercise); Medications; Angioplasty and stent placement; Endarterectomy; Coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery; Fibrinolytic therapy
Tests: Coronary calcium scan; Blood tests (including cholesterol and blood sugar levels, C-reactive protein); Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Exercise stress tests; Echocardiogram; Doppler ultrasound; Ankle-brachial index (ABI); Cardiac catheterization and angiogram; Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA); Positron emission tomography (PET)
Medications_Drugs: Statins; Niacin; Fibrates; Bile acid sequestrants; Aspirin; Blood pressure medicine;  Other medicines to control conditions like diabetes; Fibrinolytic therapy (clot-dissolving medicine)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves listening for a humming sound with a stethoscope;  further confirmation may involve other tests.
Treatments: Close monitoring; Ultrasound-guided compression; Catheter embolization; Surgery
Tests: Duplex ultrasound; Computerized tomography (CT) angiogram; Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing symptoms and a physical exam, potentially listening for a bruit (whooshing sound from blood flow).  Diagnostic tests are used to confirm the presence and characteristics of the AVM.
Treatments: Monitoring with regular imaging; Conservative management; Surgery (complete removal or endovascular embolization); Stereotactic radiosurgery
Tests: Cerebral angiography; CT scan; CT angiography; MRI; Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA); Transcranial doppler ultrasound

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing joint swelling, redness, warmth, and range of motion; analysis of blood, urine, and joint fluid; imaging studies such as X-rays, CT scans, MRIs, and ultrasounds.
Treatments: Medications; Physical therapy; Surgery (joint repair, joint replacement, joint fusion); Weight loss; Exercise; Heat and cold therapy; Assistive devices; Acupuncture; Glucosamine; Chondroitin; Fish oil; Yoga; Tai chi; Massage
Tests: Physical examination; Blood test; Urine test; Joint fluid analysis; X-ray; Computerized tomography (CT); Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Ultrasound; Arthroscopy
Medications_Drugs: Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Prednisone; Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs); Biologic agents; Targeted synthetic DMARDs

Diagnosis: Asbestosis diagnosis is challenging due to overlapping symptoms with other respiratory diseases.  Diagnosis involves reviewing health history, occupational exposure, and a physical exam including lung auscultation for crackling sounds.  Imaging tests (chest X-ray, CT scan) and pulmonary function tests (spirometry) are used;  bronchoscopy and thoracentesis may be employed to obtain tissue or fluid samples for analysis of asbestos fibers or abnormal cells.
Treatments: Supplemental oxygen; Pulmonary rehabilitation program; Lung transplant
Tests: Chest X-ray; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Pulmonary function tests; Spirometer; Bronchoscopy; Thoracentesis

Diagnosis: Review of symptoms; Stool examination for eggs and larvae (present at least 40 days post-infection); Blood test for elevated eosinophils; X-ray of abdomen or chest to visualize worms; Ultrasound to visualize worms in pancreas or liver; CT scan or MRI to detect worms blocking ducts.
Treatments: Anti-parasite medication; Surgery (in cases of heavy infestation and complications)
Tests: Stool test; Blood test; X-ray; Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI
Medications_Drugs: Albendazole (Albenza); Ivermectin (Stromectol); Mebendazole; Pyrantel pamoate (for pregnant women)

Diagnosis: Diagnosing aspergillosis can be difficult due to its similarity to other lung conditions and the commonality of Aspergillus in the environment. Diagnosis involves imaging tests (chest X-ray or CT scan) to reveal fungal masses or characteristic signs; respiratory secretion (sputum) tests to check for aspergillus filaments and culture growth; tissue and blood tests (skin tests and blood tests for antibodies) to confirm allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis; and potentially a biopsy for invasive aspergillosis.
Treatments: Observation; Oral corticosteroids; Antifungal medications; Surgery; Embolization
Tests: Chest X-ray; CT scan; Respiratory secretion (sputum) test; Skin test; Blood test; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Physical exam to rule out other conditions; Lung function tests (spirometry, peak flow) to assess airway narrowing, often before and after bronchodilator use; Methacholine challenge to induce airway narrowing; Imaging tests (chest X-ray) to identify structural abnormalities; Allergy testing (skin or blood test) to identify triggers; Nitric oxide test to measure airway inflammation; Sputum eosinophils test to identify eosinophils; Provocative testing for exercise- and cold-induced asthma. Asthma severity is classified based on frequency and severity of symptoms, physical exam findings, and test results.
Treatments: Avoidance of triggers;  Long-term control medications; Quick-relief inhalers; Allergy medications
Tests: Spirometry; Peak flow; Methacholine challenge; Chest X-ray; Allergy testing; Nitric oxide test; Sputum eosinophils; Provocative testing for exercise and cold-induced asthma
Medications_Drugs: Fluticasone propionate (Flovent HFA, Flovent Diskus, Xhance); Budesonide (Pulmicort Flexhaler, Pulmicort Respules, Rhinocort); Ciclesonide (Alvesco); Beclomethasone (Qvar Redihaler); Mometasone (Asmanex HFA, Asmanex Twisthaler); Fluticasone furoate (Arnuity Ellipta); Montelukast (Singulair); Zafirlukast (Accolate); Zileuton (Zyflo); Fluticasone-salmeterol (Advair HFA, Airduo Digihaler); Budesonide-formoterol (Symbicort); Formoterol-mometasone (Dulera); Fluticasone furoate-vilanterol (Breo Ellipta); Theophylline (Theo-24, Elixophyllin, Theochron); Albuterol (ProAir HFA, Ventolin HFA); Levalbuterol (Xopenex, Xopenex HFA); Ipratropium (Atrovent HFA); Tiotropium (Spiriva, Spiriva Respimat); Prednisone (Prednisone Intensol, Rayos); Methylprednisolone (Medrol, Depo-Medrol, Solu-Medrol); Allergy shots

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on symptoms, severity assessment (using peak flow meter and asthma action plan zones), and lung function tests.  If at-home treatment is ineffective or symptoms are severe, a healthcare professional will conduct an examination and perform tests.
Treatments: At-home management following an asthma action plan; Inhaled quick-relief medications (with inhaler or nebulizer); Oral corticosteroids; Oxygen therapy; Ipratropium; Mechanical ventilation (intubation in severe cases); Monitoring of symptoms
Tests: Peak flow meter; Spirometer (measuring forced expiratory volume - FEV-1); Pulse oximeter; Nitric oxide measurement
Medications_Drugs: Albuterol (ProAir HFA, Proventil-HFA, Ventolin HFA); Levalbuterol (Xopenex, Xopenex HFA); Ipratropium (Atrovent HFA); Oral corticosteroids

Diagnosis: Astigmatism is diagnosed with a complete eye exam including a series of tests to check eye health and a refraction to determine how the eyes bend light;  This involves using various instruments, aiming bright lights at the eyes, and having the patient look through several lenses.
Treatments: Corrective lenses (eyeglasses; contact lenses); Refractive surgery (LASIK; LASEK; PRK; Epi-LASIK; SMILE; clear lens extraction; implantable contact lenses)
Tests: Eye exam; Refraction

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a neurological exam assessing symptoms and neurological function; imaging tests like MRI (potentially with functional MRI, perfusion MRI, and magnetic resonance spectroscopy), CT scans, and PET scans to determine tumor location and size; and a biopsy to obtain a tissue sample for analysis of cell type, growth rate, and genetic material (DNA) to determine prognosis and guide treatment planning.
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Clinical trials; Supportive/palliative care
Tests: Neurological exam; MRI; Functional MRI; Perfusion MRI; Magnetic resonance spectroscopy; CT scan; PET scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves physical and neurological exams assessing vision, balance, coordination, and reflexes;  identifying a treatable underlying cause is the goal.
Treatments: Treatment of underlying condition (e.g., vitamin deficiency, celiac disease); Supportive care for viral infections; Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Speech therapy; Adaptive devices (e.g., walking sticks, modified utensils, communication aids); Aerobic and strength exercises; Omaveloxolone (Skyclarys) for Friedreich's ataxia.
Tests: Blood tests; MRI of the brain; Spinal tap (lumbar puncture); Genetic testing; Complete blood count (CBC); CT scan; Urinalysis

Diagnosis: A doctor's examination and chest X-ray may suffice; other tests may be used to confirm the cause, type, or severity of atelectasis.
Treatments: Chest physical therapy (deep breathing exercises with incentive spirometer, postural drainage, percussion, mechanical mucus clearance devices); Surgery (to remove blockages or tumors); Suctioning mucus; Bronchoscopy (to remove blockages);  Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP); Chemotherapy; Radiation
Tests: Chest X-ray; CT scan; Oximetry; Chest ultrasound; Bronchoscopy

Diagnosis: Visual inspection by a doctor; Skin scraping from the affected area for lab testing to confirm diagnosis and rule out other conditions.
Treatments: Nonprescription products and self-care; Prescription-strength cream or ointment; Antifungal pills; Combination of topical and oral medicine.
Tests: Skin scraping
Medications_Drugs: clotrimazole; econazole; ciclopirox; terbinafine; itraconazole; terbinafine (Lamisil AT); clotrimazole (Lotrimin AF)

Diagnosis: Clinical evaluation of symptoms; skin examination; review of medical history; allergy testing; patch testing to identify specific allergens.
Treatments: Regular moisturizing; medicated creams; wet dressings; light therapy; counseling; relaxation techniques; behavior modification; biofeedback; avoiding skin irritants; avoiding extreme temperatures; short warm baths with moisturizer application.
Tests: Patch testing
Medications_Drugs: tacrolimus (Protopic); pimecrolimus (Elidel); antibiotics; cyclosporine; methotrexate; prednisone; mycophenolate; azathioprine; dupilumab (Dupixent); tralokinumab (Adbry); hydrocortisone (1% cream); cetirizine (Zyrtec Allergy); fexofenadine (Allegra Allergy); diphenhydramine (Benadryl).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis may be incidental during a health checkup;  a healthcare provider examines the patient, reviews medical history and symptoms; tests are conducted to identify underlying conditions that may cause irregular heartbeats (e.g., heart or thyroid disease).
Treatments: Medicine; Cardioversion (electrical and drug); Surgery or catheter procedures (AV node ablation; Maze procedure; Hybrid atrial fibrillation ablation; Pulsed field ablation); Cardiac ablation
Tests: Blood tests; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; Event recorder; Implantable loop recorder; Echocardiogram; Exercise stress tests; Chest X-ray
Medications_Drugs: Beta blockers; Calcium channel blockers; Digoxin; Anti-arrhythmics; Warfarin (Jantoven); Apixaban (Eliquis); Dabigatran (Pradaxa); Edoxaban (Savaysa); Rivaroxaban (Xarelto)

Diagnosis: Physical examination including heart auscultation and blood pressure measurement; review of symptoms, health habits, and medical history.
Treatments: Medications; Cardioversion (electrical and pharmacologic); Radiofrequency ablation.
Tests: Blood tests (liver, thyroid, kidney function); Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; Event recorder; Implantable loop recorder; Echocardiogram; Exercise stress test; CT scan of the lungs; Electrophysiological (EP) study.

Diagnosis: ASDs may be detected prenatally or postnatally; smaller defects may not be discovered until later in life.  A heart murmur may be audible via stethoscope.  Echocardiogram is the primary diagnostic test.  Other tests may be used if the diagnosis is uncertain.
Treatments: Regular health checkups (for small defects that don't close); Catheter-based repair (for secundum ASDs); Open-heart surgery (for primum, sinus venosus, and coronary sinus ASDs); Minimally invasive surgery; Robot-assisted heart surgery
Tests: Echocardiogram; Chest X-ray; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan; Computerized tomography (CT) scan

Diagnosis: Physical examination including heart auscultation and blood pressure measurement; patient history including symptoms and medical history; electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG).
Treatments: Vagal maneuvers; Medications; Cardioversion; Catheter ablation; Pacemaker; AV node ablation (in conjunction with pacemaker placement).
Tests: Blood tests; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; Echocardiogram; Exercise test (stress test); Electrophysiological (EP) study and cardiac mapping.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis may occur prenatally via ultrasound or specialized heart imaging; postnatally, symptoms (heart murmur) are usually noticeable within the first weeks of life.  Further diagnosis utilizes pulse oximetry, electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG), echocardiogram, chest X-ray, and cardiac catheterization.
Treatments: Surgery (may involve one or two patches to close the heart wall hole; mitral valve repair or replacement; separation of a single valve into two valves; tricuspid valve repair or replacement); Preventive antibiotics (in some cases before certain dental and surgical procedures to prevent infective endocarditis)
Tests: Pulse oximetry; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Echocardiogram; Chest X-ray; Cardiac catheterization

Diagnosis: Clinical examination including assessment of symptoms and medical history; Auscultation of heart and lungs;  Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG).
Treatments: Vagal maneuvers; Medications; Cardioversion; Catheter ablation
Tests: Blood tests; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; Echocardiogram; Exercise stress tests; Electrophysiological study (EP study)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is made if core ADHD symptoms begin before age 12 and cause significant ongoing problems at home and school; there's no specific test; diagnosis involves a medical exam to rule out other causes; information gathering (medical history, school records); interviews/surveys with family, teachers, and caregivers; and ADHD rating scales.  For young children, diagnosis is more challenging and may require specialist evaluation.
Treatments: Medicines; behavior therapy; counseling; education services; social skills training; parent skills training; talk therapy; family therapy
Tests: Medical exam; ADHD rating scales
Medications_Drugs: dextroamphetamine (Dexedrine Spansule); dextroamphetamine-amphetamine (Adderall XR, Mydayis); lisdexamfetamine (Vyvanse); methylphenidate (Concerta, Ritalin, others); dexmethylphenidate (Focalin); dexmethylphenidate-serdexmethylphenidate (Azstarys); atomoxetine (Strattera); viloxazine (Qelbree); guanfacine (Intuniv); clonidine (Onyda XR); bupropion (Aplenzin, Wellbutrin XL, others)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is usually made at birth or shortly after; sometimes suspected prenatally if fetal sex from blood tests differs from ultrasound imaging of genitalia.  Diagnosis involves a physical exam to check for testicles and evaluate genitalia; questioning of family and medical history.
Treatments: Hormone therapy; Surgery to maintain sexual function, create more typical-appearing genitals; Ongoing medical care, including cancer screenings in adulthood; Counseling and support for family
Tests: Blood tests to measure hormone levels; Blood tests to analyze chromosomes; Ultrasound of the pelvis and belly; X-ray studies using contrast dye; Minimally invasive surgery to collect tissue sample (if needed)

Diagnosis: Atypical hyperplasia of the breast is most often diagnosed during a breast biopsy following a concerning finding on a clinical breast exam or imaging tests like mammogram or ultrasound.
Treatments: Surgery to remove atypical cells; More-frequent breast cancer screening; Medicine to lower the risk of breast cancer; Risk-reducing mastectomy or prophylactic mastectomy; Avoidance of hormone therapy for menopause
Tests: Breast biopsy; Mammogram; Ultrasound; Breast self-exam; Clinical breast exam; Screening mammograms; Breast MRI; Molecular breast imaging; other supplemental breast imaging tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves assessing symptoms and duration, and may include input from teachers (for children), psychologists, and speech-language pathologists.  Audiologists conduct hearing tests.
Treatments: Hearing aids and wireless listening devices; FM systems; Auditory training (hearing rehabilitation); Computer-based training
Tests: Tympanometry; Acoustic reflex test; Auditory brainstem response; Evoked potential test

Diagnosis: There is no specific medical test to diagnose autism spectrum disorder. Diagnosis involves observation of the child's development and behavior across social interaction, communication, and behavior; standardized tests assessing hearing, speech, language, developmental level, and social/behavioral issues; structured assessments of social and communication interactions; and input from other specialists.  Genetic testing may be recommended to rule out other genetic conditions.
Treatments: Behavior and communication therapies (including Applied Behavior Analysis); educational therapies; family therapies; speech therapy; occupational therapy; physical therapy;  medication to manage associated symptoms (such as hyperactivity, severe behavioral symptoms, or anxiety).
Tests: Hearing tests; speech tests; language tests; developmental level tests; tests assessing social and behavioral issues; genetic testing (to rule out conditions such as Rett syndrome or fragile X syndrome).
Medications_Drugs: Specific medications are not listed, but examples include those for hyperactivity, antipsychotic medications for severe behavioral symptoms, and antidepressants for anxiety.

Diagnosis: Review of symptoms; physical exam; assessment of symptom patterns suggestive of autoimmune encephalitis; testing for antibodies attacking brain proteins and receptors; ruling out other conditions (infections, other autoimmune diseases) using various tests;  application of established autoimmune encephalitis criteria.
Treatments: Immunotherapy; tumor removal (if applicable); oral corticosteroids; plasma exchange;  rehabilitation (occupational, speech, mental health); treatment of complications (epilepsy, sleep disorders, movement problems); cancer treatment (if applicable).
Tests: Antibody tests (blood and cerebrospinal fluid); lumbar puncture; MRI of the brain; EEG; other imaging tests (to rule out cancer).
Medications_Drugs: Methylprednisolone (Solu-Medrol); Immunoglobulin (IVIg); rituximab (Rituxan, Truxima); cyclophosphamide; tocilizumab (Actemra, Tofidence, Tyenne).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam and review of symptoms;  Lab tests check for antibodies in the blood or cerebrospinal fluid (obtained via lumbar puncture); Brain imaging (MRI and FDG-PET scan) looks for signs of autoimmune activity and rules out other causes; EEG measures brain electrical activity and may show seizure activity.
Treatments: Immunotherapy; Treatment of underlying cancer (if present); Plasma exchange; Antiseizure medications (may have limited effectiveness); Surgery (for Rasmussen syndrome); Rehabilitation (occupational and speech therapy).
Tests: Blood test; Cerebrospinal fluid analysis (via lumbar puncture); MRI; FDG-PET scan; EEG; Video EEG
Medications_Drugs: Methylprednisolone (Solu-Medrol); Prednisone; Immunoglobulin; Rituximab (Rituxan, Truxima); Cyclophosphamide; Mycophenolate (Cellcept, Myhibbin); Azathioprine (Azasan, Imuran); Tocilizumab (Actemra, Tofidence, Tyenne); Antiseizure medications (specific names not listed).

Diagnosis: Autoimmune hepatitis is diagnosed through blood tests to detect specific antibodies, distinguishing it from viral hepatitis and other conditions; a liver biopsy confirms the diagnosis and assesses the extent and type of liver damage.
Treatments: Medications to slow or stop the immune system's attack on the liver; Liver transplant (when medications are ineffective or cirrhosis/liver failure develops)
Tests: Blood tests for antibodies; Liver biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is challenging due to symptom overlap with pancreatic cancer.  A combination of imaging, blood tests, and biopsy results is used.  Elevated IgG4 levels in blood are common in Type 1 AIP, but not specific.  A distinctive appearance under a microscope on biopsy is characteristic. A steroid trial may be used to confirm diagnosis, but should be done with caution and under expert guidance.
Treatments: Biliary stenting; Steroids (prednisolone or prednisone); Immunosuppressants and immunomodulators
Tests: CT; MRI; Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS); Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP); Blood test for IgG4 levels; Endoscopic core biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Prednisolone; Prednisone; Mycophenolate (CellCept); Mercaptopurine (Purinethol, Purixan); Azathioprine (Imuran, Azasan); Rituximab (Rituxan)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis depends on symptoms and risk factors.  For those with known risk factors (e.g., diabetes, cancer treatment with neurotoxic drugs), a physical exam and symptom review are conducted.  For those without risk factors, a more thorough evaluation including medical history review, physical exam, and autonomic function tests may be necessary.
Treatments: Treating the underlying disease; Managing specific symptoms with diet changes; Medications to help stomach emptying; Medications to ease constipation; Medications to ease diarrhea; Bladder retraining; Medications to manage bladder symptoms
Tests: Autonomic function tests; Tilt-table test; Gastrointestinal tests (e.g., gastric-emptying tests); Quantitative sudomotor axon reflex test; Thermoregulatory sweat test; Urinalysis; Urodynamic tests; Ultrasound of the urinary tract

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing joint tenderness and range of motion; Imaging tests to pinpoint the source of pain and reveal bone changes.
Treatments: Rest; Exercises; Electrical stimulation; Core decompression; Bone transplant (graft); Bone reshaping (osteotomy); Joint replacement; Regenerative medicine treatment (bone marrow aspirate and concentration)
Tests: X-rays; MRI; CT scan; Bone scan

Diagnosis: Baby acne is usually diagnosed visually; no testing is needed.
Treatments: Often clears up on its own; prescription medicine may be needed for cysts, scarring, or lack of improvement.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Physical examination assessing ability to sit, stand, walk, and lift legs; pain rating on a 0-10 scale; assessment of pain's impact on daily activities; evaluation to rule out serious causes.
Treatments: Home treatment (heat, light activity); Stronger medicines; Physical therapy; Cortisone shots; Radiofrequency ablation; Implanted nerve stimulators; Surgery; Acupuncture; Chiropractic care; Massage; Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS); Yoga
Tests: X-ray; MRI; CT scan; Blood tests; Electromyography (EMG); Bone scan; Discogram; Urinalysis
Medications_Drugs: Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Prescription NSAIDs; Muscle relaxants; Topical pain relievers; Oxycodone; Hydrocodone; Duloxetine; Amitriptyline

Diagnosis: A pelvic exam to visually inspect the vagina and palpate pelvic organs; a vaginal discharge sample is tested for "clue cells" (vaginal cells covered in bacteria); vaginal pH is tested using a pH strip (pH 4.5 or higher indicates BV).
Treatments: Metronidazole (oral or vaginal gel); Clindamycin (cream, oral, or suppository); Tinidazole (oral); Secnidazole (oral granules)
Tests: Pelvic exam; Vaginal discharge analysis for clue cells; Vaginal pH test

Diagnosis: Dentist assesses breath odor from mouth and nose, rates odor on a scale; dentist may scrape the back of the tongue and rate its odor; some devices can detect certain chemicals causing bad breath (availability varies).
Treatments: Regular oral hygiene (brushing, flossing, tongue cleaning); Mouth rinses; Antibacterial toothpaste; Treatment of gum disease (periodontist referral may be necessary); Replacement of faulty fillings; Artificial saliva preparation; Medications to increase saliva flow; Dietary changes (reducing onion, garlic, and sugary foods);  Chewing sugarless gum or sucking on sugarless candy.
Tests: Breath odor assessment; Tongue scraping; Chemical detection devices (availability varies).
Medications_Drugs: Artificial saliva preparation; Medications to increase saliva flow (specific medication names not provided).

Diagnosis: Bags under eyes are usually evident without a medical diagnosis; a healthcare professional may assess the skin under the eyes to determine the cause of puffiness or to discuss medical or surgical treatment options.
Treatments: Cool compress; Reduced fluid intake before bed; Reduced salt in diet; Avoiding smoking; Getting enough sleep; Sleeping with head elevated; Reducing allergy symptoms; Nonprescription allergy medications; Makeup to mask under-eye circles; Laser resurfacing; Chemical peels; Fillers; Blepharoplasty (eyelid surgery)
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Physical exam;  Imaging tests may be ordered if symptoms mimic more serious conditions.
Treatments: Avoidance of triggering activities; Nonprescription pain relievers; Steroid injection into the knee; Gentle range-of-motion and strengthening exercises; Needle aspiration; Arthroscopic surgery;  Cyst removal surgery (rarely). R.I.C.E. (rest, ice, compression, elevation)
Tests: Ultrasound; X-ray; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
Medications_Drugs: Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Cortisone; Naproxen sodium; Aspirin

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a review of medical history and a physical and neurological examination.  Further testing is conducted to determine the underlying cause, focusing on the inner ear's balance function if symptoms suggest this involvement.
Treatments: Balance retraining exercises (vestibular rehabilitation); Positioning procedures (canalith repositioning); Diet and lifestyle changes; Medications; Surgery; Stereotactic radiosurgery
Tests: Hearing tests; Posturography test; Electronystagmography; Videonystagmography; Rotary chair test; Dix-Hallpike maneuver; Vestibular evoked myogenic potentials test; MRI; CT scans; Blood pressure tests; Heart rate tests

Diagnosis: Barrett's esophagus is diagnosed via endoscopy, a procedure using a lighted tube with a camera to visualize the esophagus.  Abnormal tissue (red and velvety) is noted, and a biopsy is taken for pathological examination to determine the degree of dysplasia (precancerous changes).  Two pathologists, one specializing in gastroenterology pathology, ideally confirm the diagnosis and dysplasia grade.
Treatments: Periodic endoscopy; GERD treatment (medication and lifestyle changes); Surgery or endoscopy for hiatal hernia repair or lower esophageal sphincter tightening; Endoscopic resection; Radiofrequency ablation; Cryotherapy; Esophagectomy (surgery to remove damaged esophagus); Lifelong medication to reduce acid (if treatment other than surgery for abnormal tissue is used).
Tests: Endoscopy; Biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Proton pump inhibitor medication (specific drug name not mentioned)

Diagnosis: A pelvic exam; questioning about medical history;  a sample of vaginal or cervical secretions to test for sexually transmitted infection; biopsy to check for cancerous cells (if postmenopausal or over 40).
Treatments: Sitz baths; surgical drainage with or without catheter placement; antibiotics; marsupialization; surgical removal of Bartholin's gland
Tests: Pelvic exam;  testing of vaginal or cervical secretions; biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a medical history review focusing on the lesion's onset, changes, pain, presence of other lesions, prior skin cancer history (personal and family), and sun safety practices; a physical exam assessing the suspicious area and the rest of the body for lesions; and a skin biopsy to determine the presence and type of skin cancer.
Treatments: Surgical excision; Mohs surgery; Curettage and electrodessication (C and E); Radiation therapy; Freezing (cryosurgery); Topical treatments; Photodynamic therapy; Targeted drug therapy; Chemotherapy
Tests: Skin biopsy

Diagnosis: Physical exam; Discussion of symptoms, fluid intake, family history, bowel and bladder habits, and problems caused by bed-wetting; Urine tests to check for infection or diabetes; X-rays or other imaging tests of the kidneys or bladder; Other urinary tract tests or assessments as needed.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (limiting evening fluids, avoiding caffeine, double voiding before bed); Moisture alarms; Medication; Addressing underlying causes such as constipation or sleep apnea
Tests: Urinalysis; X-ray; Urine tests;  X-rays or other imaging tests of the kidneys or bladder; Other types of urinary tract tests or assessments

Diagnosis: Inspect your home for bedbugs, particularly in crevices in walls, mattresses, and furniture; Look for dark specks (excrement), skin castings (pale yellow), and rusty or reddish stains (blood smears).  Inspection may need to be done at night when bedbugs are active.
Treatments: Hydrocortisone cream; Oral antihistamine (e.g., diphenhydramine); Vacuuming; Laundering items in water at least 120°F (48.9°C) or drying on high heat for 20 minutes; Placing infested items in an enclosed vehicle in direct sunlight to reach at least 120°F (48.9°C); Professional extermination (using pesticides and non-chemical treatments); Discarding heavily infested items.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Visual examination of the skin to identify and stage pressure ulcers; assessment of patient history including onset, pain level, prior occurrences, treatment history, care assistance, positioning routine, medical conditions, diet, and nutrition.
Treatments: Reducing pressure through repositioning and support surfaces; wound cleaning and dressing with appropriate bandages (films, gauzes, gels, foams, treated coverings); debridement of damaged tissue; pain management with NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen, naproxen sodium) and topical pain medications; nutritional support; surgery (flap surgery) for non-healing ulcers.
Tests: Blood tests

Diagnosis: Allergy to bee venom is diagnosed through skin testing (injecting a small amount of bee venom into the skin to observe a reaction) and/or blood testing (measuring the immune system's response to bee venom).  The healthcare professional may also test for allergies to yellow jackets, hornets, and wasps.
Treatments: Home treatment for minor stings; Emergency treatment for allergic reactions (including CPR, epinephrine, oxygen, antihistamines, glucocorticoids, beta agonists); Immunotherapy (allergy shots).
Tests: Skin test; Blood test
Medications_Drugs: Epinephrine; Oxygen; Prednisone; Albuterol; Diphenhydramine; Chlorpheniramine; Loratadine; Cetirizine; Fexofenadine; Ibuprofen; Acetaminophen

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily based on symptoms; recurrent mouth sores (at least three times in 12 months) are nearly always present and often necessary for diagnosis; at least two additional symptoms are required, such as recurrent genital sores, eye inflammation, or skin sores; lab tests may rule out other conditions.
Treatments: Topical medicines for flares; whole-body treatments for severe disease; corticosteroids;  medicines to suppress the immune system; interferon alfa-2b; tumor necrosis factor blockers; rest during flares; moderate exercise during symptom remission; support groups.
Tests: Pathergy test; Blood tests; Other lab tests
Medications_Drugs: colchicine; apremilast; prednisone; azathioprine; cyclosporine; cyclophosphamide; interferon alfa-2b; infliximab; adalimumab; corticosteroid creams, gels, and ointments; corticosteroid mouth rinses; corticosteroid eye drops.

Diagnosis: Clinical evaluation of facial muscle movement;  EMG to confirm nerve damage and severity; MRI or CT scan to rule out other conditions such as tumors or skull fractures; blood tests to rule out other conditions like Lyme disease and infections.
Treatments: Corticosteroids; Antiviral drugs; Physical therapy; Lubricating eye drops and ointment; Eye protection (glasses, goggles, eye patch);  Rarely, decompression surgery (not recommended); Facial reanimation surgery (for lasting problems); Pain relievers; Acupuncture; Biofeedback training; OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox)
Tests: Electromyography (EMG); Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Computerized tomography (CT); Blood tests
Medications_Drugs: Prednisone; Valacyclovir; Acyclovir; Aspirin; Ibuprofen; Acetaminophen; OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox)
