Diagnosis: Benign adrenal tumors are often discovered incidentally on imaging performed for other reasons.  Diagnosis involves assessing the likelihood of malignancy and determining if the tumor is producing excess hormones.  This assessment includes physical examination and blood and urine hormone level testing.
Treatments: Observation (with repeat imaging and hormone testing); Medication for symptoms; Adrenalectomy (surgical removal of the adrenal gland)
Tests: Blood tests; Urine tests; CT scan; MRI; M-iodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) imaging; Positron emission tomography (PET); Ga-DOTATATE PET scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a physical exam evaluating dizziness triggered by specific head and eye movements (lasting less than a minute),  nystagmus (involuntary eye movements), and difficulty controlling eye movements.  Additional testing may be done if the cause is unclear.
Treatments: Canalith repositioning procedure; Canal plugging surgery; Physical therapy; Home treatments (avoiding triggering movements, using good lighting, using a cane for stability)
Tests: Electronystagmography (ENG); Videonystagmography (VNG); Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves determining the tumor's location and type using imaging and biopsy.  MRI is the preferred imaging method to visualize the nerves and surrounding tissue, determining if the tumor is intra- or extra-neural.  A CT scan may be used as an alternative if MRI is not possible or further bone detail is needed. Electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction studies assess nerve function and help locate the tumor. A tumor biopsy or nerve biopsy is performed to analyze tissue and determine the tumor type.
Treatments: Surgical removal; Observation (regular checkups and imaging tests)
Tests: MRI; CT scan; Electromyogram (EMG); Nerve conduction study; Tumor biopsy; Nerve biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a review of symptoms and a physical exam, including a digital rectal exam to assess prostate size.  Urine and blood tests check for other conditions mimicking BPH symptoms and kidney problems.  Further tests may be needed to confirm BPH, depending on complexity.
Treatments: Medicines; Surgery; Procedures with smaller/fewer/no cuts;  Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP); Transurethral incision of the prostate (TUIP); Transurethral microwave thermotherapy (TUMT); Laser therapy (including photoselective vaporization of the prostate (PVP), holmium laser ablation of the prostate, and holmium laser enucleation of the prostate (HoLEP)); Prostate lift
Tests: Digital rectal exam; Urine test; Blood test; Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) blood test; Urinary flow test; Postvoid residual volume test; 24-hour voiding diary; Transrectal ultrasound; Prostate biopsy; Urodynamic and pressure flow studies; Cystoscopy; Computerized tomography (CT) urogram; Intravenous pyelogram
Medications_Drugs: alfuzosin (Uroxatral); doxazosin (Cardura); tamsulosin (Flomax); silodosin (Rapaflo); terazosin; finasteride (Proscar); dutasteride (Avodart); tadalafil (Cialis)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is typically based on a description of symptoms and medical history; distinguishing between acid and bile reflux requires further testing to assess esophageal and stomach damage and precancerous changes.
Treatments: Lifestyle adjustments; Medications; Surgery
Tests: Endoscopy; Ambulatory acid tests; Esophageal impedance
Medications_Drugs: Ursodeoxycholic acid; Sucralfate; Bile acid sequestrants

Diagnosis: Mental health evaluation involving discussion of feelings and eating habits with a mental health professional specializing in eating disorders;  assessment for health problems associated with binge-eating disorder (e.g., high cholesterol, high blood pressure, heart problems, diabetes, GERD, poor nutrition, electrolyte imbalances, sleep-related breathing disorders).
Treatments: Talk therapy (CBT, CBT-E, ICAT, Dialectical behavior therapy);  Lifestyle changes (regular eating, avoiding dieting, planning for triggering situations, getting proper nutrition, staying connected, physical activity); Medications.
Tests: Physical exam (including weight measurement); Blood tests; Urine tests; Sleep study (visit with sleep disorder specialist).
Medications_Drugs: Lisdexamfetamine dimesylate (Vyvanse);  Certain anti-seizure medications; Certain antidepressants.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a mental health assessment by a psychiatrist, including interviews about thoughts, feelings, and behavior patterns; information from family or friends; and potentially mood charting to track moods, sleep, and other factors.  The same criteria are used for children and adults, but symptoms may manifest differently in children and adolescents, often alongside other conditions like ADHD.
Treatments: Medicines; Ongoing medication; Intensive outpatient programs; Partial hospitalization programs; Treatment for alcohol or drug misuse; Hospital stay; Talk therapy (psychotherapy); Interpersonal and social rhythm therapy; Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT); Psychoeducation; Education and support groups
Tests: Physical exam; lab tests
Medications_Drugs: lithium (Lithobid); valproic acid; divalproex sodium (Depakote, Depakote ER); carbamazepine (Tegretol, Tegretol XR, Equetro); lamotrigine (Lamictal); olanzapine (Zyprexa, Lybalvi); risperidone (Risperdal); quetiapine (Seroquel, Seroquel XR); aripiprazole (Abilify, Aristada); ziprasidone (Geodon); lurasidone (Latuda); asenapine (Saphris); lumateperone (Caplyta); cariprazine (Vraylar);  fluoxetine; Symbyax (fluoxetine and olanzapine); Benzodiazepines

Diagnosis: A healthcare professional takes a sample of fluid from the nose and throat to test for bird flu infection; a sample of fluid from the eye may also be taken if pink eye is present.  Diagnosis is considered if symptoms are present and potential exposure through work, travel, or hobbies is identified.
Treatments: Antiviral medications; Isolation from others to prevent spread;  Testing of close contacts and antiviral medication for high-risk exposed individuals.
Tests: Nasal and throat fluid sample; Eye fluid sample (if pink eye is present)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on visual examination of the tongue and consideration of potential causes or risk factors.  Differential diagnosis includes normal tongue color variations, staining from food or medications, fungal or viral infections, and conditions like oral hairy leukoplakia and pseudo-black hairy tongue (associated with bismuth-containing products like Pepto-Bismol).
Treatments: Good oral and tongue hygiene; cessation of tobacco use and irritating mouthwashes; smoking cessation programs.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Bladder cancer is diagnosed through a combination of methods.  Cystoscopy (visual examination of the bladder using a cystoscope) allows for direct visualization and biopsy; urine cytology (microscopic examination of urine for cancer cells) detects cancerous cells; imaging tests such as CT urogram or retrograde pyelogram provide detailed views of the urinary tract to assess tumor extent. Biopsy is crucial for confirming diagnosis and determining the type, grade, and stage of cancer.
Treatments: Transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT); Intravesicle therapy (chemotherapy or immunotherapy, such as BCG); Cisplatin-based combination chemotherapy; Cystectomy (complete removal of the bladder); Radiation therapy; Adjuvant immunotherapy
Tests: Cystoscopy; Biopsy; Urine cytology; CT urogram; Retrograde pyelogram

Diagnosis: Often detected during routine pregnancy ultrasound; confirmed with MRI; newborn assessment includes evaluation of bladder exposure, testicle position, inguinal hernia, umbilical anatomy, anal position, and pubic bone separation.  Criteria include a bladder that doesn't fill or empty correctly; low umbilical cord placement; separated pubic bones; smaller than typical genitals.
Treatments: Complete primary repair (single surgery closing bladder, stomach area, urethra, and repairing sex organs, potentially including pelvic bone repair); Staged repair (three surgeries: initial bladder and stomach closure, later urethra and sex organ repair, and finally bladder neck repair during toilet training); Catheterization; Pain management (spinal canal analgesia) ; Immobilization (devices to keep lower legs still).
Tests: Pregnancy ultrasound; MRI; Newborn physical examination
Medications_Drugs: Opioids (mentioned as a less desirable alternative to spinal analgesia)

Diagnosis: Diagnosing bladder stones involves a physical exam (checking for bladder enlargement and prostate size); a urine test (analyzing for blood, bacteria, and minerals, and checking for urinary tract infections); and imaging tests such as CT scan, ultrasound, and X-ray to visualize the stones.
Treatments: Passing stones naturally (with increased water intake); Breaking stones apart using a laser, ultrasound, or other device via cystoscopy; Surgical removal of stones; Treatment of underlying conditions like bladder outlet obstruction or enlarged prostate.
Tests: Physical exam; Urine test; CT scan; Ultrasound; X-ray

Diagnosis: Diagnosis can be difficult; even if *Blastocystis hominis* is found in stool, it may not be the cause of symptoms.  Diagnosis involves reviewing medical history, inquiring about recent activities (e.g., travel), and physical exam.  Lab tests include stool (fecal) exam to detect parasites; endoscopy if fecal exam is negative and symptoms persist; blood tests (though not commonly used for *Blastocystis hominis*, may be used to rule out other causes).
Treatments: No treatment is needed if asymptomatic; mild symptoms may resolve spontaneously.  For symptomatic infections, potential medications include antibiotics (metronidazole, tinidazole), combination medications (sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim), and anti-protozoal medications (paromomycin, nitazoxanide).
Tests: Stool (fecal) exam; Endoscopy; Blood tests
Medications_Drugs: Metronidazole; Tinidazole; Sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim; Paromomycin; Nitazoxanide

Diagnosis: Examination of the eyes using a magnifying instrument; Swabbing skin for analysis of oil or crust for bacteria, fungi, or evidence of allergy.
Treatments: Warm compresses; Eyelid scrubs; Topical antibiotic eyedrops, creams, or ointments; Oral antibiotics; Steroid eyedrops or ointments; Topical cyclosporine (Restasis); Treatment of underlying conditions (e.g., seborrheic dermatitis, rosacea); Intense pulsed light therapy (further study needed).
Tests: Examining your eyes with a magnifying instrument; Swabbing skin for bacterial, fungal, or allergy testing.
Medications_Drugs: Topical antibiotics; Oral antibiotics; Steroid eyedrops or ointments; Topical cyclosporine (Restasis).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing symptoms, examining the eyes and nose to check for nasal passage obstructions, and potentially further tests to locate the blockage.  A tear drainage test measures tear drainage speed; irrigation and probing flushes the tear drainage system or inserts an instrument to check for blockages; eye imaging tests (X-ray, CT, or MRI) with contrast dye identify blockage location and cause.
Treatments: Watch-and-wait or massage;  Antibiotic eye drops or pills; Dilation, probing and flushing; Stenting or intubation; Balloon catheter dilation; Dacryocystorhinostomy (external or endoscopic/endonasal)
Tests: Tear drainage test; Irrigation and probing; Eye imaging tests (X-ray; computerized tomography (CT); magnetic resonance imaging (MRI))

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of blood in urine (hematuria) involves a physical exam, discussion of health history, and various tests to identify the underlying cause.  The cause may not always be found.
Treatments: Antibiotics for urinary tract infection; Medication to shrink enlarged prostate; Treatment using sound waves to break up bladder or kidney stones; In some cases, no treatment is needed.
Tests: Urine tests; Imaging tests (CT scan, MRI, ultrasound); Cystoscopy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a psychological evaluation assessing risk factors, thoughts, feelings, and behaviors related to negative self-image; personal, social, family, and medical history are also considered; signs and symptoms are evaluated.
Treatments: Cognitive behavioral therapy; Medications; Psychiatric hospitalization
Tests: Psychological evaluation
Medications_Drugs: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs); Other medications ( unspecified)

Diagnosis: Visual examination of the body and clothing to identify lice and eggs.
Treatments: Thorough washing of body and contaminated items with soap and hot water; drying clothing and bedding in a hot dryer; dry cleaning and ironing clothing; over-the-counter lotions or shampoos containing 1% permethrin (Nix) or pyrethrin; prescription lotion (if other treatments fail).
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Visual examination by a doctor;  Pus sample may be sent to the lab for testing to determine antibiotic sensitivity, especially in cases of recurring infections or infections unresponsive to standard treatment.
Treatments: Warm compresses; Incision and drainage; Antibiotics
Tests: Pus culture

Diagnosis: Bone cancer diagnosis involves imaging tests to visualize the affected bone; a tissue biopsy is performed to confirm the presence of cancer cells.
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy
Tests: X-ray; MRI; CT scan; PET scan; Bone scan; Biopsy (needle biopsy; surgical biopsy)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves imaging tests such as X-ray; bone scan (bone scintigraphy); CT scan; MRI scan; and PET scan.  A biopsy may be performed to confirm the diagnosis.
Treatments: Bone-building medicines; Radiopharmaceutical medicines; Chemotherapy; Hormone therapy; Pain medicines; Targeted therapy; Radiation therapy; Stereotactic body radiotherapy; Surgery (orthopedic fixation; bone cement injection)
Tests: X-ray; Bone scan; CT scan; MRI scan; PET scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Physical exam to pinpoint pain; X-rays or other imaging tests (CT scan; MRI) to view joints and bones.
Treatments: Pain relievers; Physical therapy; Surgery (bone spur removal or joint replacement); Weight loss (for osteoarthritis of hips or knees)
Tests: X-ray; CT scan; MRI

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a detailed interview with a doctor or mental health professional; a mental health evaluation, possibly including questionnaires; review of medical history and physical exam; and discussion of symptoms.  Diagnosis is usually made in adults, not children or teenagers.
Treatments: Psychotherapy (talk therapy); hospitalization (if safety is at risk); treatment for co-occurring mental health conditions (e.g., depression, substance misuse); Dialectical behavior therapy (DBT); Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT); Schema-focused therapy; Mentalization-based therapy (MBT); Systems Training for Emotional Predictability and Problem-Solving (STEPPS); Transference-focused psychotherapy (TFP);  individual therapy; group therapy; family education.
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: The FDA hasn't approved any drugs specifically for borderline personality disorder; however, antidepressants; antipsychotics; and mood-stabilizing drugs may be used to treat associated symptoms or co-occurring conditions.

Diagnosis: Evaluation of muscle weakness or paralysis; assessment of symptoms like drooping eyelids and weak voice; inquiry about recent food consumption and potential wound exposure; in infant botulism, inquiry about recent honey consumption, constipation, and decreased activity; analysis of blood, stool, or vomit for botulinum toxin (though results may take days, the provider's exam is the primary diagnostic method).
Treatments: Induction of vomiting; bowel stimulant medication; surgical removal of infected tissue (wound botulism); antitoxin (foodborne or wound botulism); botulism immune globulin (infant botulism); antibiotics (wound botulism); mechanical ventilation; rehabilitation therapy (speech, swallowing, etc.)
Tests: Blood analysis for botulinum toxin; Stool analysis for botulinum toxin; Vomit analysis for botulinum toxin
Medications_Drugs: Bowel stimulant drugs; Antibiotics; Antitoxin; Botulism immune globulin

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam and assessment of symptoms.  Severity assessment may require additional tests.
Treatments: Physical therapy; Surgery (nerve graft; nerve transfer; muscle transfer; neurolysis; nerve repair); Splints
Tests: X-ray; Electromyography (EMG); Nerve conduction studies; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Computerized tomography (CT) myelography

Diagnosis: Physical examination including listening to the heart with a stethoscope and reviewing patient symptoms and medical history; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) is the main test.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes; Change in medications; Pacemaker; Treatment of underlying conditions (e.g., thyroid disease, sleep apnea)
Tests: Blood tests; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; Event recorder; Tilt table test; Stress exercise test; Sleep study
Medications_Drugs: Metoprolol; Eliquis (the page mentions these medications in patient discussions, not as direct treatments for bradycardia)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of brain aneurysms involves assessing for bleeding in the brain (often initially via CT scan) and detecting the aneurysm itself.  A CT angiogram, MRI (including MR angiography), and lumbar puncture (to analyze cerebrospinal fluid for blood) may be used. Cerebral angiogram is used if other tests are insufficient.  Diagnosis of unruptured aneurysms relies on imaging tests and family/personal risk factor assessment.
Treatments: Aneurysm clipping; Endovascular coiling; Endovascular stents; Flow diversion; Angioplasty; Ventricular or lumbar draining catheters; Shunt surgery
Tests: CT scan; CT angiogram; Lumbar puncture; MRI; MR angiography; Cerebral angiogram

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing symptoms and conducting a physical exam.  Imaging tests, usually performed by neuroradiologists, are crucial.
Treatments: Surgical removal (resection); Endovascular embolization; Stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS); Monitoring (observation)
Tests: Cerebral angiography; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Computerized tomography angiography; Magnetic resonance angiography

Diagnosis: Brain metastases are diagnosed through a neurological exam assessing cognition, speech, vision, hearing, balance, coordination, strength, sensation, and reflexes;  imaging tests such as MRI (often with contrast), CT, and PET scans are used to determine location and size of metastases; a biopsy may be performed to obtain tissue for laboratory analysis.
Treatments: Surgery; Whole-brain radiation; Stereotactic radiosurgery; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy; Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Speech therapy; Cognitive rehabilitation therapy; Palliative care
Tests: Neurological exam; MRI; CT scan; PET scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a neurological exam (assessing vision, hearing, balance, coordination, strength, and reflexes); head CT scan (initial imaging to detect problems in and around the brain); brain MRI (detailed imaging to visualize brain tumors and differentiate them from healthy tissue, potentially with functional MRI, magnetic resonance spectroscopy, or magnetic resonance perfusion); PET scan (detecting rapidly growing tumors); and brain biopsy (tissue sample for lab testing to determine cancerous nature, grade, and DNA changes).
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy; Radiosurgery; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Observation (for small, benign, asymptomatic tumors)
Tests: Neurological exam; Head CT scan; Brain MRI (including functional MRI, magnetic resonance spectroscopy, and magnetic resonance perfusion); PET scan; Brain biopsy

Diagnosis: Breast cancer diagnosis often begins with a clinical breast exam checking for skin or nipple changes and lumps in the breasts, collarbones, and armpits; imaging tests (mammogram, ultrasound, MRI) may be used to further examine breast tissue; a biopsy is performed to obtain a tissue sample for laboratory testing to confirm the presence of cancer and determine cancer type and growth rate.
Treatments: Surgery (lumpectomy, mastectomy); Radiation; Chemotherapy; Hormone therapy
Tests: Clinical breast exam; Mammogram; Diagnostic mammogram; Breast ultrasound; Breast MRI; Core needle biopsy; Blood tests (complete blood count, kidney and liver function tests); Bone scan; CT scan; PET scan; Sentinel node biopsy;  Chest X-ray

Diagnosis: Diagnosis usually involves a breast exam; imaging tests such as breast ultrasound or mammogram; and possibly fine-needle aspiration or breast biopsy.  A fluid-filled area on ultrasound usually indicates a cyst. Fine-needle aspiration, where fluid is removed from the lump, can confirm the diagnosis if the lump disappears after aspiration and the fluid is not bloody.  If the lump persists after aspiration or the fluid is bloody, further testing is needed.
Treatments: No treatment is necessary for simple, asymptomatic, fluid-filled cysts confirmed by ultrasound or fine-needle aspiration; Fine-needle aspiration (to drain fluid); Surgery (in unusual circumstances, such as recurring cysts or cysts with blood-tinged fluid); Hormone therapy (birth control pills or tamoxifen, only for severe symptoms); Discontinuing hormone therapy after menopause.
Tests: Breast exam; Mammography; Breast ultrasound; Fine-needle aspiration; Breast biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Birth control pills; Tamoxifen; Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a clinical breast exam, medical history, and assessment of symptoms.  Further testing may be necessary if a lump, thickening, or focused area of pain is detected.  If the exam and history reveal nothing unusual, additional tests may not be needed.
Treatments: Eliminate underlying cause or aggravating factor; Use topical NSAID medication; Adjust birth control pills; Reduce dose of menopausal hormone therapy; Prescription medication (Danazol; Tamoxifen); Vitamins and dietary supplements (Evening primrose oil; Vitamin E)
Tests: Clinical breast exam; Mammogram; Ultrasound; Breast biopsy

Diagnosis: Physical examination of the ankle, foot, and lower leg, checking for tenderness and assessing range of motion; observation of gait.
Treatments: Reduction; Immobilization (cast or boot); Surgery (pins, plates, or screws); Physical therapy; Pain relievers (e.g., acetaminophen)
Tests: X-rays; Bone scan; CT scan; MRI scan

Diagnosis: Physical examination for tenderness, swelling, deformity, or open wounds; X-rays to determine location and extent of break; MRI may be used for more detailed images.
Treatments: Reduction (setting the bone); Immobilization with splint, sling, brace, or cast; Over-the-counter pain relievers; Prescription pain medication (narcotics); Antibiotics (for open fractures); Rehabilitation exercises; Physical therapy; Surgery with fixation devices (wires, plates, nails, screws).
Tests: X-ray; MRI
Medications_Drugs: Over-the-counter pain relievers; Prescription pain medication (narcotics); Antibiotics; Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing tenderness, swelling, and open wounds; X-rays to determine fracture location, severity, and joint involvement; CT scan for detailed imaging.
Treatments: Sling; Pain management; Exercises to restore movement; Physical therapy; Surgery (for breaks through skin, displacement, or multiple fragments).
Tests: X-ray; CT scan
Medications_Drugs: Over-the-counter pain relievers; Prescription narcotic pain medication (short-term use).

Diagnosis: Physical examination of the ankle, foot, and lower leg, checking for tenderness and range of motion; observation of gait.  Imaging tests may be used to confirm diagnosis.
Treatments: Reduction (for displaced fractures); Immobilization (cast, brace, boot, taping); Surgery (pins, plates, screws); Physical therapy
Tests: X-rays; Bone scan; CT scan; MRI scan

Diagnosis: Physical exam of the affected hand; X-rays.
Treatments: Reduction (manipulating bone pieces back into position); Immobilization with splint or cast (keeping hand above heart level); Regular finger movement;  Surgery (implanting pins, plates, rods, or screws; bone graft); Rehabilitation exercises or physical therapy.
Tests: X-ray
Medications_Drugs: Over-the-counter pain relievers; Opioid medication (e.g., codeine); NSAIDs; Antibiotics (for open fractures).

Diagnosis: Diagnosed in emergency or hospital settings due to symptoms mimicking heart attack;  healthcare professional examines patient, asks about symptoms and medical history (including recent major stresses);  absence of prior heart disease symptoms is a common finding;  diagnostic tests are used to rule out heart attack and identify characteristic findings.
Treatments: Hospitalization; Medications to reduce heart strain and prevent further episodes;  Angiogram and procedures to open blocked arteries are NOT used in treatment as blocked arteries are not the cause.
Tests: Blood tests; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Coronary angiogram; Echocardiogram; Cardiac MRI
Medications_Drugs: Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors); Angiotensin 2 receptor blockers (ARBs); Beta blockers; Diuretics; Blood thinners (if blood clot present)

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing tenderness, swelling, deformity, or open wounds; X-rays to pinpoint fracture location and extent of injury; CT scan or MRI for stress fractures or detailed imaging.
Treatments: Rest and immobilization; Surgery; Splinting; Casting; Reduction (realignment of bone fragments); Crutches or cane; Rehabilitation exercises; Physical therapy; Metal plates, rods, or screws implantation; External metal frame.
Tests: X-ray; CT scan; MRI

Diagnosis: Physical examination including gentle palpation of the nose and surrounding areas to check for pain, swelling, and broken bones; visual inspection of the nasal cavity for blockages or other injuries;  CT scan may be ordered for serious injuries or if a full exam isn't possible. X-rays are typically not needed.
Treatments: Ice application; Over-the-counter pain medication; Manual realignment (reduction) of fractured bones and cartilage; Nasal splinting (packing, external dressing, internal splint); Antibiotics; Surgery (for serious breaks, multiple breaks, or breaks untreated for >14 days); Rhinoplasty; Septoplasty
Tests: CT scan; X-ray

Diagnosis: Physical exam involving gentle palpation of the ribs, lung auscultation, and observation of rib cage movement during breathing; imaging tests may include X-ray (may miss fresh breaks or cracks), CT scan (better for detecting breaks and soft tissue/blood vessel injuries), MRI (for soft tissue and organ damage around ribs, smaller breaks), and bone scan (for stress fractures).
Treatments: Rest and reduced activity; icing the area; pain medication (oral or injected nerve blocks); deep breathing exercises (post-pain management).
Tests: X-ray; CT scan; MRI; Bone scan

Diagnosis: Physical exam checking for tenderness, skin integrity, blood flow, and nerve signals; X-rays to confirm fracture.
Treatments: Reduction (realigning bone fragments); Buddy taping; Stiff-bottomed shoe; Casting; Surgery (pins, plates, or screws).
Tests: X-rays
Medications_Drugs: ibuprofen; naproxen sodium; acetaminophen; Prescription painkillers

Diagnosis: Physical exam of the affected hand; X-rays;  CT scan (to uncover fractures missed by X-rays and visualize soft tissue and blood vessel injuries); MRI (for more sensitive detection of small fractures and ligament injuries).
Treatments: Reduction (manipulation of bone fragments); Immobilization (splint or cast); Elevation of hand above heart level; Over-the-counter pain relievers; Opioid medication (e.g., codeine);  Antibiotics (for open fractures); Physical therapy; External fixation; Surgery (implantation of pins, plates, rods, or screws; bone graft); Rehabilitation exercises.
Tests: X-ray; CT scan; MRI; Bone scan
Medications_Drugs: Codeine; Over-the-counter pain relievers; NSAIDs (Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs); Antibiotics

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is usually based on symptoms and listening to the child's lungs with a stethoscope.  Tests are not usually needed unless the child is at risk of severe bronchiolitis, symptoms worsen, or another problem is suspected.
Treatments: Comfort measures at home; Oxygen therapy (hospital); Intravenous fluids (hospital); Nebulized albuterol treatment (severe cases);  Antibiotics (for secondary bacterial infections such as pneumonia or ear infection)
Tests: Chest X-ray; Viral testing (nasal swab); Blood tests (white blood cell count, oxygen level)

Diagnosis: Physical exam with stethoscope to listen to lungs;  Chest X-ray to rule out pneumonia or other conditions (especially important for smokers); Sputum tests to identify bacterial infections or allergies; Pulmonary function test (spirometry) to assess lung capacity and airflow, helpful in diagnosing chronic bronchitis, asthma, or emphysema.  During the first few days, it can be difficult to distinguish from a common cold.
Treatments: Rest; Hydration; Avoiding lung irritants; Humidifier use; Face covering in cold air; Pulmonary rehabilitation (for chronic bronchitis); Oxygen therapy (for chronic bronchitis); Cough medicine (cough suppressants); Inhalers and other medications to reduce inflammation (for allergies, asthma, or COPD); Antibiotics (if bacterial infection suspected).
Tests: Chest X-ray; Sputum tests; Pulmonary function test (spirometry)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is made by testing blood or bone marrow; other tests help identify complications.
Treatments: Antibiotics for at least six weeks
Tests: Blood test; Bone marrow test; X-rays; CT scan; MRI scan; Cerebrospinal fluid culture; Echocardiography

Diagnosis: Brugada syndrome is usually diagnosed in adults and adolescents; diagnosis in young children is rare due to often unnoticed symptoms. Diagnosis involves a physical exam, listening to the heart with a stethoscope, and tests to check the heartbeat.  An ECG (with or without medication) and a 24-hour Holter monitor may be used;  an echocardiogram helps identify structural heart problems but doesn't diagnose Brugada syndrome itself; electrophysiological (EP) testing and mapping may be performed in some cases.
Treatments: Medication; Catheter ablation; Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD);  Aggressive fever treatment; Avoidance of triggering drugs and excessive alcohol; Avoidance of competitive sports (for high-risk individuals)
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG); 24-hour Holter monitor; Echocardiogram; Electrophysiological (EP) testing and mapping

Diagnosis: There is no single test to diagnose Buerger's disease; diagnosis is based on exclusion of other conditions with similar symptoms and clinical findings.  Tests are used to rule out other potential causes.
Treatments: Cessation of all tobacco use; Medicines to improve blood flow; Compression therapy; Surgery (amputation in severe cases)
Tests: Blood tests; Exam of arteries in hands and feet (using blood pressure cuffs and ultrasound); CT or MRI scan of blood vessels; Angiogram of hands and feet
Medications_Drugs: Aspirin; Bosentan (Tracleer); Blood pressure medications ( unspecified)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a discussion of eating habits, weight loss methods, and physical symptoms; a physical exam; blood and urine tests; an ECG or other cardiac tests; and a mental health evaluation assessing body image and weight perception.  A diagnosis typically includes at least one episode of bingeing and purging per week for three months, but any such behavior warrants treatment.
Treatments: Talk therapy (CBT-E, FBT, Dialectical behavioral therapy); Medication; Nutrition education; Hospitalization (if symptoms are severe)
Tests: Blood test; Urine test; ECG; Mental health evaluation

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a discussion of symptoms and medical history, a physical exam, and potentially blood tests and/or a skin biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.  A dermatologist may be consulted.
Treatments: Corticosteroid creams (e.g., clobetasol propionate); Oral corticosteroids; Dapsone; Doxycycline; Azathioprine; Rituximab; Mycophenolate; Methotrexate; Wound care; Lifestyle modifications (limiting activities, protecting skin, wearing loose-fitting clothes, dietary adjustments)
Tests: Blood tests; Skin biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Clobetasol propionate; Oral corticosteroids; Dapsone; Doxycycline; Azathioprine; Rituximab; Mycophenolate; Methotrexate

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of bundle branch block is typically made using an electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG), which measures the heart's electrical activity and can reveal the presence and location of the block.  A thorough medical exam is usually necessary for left bundle branch block, while a full checkup might not be needed for right bundle branch block in otherwise healthy individuals.  An echocardiogram may be used to assess the heart's structure and identify underlying causes.
Treatments: Most people with bundle branch block don't require treatment. For those with underlying heart conditions, treatment focuses on managing those conditions. Medications might be used to manage high blood pressure or heart failure symptoms. A pacemaker may be recommended for those with a history of fainting. Cardiac resynchronization therapy (biventricular pacing) might be necessary for bundle branch block with low heart-pumping function.
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Echocardiogram

Diagnosis: A physical exam by a healthcare professional; X-ray of the foot to determine treatment.
Treatments: Different shoes; Padding (bunion pads or cushions); Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Cortisone shots; Shoe inserts (padded or orthotic); Ice or ice pack; Surgery (removing swollen tissue; straightening the big toe; realigning bones; joining bones)
Tests: X-ray
Medications_Drugs: Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Cortisone shots

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves physical exam (checking swollen lymph nodes and neurological function); blood tests (checking for lymphoma cells and LDH levels, and infections like EBV and HIV); imaging tests (CT, PET, and MRI scans); lymph node biopsy; bone marrow aspiration and biopsy; lumbar puncture (if neurological symptoms or high CNS lymphoma risk); lab testing of lymphoma cells (microscopic examination, protein marker analysis – including Ki-67, CD10, CD19, CD20, CD79a, CD22, CD38, CD45, and absence of BCL2, CD44, and TdT– and DNA analysis for MYC translocation).  The "starry sky" appearance under a microscope is noted.
Treatments: Chemotherapy; Immunotherapy; Clinical trials; Bone marrow transplant (stem cell transplant); Radiation therapy; Antiretrovirals (in HIV-positive individuals)
Tests: Blood tests; CT scan; PET scan; MRI; Lymph node biopsy; Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy; Lumbar puncture

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of burning mouth syndrome involves ruling out other conditions through a review of medical history, medication use, oral examination, and assessment of oral hygiene practices.  Further investigation may include blood tests, oral cultures, biopsies, allergy tests, salivary measurements, gastric reflux tests, and imaging studies.  There is no single definitive test.
Treatments: Saliva replacement products; Oral rinses; Lidocaine; Capsaicin; Alpha-lipoic acid; Clonazepam; Certain antidepressants; Medications that block nerve pain; Cognitive behavioral therapy; Treatment of underlying conditions (for secondary burning mouth syndrome)
Tests: Blood tests; Oral cultures; Biopsies; Allergy tests; Salivary measurements; Gastric reflux tests; MRI; CT scan
Medications_Drugs: Lidocaine; Capsaicin; Alpha-lipoic acid; Clonazepam (Klonopin); Certain antidepressants

Diagnosis: Assessment of burn severity through skin examination; referral to burn center if burn covers >10% of total body surface area, is very deep, or is located on the face, feet, or groin, or meets other American Burn Association criteria; evaluation for other injuries; lab tests, X-rays, or other diagnostic tests may be ordered.
Treatments: Home treatment for minor burns; for major burns: pain control; removal of dead tissue (debridement); infection prevention; scar reduction; restoration of function; skin grafts; physical therapy; occupational therapy; breathing assistance (intubation); feeding tube; escharotomy; IV fluids
Tests: Chest X-rays; Upper endoscopy; Lab tests; X-rays
Medications_Drugs: Morphine; anti-anxiety medications; bacitracin; silver sulfadiazine (Silvadene); IV antibiotics; ibuprofen; acetaminophen; tetanus shot

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is often based on medical history and physical exam; Imaging tests (X-ray, ultrasound, or MRI) may be used if physical exam is inconclusive; Lab tests (blood tests or analysis of bursa fluid) may be used to determine the cause of inflammation.
Treatments: Rest; Ice; Over-the-counter pain relievers (ibuprofen, naproxen sodium); Corticosteroid injection; Antibiotics (if infection is present); Physical therapy; Surgery (rarely, to drain or remove bursa); Assistive devices (e.g., walking cane).
Tests: X-ray; Ultrasound; MRI; Blood tests; Analysis of fluid from inflamed bursa

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on diarrhea and other symptoms, along with the presence of C. difficile in a stool sample.  Regular, formed stools negate the need for testing.  Recent antibiotic use is not required for diagnosis.
Treatments: Antibiotics; Surgery (for severe pain, organ failure, toxic megacolon, or inflammation); Antibody-based therapy (bezlotoxumab); Fecal microbiota transplant (FMT); Probiotics (research use only)
Tests: Stool test for C. difficile toxins or bacterial strains; Flexible sigmoidoscopy; Colonoscopy; X-ray of the stomach area; CT scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing health history, assessing symptoms via physical exam, and potentially utilizing diagnostic tests.  Confirmation often relies on skin biopsy results.
Treatments: Restoring oxygen and blood flow to the skin (anticoagulants; low-dose tissue plasminogen activator; hyperbaric oxygen therapy); Reducing calcium buildup (dialysis adjustments; medication changes; sodium thiosulfate; cinacalcet); Intensive wound treatment (debridement; wet dressings; antibiotics); Pain control
Tests: Skin biopsy; Blood tests (creatinine, calcium, phosphorus, parathyroid hormone, vitamin D); X-rays (to show calcium buildups in blood vessels)
Medications_Drugs: Anticoagulants; Low-dose tissue plasminogen activator; Sodium thiosulfate; Cinacalcet (Sensipar); Antibiotics; Warfarin; Corticosteroids; Iron; Calcium supplements; Vitamin D supplements

Diagnosis: Cancer diagnosis involves a physical exam checking for lumps or abnormalities; laboratory tests such as blood and urine tests to identify abnormalities; imaging tests like CT scans, bone scans, MRI, PET scans, ultrasounds, and X-rays; and a biopsy to definitively diagnose cancer by microscopic examination of cells.  Abnormal cells are characterized by irregular size, shape, and organization compared to normal cells. Staging involves further tests (imaging, etc.) to determine the extent of cancer spread.
Treatments: Surgery; Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy (external beam radiation; brachytherapy); Bone marrow transplant (stem cell transplant); Immunotherapy (biological therapy); Hormone therapy; Targeted drug therapy; Palliative treatment (surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, hormone therapy, medications for symptom relief); Clinical trials
Tests: Physical exam; Urine test; Blood test; Complete blood count (CBC); Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Bone scan; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; Ultrasound; X-ray; Biopsy; Pap smear; Sentinel node biopsy; Colonoscopy; Mammogram; Chest X-rays; Urinalysis

Diagnosis: Visual examination by a doctor or dentist;  Tests may be done to rule out other health problems if sores are severe or persistent.
Treatments: Mouth rinses (dexamethasone, lidocaine); Topical products (benzocaine, fluocinonide, hydrogen peroxide, other products); Oral medications (sucralfate, colchicine, oral steroids); Cautery (Debacterol, silver nitrate); Nutritional supplements (folate, vitamin B-6, vitamin B-12, zinc); Self-care measures (salt water rinse, baking soda rinse, milk of magnesia, ice, gentle brushing).
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: Dexamethasone; Lidocaine; Benzocaine; Fluocinonide; Hydrogen peroxide; Sucralfate; Colchicine; Oral steroids.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is suspected based on symptoms and exposure history; confirmed by blood test for carbon monoxide levels.  The blood test should be done as soon as possible after removing the person from the exposure environment, but should not delay treatment.
Treatments: Breathing pure oxygen; Hyperbaric oxygen therapy; Ventilation (for those unable to breathe on their own)
Tests: Blood test for carbon monoxide

Diagnosis: Assessment of signs and symptoms to rule out other causes; confirmation may involve urine and blood tests to detect excess serotonin and other tumor-released substances; imaging tests (CT scan, MRI, nuclear medicine scans) to locate tumors; endoscopy (including bronchoscopy and colonoscopy) for visualization and biopsy to confirm diagnosis.
Treatments: Surgery; Octreotide (Sandostatin) injections; Lanreotide (Somatuline Depot) injections; Telotristat (Xermelo); Peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT); Hepatic artery embolization; Radiofrequency ablation; Cryotherapy; Chemotherapy
Tests: Urine test; Blood test; CT scan; MRI; Nuclear medicine scans; Endoscopy; Bronchoscopy; Colonoscopy; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves blood tests to detect high hormone levels or byproducts; urine tests to detect excess chemicals; imaging tests (CT scan, MRI, PET scan, X-ray, nuclear medicine scans) to locate the tumor; endoscopy (including bronchoscopy, colonoscopy, capsule endoscopy) for visualization; and biopsy to confirm diagnosis and determine cell type and aggressiveness.
Treatments: Surgery; Medications to control excess hormones; Chemotherapy; Targeted drug therapy; Peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT); Hepatic artery embolization; Radiofrequency ablation; Cryoablation
Tests: Blood tests; Urine tests; CT scan; MRI; PET scan; X-ray; Nuclear medicine scans; Endoscopy; Bronchoscopy; Colonoscopy; Capsule endoscopy; Biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Octreotide (Sandostatin, Bynfezia Pen); Lanreotide (Somatuline Depot); Telotristat (Xermelo)

Diagnosis: Physical exam to assess symptoms; imaging tests (CT scan, MRI, PET scan) to locate and size the cancer; biopsy to confirm cancer and characterize cells; further tests to identify the primary cancer site.
Treatments: Chemotherapy; Immunotherapy; Targeted therapy; Radiation therapy; Surgery; Palliative care.
Tests: Physical exam; CT scan; MRI; PET scan; Biopsy; Organ function tests; Tumor marker tests (e.g., prostate-specific antigen test, cancer antigen 125 test);  Laboratory testing of cancer cells.

Diagnosis: Cardiogenic shock is usually diagnosed in an emergency setting by checking for signs and symptoms of shock and performing tests to determine the cause.  Diagnosis involves assessing low blood pressure.
Treatments: Emergency life support (oxygen, ventilator, IV fluids and medications); Medications to increase heart pumping ability and reduce blood clot risk; Angioplasty and stenting; Balloon pump; Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO); Coronary artery bypass surgery; Surgery to repair heart injury; Ventricular assist device (VAD)
Tests: Blood pressure measurement; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Chest X-ray; Blood tests; Arterial blood gas test; Echocardiogram; Cardiac catheterization (angiogram)
Medications_Drugs: Dopamine; Epinephrine; Norepinephrine; Dobutamine; Milrinone; Aspirin; Clopidogrel; Tirofiban; Eptifibatide; Heparin

Diagnosis: Physical examination including review of personal and family medical history; assessment of symptom onset and triggers.
Treatments: Medications; Septal ablation; Other types of ablation; Ventricular assist device (VAD); Pacemaker; Cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) device; Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD); Septal myectomy; Heart transplant
Tests: Blood tests (including BNP, iron levels, kidney, thyroid, and liver function); Chest X-ray; Echocardiogram; Electrocardiogram (ECG); Exercise stress tests; Cardiac catheterization (including coronary angiogram and biopsy); Cardiac MRI; Cardiac CT scan; Genetic testing

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a medical history and physical exam, including auscultation for a carotid bruit (swooshing sound indicating narrowed artery);  neurological examination assessing physical and mental abilities (strength, memory, speech).
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (quitting smoking, weight loss, healthy diet, reduced salt intake, regular exercise); Medications to control blood pressure or lower cholesterol; Carotid endarterectomy; Carotid angioplasty; Carotid stenting
Tests: Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI; CT angiography; MR angiography

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing the patient's symptom history (pattern, timing, affected fingers), conducting a physical exam to assess finger sensation and muscle strength, and potentially triggering symptoms through wrist bending or nerve tapping.  The absence of little finger symptoms suggests a condition other than carpal tunnel syndrome.
Treatments: Wrist splinting; Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs); Corticosteroid injections; Surgery (carpal tunnel release; endoscopic surgery; open surgery; ultrasound-guided surgery)
Tests: X-ray; Ultrasound; Electromyography (EMG); Nerve conduction study

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of Castleman disease involves a review of medical history and physical exam, followed by blood and urine tests to rule out other conditions and detect anemia or changes in blood proteins.  Imaging tests (CT scan, PET scan) identify enlarged lymph nodes, liver, or spleen. A lymph node biopsy is essential for definitive diagnosis and to differentiate from related disorders like lymphoma.
Treatments: Surgery (lymph node removal); Radiation therapy; Rituximab; Siltuximab; Antiviral medications; Chemotherapy; Corticosteroids; Sirolimus
Tests: Blood and urine tests; CT scan; PET scan; Lymph node biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Rituximab; Siltuximab; Antiviral medications; Corticosteroids; Sirolimus

Diagnosis: Eye doctors review medical history and symptoms, performing an eye exam including vision tests (visual acuity tests using eye charts to assess reading ability), eye structure exams (slit lamp examination of the front of the eye), retinal exams (examining the retina after pupil dilation to check for cataract signs), and fluid pressure tests (applanation tonometry).  Cataracts are diagnosed based on the findings of these examinations.
Treatments: Cataract surgery; Eyeglasses; Contact lenses
Tests: Vision test (visual acuity test); Eye structure exam (slit lamp examination); Retinal exam; Fluid pressure test (applanation tonometry)

Diagnosis: Cerebral cavernous malformations (CCMs) are often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally on brain imaging performed for other reasons.  Symptoms may prompt further investigation.  Genetic testing may be considered if there is a family history.
Treatments: Close observation; Surgical removal or treatment of the malformation; Medications to control seizures (if present)
Tests: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Genetic testing

Diagnosis: Clinical examination including visual inspection of teeth for decay and probing for soft areas; questioning the patient about tooth pain and sensitivity; review of dental X-rays to identify cavities and decay.  The dentist will also determine the type of cavity (smooth surface, pit and fissure, or root).
Treatments: Fluoride treatments; Fillings (composite resin, porcelain, dental amalgam); Crowns (gold, high-strength porcelain, resin, porcelain fused to metal); Root canals; Tooth extractions; Bridges; Dental implants
Tests: Dental X-rays

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves serology testing (detecting antibodies in the blood indicative of an immune reaction to gluten); genetic testing for HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 (to rule out celiac disease); and potentially endoscopy with biopsy or capsule endoscopy to visualize the small intestine and assess villous damage.  It's crucial to test before starting a gluten-free diet as this can affect test results.  A skin biopsy may be performed if dermatitis herpetiformis is suspected.
Treatments: Strict lifelong gluten-free diet; Vitamin and mineral supplementation (for deficiencies); Steroids (for severe damage or refractory disease); Azathioprine; Budesonide; Dapsone (for dermatitis herpetiformis)
Tests: Serology testing; Genetic testing (HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8); Upper endoscopy with biopsy; Capsule endoscopy; Skin biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Azathioprine; Budesonide; Dapsone; Steroids (type not specified)

Diagnosis: Visual examination of the skin to assess dimpling and potential causes to determine appropriate treatment.  Methods that treat fat don't necessarily remove dimpling, and vice versa.
Treatments: Laser and radiofrequency treatments (ablative and non-ablative); Acoustic wave therapy; Massage (including Endermologie); Surgery (subcision, fat grafting); 0.3% retinol cream application; Weight loss; Physical activity.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is typically made by visual examination of the skin; blood tests and other tests may be used to rule out other conditions.
Treatments: Prescription oral antibiotics; intravenous antibiotics (if symptoms are severe or unresponsive to oral medication); elevating the affected body part; applying cool, damp cloths;  use of compression wraps or stockings (as recommended by a healthcare professional); nonprescription pain medication.
Tests: Blood tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves assessing family history of stroke, epilepsy, or related conditions; listening for a bruit (whooshing sound) with a stethoscope; and utilizing imaging tests.
Treatments: Observation; Surgery; Stereotactic radiosurgery; Endovascular embolization
Tests: Angiogram; Magnetic resonance angiogram; Computerized tomography angiogram; MRI; CT scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on symptoms and a sleep study called polysomnography, which monitors breathing, heart, lung, and brain activity, arm and leg movements, and blood oxygen levels during sleep.  A split-night study may be used, where treatment is initiated during the second half of the night if central sleep apnea is diagnosed.  Neurologists and cardiologists may also be involved in evaluation, and imaging of the head or heart may be necessary.
Treatments: Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP); Bilevel positive airway pressure (BPAP); Adaptive servo-ventilation (ASV); Supplemental oxygen; Addressing associated medical problems; Reduction of opioid medicines; Transvenous phrenic nerve stimulation
Tests: Polysomnography; Head imaging; Heart imaging

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is made through evaluation of symptoms, medical history, physical exam, monitoring of growth and development, and referral to specialists (pediatric neurologists, pediatric physical medicine and rehabilitation specialists, and child development specialists).  A series of tests may be needed to rule out other conditions.  The type of cerebral palsy is determined by the main movement condition present.
Treatments: Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Speech and language therapy; Recreational therapy; Medications; Muscle or nerve injections (e.g., onabotulinumtoxinA (Botox)); Oral muscle relaxants (baclofen, tizanidine, diazepam, dantrolene); Intrathecal baclofen pump; Botox injections into salivary glands; Orthopedic surgery; Selective dorsal rhizotomy; Braces; Splints; Adaptive equipment (walkers, canes, standing/seating systems, electric wheelchairs); Surgical procedures to correct bone changes and muscle tightness
Tests: MRI; Cranial ultrasound; EEG; Blood tests; Urine tests; Skin tests; Tests for vision, hearing, speech, intellect, development, movement, and other medical conditions

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a Pap test to detect abnormal cells;  colposcopy with biopsy (punch biopsy; endocervical curettage; loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP)); cone biopsy may be used to obtain deeper tissue samples for testing;  further imaging tests (X-ray, MRI, CT, PET scan) and visual examination of the bladder and rectum may be used for staging to determine the extent of the cancer.
Treatments: Surgery (cone biopsy; trachelectomy; hysterectomy (including minimally invasive hysterectomy)); Radiation; Chemotherapy; Combination of surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy.
Tests: Pap test; HPV DNA test; Colposcopy; Punch biopsy; Endocervical curettage; Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP); Cone biopsy; X-ray; MRI; CT scan; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; Visual examination of bladder and rectum.

Diagnosis: Physical examination; Blood tests; MRI; Electromyography (EMG) may be used to rule out other conditions.
Treatments: Botulinum toxin injections (Botox, Dysport, Xeomin, Myobloc); Oral medications with muscle-relaxing effects; Sensory tricks; Heat packs; Massage; Neck strengthening and flexibility exercises; Stress management techniques; Deep brain stimulation; Nerve surgery.
Tests: Blood tests; MRI; Electromyography (EMG)

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing neck range of motion, reflexes, muscle strength, and gait; Imaging tests such as neck X-ray (to show bone spurs and rule out other causes), MRI (to pinpoint nerve pinching), and CT myelography (for detailed spinal cord and nerve root imaging); Nerve function tests like electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction studies.
Treatments: Medications; Physical therapy; Traction; Surgery; Self-care (regular exercise, over-the-counter pain relievers, heat/ice, soft neck brace); Chiropractic adjustments; Massage therapy; Acupuncture
Tests: Neck X-ray; MRI; Computed tomography (CT) myelography; Electromyography (EMG); Nerve conduction study
Medications_Drugs: Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Prednisone; Cyclobenzaprine; Anti-seizure medications; Antidepressants

Diagnosis: Physical exam including pelvic exam to check for swelling and tenderness; Speculum examination of vagina and cervix; Specimen collection (cervical and vaginal fluid) for lab testing for infections; Urinalysis may also be performed.
Treatments: No treatment needed for allergic reactions; Antibiotics for STIs (gonorrhea, chlamydia, bacterial vaginosis); Antiviral medication for genital herpes (does not cure herpes); Repeat testing for gonorrhea or chlamydia may be recommended.
Tests: Pelvic exam; Speculum examination; Cervical and vaginal fluid sample collection; Urinalysis

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing symptoms and risk factors; two or more blood tests to confirm diagnosis if symptoms are present; further tests to assess chronic disease and complications if diagnosed.
Treatments: Kill parasite and ease symptoms; benznidazole and nifurtimox (for acute phase in affected regions and children under 18 with chronic infection in the US); medications to slow disease progression and complications in chronic phase; medication for heart complications; pacemaker or other devices for heart rhythm control; heart surgery or transplant (if necessary); diet changes for digestive complications; medication for digestive complications; corticosteroids for digestive complications; surgery for severe digestive complications.
Tests: Blood tests; Electrocardiogram; Chest X-ray; Echocardiogram; Abdominal X-ray; Upper endoscopy

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing muscle weakness, muscle bulk, reflexes, sensory loss, and foot deformities;  Nerve conduction studies to measure nerve signal strength and speed; Electromyography (EMG) to measure muscle electrical activity; Nerve biopsy for laboratory analysis to differentiate from other disorders; Genetic testing to detect common genetic defects.
Treatments: Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Orthopedic devices (braces, splints, custom shoes); Corrective foot surgery
Tests: Nerve conduction studies; Electromyography (EMG); Nerve biopsy; Genetic testing
Medications_Drugs: Prescription pain medication (specific medication not specified)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on reported symptoms; no specific tests exist to diagnose chemo brain; other conditions are ruled out using blood tests, brain scans, and other tests as deemed necessary by the healthcare professional.
Treatments: Cognitive rehabilitation; Cognitive remediation; Brain-training exercises; Memory and thinking exercises; Tracking memory troubles and adapting daily routines; Learning new ways to perform tasks; Stress relief techniques (progressive muscle relaxation, mindfulness); Lifestyle modifications (managing home/work environment, preparing for tasks, staying organized, taking breaks); Exercise (physical and brain training); Complementary therapies (art therapy, music therapy, meditation).
Tests: Blood tests; Brain scans
Medications_Drugs: Methylphenidate (Concerta, Ritalin); Donepezil (Aricept, Adlarity); Modafinil (Provigil); Memantine (Namenda)

Diagnosis: Chest pain diagnosis begins with assessment for life-threatening conditions like heart attack and pulmonary embolism.  Initial tests focus on cardiac evaluation (ECG) and identification of cardiac damage (blood tests). Chest X-ray and CT scan evaluate lung conditions and other structures like the aorta. Further testing depends on initial results.
Treatments: Medications; Angioplasty and stent placement; Coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG); Emergency repair surgery; Lung reinflation; Talk therapy (cognitive behavioral therapy)
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Blood tests; Chest X-ray; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Echocardiogram; CT coronary angiogram; Exercise stress test; Coronary catheterization
Medications_Drugs: Nitroglycerin; Blood pressure medicines; Aspirin; Clot-busting drugs (thrombolytics); Blood thinners; Acid-reducing medicines; Anti-anxiety medicines

Diagnosis: Review of medical history and symptoms; physical exam; magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to visualize structural differences in the brain, cerebellum, and spinal canal; computerized tomography (CT) scan may be used to rule out other conditions such as tumors or bone/blood vessel problems.
Treatments: Monitoring with regular exams and MRIs (for asymptomatic cases); pain medicine (for headache or pain); posterior fossa decompression surgery (to reduce pressure on cerebellum and spinal cord); shunt placement (for syrinx or hydrocephalus).
Tests: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Computerized tomography (CT) scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is most often based on the characteristic rash;  Confirmation can be done with blood tests or a tissue study of affected skin samples.
Treatments: In otherwise healthy children, often no treatment is needed; Antihistamines for itching;  For high-risk individuals, antiviral medications (acyclovir, valacyclovir, famciclovir) may be prescribed to shorten illness and reduce complications; Post-exposure vaccination may be considered; Treatment of complications (e.g., antibiotics for infected skin and pneumonia, antiviral medication for encephalitis) may be necessary;  Hospitalization may be required for severe cases.  Home remedies such as cool baths, calamine lotion, soft diet, and acetaminophen for fever may help manage symptoms.
Tests: Blood tests; Tissue study of affected skin samples

Diagnosis: Examination of affected skin; discussion of symptoms and recent cold exposure; blood tests may be used to rule out other conditions; skin biopsy may be performed.
Treatments: Self-care (keeping hands and feet warm and dry); topical corticosteroid; blood pressure medication
Tests: Blood tests; Skin biopsy

Diagnosis: Identifying child abuse or neglect requires careful evaluation, including physical and behavioral signs.  Factors considered include physical exam (evaluating injuries and signs/symptoms); lab tests; X-rays; other tests; child's medical and developmental history; observation of child's behavior and parent-child interactions; discussions with parents/caregivers; and talking with the child (when possible).
Treatments: Medical care (immediate medical attention if needed, follow-up care); Psychotherapy (Trauma-focused CBT; Child-parent psychotherapy); Social services (home visits, ensuring essential needs); Mental health services (for children in foster care)
Tests: Physical exam; Lab tests; X-rays; other tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of Childhood Apraxia of Speech (CAS) is based on a pattern of observed speech problems, not a single test.  Evaluation by a speech-language pathologist includes review of symptoms and medical history; examination of speech muscles; assessment of speech sound, word, and phrase production; and assessment of language skills (vocabulary, sentence structure, comprehension).  Diagnosis can be challenging, especially in children with limited speech or interaction difficulties.  A trial of speech therapy may aid in confirming the diagnosis.
Treatments: Speech therapy (focusing on practicing syllables, words, and phrases; using various cues such as auditory, visual, and tactile cues; incorporating speech drills, sound and movement exercises, vowel practice, and paced learning); Alternative communication methods (sign language, gestures, electronic devices); Therapy for co-existing language delays, motor skill issues, or other medical conditions.
Tests: Hearing tests; Oral-motor assessment (examining lips, tongue, jaw, palate for structural issues and muscle tone); Speech evaluation (observing sound, word, and sentence production; assessing coordination and smoothness of speech movements; evaluating melody and rhythm).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis considers symptoms, frequency, and medical history;  tests may rule out other conditions and identify causes;  diagnosis may be delayed until symptoms are observed over months or years, especially in children under 5;  in younger children, diagnosis relies on parent-reported symptoms.
Treatments: Wait-and-see approach (for mild symptoms in children under 3);  medicines to improve symptoms (for frequent or severe wheezing in infants/toddlers);  preventative long-term control medicines.
Tests: Lung function tests (spirometry);  bronchoprovocation; Exhaled nitric oxide test; Allergy skin testing.
Medications_Drugs: fluticasone (Flovent Diskus); budesonide (Pulmicort Flexhaler); mometasone (Asmanex HFA); ciclesonide (Alvesco); beclomethasone (Qvar Redihaler); montelukast (Singulair); zafirlukast (Accolate); zileuton (Zyflo); fluticasone and salmeterol (Advair Diskus); budesonide and formoterol (Symbicort); fluticasone and vilanterol (Breo Ellipta); mometasone and formoterol (Dulera); albuterol (ProAir HFA, Ventolin HFA); theophylline (Theo).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves calculating the child's BMI and determining its percentile on a standard growth chart compared to children of the same sex and age.  Cutoff points define underweight (BMI 5th percentile or below), healthy weight (BMI between 5th and 84th percentiles), overweight (BMI between 85th and 94th percentiles), obese (BMI 95th percentile or above), and severely obese (BMI ≥120% of the 95th percentile).  Assessment also considers family history of obesity/related conditions, eating habits, activity level, screen time, blood pressure, other health conditions, and mental health history.
Treatments: Changes in eating habits and physical activity; guidance from a healthcare team on nutrition and physical activity; family-based skills building for long-term healthy lifestyle; dietitian visits; more-regular healthcare visits focused on healthy habits; medication; weight-loss surgery (for some teens with severe obesity)
Tests: Blood tests (cholesterol test; blood sugar test; liver test; hormone level tests)
Medications_Drugs: Semaglutide (Wegovy); Liraglutide (Saxenda); Phentermine and topiramate (Qsymia); Phentermine; Lisdexamfetamine

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves ruling out other mental health disorders and substance use/medical conditions; physical exam to rule out other problems and check for complications; tests and screenings to rule out conditions with similar symptoms and screen for alcohol and drugs; imaging studies (MRI or CT scan); psychiatric evaluation assessing appearance, thoughts, feelings, behavior, self-harm risk, cognitive function, mood, anxiety, psychotic symptoms, and family/personal history; application of DSM-5 criteria.  The process can be lengthy due to symptom overlap with other conditions.
Treatments: Medications; Psychotherapy (individual and family therapy); Life skills training; Hospitalization; Partial hospitalization; Residential care
Tests: Physical exam; Tests to rule out conditions with similar symptoms; Alcohol and drug screenings; MRI; CT scan
Medications_Drugs: Aripiprazole (Abilify); Lurasidone (Latuda); Olanzapine (Zyprexa); Quetiapine (Seroquel); Risperidone (Risperdal); Paliperidone (Invega); Perphenazine; Thiothixene; Antidepressants; Anti-anxiety drugs

Diagnosis: Chlamydia diagnosis involves analyzing a sample of cells from urine or via swab from the cervix, vagina, throat, or anus.  A home test may be used for initial screening, requiring confirmation by a healthcare professional.  CDC recommends testing for anyone with symptoms or those in high-risk groups.
Treatments: Antibiotics
Tests: Urine test; Cervical swab; Vaginal swab; Throat swab; Anal swab

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves assessment of signs and symptoms, liver function tests, tumor marker tests (CA 19-9), imaging tests (ultrasound, CT scans, MRI, MRCP, ERCP), and biopsy (fine-needle aspiration or during ERCP).  The extent of the cancer is determined through further imaging after diagnosis.
Treatments: Surgery (including removal of part of the bile duct, liver tissue, pancreas tissue, or lymph nodes); Liver transplant; Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy (external beam radiation; brachytherapy); Targeted drug therapy; Immunotherapy; Radiofrequency ablation; Photodynamic therapy; Biliary drainage (including stenting and bypass surgery)
Tests: Liver function tests; Tumor marker test (CA 19-9); Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP); Endoscopic ultrasound; Ultrasound; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP); Biopsy (fine-needle aspiration or during ERCP)

Diagnosis: Physical exam evaluating symptoms and medical history;  Blood tests to detect infection or gallbladder issues; Imaging tests (abdominal ultrasound, endoscopic ultrasound, CT scan, magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography) to visualize gallbladder and bile ducts and identify stones; HIDA scan to track bile flow and identify blockages.
Treatments: Hospital stay for inflammation control; Fasting; Intravenous fluids; Antibiotics; Pain medications; Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) for stone removal; Gallbladder drainage (cholecystostomy, percutaneous drainage, endoscopic drainage); Cholecystectomy (laparoscopic or open).
Tests: Blood tests; Abdominal ultrasound; Endoscopic ultrasound; CT scan; Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP); Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of cholera is confirmed through stool testing; rapid cholera dipstick tests are available for quick confirmation, especially in remote areas.  Symptoms of severe cholera may be apparent in endemic areas, but testing is essential for definitive diagnosis.
Treatments: Rehydration (oral rehydration salts [ORS] solution; intravenous [IV] fluids); Antibiotics (for severe cases to shorten duration of diarrhea); Zinc supplements (for children to lessen diarrhea and shorten duration)
Tests: Stool test; Rapid cholera dipstick test
Medications_Drugs: Oral rehydration salts (ORS); Antibiotics; Zinc supplements

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing symptoms and medical history; performing a physical exam; ordering blood tests to measure bile acid levels and assess liver function.
Treatments: Ursodiol; Other medications to relieve itching; Cool or lukewarm water soaks; Close monitoring of the baby; Early delivery (around 37 weeks); Progestin-containing contraceptives; Intrauterine devices (IUDs); Barrier methods (condoms or diaphragms)
Tests: Blood tests to measure bile acid levels and liver function; Ultrasound; Nonstress testing; Fetal biophysical profile (BPP)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam to assess signs and symptoms; imaging tests such as X-ray, bone scan, MRI, and CT scan; and a biopsy to analyze suspicious tissue and confirm the presence of cancer.  The biopsy location influences the procedure and requires careful planning to avoid interfering with future surgery.
Treatments: Surgery (scraping cancer cells from the bone; cutting away cancer and surrounding tissue, potentially including limb amputation or limb salvage surgery); Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy (used less frequently, mainly for fast-growing types)
Tests: Physical exam; X-ray; Bone scan; MRI; CT scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Physical exam; review of health history; imaging tests (CT scans and MRIs); biopsy to confirm cancer and characterize cancer cells.
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy (including proton therapy and stereotactic body radiotherapy); Targeted therapy
Tests: CT scan; MRI; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a neurological exam assessing vision, hearing, balance, coordination, and reflexes to pinpoint brain areas affected; brain imaging (MRI and CT scans) to visualize the tumor and aid surgical planning; and genetic testing to identify genetic changes associated with some cases.
Treatments: Surgery (to remove the tumor, potentially with temporary drainage for hydrocephalus); Chemotherapy (may be used alongside surgery and/or radiation); Radiation therapy (may be used after surgery, even if tumor was completely removed, or later if recurrence occurs); Clinical trials
Tests: Neurological exam; MRI; CT scan; Genetic testing

Diagnosis: A thorough medical history and physical exam are conducted;  treatment for common causes is often started before extensive testing; if initial treatment fails, tests for less common causes may be pursued.
Treatments: Addressing underlying conditions (e.g., allergies, acid reflux, asthma, infection); Smoking cessation; Switching ACE inhibitor medications; Lifestyle changes (e.g., hydration, humidification, avoiding tobacco smoke); Cough suppressants (not recommended for children);  Surgery (in some cases of acid reflux).
Tests: Chest X-ray; X-ray of sinuses; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Lung function tests (spirometry); Asthma challenge test (methacholine); Bacterial culture of sputum; Bronchoscopy; Biopsy; Rhinoscopy
Medications_Drugs: Antihistamines; Corticosteroids; Decongestants; Inhaled corticosteroids; Bronchodilators; Antibiotics; Acid blockers; Methacholine (Provocholine); Cough suppressants.

Diagnosis: Physical examination for signs of illness, infection, or neurological problems; review of headache history; imaging tests (CT scan or MRI) if the cause remains uncertain.
Treatments: Treatment of underlying condition; pain prevention strategies (including medication withdrawal); antidepressants; beta-blockers; anti-seizure medications; NSAIDs; botulinum toxin injections; acupuncture; biofeedback; massage; herbs, vitamins, and minerals (feverfew, butterbur, vitamin B2 (riboflavin), coenzyme Q10, magnesium sulfate); electrical stimulation of the occipital nerve; cognitive behavioral therapy.
Tests: CT scan; MRI; EEG (electroencephalogram); Urinalysis
Medications_Drugs: nortriptyline (Pamelor); fluoxetine (Prozac, Sarafem); atenolol (Tenormin); metoprolol (Lopressor, Toprol-XL); propranolol (Inderal, Innopran XL); topiramate (Topamax, Qudexy XR); divalproex sodium (Depakote); gabapentin (Neurontin, Gralise); naproxen sodium (Anaprox, Naprelan); onabotulinumtoxinA (Botox).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis often involves ruling out other conditions like shin splints or stress fractures; Physical exam may reveal muscle bulge, tenderness, or tension after exercise; Imaging studies (MRI, NIRS) can assess muscle compartment structure and blood flow; Compartment pressure measurement (gold standard) involves needle insertion to measure pressure before and after exercise, but is invasive and usually only done if other tests suggest the condition.
Treatments: Pain medications; Physical therapy; Athletic shoe inserts (orthotics); Massage; Rest from exercise; Modification of running technique; Botulinum toxin A (Botox) injections; Fasciotomy (surgical procedure)
Tests: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS); Compartment pressure measurement

Diagnosis: Review of family and medical history; physical exam; neutrophil function tests (e.g., dihydrorhodamine 123 (DHR) test); genetic testing; prenatal testing (if indicated by family history).
Treatments: Infection management; interferon-gamma injections; stem cell transplantation
Tests: Neutrophil function tests (e.g., DHR test); Genetic testing
Medications_Drugs: trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole (Bactrim, Sulfatrim Pediatric); itraconazole (Sporanox, Tolsura); Additional antibiotics or antifungal medicines (as needed)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing symptoms and skin examination;  patients may keep a diary tracking activities, medications, diet, hive location, duration, and presence of bruising or swelling; blood tests may be used to determine the cause; skin biopsy may be performed if needed for clarification.
Treatments: Nonprescription anti-itch medicines; Prescription-strength medicines;  Treatments to calm an overactive immune system; Self-care measures (avoiding triggers, applying cold, cool showers/baths, anti-itch creams/lotions, loose clothing, sunscreen, symptom tracking).
Tests: Blood tests; Skin biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Montelukast (Singulair); Doxepin (Silenor, Zonalon); Ranitidine; Omalizumab (Xolair); Cyclosporine (Neoral, Sandimmune); Tacrolimus (Prograf, Protopic); Hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil); Mycophenolate (Cellcept); Loratadine (Alavert, Claritin); Famotadine (Pepcid AC); Cimetidine (Tagamet HB); Nizatidine (Axid AR); Cetirizine (Zyrtec Allergy); Diphenhydramine (Benadryl)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a discussion of personal and family history, including high blood pressure, medication use affecting kidney function, changes in urinary habits, and family history of kidney disease.  A physical exam checks for heart or blood vessel problems and neurological issues.  Further diagnostic tests are then conducted to determine disease severity (stage).
Treatments: Treating the underlying cause; Managing complications (high blood pressure, swelling, anemia, high cholesterol, bone health); Dialysis (hemodialysis; peritoneal dialysis); Kidney transplant
Tests: Blood tests; Urine tests; Ultrasound; Kidney biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors; Angiotensin II receptor blockers; Diuretics; Erythropoietin; Iron supplements; Statins; Calcium supplements; Vitamin D supplements; Phosphate binders

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves blood tests to count cells (including lymphocytes and B cells), flow cytometry/immunophenotyping to identify lymphocyte types and analyze leukemia cell characteristics, and fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) to analyze lymphocytes for genetic changes.  Bone marrow biopsy, CT scans, and PET scans may be used as additional diagnostic tools.  Staging is performed to determine disease aggressiveness and prognosis.
Treatments: Watchful waiting (no immediate treatment for early stages); Chemotherapy; Targeted drug therapy; Immunotherapy; Bone marrow transplant (stem cell transplant); Supportive care (including cancer screening, vaccinations, and monitoring for other health problems)
Tests: Complete blood count (CBC); Flow cytometry; Immunophenotyping; Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH); Bone marrow biopsy; Bone marrow aspiration; Computerized tomography (CT); Positron emission tomography (PET)

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing vital signs and lymph node, spleen, and abdominal swelling; Complete blood count (CBC) to check blood cell counts, particularly white blood cells; Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy to examine bone marrow samples; Tests for the Philadelphia chromosome or BCR-ABL gene (FISH and PCR).
Treatments: Targeted therapy (tyrosine kinase inhibitors); Bone marrow transplant; Chemotherapy; Clinical trials
Tests: Complete blood count (CBC); Bone marrow aspiration; Bone marrow biopsy; Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH); Polymerase chain reaction (PCR)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing patient symptoms, family medical history, and maintaining a pain journal.  A pelvic exam checks for tenderness, growths, and muscle tension.  Lab tests screen for infections (chlamydia, gonorrhea, UTI). Imaging (ultrasound, CT scan, MRI) detects growths or abnormalities.  Laparoscopy allows direct visualization of pelvic organs.  Finding a definitive cause may not always be possible.
Treatments: Medications; Physical therapy; Spinal cord stimulation; Trigger point injections; Talk therapy (cognitive behavioral therapy, sex therapy); Surgery (Laparoscopy, Hysterectomy, Oophorectomy); Pain rehabilitation programs; Acupuncture; Lifestyle modifications (good posture, weight loss, regular exercise, relaxation techniques)
Tests: Pelvic exam; Lab tests (blood and urine); Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI; Laparoscopy
Medications_Drugs: Aspirin; Ibuprofen; Acetaminophen; Prescription pain relievers; Birth control pills;  Antibiotics; Amitriptyline; Nortriptyline; Duloxetine; Venlafaxine; Cyclobenzaprine

Diagnosis: Physical exam including palpation of nose and face; nasal endoscopy; CT or MRI scans; nasal and sinus tissue samples (if treatment ineffective or condition worsens); allergy skin test (if allergies suspected).
Treatments: Nasal corticosteroids; Saline nasal rinses; Corticosteroid shots or pills; Allergy medicines; Aspirin desensitization treatment;  Medicine to treat nasal polyps and chronic sinusitis (dupilumab, omalizumab, or mepolizumab); Antibiotics; Immunotherapy; Endoscopic sinus surgery
Tests: Nasal endoscopy; CT scan; MRI; Nasal and sinus tissue samples; Allergy skin test
Medications_Drugs: fluticasone; budesonide; mometasone; beclomethasone; dupilumab; omalizumab; mepolizumab; Antibiotics (specific antibiotic not specified)

Diagnosis: Definitive diagnosis is only possible post-mortem through brain autopsy showing degeneration of brain tissue and tau protein deposits.  During life, a clinical diagnosis of  traumatic encephalopathy syndrome (TES) may be made based on a cluster of symptoms in individuals with a history of repeated head trauma; however, this is not definitive for CTE. Research is ongoing to develop in-vivo diagnostic tools using neuropsychological tests, specialized MRI, and other biomarkers.
Treatments: There is no specific treatment for CTE;  Cognitive behavioral therapy; Management of depression and anxiety symptoms with medication
Tests: Autopsy; EEG (electroencephalogram); MRI; Positron emission tomography scan; SPECT scan; Neuropsychological tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves several tests to detect antibodies suggestive of Churg-Strauss syndrome, measure eosinophil levels (though elevated levels can be present in other conditions), and identify abnormalities in lungs and sinuses via imaging.  A tissue biopsy from affected areas (lungs, skin, muscle) may be performed to confirm vasculitis.
