Treatments: Corticosteroids; Immunosuppressive drugs; Self-care measures
Tests: Blood tests; X-rays; CT scans; Echocardiograms; Biopsy of affected tissue
Medications_Drugs: Prednisone; Mepolizumab (Nucala); Azathioprine (Azasan, Imuran); Benralizumab (Fasenra); Cyclophosphamide; Methotrexate (Trexall); Rituximab (Rituxan)

Diagnosis: Cirrhosis is often first detected through routine blood tests or checkups.  Confirmation involves a combination of laboratory and imaging tests; a liver biopsy may be performed to assess the severity of liver damage and identify the cause. Blood tests check for liver malfunction (e.g., high bilirubin, elevated enzymes), kidney function (creatinine), blood count, and screen for hepatitis viruses; INR is checked for clotting ability. Imaging tests such as MRE, MRI, CT, and ultrasound may be used to detect liver hardening.
Treatments: Treatment for the underlying cause (e.g., alcohol dependency treatment, weight loss, medications for hepatitis); Medications to slow progression or manage symptoms (e.g., medications for primary biliary cholangitis);  Nutritional support; Liver transplantation (for advanced cases)
Tests: Blood tests; Liver biopsy; MRE; MRI; CT scan; Ultrasound
Medications_Drugs: Acetaminophen (up to 2 grams/day); Antiviral drugs (for hepatitis C)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a review of symptoms, physical exam, skin evaluation on limbs, and tests to check blood flow.  Claudication may go undiagnosed as pain is sometimes considered a normal part of aging.
Treatments: Exercise; Medications; Angioplasty; Vascular surgery; Self-care (including lifestyle changes like quitting smoking, healthy diet, and foot care)
Tests: Pulse measurement in palms or feet; Ankle-brachial index; Segmental blood pressure measurement; Exercise testing; Doppler ultrasound; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or computed tomography (CT) angiography
Medications_Drugs: Cilostazol; Statins; Anti-platelet drugs (including aspirin and clopidogrel)

Diagnosis: Most cases are diagnosed at birth visually; prenatal ultrasound can detect cleft lip from around 13 weeks, sometimes earlier with 3D ultrasound; cleft palate alone is harder to detect via ultrasound.
Treatments: Surgery to repair cleft lip (between 3-6 months); Surgery to repair cleft palate (by 9-18 months, usually around 1 year); Follow-up surgeries (ages 2-late teens); Nasal repair; Ear tube surgery; Orthodontic treatment; Nasoalveolar molding; Prosthetic placement (for cleft palate); Feeding strategies (special bottle nipple/feeder); Speech therapy; Monitoring for ear infections; Hearing aids/devices (if needed); Therapy with a psychologist.
Tests: Prenatal ultrasound; Amniocentesis (if genetic syndrome suspected)

Diagnosis: Clubfoot is often diagnosed soon after birth by visual examination of the foot's shape and position; sometimes X-rays are used to assess severity, but usually not needed; prenatal diagnosis may be possible via ultrasound at around 20 weeks gestation.
Treatments: Stretching and casting (Ponseti method); Stretching, splinting, and taping (French method); Surgery (tibialis anterior tendon transfer; posterior release/posteromedial release);  Shoes and braces.
Tests: Ultrasound; X-ray

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on the description of pain, location, severity, and other symptoms; frequency and duration of headaches are also important; a neurologist makes the diagnosis based on medical history, symptoms, and physical and neurological examination;  tests may be used to rule out other causes.
Treatments: Fast-acting treatments to stop an attack; preventive therapy to stop attacks during a cluster period; surgery (rarely); noninvasive vagus nerve stimulation; nerve block;  lifestyle and home remedies; alternative medicine (melatonin; capsaicin).
Tests: MRI scan; CT scan
Medications_Drugs: Sumatriptan (Imitrex); Zolmitriptan (Zomig); Octreotide (Sandostatin); Lidocaine; Dihydroergotamine; Verapamil (Calan SR, Verelan); Prednisone (Prednisone Intensol, Rayos); Galcanezumab (Emgality); Lithium (Lithobid); Topiramate (Topamax, Qudexy XR)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis depends on severity; severe coarctation is often diagnosed soon after birth or prenatally via ultrasound; mild cases may be diagnosed later in life; diagnosis involves checking blood pressure in arms and legs (higher in arms, lower in legs suggests coarctation);  a weak or delayed pulse in the legs and a heart murmur may be present.
Treatments: Medicines; Heart procedure; Surgery; Balloon angioplasty and stenting; Resection with end-to-end anastomosis; Subclavian flap aortoplasty; Bypass graft repair; Patch aortoplasty
Tests: Echocardiogram; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Chest X-ray; Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Coronary angiogram with cardiac catheterization; CT angiogram
Medications_Drugs: Blood pressure medicines; Medicine to keep the ductus arteriosus open

Diagnosis: Clinical examination; Laboratory testing of a blister sample.
Treatments: Antiviral medication; Cold sore ointment (docosanol);  Home remedies (lip balm, creams, compresses, pain relievers);  Stress reduction techniques.
Tests: Laboratory testing of a blister sample
Medications_Drugs: Acyclovir (Zovirax); Valacyclovir (Valtrex); Famciclovir; Penciclovir (Denavir); docosanol (Abreva); lidocaine; benzocaine; lysine (oral supplement and cream);  rhubarb and sage cream; propolis ointment.

Diagnosis: An ice cube is placed on the skin for five minutes; a raised bump (hive) forming a few minutes after removal indicates cold urticaria (ice cube or cold contact test);  Further testing may be needed if another underlying condition is suspected.
Treatments: Avoiding cold exposure; Home remedies such as over-the-counter antihistamines; Prescription medications; Treatment of underlying conditions if present; Epinephrine autoinjector (for systemic reactions).
Tests: Ice cube test; Other tests may be necessary if an underlying condition is suspected.

Diagnosis: A complete physical exam including measuring height, weight, and head circumference; listening to heart, lung, and abdominal sounds; examining limbs, fingers, toes, eyes, ears, and genitals; assessing reaction to touch or movement; and looking for signs of rash, inflammation, or infection/allergies.  Lab tests, X-rays, and other diagnostic tests are not usually needed but may be used in unclear cases to rule out other conditions.
Treatments: Soothing strategies (pacifier; car ride/stroller; walking/rocking; swaddling; warm bath; tummy rub/back rub; heartbeat audio; soothing sounds; white noise; dimming lights); changes in feeding practices (upright bottle feeding; frequent burping; curved bottle; collapsible bag bottle); dietary changes (formula changes, specifically extensive hydrolysate formula like Similac Alimentum, Nutramigen, Pregestimil; maternal diet changes eliminating common allergens like dairy, eggs, nuts, wheat, or potentially irritating foods like cabbage, onions, caffeinated beverages); parent self-care (taking breaks; using crib for short breaks; expressing feelings; avoiding self-judgment; maintaining parent's health through healthy food, exercise, and adequate sleep; avoiding alcohol and drugs; having a rescue plan); probiotics (Lactobacillus reuteri, though evidence is limited).  Massage therapy and other alternative treatments (herbal teas; herbal remedies like fennel oil; sugar water; gripe water; chiropractic) are mentioned but lack sufficient evidence.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Colon cancer diagnosis involves visual examination of the colon using a colonoscopy, which may include biopsy to obtain tissue samples for lab analysis to determine the presence and characteristics of cancerous cells; blood tests may reveal low red blood cell count suggesting bleeding or track CEA levels to monitor treatment response, but are not used for initial diagnosis; staging involves imaging scans (e.g., CT scan) to determine the extent of cancer spread.
Treatments: Surgery (polypectomy, endoscopic mucosal resection, laparoscopic surgery, partial colectomy, colostomy, lymph node removal); Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy
Tests: Colonoscopy; Biopsy; Blood tests (Complete Blood Count (CBC), Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)); Imaging scans (CT scan, X-ray); Stool DNA test (mentioned but not detailed)

Diagnosis: Colon polyps are diagnosed primarily through screening tests designed to detect polyps before they become cancerous.  Diagnosis relies on visual identification of polyps during procedures such as colonoscopy, flexible sigmoidoscopy, or virtual colonoscopy.  Stool-based tests can indicate the presence of polyps indirectly by detecting blood or tumor markers, prompting further investigation with colonoscopy.  Histopathological examination of polyp tissue samples is crucial for determining the type of polyp and its cancerous potential.
Treatments: Polypectomy; Minimally invasive surgery; Total proctocolectomy
Tests: Colonoscopy; Virtual colonoscopy; Flexible sigmoidoscopy; Stool-based tests (fecal occult blood test; stool DNA test)

Diagnosis: A thorough eye exam using specially designed pictures (colored dots with hidden numbers or shapes) is used to assess color vision deficiency. Difficulty or inability to see some patterns in the dots indicates a color vision deficiency.
Treatments: Stopping medication causing color vision problems; Treating underlying eye disease; Colored filters over eyeglasses or colored contact lenses (to enhance contrast, not improve color vision); Gene replacement techniques (under study for rare retinal disorders).
Tests: Thorough eye exam;  Specialized color vision tests using pictures of colored dots with hidden shapes or numbers.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis relies on physical clues observed by healthcare professionals, information from family/friends regarding events preceding the coma (e.g., vomiting, headaches, loss of consciousness), noticeable symptoms before loss of consciousness, medical history, recent health/behavioral changes, and drug use.  Physical exam includes checking movements, reflexes, response to stimuli, pupil size, breathing patterns, skin for bruises, arousal response to stimuli, reflexive eye movements, and caloric testing (ear irrigation).
Treatments: Maintaining airway, breathing, and circulation; Breathing assistance; Intravenous medications; Treatment addressing underlying cause (e.g., brain swelling, drug overdose, seizures, diabetes, liver disease); Glucose or antibiotics (IV, potentially before test results); Medications to treat drug overdose or seizures.
Tests: Complete blood count; Electrolytes and sugar (glucose) levels; Thyroid, kidney, and liver function tests; Carbon monoxide levels; Drug/alcohol screen; Spinal tap (lumbar puncture); CT scan; MRI; Electroencephalogram (EEG)

Diagnosis: Most common colds are diagnosed based on symptoms; a nasal or throat swab may be used to rule out other illnesses; a chest X-ray may be ordered to rule out lung illness.
Treatments: Rest; Increased fluid intake; Humidifying the air; Saline nasal rinses; Pain relievers; Decongestant nasal sprays (adults, up to 5 days); Cough syrups (use with caution, may not be effective)
Tests: Nasal swab; Throat swab; Chest X-ray
Medications_Drugs: Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Decongestant nasal sprays (specific brand names not listed)

Diagnosis: A healthcare professional generally diagnoses a common cold in babies based on their symptoms.  A chest X-ray or other tests may be used to rule out bacterial infections or other conditions.
Treatments: Supportive care (rest, fluids); Fever reducers for discomfort; Saline nasal drops; Humidifier to moisten air; Nasal suction with a bulb syringe
Tests: Chest X-ray; Other tests (unspecified)

Diagnosis: Visual examination of the wart; Scraping the wart's top layer to check for dark pinpoint dots; Shave biopsy to rule out other skin growths.
Treatments: Salicylic acid; 5-fluorouracil; Candida antigen injection; Cryotherapy (liquid nitrogen freezing); Trichloroacetic acid or other acids; Curettage; Laser treatment (carbon dioxide laser, pulsed-dye laser, photodynamic therapy); Nonprescription salicylic acid products; Liquid nitrogen products (over-the-counter); Duct tape (limited effectiveness).
Tests: Shave biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of CRPS is based on a physical exam and medical history; there's no single definitive test, but diagnostic procedures may provide clues.
Treatments: Medications; Heat therapy; Topical analgesics; Physical or occupational therapy; Mirror therapy; Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS); Biofeedback; Spinal cord stimulation; Intrathecal drug pumps; Acupuncture
Tests: Bone scan; Sweat production tests; X-rays; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
Medications_Drugs: Aspirin; Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Opioid medications; Amitriptyline; Gabapentin; Prednisone; Alendronate; Calcitonin; Sympathetic nerve-blocking medication; Intravenous ketamine; Prazosin; Phenoxybenzamine; Clonidine; Capsaicin cream; Lidocaine cream; Lidocaine patches

Diagnosis: There's no consensus on the timeframe for diagnosis; Complicated grief may be considered when grief intensity remains high months after a loved one's death; Some professionals diagnose it when grief is intense, persistent, and debilitating beyond 12 months; A comprehensive medical and psychological exam is often conducted to differentiate it from major depression and determine the correct diagnosis.
Treatments: Complicated grief therapy (psychotherapy); Other types of psychotherapy to address co-occurring conditions like depression or PTSD
Tests: Comprehensive medical and psychological exam
Medications_Drugs: Antidepressants (may be helpful if clinical depression is also present)

Diagnosis: Evaluation by a healthcare provider or mental health professional involving questions about gambling habits, review of medical information (including medications and physical exam to identify associated health problems), and a mental health assessment focusing on symptoms, thoughts, feelings, and behavior patterns related to gambling.  This may include evaluation for related mental health disorders.
Treatments: Behavioral therapy; Cognitive behavioral therapy; Family therapy; Medications; Self-help groups; Outpatient program; Inpatient program; Residential treatment program; Structured internet-based programs; Telephone visits with a mental health professional; Treatment for substance misuse, depression, anxiety, or other mental health issues.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Compulsive sexual behavior is not a formal diagnosis in the DSM-5-TR but may be diagnosed as an impulse control disorder or behavioral addiction.  The ICD-11 classifies it as an impulse control disorder. Diagnosis relies on a mental health exam assessing sexual thoughts, behaviors, and urges; substance use; relationships; and problems caused by the behavior.  A mental health professional's clinical judgment, considering the severity and impact on life, is crucial, as standard diagnostic guidelines are still under development.
Treatments: Talk therapy (cognitive behavioral therapy, acceptance and commitment therapy, mindfulness-based therapies, psychodynamic psychotherapy); Medications; Self-help groups
Tests: Mental health exam

Diagnosis: Evaluation of symptoms and medical history; neurological exam (checking vision, hearing, strength and sensation, balance, coordination, reflexes); cognitive testing (evaluating memory, concentration, and ability to recall information); brain imaging (CT scan or MRI) may be used for severe symptoms or suspected complications.
Treatments: Physical and mental rest (relative rest, avoiding activities that worsen symptoms); Gradual increase in daily activities as tolerated; Light exercise as tolerated; Rehabilitation for vision, balance, or thinking and memory problems; Pain relief (acetaminophen).
Tests: Neurological exam; Cognitive testing; CT scan; MRI

Diagnosis: Prenatal diagnosis in at-risk fetuses via amniocentesis and chorionic villus sampling; Newborn screening for 21-hydroxylase deficiency; Physical exam, blood and urine tests (checking hormone and electrolyte levels) in children and adults; Genetic testing to confirm diagnosis.  In female infants with atypical genitalia, chromosome testing and pelvic ultrasound are used to assess reproductive organs.
Treatments: Hormone replacement therapy; Corticosteroid medication; Mineralocorticoid medication; Salt supplements; Reconstructive surgery (for some female infants); Mental health support
Tests: Amniocentesis; Chorionic villus sampling; Newborn screening for 21-hydroxylase deficiency; Physical exam; Blood tests; Urine tests; Pelvic ultrasound; Chromosome testing; X-ray; Genetic testing

Diagnosis: Most often diagnosed during routine prenatal ultrasound; occasionally diagnosed after birth or later in childhood if signs and symptoms are mild or absent.  Prenatal ultrasound assesses lung, heart, and organ growth and function.
Treatments: Fetoscopic endoluminal tracheal occlusion (FETO); Vaginal delivery; Cesarean section (C-section); Ex utero intrapartum treatment (EXIT) procedure;  Breathing tube with ventilator support; Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) or extracorporeal life support (ECLS); Surgery to close diaphragmatic hole; Supplemental oxygen; Feeding support
Tests: Prenatal ultrasound; Fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Fetal echocardiogram; Genetic tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis may occur prenatally via fetal ultrasound or postnatally based on symptoms (growth delays, cyanosis, murmurs) and physical examination.  Symptoms vary by age; infants may show difficulty breathing during feeding, younger children may experience nausea and vomiting, while teenagers may present with chest pain, fainting, or palpitations during exercise.
Treatments: Observation and follow-up; Open-heart surgery; Cardiac catheterization procedures; Heart transplant
Tests: Pulse oximetry; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Echocardiogram (including fetal echocardiogram); Chest X-ray; Cardiac catheterization; Heart MRI

Diagnosis: Physical examination including listening to the heart with a stethoscope; review of symptoms, medical and family history.
Treatments: Regular health checkups; Medications; Surgery; Implantable heart devices (pacemaker or implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD)); Catheter-based treatments; Open-heart surgery; Heart transplant
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG); Chest X-ray; Pulse oximetry; Echocardiogram; Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE); Exercise stress tests; Heart MRI; Cardiac catheterization

Diagnosis: Physical examination (including neurological exam); review of symptoms and medical history; blood tests to detect abnormal antibodies and rule out other conditions; electromyography (EMG) to assess muscle and motor neuron health; repetitive nerve stimulation to measure nerve signal transmission and fatigue; genetic testing to identify affected genes; cholinesterase challenge test to assess response to cholinesterase inhibitors; lung function tests; sleep study; muscle biopsy.
Treatments: Medication; Supportive treatments (physical, speech, and occupational therapies; breathing support including CPAP, intubation, and mechanical ventilation; feeding support including enteral nutrition and gastrostomy/jejunostomy; surgical correction of orthopedic deformities); Ongoing care and monitoring
Tests: Blood tests; Electromyography (EMG); Repetitive nerve stimulation; Genetic testing; Cholinesterase challenge test; Lung function tests; Sleep study; Muscle biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Acetazolamide; 3,4-diaminopyridine (amifampridine); Albuterol; Ephedrine; Fluoxetine; Neostigmine; Pyridostigmine

Diagnosis: Conjoined twins are diagnosed using routine ultrasound (7-12 weeks gestation); more detailed ultrasounds and echocardiograms (mid-pregnancy) assess the extent of connection and organ function; MRI provides further detail on connection sites and shared organs.
Treatments: Monitoring during pregnancy; Referral to maternal-fetal medicine specialist and other pediatric specialists (pediatric surgeon; pediatric urologist; pediatric orthopedic surgeon; plastic and reconstructive surgeon; pediatric cardiologist; pediatric cardiovascular surgeon; neonatologist); C-section delivery; Separation surgery (6-12 months post-birth or emergently);  Medical comfort care (nutrition, fluids, touch, pain relief); Pediatric rehabilitation services (physical, occupational, speech therapies).
Tests: Ultrasound; Echocardiogram; MRI

Diagnosis: Physical exam including abdominal palpation, anal and rectal examination, and review of medical history, diet, exercise habits, and bowel movements.  Further testing may be necessary based on initial findings.
Treatments: Diet and lifestyle changes (high-fiber diet, increased water intake, regular exercise, good bowel habits); Laxatives (fiber supplements, osmotics, stimulants, lubricants, stool softeners); Enemas; Suppositories; Prescription medications (Lubiprostone, Linaclotide, Plecanatide, Prucalopride, Methylnaltrexone, Naldemedine, Naloxegol); Pelvic muscle training (biofeedback); Surgery
Tests: Blood tests; Endoscopy (colonoscopy; sigmoidoscopy); X-ray; CT scan; MRI; Colorectal transit study (radiopaque marker study; scintigraphy); Anorectal manometry; Balloon expulsion test; Defecography
Medications_Drugs: psyllium; calcium polycarbophil; methylcellulose; oral magnesium hydroxide; magnesium citrate; lactulose; polyethylene glycol; bisacodyl; sennosides; mineral oil; docusate sodium; docusate calcium; Lubiprostone; Linaclotide; Plecanatide; Prucalopride; Methylnaltrexone; Naldemedine; Naloxegol

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves gathering a complete medical history (including diet and physical activity), conducting a physical exam (including rectal examination for impacted stool), and potentially further testing depending on severity.
Treatments: Over-the-counter fiber supplements; Stool softeners; Glycerin suppositories; Laxatives; Enema; Hospital enema; Massage; Acupuncture
Tests: Abdominal X-ray; Anorectal manometry or motility test; Barium enema X-ray; Rectal biopsy; Transit study or marker study; Blood tests (e.g., thyroid panel)
Medications_Drugs: Metamucil; Citrucel; polyethylene glycol (GlycoLax, MiraLax, others); mineral oil

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on symptoms, medical and family history, exposure to lung irritants, physical exam (including lung auscultation), and diagnostic tests such as pulmonary function tests (spirometry, lung volume test, lung diffusion test), imaging (chest X-ray, CT scan), and blood tests (arterial blood gas analysis, testing for AAT deficiency).  Many cases are not diagnosed until advanced.
Treatments: Quitting smoking; Medication; Oxygen therapy (implied by pulse oximetry and six-minute walk test); Possibly surgery (depending on CT scan results)
Tests: Spirometry; Lung volume test; Lung diffusion test; Pulse oximetry; Six-minute walking test; Exercise stress test; Chest X-ray; CT scan; Arterial blood gas analysis; Blood tests (to rule out other conditions or find cause of symptoms)
Medications_Drugs: Albuterol (ProAir, Ventolin, Proventil); Ipratropium (Atrovent); Levalbuterol (Xopenex); Ipratropium bromide-albuterol (Combivent Respimat); Inhaled corticosteroids; Aclidinium bromide-formoterol fumarate (Duaklir Pressair); Glycopyrrolate-formoterol fumarate (Bevespi Aerosphere); Tiotropium bromide-olodaterol (Stiolto Respimat); Umeclidinium-vilanterol (Anoro Ellipta); Budesonide-glycopyrrolate-formoterol fumarate (Breztri Aerosphere); Fluticasone-vilanterol (Breo Ellipta); Fluticasone furoate-umeclidinium-vilanterol (Trelegy Ellipta); Budesonide-formoterol (Breyna, Symbicort); Fluticasone propionate-salmeterol (Advair, AirDuo RespiClick, Wixela Inhub); Oral corticosteroids; Roflumilast (Daliresp); Theophylline (Elixophyllin, Theo-24, Theochron); Nicotine replacement products (mentioned, but specific products not listed); Antibiotics

Diagnosis: Physical examination of the feet to rule out other conditions like warts and cysts; paring away a bit of hardened skin to differentiate from warts (bleeding or black points indicate a wart).
Treatments: Avoiding repetitive actions; wearing properly fitting shoes; using protective pads; trimming excess skin by a healthcare provider; medicated patches containing 40% salicylic acid; nonprescription salicylic acid gel or liquid; custom-made padded shoe inserts (orthotics); surgery to correct bone alignment.
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: Salicylic acid (Clear Away, MediPlast, others); salicylic acid gel (Compound W, Keralyt); salicylic acid liquid (Compound W, Duofilm).

Diagnosis: Examination by a healthcare professional including review of medical history and symptoms;  Further tests may be conducted if symptoms such as chest pain or shortness of breath are present.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (e.g., not smoking, healthy diet, exercise); Medications; Heart procedure or heart surgery; Coronary artery stent placement; Coronary artery bypass surgery.
Tests: Blood tests (including cholesterol and high-sensitivity C-reactive protein); Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Echocardiogram; Exercise stress test; Nuclear stress test; Heart CT scan; Cardiac catheterization and angiogram.
Medications_Drugs: Statins; Niacin; Fibrates; Bile acid sequestrants; Aspirin; Beta blockers; Calcium channel blockers; Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors; Angiotensin 2 receptor blockers (ARBs); Nitroglycerin; Ranolazine.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of COVID-19 is primarily done through molecular tests (PCR or NAAT tests) which detect the virus's genetic material, or antigen tests which detect viral proteins.  A positive PCR test virtually confirms COVID-19; a negative PCR test strongly suggests its absence.  A negative antigen test should be repeated after 48 hours for greater accuracy.  Symptoms and recent exposure to the virus are also considered.
Treatments: Rest; Fluids; Management of symptoms with over-the-counter medications;  Antiviral medications (Paxlovid, remdesivir, molnupiravir) for high-risk individuals; Hospitalization for severe cases; Oxygen therapy; Mechanical ventilation; ECMO;  Convalescent plasma (for weakened immune systems); Baricitinib; Tocilizumab; Dexamethasone.
Tests: PCR test (NAAT test); Antigen test (rapid COVID-19 test)
Medications_Drugs: Nirmatrelvir and ritonavir (Paxlovid); Remdesivir (Veklury); Molnupiravir (Lagevrio); Ibuprofen; Acetaminophen; Baricitinib (Olumiant); Tocilizumab (Actemra); Dexamethasone

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on symptoms, physical examination, and testing to rule out other conditions with similar symptoms (progressive supranuclear palsy, Alzheimer's disease, Pick's disease, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease).  Imaging tests (MRI, CT scans) may be used to rule out other conditions; PET scans can identify brain changes related to corticobasal degeneration, but more research is needed.  Testing for amyloid and tau proteins in blood or cerebrospinal fluid may help determine if Alzheimer's disease is the cause.
Treatments: Occupational therapy; Physical therapy; Speech therapy; Dietary management (dietitian consultation); Walking devices; Medications to manage symptoms (specific medications not listed)
Tests: MRI; CT scan; PET scan; Blood tests for amyloid and tau proteins; Cerebrospinal fluid analysis for amyloid and tau proteins

Diagnosis: Physical exam to assess breastbone tenderness and swelling; movement of rib cage and arms to trigger symptoms; electrocardiogram and chest X-ray to rule out other conditions; no specific laboratory or imaging test confirms costochondritis.
Treatments: Pain relief; Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs; Narcotics; Tricyclic antidepressants; Anti-seizure drugs; Stretching exercises; Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS); Corticosteroid injection into painful joint; Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Topical pain relievers; Heat or ice; Rest.
Tests: Electrocardiogram; Chest X-ray
Medications_Drugs: Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Tramadol; Amitriptyline; Gabapentin; Acetaminophen

Diagnosis: Brain-imaging tests such as MRI or CT scans are used to rule out other causes;  a lumbar puncture (spinal tap) may be rarely recommended to analyze cerebrospinal fluid.  Diagnosis differentiates between primary and secondary cough headaches based on response to treatment and the presence of an underlying condition.
Treatments: For primary cough headaches, daily preventative medication may be recommended; For secondary cough headaches, surgery to address the underlying problem is often needed; Preventative medications are usually ineffective for secondary cough headaches.
Tests: MRI; CT scan; Lumbar puncture (spinal tap)
Medications_Drugs: Indomethacin (Indocin); Propranolol (Inderal LA); Acetazolamide; methysergide; naproxen sodium (Aleve); methylergonovine; intravenous dihydroergotamine (D.H.E. 45); phenelzine (Nardil)

Diagnosis: Visual examination of the baby's scalp by a healthcare professional.
Treatments: Home care tips (gentle rubbing, daily washing with baby shampoo, loosening scales with brush or comb, using petroleum jelly or mineral oil); low-potency hydrocortisone cream; shampoo with 2% antifungal ketoconazole; over-the-counter cortisone or antifungal creams (only after consulting a doctor).
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a medical history review and symptom discussion.  A neurological exam assesses vision, hearing, balance, coordination, reflexes, and growth/development to pinpoint affected brain areas. Blood tests detect hormonal changes indicating pituitary gland involvement. Imaging tests (X-rays, CTs, MRIs) visualize tumor size and location.  Additional tests may be needed depending on the situation.
Treatments: Surgery (open craniotomy or minimally invasive transsphenoidal procedure); Radiation therapy (external beam, including proton beam therapy and IMRT; stereotactic radiosurgery; brachytherapy); Chemotherapy (intra-tumoral injection); Targeted therapy (for papillary craniopharyngioma with BRAF gene mutation)
Tests: Neurological exam; Blood tests; X-rays; CT scans; MRIs

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing suture ridges and facial asymmetry; Imaging studies such as CT scan, MRI, or cranial ultrasound to visualize fused sutures; Laser scan and photographs for precise skull measurements; Genetic testing if an underlying genetic syndrome is suspected.
Treatments: Specially molded helmet; Surgery (endoscopic or open); Helmet therapy post-minimally invasive surgery
Tests: Physical exam; CT scan; MRI; Cranial ultrasound; Laser scan; Photographs; Genetic testing

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical and personal history, neurological exam (assessing muscle twitching, spasms, reflex changes, coordination problems, vision problems, blindness), and diagnostic tests.  A brain biopsy or autopsy is the gold standard for confirmation.  A clinical diagnosis can often be made before death.
Treatments: No effective treatment exists; Focus is on symptom relief and comfort care.
Tests: Electroencephalogram (EEG); Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Spinal fluid tests (lumbar puncture); Real-time quaking-induced conversion (RT-QuIC)

Diagnosis: Crohn's disease is diagnosed by ruling out other causes of symptoms and using a combination of tests.  There is no single diagnostic test; diagnosis is based on clinical presentation and findings from various tests.  The presence of granulomas on biopsy may be suggestive.
Treatments: Anti-inflammatory medicines; Immune system suppressors; Biologics; JAK inhibitors; Antibiotics; Other symptom-relieving medications
Tests: Blood tests; Stool studies; Colonoscopy with biopsy; CT scan; CT enterography; MRI; MR enterography; Capsule endoscopy; Barium enema; Fecal occult blood test; Flexible sigmoidoscopy
Medications_Drugs: Prednisone; Budesonide; Sulfasalazine; Mesalamine; Azathioprine; Mercaptopurine; Methotrexate; Infliximab; Adalimumab; Certolizumab pegol; Ustekinumab; Vedolizumab; Risankizumab; Upadacitinib; Ciprofloxacin; Metronidazole

Diagnosis: Croup is usually diagnosed by a healthcare provider observing the child's breathing, listening to the child's chest with a stethoscope, and examining the child's throat; X-rays or other tests may be used to rule out other illnesses.
Treatments: Comfort measures (holding the child, singing lullabies, offering a favorite blanket or toy, speaking in a soothing voice, ensuring adequate fluid intake);  Corticosteroid (e.g., dexamethasone); Epinephrine (inhaled via nebulizer); Hospitalization for severe cases; Humidified or cool air; Upright positioning; Fever reducer (acetaminophen or ibuprofen).
Tests: X-ray

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a blood test where the sample is kept at body temperature (98.6°F/37°C), then cooled before testing; other blood and urine tests may be used to determine the underlying cause.
Treatments: Watchful waiting (for asymptomatic cases); Medications to suppress the immune system or treat viral infections; Plasma exchange (for severe symptoms)
Tests: Blood test; Urine test

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of spinal CSF leak involves medical history review, physical exam, and imaging studies such as MRI with gadolinium, radioisotope cisternography, and myelography.  A spinal tap (lumbar puncture) may be used to measure CSF pressure and is often part of other tests. Cranial CSF leak diagnosis begins with medical history, physical exam (including nasal and ear evaluation), and may involve MRI with gadolinium, tympanometry, and CT cisternography (considered the gold standard for locating cranial leaks). High-resolution CT may also be used.  Fluid from nasal discharge or ear drainage may be sent for testing.
Treatments: Bed rest; Epidural blood patch; Fibrin sealant; Surgery; Trans-venous embolization; Elevating the head of the bed; Stool softeners
Tests: MRI with gadolinium; Radioisotope cisternography; Myelography; Spinal tap (lumbar puncture); Tympanometry; CT cisternography; High-resolution CT

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves evaluating medication use (glucocorticoids); physical exam for characteristic signs (round face, neck hump, thin skin, stretch marks); and hormone level measurements in urine and blood (24-hour urine collection may be required); saliva cortisol level testing; imaging (CT or MRI scans of pituitary and adrenal glands); and potentially inferior petrosal sinus sampling to pinpoint ACTH-producing tumor location.  Differential diagnosis considers conditions with similar symptoms such as polycystic ovary syndrome, depression, eating disorders, and alcoholism.
Treatments: Reducing glucocorticoid use; Surgery (tumor removal, adrenalectomy); Radiation therapy; Medications
Tests: Urine tests; Blood tests; Saliva test; CT scan; MRI scan; Inferior petrosal sinus sampling
Medications_Drugs: ketoconazole; osilodrostat (Isturisa); mitotane (Lysodren); levoketoconazole (Recorlev); metyrapone (Metopirone); mifepristone (Korlym, Mifeprex); pasireotide (Signifor); Cortisol replacement medicine; Aldosterone replacement medicine

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam to check the skin for signs of lymphoma; a skin biopsy to test a tissue sample for lymphoma cells; blood tests to look for lymphoma cells; a bone marrow biopsy to check for lymphoma cells; and imaging tests (CT scans and PET scans) to assess the condition.
Treatments: Radiation therapy; Surgery to remove the cancer; Injecting medicine into the cancer; Chemotherapy (applied to skin or given intravenously); Targeted therapy (injected into the cancer or given intravenously)
Tests: Physical exam; Skin biopsy; Blood tests; Bone marrow biopsy; CT scan; PET scan
Medications_Drugs: Steroids; Hydroxyurea (mentioned in a discussion forum, not explicitly as a treatment for cutaneous B-cell lymphoma in the main article); Zanubrutinib (mentioned in a discussion forum, not explicitly as a treatment for cutaneous B-cell lymphoma in the main article)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam checking for scaly areas, growths, and swollen lymph nodes; blood tests (complete blood count) may reveal cancer cells (more common in Sezary syndrome); skin biopsies (punch or excisional) are crucial but may not always detect cancer cells, potentially requiring multiple biopsies; imaging tests (CT scan, PET scan) may be used if spread is suspected; diagnosis can be challenging due to overlapping symptoms with other skin conditions, and early tests may be negative.
Treatments: Skin creams and ointments; Light therapy; Photodynamic therapy; Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy; Bone marrow transplant
Tests: Physical exam; Complete blood count; Skin biopsy (punch biopsy; excisional biopsy); CT scan; PET scan; MRI
Medications_Drugs: Steroid medicines; Chemotherapy medicines (specific names not provided);  Chemotherapy (specific names not provided); Targeted therapy medicines (specific names not provided); Immunotherapy medicines (specific names not provided)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is challenging due to the lack of a specific test; it involves reviewing medical history, conducting a physical exam, and assessing symptom patterns;  ruling out other conditions is crucial; imaging studies (endoscopy, ultrasound, CT scan) may be used to check for digestive issues; motility tests assess food movement; laboratory tests check for thyroid problems and metabolic conditions.
Treatments: Controlling signs and symptoms during episodes; intravenous (IV) fluids (for dehydration); anti-nausea drugs; pain-relieving medications; medications that suppress stomach acid; antidepressants; anti-seizure medications; medications for migraines; biofeedback; cognitive behavioral therapy; lifestyle changes (adequate sleep, fluid intake, dietary adjustments, stress reduction).
Tests: Endoscopy; Ultrasound; Computed tomography (CT) scan; Motility tests; Laboratory tests
Medications_Drugs: Anti-nausea drugs; Pain-relieving medications; Medications that suppress stomach acid; Antidepressants; Anti-seizure medications; Medications for migraines; Coenzyme Q10; L-carnitine; Riboflavin

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam and lab tests to rule out medical causes; a psychological evaluation including discussions about thoughts, feelings, and behaviors, possibly with self-assessment questionnaires and input from family/friends; mood charting to track moods, sleep, and other relevant factors; application of DSM-5 criteria:  many periods of elevated mood (hypomanic symptoms) and depressive symptoms for at least two years (one year for children and teenagers), with these highs and lows occurring during at least half that time; periods of stable moods lasting less than two months; symptoms significantly impacting social, work, school, or other important areas; symptoms not meeting criteria for bipolar disorder, major depression, or other mental disorders; symptoms not caused by substance use or medical condition.
Treatments: Medications; psychotherapy (including CBT and IPSRT); lifestyle modifications (regular exercise, sufficient sleep, avoiding alcohol and drugs); addressing warning signs early;  family/friend involvement in monitoring symptoms.
Tests: Physical exam; lab tests; psychological evaluation; mood charting

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves newborn screening (IRT blood test); a sweat test (measuring chloride levels in sweat) is performed to confirm positive newborn screens; genetic testing identifies specific gene mutations;  clinical evaluation considers symptoms such as repeated bouts of inflamed pancreas, nasal polyps, chronic sinus infections, lung infections, bronchiectasis, or male infertility.
Treatments: Preventing and controlling lung infections; Removing and loosening lung mucus; Treating and preventing intestinal blockage; Ensuring adequate nutrition;  managing diabetes or liver disease as needed.
Tests: Newborn screening (IRT blood test); Sweat test; Genetic testing
Medications_Drugs: Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) modulators; Antibiotics; Anti-inflammatory medicines; Hypertonic saline; Bronchodilators; Pancreatic enzyme capsules; Stool softeners; Acid-reducing medicines.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on symptoms and medical history; urine analysis may be performed to check for bacteria, blood, or pus; urine culture may be done to identify the type of bacteria; imaging (X-ray or ultrasound) may be used to rule out other causes of bladder inflammation.
Treatments: Antibiotics (for bacterial cystitis); Vaginal estrogen cream (for post-menopausal women with cystitis); Oral medication; Intravesical medication; Nerve stimulation; Surgery (last resort for interstitial cystitis); Avoiding irritating substances (bubble bath, spermicide); Increased fluid intake; Pain management medication (for cystitis due to chemotherapy or radiation).
Tests: Urine analysis; Urine culture; X-ray; Ultrasound; Cystoscopy

Diagnosis: CMV infection is diagnosed through lab tests detecting the virus in blood, saliva, urine, or tissue samples.  During pregnancy, testing may be recommended based on exposure, symptoms (fever, headache, fatigue, sore throat, swollen glands), ultrasound findings suggesting fetal infection, or a weakened immune system.  Antibody blood tests can detect past infections.  In newborns suspected of congenital CMV, testing occurs within three weeks of birth, followed by tests assessing organ health (liver, kidneys).  Testing is also important for those with weakened immune systems (HIV, AIDS, transplant recipients).
Treatments: Medications; Speech therapy; Occupational therapy; Assistive devices (hearing aids)
Tests: Blood tests; Saliva tests; Urine tests; Tissue sample tests; Ultrasound imaging; Amniocentesis

Diagnosis: Visual examination of the hair and scalp by a doctor.
Treatments: Regular cleansing with a gentle shampoo; Medicated dandruff shampoo; Moisturizing conditioner;  Alternating between two types of dandruff shampoos; Prescription-strength shampoo; Steroid lotion; Lifestyle modifications (stress management, healthy diet, scalp care routine, limited sun exposure, limiting hair styling products).
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: Pyrithione zinc (e.g., DermaZinc, Head & Shoulders); Coal tar (e.g., Neutrogena T/Gel, Scalp 18 Coal Tar Shampoo); Salicylic acid (e.g., Jason Dandruff Relief Treatment Shampoo, Baker P&S); Selenium sulfide (e.g., Head & Shoulders Intensive, Selsun Blue); Ketoconazole (e.g., Nizoral Anti-Dandruff); Fluocinolone (e.g., Capex, Derma-Smoothe/FS); Tea tree oil (although evidence for its effectiveness is lacking).

Diagnosis: Physical examination to assess pain with pressure on the thumb side of the wrist; Finkelstein test (pain with thumb flexion across palm, finger flexion over thumb, and wrist flexion towards little finger).
Treatments: Immobilization with splint or brace; avoidance of repetitive thumb movements and pinching; ice application; physical therapy; corticosteroid injections; surgery (for serious cases)
Tests: Finkelstein test; X-rays (generally not needed)

Diagnosis: Physical exam checking for leg swelling, tenderness, or skin color changes;  D-dimer blood test to rule out PE; Duplex ultrasound as the standard test to visualize blood flow in veins; Venography (rarely used, invasive X-ray with dye); MRI scan for DVT in abdominal veins.
Treatments: Blood thinners (anticoagulants); Clot busters (thrombolytics); Vena cava filter placement; Support stockings (compression stockings)
Tests: D-dimer blood test; Duplex ultrasound; Venography; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is often made based on symptoms;  For children, weight change may be used; Blood tests and urinalysis may be used to confirm diagnosis and assess severity.
Treatments: Fluid replacement; Electrolyte replacement; For infants and children with dehydration from diarrhea, vomiting, or fever: Pedialyte or Smart Water (start with small amounts and increase as tolerated); For older children: watered-down sports drinks (1:1 ratio of sports drink to water); For adults with mild to moderate dehydration: increased water or other liquid intake; For severe dehydration: intravenous fluids and salts.
Tests: Blood tests; Urinalysis

Diagnosis: Physical exam and medical history; further tests may be needed depending on findings, potentially involving specialists.
Treatments: Medication adjustment or addition; Psychological counseling; Addressing alcohol or illicit drug use
Tests: Blood tests; Urinalysis

Diagnosis: Review of family and medical history; Physical exam;  May require additional tests to rule out other sleep disorders.
Treatments: Improving sleep habits (sleep hygiene: regular sleep schedule, avoiding naps, caffeine, alcohol, and tobacco before bed; exercising at least two hours before bed; avoiding stimulating activities before bed; using bedroom only for sleep and sex); Melatonin supplements; Light therapy; Chronotherapy
Tests: Actigraphy; Sleep diary; Sleep study (polysomnography)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical history (recent changes like infections, new medications, injuries, pain, substance use); mental status review (testing awareness, attention, thinking, potentially using tests or screenings, and information from family); physical and neurological exams (checking for health problems, disease, vision, balance, coordination, reflexes, to rule out stroke or other diseases); and blood, urine, and other tests; brain imaging tests may be used if other information is insufficient.
Treatments: Addressing underlying causes (stopping medications, treating infections, correcting imbalances); supportive care (protecting airway, providing fluids/nutrition, assisting movement, pain treatment, managing bladder control, avoiding restraints/tubes, minimizing environmental/caregiver changes, involving family); medications to control pain, agitation, confusion, distrust, fear, or hallucinations (only when symptoms severely impair examination, treatment, or safety, and don't improve with other treatments).
Tests: Medical history; Mental status review; Physical exam; Neurological exam; Blood tests; Urine tests; Brain-imaging tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves recognizing the pattern of skill and function loss, assessing remaining abilities, reviewing medical history and symptoms, conducting a physical exam, and potentially involving a person close to the patient.  Cognitive and neuropsychological tests evaluate thinking abilities; neurological evaluation assesses movement, balance, senses, and reflexes.  Biomarkers, such as amyloid and tau protein, can aid in Alzheimer's diagnosis.  A psychiatric exam helps rule out other mental health conditions.  No single test definitively diagnoses dementia; multiple tests are typically needed.
Treatments: Medications; Occupational therapy; Environmental modifications (reducing clutter and noise, using monitoring systems);  Simpler tasks and structured routines;  Exercise; Engaging in enjoyable activities; Establishing a nighttime routine;  Lecanemab-irmb (Leqembi); Donanemab-azbt (Kisunla)
Tests: Cognitive and neuropsychological tests; Neurological evaluation; CT scan; MRI; PET scan; Blood tests; Spinal fluid examination
Medications_Drugs: Donepezil (Aricept, Adlarity); Rivastigmine (Exelon); Galantamine (Zunveyl); Memantine (Namenda); Lecanemab-irmb (Leqembi); Donanemab-azbt (Kisunla)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is difficult due to overlapping symptoms with other diseases (chikungunya, Zika virus, malaria, typhoid fever).  Diagnosis involves reviewing medical and travel history (including details of international trips and mosquito exposure); a blood test to detect dengue viruses is used for confirmation.
Treatments: Plenty of fluids; supportive care in a hospital (for severe cases); intravenous (IV) fluid and electrolyte replacement (for severe cases); blood pressure monitoring (for severe cases); blood transfusion (for severe cases)
Tests: Blood test

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a physical exam to rule out physical health problems, medications, or substance use; lab tests to identify underlying medical issues; and a mental health evaluation assessing symptoms, thoughts, feelings, and behavior patterns to differentiate depersonalization-derealization disorder from other mental health conditions.
Treatments: Talk therapy (cognitive behavioral therapy and psychodynamic therapy)
Tests: Physical exam; Lab tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a physical exam, questions about health history, potentially lab tests (e.g., complete blood count, thyroid function tests), and a psychiatric evaluation including symptom assessment, thoughts, feelings, and behavior patterns, often using DSM-5 criteria.
Treatments: Medications; Psychotherapy; Hospital stay (for severe depression); Outpatient treatment program
Tests: Complete blood count; Thyroid function tests
Medications_Drugs: citalopram (Celexa); escitalopram (Lexapro); fluoxetine (Prozac); paroxetine (Paxil, Pexeva); sertraline (Zoloft); vilazodone (Viibryd); duloxetine (Cymbalta); venlafaxine (Effexor XR); desvenlafaxine (Pristiq, Khedezla); levomilnacipran (Fetzima); bupropion (Wellbutrin XL, Wellbutrin SR, Aplenzin, Forfivo XL); mirtazapine (Remeron); nefazodone; trazodone; vortioxetine (Trintellix); imipramine (Tofranil); nortriptyline (Pamelor); amitriptyline; doxepin; trimipramine (Surmontil); desipramine (Norpramin); protriptyline (Vivactil); tranylcypromine (Parnate); phenelzine (Nardil); isocarboxazid (Marplan); selegiline (Emsam); mood stabilizers; antipsychotics; anti-anxiety medications; stimulant medications

Diagnosis: Physical examination of the skin; review of symptoms and medical history; skin biopsy to rule out other conditions; patch testing to identify allergens.
Treatments: Prescription-strength corticosteroid cream, gel, or ointment; Cream or ointment with a calcineurin inhibitor; Light therapy (phototherapy); Oral corticosteroids; Injectable biologic dupilumab; Wet dressings;  Anti-itch cream (e.g., 1% hydrocortisone cream); Moisturizer; Cool, wet cloth compresses; Oatmeal baths; Medicated shampoos (e.g., selenium sulfide, zinc pyrithione, coal tar, ketoconazole); Bleach baths; Vinegar baths.
Tests: Skin biopsy; Patch test
Medications_Drugs: Corticosteroid cream, gel, or ointment; Calcineurin inhibitor; Oral corticosteroids; Dupilumab; 1% hydrocortisone cream;  Selenium sulfide; Zinc pyrithione; Coal tar; Ketoconazole.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a skin exam to look for signs of skin cancer and a skin biopsy to test for cancer cells; imaging tests like MRI may be used to determine the extent of the cancer.
Treatments: Surgery to remove the cancer; Mohs surgery; Radiation therapy; Targeted therapy; Clinical trials
Tests: Skin exam; Skin biopsy; MRI

Diagnosis: A raised line or welt appears on the skin within minutes after a tongue depressor is drawn across the arm or back.
Treatments: Often no treatment is needed; Mild oral antihistamines may be suggested for severe or bothersome symptoms.
Tests: Skin stroking test
Medications_Drugs: fexofenadine (Allegra); loratadine (Alavert, Claritin, others); cetirizine; doxepin

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of dermatomyositis involves evaluating symptoms and conducting tests to detect muscle damage and autoantibodies.  Elevated muscle enzymes in blood tests, along with characteristic skin findings, suggest the condition.  Further confirmation may involve electromyography, MRI, and skin or muscle biopsies.
Treatments: Medications; Physical therapy; Speech therapy; Dietetic assessment; Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg); Surgery
Tests: Blood analysis; Chest X-ray; Electromyography; MRI; Skin biopsy; Muscle biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Prednisone; Azathioprine; Methotrexate; Mycophenolate mofetil; Rituximab; Hydroxychloroquine

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam; imaging tests such as CT and MRI scans to visualize the tumor; and a biopsy to definitively identify the tumor cells and assess their aggressiveness.
Treatments: Monitoring tumor growth; Surgery (complete or partial tumor removal); Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Anti-inflammatory drugs; Hormone therapies; Targeted therapies
Tests: Physical exam; CT scan; MRI; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves tissue biopsy (obtained surgically or via needle) sent to a lab for testing to identify cancer presence and specific DNA changes;  Imaging tests (ultrasound, CT, MRI, PET) determine cancer size and location; Results help differentiate from similar cancers and inform treatment selection.
Treatments: Surgery (to remove all or as much cancer as possible); Chemotherapy (whole body or hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC) for abdominal cancers); Radiation therapy (for abdominal cancers or to manage symptoms in spread cancers); Targeted drug therapy (if cancer recurs or spreads)
Tests: Biopsy; Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI; PET scan

Diagnosis: Physical exam involving visual inspection of the nose with a bright light and sometimes a nasal speculum;  Use of a long, thin scope with a light (if needed) to visualize further into the nasal passages.
Treatments: Surgery (septoplasty);  Medication management of symptoms (decongestants; antihistamines; nasal steroid sprays); Rhinoplasty (sometimes performed concurrently with septoplasty)
Tests: Physical exam

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of type 1 diabetes involves testing for the presence of autoantibodies and ketones in urine;  an A1C level of 6.5% or higher on two separate tests; a random blood sugar level of 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) or higher; a fasting blood sugar level of 126 mg/dL (7 mmol/L) or higher on two separate tests; or a glucose tolerance test result of more than 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) after two hours.  Symptoms often start suddenly.  For type 2 diabetes and prediabetes, screening guidelines consider BMI, age, risk factors (high blood pressure, abnormal cholesterol, inactivity, PCOS, family history, heart disease), and gestational diabetes history.
Treatments: Automated insulin delivery system (continuous glucose monitor, insulin pump, computer algorithm); Pancreas transplantation; Islet transplantation; Immune suppressive medication (research setting); Healthy diet; Maintaining a healthy weight; Regular physical activity; Blood sugar monitoring; Insulin; Oral drugs (for type 2 diabetes)
Tests: A1C test; Random blood sugar test; Fasting blood sugar test; Glucose tolerance test; Urine test for ketones; Autoantibody test

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves assessing symptoms (excessive thirst and urination), evaluating urine concentration, and identifying the type of diabetes insipidus (central, nephrogenic, gestational, or primary polydipsia) through tests that measure ADH levels and kidney response to ADH.  A water deprivation test, measuring changes in body weight, urine output, and urine/blood concentration, is key; blood tests check sodium, potassium, and calcium levels.  Imaging (MRI) may identify pituitary or hypothalamic issues; genetic testing may be considered in families with a history of the condition.
Treatments: Increased water intake; Treatment of underlying disorders (e.g., pituitary tumors); Desmopressin (DDAVP, Nocdurna) for central and gestational DI; Low-salt diet for nephrogenic DI; Hydrochlorothiazide (Microzide) for nephrogenic DI; Discontinuing causative medications (if applicable); Reducing fluid intake for primary polydipsia; Treatment of any associated mental illness.
Tests: Water deprivation test; Urine test; Blood tests (sodium, potassium, calcium levels); Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Genetic testing

Diagnosis: Physical exam; review of medical history; blood tests to measure blood sugar level, ketone level, and levels of nitrogen, creatinine, potassium, and sodium in the blood.  A medical identification bracelet or necklace is helpful if the patient has diabetes.
Treatments: Intravenous fluids; Potassium, sodium, or phosphate supplements; Insulin; Glucagon injection; Intravenous dextrose.
Tests: Blood sugar level test; Ketone level test; Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) test; Creatinine test; Blood test for potassium, sodium, and nitrogen levels.

Diagnosis: Symptoms of low blood sugar are checked with a blood glucose meter; hypoglycemia is often defined as blood sugar below 70 mg/dL or 3.9 mmol/L, but the specific range may vary by individual.
Treatments: Eat or drink carbohydrates (glucose tablets, glucose gel, hard candy, jelly beans, fruit juice, regular soda, sugar, corn syrup, honey); Recheck blood sugar after 15 minutes and repeat treatment if necessary; Have a snack or meal to prevent further drops;  Glucagon injection (emergency treatment for severe hypoglycemia); Continuous glucose monitor (for frequent or severe hypoglycemia); Insulin dose adjustment as needed
Tests: Blood glucose meter

Diagnosis: Physical exam and blood tests (measuring blood sugar level, ketone level, and blood acidity);  Additional tests may be needed to identify the underlying cause and check for complications.
Treatments: Fluids (oral or IV); Electrolyte replacement (IV); Insulin therapy (IV)
Tests: Blood tests; Urinalysis; Chest X-ray; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG)

Diagnosis: Diabetic nephropathy is usually diagnosed during routine diabetes management testing.  Key tests include urinary albumin test, albumin/creatinine ratio, and glomerular filtration rate (GFR).  A kidney biopsy may be used for confirmation.  Yearly testing is recommended for type 2 diabetics and type 1 diabetics after 5 years.
Treatments: Control of diabetes and high blood pressure through diet, lifestyle changes, exercise, and medication;  Kidney transplant; Kidney dialysis (hemodialysis and peritoneal dialysis); Symptom management for end-stage kidney disease;  Weight-loss surgery (if needed)
Tests: Urinary albumin test; Albumin/creatinine ratio; Glomerular filtration rate (GFR); X-rays; Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI scan; Kidney biopsy
Medications_Drugs: ACE inhibitors; Angiotensin 2 receptor blockers (ARBs); Insulin; Metformin; Glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists; SGLT2 inhibitors; Statins; Finerenone (Kerendia); Aspirin

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing muscle strength, tone, reflexes, and sensitivity to touch, pain, temperature, and vibration;  Filament testing; Sensory testing; Nerve conduction testing; Electromyography; Autonomic testing.
Treatments: Maintain blood sugar within target range; Control blood pressure; Maintain healthy weight; Regular physical activity;  Prescription medications for pain relief.
Tests: Filament testing; Sensory testing; Nerve conduction testing; Electromyography; Autonomic testing
Medications_Drugs: Pregabalin (Lyrica); Gabapentin (Gralise, Neurontin); Amitriptyline; Nortriptyline (Pamelor); Desipramine (Norpramin); Duloxetine (Cymbalta); Venlafaxine (Effexor XR); Acetaminophen (Tylenol, others)

Diagnosis: Comprehensive dilated eye exam to visualize abnormalities inside and outside the eye.
Treatments: Close monitoring for mild/moderate nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy; Injection of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) inhibitors into the vitreous; Photocoagulation (focal or panretinal); Vitrectomy
Tests: Dilated eye exam; Fluorescein angiography; Optical coherence tomography (OCT)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of diaper rash is primarily based on clinical examination of the affected area;  Visual inspection for redness, inflammation, and possible secondary infections (fungal or bacterial) are key diagnostic criteria. If home treatment fails to resolve the rash, a doctor's consultation is recommended to rule out complications or alternative diagnoses.
Treatments: Keeping the diaper area clean and dry; Applying a barrier cream, paste, or ointment (zinc oxide or petroleum jelly); Using a mild hydrocortisone cream (0.5% to 1%) for a limited duration; Applying antifungal cream for fungal infections; Oral antibiotic medication for bacterial infections; Increasing airflow to the diaper area; Daily bathing with mild, fragrance-free soap; Avoiding irritating products;  Consultation with a dermatologist if the rash persists.
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: 0.5% to 1% hydrocortisone cream; Antifungal cream (e.g., Lotrimin); Oral antibiotics;  Products containing zinc oxide or petroleum jelly (e.g., A + D, Balmex, Desitin, Triple Paste)

Diagnosis: Medical history review; Medication review; Physical exam; Evaluation of symptom severity and duration.  Further testing may be done depending on the findings of these initial steps.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (increased fluid intake, dietary adjustments); Fluid and electrolyte replacement (oral or IV); Antibiotics; Antiparasitics; Treatment of underlying conditions; Antidiarrheal medications (loperamide, bismuth subsalicylate); Probiotics
Tests: Blood tests (complete blood count, electrolyte levels, kidney function); Stool test; Hydrogen breath test; Flexible sigmoidoscopy; Colonoscopy; Upper endoscopy; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam checking for swollen lymph nodes and enlarged spleen/liver;  followed by blood tests, imaging tests, and a tissue biopsy (lymph node or other tissue depending on symptoms and imaging).  Lab testing of biopsy samples and bone marrow (if indicated) identifies the presence and characteristics of lymphoma cells, including specific protein markers (CD20, CD19, CD22, CD79a, CD10) and DNA changes (translocations involving BCL2, BCL6, and MYC). Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy may be done if imaging suggests bone involvement or to determine the extent of cancer.  Lumbar puncture may be performed if neurological symptoms are present or there's a higher risk of central nervous system lymphoma.
Treatments: Immunotherapy; Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy; Targeted therapy; CAR-T cell therapy; Bone marrow transplant
Tests: Physical exam; Blood tests (including LDH levels and viral markers); MRI; CT scan; PET scan; Lymph node biopsy; Biopsy of other tissue; Bone marrow aspiration; Bone marrow biopsy; Lumbar puncture

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is typically made through a review of symptoms, physical exam, medical history, and primarily through MRI to identify the tumor's location and features (poorly defined borders).  A biopsy may be performed if MRI is inconclusive, testing for the H3K27-altered gene mutation.
Treatments: Radiation therapy; Surgery (usually not an option due to tumor location and poorly defined borders); Chemotherapy (usually ineffective, sometimes used with radiation); Palliative treatment (including steroid medicines, support for feeding and nutrition, speech therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, anti-seizure medication, pain medicine, procedures to drain fluid buildup on the brain, and counseling)
Tests: MRI; Biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Steroid medicines; Anti-seizure medication; Pain medicine

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily based on a lab test detecting a deletion in chromosome 22.  The test is ordered if a child presents with a mix of medical problems or conditions suggestive of 22q11.2 deletion syndrome, particularly heart problems.
Treatments: Surgery to repair heart problems; Calcium and vitamin D supplements for hypoparathyroidism;  Thymus tissue and bone marrow/specialized blood cell transplant (for severe thymus dysfunction); Surgery for cleft palate; Speech therapy; Occupational therapy; Developmental therapy; Mental health care (for ADHD, autism spectrum disorder, depression, or other mental health/behavioral conditions); Management of feeding and growth issues, hearing or vision problems, and other medical conditions.
Tests: Chromosome 22 deletion test

Diagnosis: Physical exam; Review of personal and family medical history; Echocardiogram (main test); Blood tests to check for underlying conditions; Chest X-ray; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; Exercise stress test; Cardiac CT or MRI scan; Cardiac catheterization (with possible biopsy); Genetic screening or counseling.
Treatments: Medications; Surgery (implantation of medical devices); Biventricular pacemaker implantation; Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) implantation
Tests: Echocardiogram; Blood tests; Chest X-ray; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; Exercise stress test; Cardiac CT scan; Cardiac MRI scan; Cardiac catheterization; Genetic testing
Medications_Drugs: Beta-blockers; Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors; Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs); Sacubitril/valsartan (Entresto); Diuretics; Digoxin (Lanoxin); Ivabradine (Corlanor); Blood thinners (anticoagulants)

Diagnosis: Suspected in sick children with a sore throat and gray membrane covering the tonsils and throat; confirmed by growing *C. diphtheriae* in a lab culture from throat membrane; cutaneous diphtheria diagnosed via lab testing of a wound sample.
Treatments: Ensuring airway isn't blocked; Placement of breathing tube (if necessary); Antibiotics; Antitoxin injection
Tests: Culture of throat membrane; Culture of wound sample

Diagnosis: Physical examination of the affected area for tenderness, swelling, or deformity; assessment for nerve or blood vessel injury; X-ray of the shoulder joint to visualize the dislocation and identify any fractures or other damage.
Treatments: Closed reduction; Surgery; Immobilization with splint or sling; Medication; Rehabilitation program
Tests: X-ray; Electromyography (EMG); MRI
Medications_Drugs: Aspirin; ibuprofen; naproxen sodium; acetaminophen; muscle relaxant; sedative; general anesthetic (rarely)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a discussion of symptoms with a healthcare professional to rule out physical causes; a mental health exam assesses thoughts, feelings, behaviors, and symptoms; information from family members may be included with permission; physical exam to rule out conditions like head injury, brain diseases, sleep deprivation, and substance use.
Treatments: Talk therapy (psychotherapy); Medication
Tests: Physical exam

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing abdominal pain and tenderness; pelvic exam (for women); blood tests for infection and immune system activity; urine test; stool test; pregnancy test; liver enzyme test; CT scan to visualize inflamed diverticula, abscesses, and fistulas.
Treatments: Liquid diet; Gradual increase in solid food (low-fiber initially); High-fiber diet (upon recovery); Fiber supplements; Antibiotics; IV antibiotics (for complicated cases); Surgery (to drain abscesses, stop bleeding, remove diseased colon section, create colostomy, or reconnect colon sections); Laparoscopic surgery; Colostomy.
Tests: Blood tests; Urine test; Stool test; Pregnancy test; Liver enzyme test; CT scan; Colonoscopy (follow-up)
Medications_Drugs: Antibiotics; Fiber supplements; Probiotics (evidence limited, consult physician before use).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing symptoms and medications, a physical exam assessing gait and balance, and neurological examination.  Further tests may include imaging (MRI, CT scan – especially if stroke is suspected, advanced age, or head trauma), hearing tests, and balance tests (eye movement testing, head movement testing like the Dix-Hallpike maneuver, posturography, rotary chair testing). Blood tests may be done to check for infection, and tests to evaluate heart and blood vessel health may also be performed.
Treatments: Medications; Balance exercises; Canalith repositioning (Epley maneuver); Vestibular rehabilitation; Talk therapy; Gentamicin injection; Labyrinthectomy
Tests: MRI; CT scan; Hearing test; Eye movement testing; Dix-Hallpike maneuver; Posturography; Rotary chair testing; Blood tests
Medications_Drugs: Water pills (diuretics);  Prescription antihistamines; Anticholinergics; Diazepam (Valium); Alprazolam (Xanax); Migraine preventive medications; Meclizine (Dramamine Less Drowsy); Dimenhydrinate (Dramamine)

Diagnosis: Diagnosed during a routine pelvic exam by observing a double cervix or feeling an unusually shaped uterus; confirmed with further tests.
Treatments: Often no treatment needed if asymptomatic; Surgery may be considered for partially divided uterus with unexplained pregnancy loss or if a double vagina is also present.
Tests: Ultrasound (transabdominal and transvaginal, potentially 3D); Sonohysterogram; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Hysterosalpingography

Diagnosis: Prenatal diagnosis involves screening tests (first trimester combined test, integrated screening test, cell-free DNA testing) to assess risk, followed by diagnostic tests (chorionic villus sampling, amniocentesis) if indicated.  Postnatal diagnosis is usually made through a physical exam within 24 hours of birth, confirmed by chromosomal karyotype analysis showing an extra full or partial chromosome 21.
Treatments: Early intervention; Ongoing healthcare;  Team care including specialists (primary care pediatrician; cardiologist; gastroenterologist; endocrinologist; developmental pediatrician; neurologist; ENT specialist; ophthalmologist; audiologist; speech-language pathologist; physical therapist; occupational therapist); Treatment of specific associated conditions (hypothyroidism, diabetes, celiac disease, GERD, heart disease, etc.).
Tests: First trimester combined test (blood test measuring PAPP-A and HCG; nuchal translucency ultrasound); Integrated screening test (first trimester: blood test measuring PAPP-A and nuchal translucency ultrasound; second trimester: quad screen measuring alpha-fetoprotein, estriol, HCG, and inhibin A); Cell-free DNA testing; Chorionic villus sampling (CVS); Amniocentesis; Chromosomal karyotype

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam, listening for a pericardial rub with a stethoscope.  Further diagnosis relies on blood tests (complete blood count, C-reactive protein level, erythrocyte sedimentation rate) to assess inflammation; electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) to check heart electrical activity; chest X-ray to detect fluid; echocardiogram to visualize heart fluid; and cardiac MRI to show pericardial thickening.  Results are interpreted considering factors like recent heart surgery.
Treatments: Medication; Surgery; Draining excess fluids (pericardiocentesis); Removing the pericardium (pericardiectomy)
Tests: Complete blood count; Blood tests to measure inflammation (C-reactive protein, erythrocyte sedimentation rate); Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Chest X-ray; Echocardiogram; Cardiac MRI

Diagnosis: A thorough evaluation by a psychiatrist, psychologist, or licensed alcohol and drug counselor; Assessment using criteria in the DSM-5 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 5th edition). Blood, urine, or other lab tests may be used for monitoring treatment and recovery, but are not diagnostic for addiction.
Treatments: Individual therapy; Group therapy; Family therapy; Detoxification (withdrawal therapy); Outpatient programs; Residential programs; Inpatient programs; Medication; Behavior therapy; Self-help groups; Long-term follow-up
Tests: Blood test; Urine test; Other lab tests
Medications_Drugs: Methadone; Buprenorphine; Naloxone; Naltrexone; A combination of buprenorphine and naloxone

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam, patient history (symptom onset, medication timing, symptom progression), and potentially further testing by an allergist.  Key factors include the timing of symptom onset relative to medication ingestion and symptom improvement or worsening.  The diagnosis may conclude that a drug allergy is present, absent, or possibly present.
Treatments: Stopping the medicine; Antihistamines; Corticosteroids; Treatment of anaphylaxis (epinephrine, hospital care); Graded challenge; Drug desensitization
Tests: Skin test; Blood tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a comprehensive eye exam including a complete health and eye health history; tear volume measurement (Schirmer tear test or phenol red thread test); assessment of tear quality using special dyes to evaluate corneal staining and tear evaporation rate; tear osmolarity test to measure tear composition; and analysis of tear samples for markers like elevated matrix metalloproteinase-9 or decreased lactoferrin.
Treatments: Regular use of nonprescription artificial tears; Punctal plugs; Treatment of underlying health issues or medication side effects;  Eyelid surgery (for conditions like ectropion); Closing tear ducts; partially or completely.
Tests: Comprehensive eye exam; Schirmer tear test; Phenol red thread test; Test to determine tear quality (dye tests assessing corneal staining and tear evaporation); Tear osmolarity test; Tear sample analysis for markers of dry eye disease (MMP-9, lactoferrin).
Medications_Drugs: Cyclosporine (Restasis); Corticosteroids; Hydroxypropyl cellulose (Lacrisert); Pilocarpine; Cevimeline; Autologous blood serum drops; Varenicline (Tyrvaya); Antibiotics (oral, eye drops, or ointments).

Diagnosis: Review of medical and family history; Complete eye exam; Examination of the back of the eye looking for drusen (yellow deposits under the retina); Amsler grid test to assess changes in central vision.
Treatments: Vitamin supplements (high-dose antioxidant vitamins and minerals for intermediate or advanced disease); Low vision rehabilitation; Surgery to implant a telescopic lens (for advanced disease in both eyes); Lifestyle modifications (healthy diet, no smoking, managing other medical conditions, maintaining healthy weight and exercise, regular eye exams).
Tests: Examination of the back of the eye; Amsler grid test; Fluorescein angiography; Indocyanine green angiography; Optical coherence tomography

Diagnosis: Review of medical history and medications; Oral examination; Blood tests; Imaging scans of salivary glands; Saliva production measurement; Biopsy of salivary glands (if Sjogren's syndrome suspected).
Treatments: Change medications causing dry mouth; Recommend moisturizing mouth products (prescription and over-the-counter mouth rinses, artificial saliva, moisturizers); Prescribe pilocarpine (Salagen); Prescribe cevimeline (Evoxac) for Sjogren's syndrome or radiation treatment; Lifestyle modifications (increased water intake, sugar-free gum/candy, humidifiers, avoiding irritants).
Tests: Blood tests; Imaging scans of salivary glands; Saliva production measurement; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Physical examination by a doctor; Review of medical history including onset of dry skin, factors influencing severity, bathing habits, and skincare routine;  Tests may be suggested to rule out underlying medical conditions such as hypothyroidism.  Dry skin may be a symptom of other skin conditions like dermatitis or psoriasis.
Treatments: Lifestyle measures such as using moisturizers and avoiding long, hot showers and baths;  Moisturizing products formulated for specific needs; Prescription creams or ointments for serious skin disease; Lotions with hydrocortisone for itchiness; Wet dressings for cracked skin to prevent infection.
Tests: Tests to rule out underlying medical conditions such as hypothyroidism
Medications_Drugs: Hydrocortisone; Prescription creams or ointments (specific names not mentioned)

Diagnosis: Severe pain following tooth extraction; visual examination of the tooth socket to assess the presence or absence of a blood clot; X-rays to rule out other conditions like bone infection and identify remaining tooth fragments.
Treatments: Flushing out the socket to remove debris; packing the socket with medicated gel or paste and a dressing; prescription pain medication; self-care including home rinsing with saline solution.
Tests: X-ray
Medications_Drugs: Prescription pain medicine (specific names not mentioned)

Diagnosis: DCIS is most often discovered during a screening mammogram;  additional breast imaging (diagnostic mammogram, ultrasound) and biopsy (core needle biopsy; stereotactic breast biopsy; ultrasound-guided breast biopsy) are used to confirm diagnosis and assess extent of disease;  biopsy tissue is examined by a pathologist to determine the presence and aggressiveness of cancer cells.
Treatments: Lumpectomy; Mastectomy; Radiation therapy; Hormone therapy
Tests: Mammogram; Diagnostic mammogram; Breast ultrasound; Core needle biopsy; Stereotactic breast biopsy; Ultrasound-guided breast biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is often made through medical history, particularly noting prior stomach surgery and evaluating signs and symptoms; a blood sugar test (oral glucose tolerance test) may be used to measure blood sugar levels at the peak of symptoms; a gastric emptying test using radioactive material may be used to measure food movement through the stomach.
Treatments: Dietary changes; Medications; Surgery
Tests: Blood sugar test (oral glucose tolerance test); Gastric emptying test

Diagnosis: Primarily diagnosed through visual examination of the hands, comparing both hands and checking for skin puckering on the palms; palpation to detect hard knots or bands of tissue; inability to fully flatten the fingers when placing the palm flat on a surface suggests the need for treatment.
Treatments: Observation (if slow progression, painless, and minimal impact on hand function); Needling; Steroid injections; Collagenase injections; Surgery (including possible skin grafts)
Tests: Physical examination

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of dural arteriovenous fistula (dAVF) relies primarily on cerebral angiography (digital subtraction angiography), which precisely defines the number and location of fistulae, the anatomy of relevant arteries and branches, fistula vessel structure, presence of cardiovascular disease, dural sinus narrowing or blockage, and affected vein dilation.  MRI can reveal dAVF shape and detect small bleeds; CT scans can show fluid buildup and bleeding.
Treatments: Endovascular procedures (using catheters, coils, or glue to block the connection); Stereotactic radiosurgery (using linear accelerator, Gamma Knife, or proton beam therapy); dAVF surgery (to disconnect or remove the fistula)
Tests: Cerebral angiography (digital subtraction angiography); MRI; CT scan

Diagnosis: Suspicion based on symptoms and answers about the home environment;  Examination of nasal lining with a lighted instrument to check for swelling and discoloration; Allergy skin test; Allergy blood test.
Treatments: Dust mite avoidance; Allergy medications; Immunotherapy; Nasal irrigation
Tests: Allergy skin test; Allergy blood test
Medications_Drugs: fexofenadine (Allegra Allergy); loratadine (Alavert, Claritin); cetirizine (Zyrtec); azelastine (Astelin, Astepro); olopatadine (Patanase); fluticasone propionate (Flonase Allergy Relief); mometasone furoate (Nasonex); triamcinolone (Nasacort Allergy 24HR); ciclesonide (Omnaris); montelukast (Singulair)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves assessment of growth, height, weight, and head size measurements plotted on percentile charts; observation of distinct facial and skeletal features; review of family history of short stature; imaging studies such as X-rays and MRI scans to examine skull and skeleton; genetic testing to identify specific genetic causes.
Treatments: Medication; Hormone therapy (growth hormone, estrogen, and other related hormones); Surgery (correcting bone growth direction, spinal stabilization and correction, increasing vertebral openings, shunt placement for hydrocephalus, limb lengthening); Ongoing health care and management of complications; Lifestyle modifications (car seat selection, infant carrier and play equipment choices, posture support, healthy diet and activities).
Tests: Height, weight, and head size measurements; X-rays; MRI scan; Genetic tests; Hormone tests (growth hormone and other relevant hormones).
Medications_Drugs: Vosoritide (Voxzogo); Synthetic growth hormone; Estrogen (for Turner syndrome).
