Diagnosis: Speech-language pathologist evaluates speech to identify type and features of dysarthria;  Neurologist investigates underlying causes;  Evaluation includes assessment of speech, muscle movement and control of face, tongue, and throat.
Treatments: Treatment of underlying cause;  Speech and language therapy (adjusting speech rate, strengthening muscles, increasing breath support, improving articulation); Alternative communication methods (visual cues, gestures, alphabet board, computer-based technology)
Tests: MRI; CT scan; EEG; EMG; Nerve conduction studies; Blood tests; Urine tests; Lumbar puncture; Brain biopsy; Neuropsychological tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing the patient's medical history and examining the affected skin; other tests may be used to rule out similar conditions, such as a skin scraping to test for fungus or a patch test to identify allergens.
Treatments: Corticosteroid creams or ointments (with or without occlusion); Oral corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone, in severe cases); Phototherapy (narrowband UVB); Calcineurin inhibitor ointments (e.g., tacrolimus); Antiperspirants; Botulinum toxin A injections; Moist cloth application; Anti-itch medications (e.g., diphenhydramine, loratadine).
Tests: Skin scraping for fungal testing; Patch test for allergens

Diagnosis: There is no single test; diagnosis considers developmental history; educational issues; medical history; family history of dyslexia or learning disabilities; questionnaires for child, caregivers, and teachers; tests of reading and language abilities; vision, hearing, and neurological tests to rule out other disorders; psychological evaluation to assess mental health factors affecting abilities; tests of reading and other academic skills analyzed by a reading expert.
Treatments: Specific educational approaches and techniques; Interventions focusing on phoneme recognition; phonics; reading comprehension; reading fluency; vocabulary building; tutoring with a reading specialist; Individualized Education Plan (IEP).
Tests: Questionnaires; Reading and language ability tests; Vision tests; Hearing tests; Neurological tests; Psychological evaluation; Tests for reading and other academic skills.

Diagnosis: A healthcare team will assess swallowing difficulties through patient description and history, physical exam, and various tests to determine the cause.
Treatments: Speech or swallowing therapy; Learning exercises; Learning swallowing techniques; Esophageal dilation; Surgery; Medications; Special diet; Feeding tube; Laparoscopic Heller myotomy; Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM); Stent placement; OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) injection
Tests: Barium X-ray; Dynamic swallowing study; Endoscopy; Biopsy; Fiber-optic endoscopic evaluation of swallowing (FEES); Esophageal manometry; CT scan; MRI scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a medical history and physical exam.  Further investigation may include blood and urine tests to detect toxins or other conditions; MRI or CT scans to examine the brain for abnormalities; electromyography (EMG) to measure muscle electrical activity; and genetic testing for specific dystonia-related genes.
Treatments: Medicines; Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Speech therapy; Stretching; Massage; Surgery (deep brain stimulation; selective denervation surgery); Sensory tricks; Heat or cold application; Stress management; Meditation; Biofeedback; Yoga
Tests: Blood or urine tests; MRI; CT scan; Electromyography (EMG); Genetic testing
Medications_Drugs: Botulinum toxin (Botox, Dysport); Carbidopa-levodopa (Duopa, Rytary); Trihexyphenidyl; Benztropine; Tetrabenazine (Xenazine); Deutetrabenazine (Austedo); Diazepam (Valium, Diastat); Clonazepam (Klonopin); Baclofen (Lioresal, Gablofen)

Diagnosis: Stool sample is sent to a laboratory to test for the presence of E. coli bacteria; Culture may be used to confirm diagnosis and identify specific toxins, such as those produced by E. coli O157:H7.
Treatments: Rest; Fluids to prevent dehydration and fatigue;  Avoid anti-diarrheal medication; For serious infections causing hemolytic uremic syndrome: IV fluids; blood transfusions; kidney dialysis.
Tests: Stool culture
Medications_Drugs: None specifically recommended; Antibiotics generally not recommended.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is often based on symptoms and a physical exam using an otoscope to visualize the eardrum; a red and bulging eardrum suggests infection; further testing may be needed if the diagnosis is unclear, treatment is ineffective, or other issues are present.  Diagnostic categories include acute otitis media (fluid in middle ear or infection symptoms), otitis media with effusion (fluid in middle ear, no infection symptoms), and chronic suppurative otitis media (long-term infection with eardrum tear and pus discharge).
Treatments: Watchful waiting; Pain management with acetaminophen or ibuprofen; Antibiotic medications; Ear tubes (myringotomy with insertion of tympanostomy tubes); Antibiotic ear drops (for chronic suppurative otitis media); Fluid suctioning (for chronic suppurative otitis media)
Tests: Otoscopic examination

Diagnosis: A health care provider visually examines the ear using an otoscope (a lighted, magnifying instrument) to determine the presence and extent of earwax blockage.
Treatments: Curettage (using a small, curved tool); Suction; Ear irrigation with warm water and saline or diluted hydrogen peroxide; Medicated ear drops (e.g., carbamide peroxide); Use of earwax-softening agents such as saline, mineral oil, or olive oil.
Tests: Otoscopic examination

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on symptoms, review of eating habits and behaviors; a physical exam to rule out other medical causes, potentially including lab tests; and a mental health evaluation assessing thoughts, feelings, and eating habits and behaviors, possibly including questionnaires.
Treatments: Learning about proper nutrition; Developing healthy eating habits; Guidance in reaching a healthy weight (if underweight); Behavioral therapy (including Family-based treatment (FBT) and Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), especially enhanced CBT); Medicine (for bulimia or binge-eating disorder to manage urges to binge or purge, or extreme focus on food and diet); Hospital stay; Day program; Specialized eating disorder programs
Tests: Physical exam; Lab tests

Diagnosis: Clinical examination including auscultation for heart murmurs; pulse oximetry; echocardiogram; electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; chest X-ray; cardiac MRI; exercise stress tests; electrophysiology study (EP study); cardiac catheterization.
Treatments: Regular health checkups; Medications; Surgery or other procedures (Tricuspid valve repair, including cone procedure; Tricuspid valve replacement; Closure of atrial septal defect; Maze procedure; Radiofrequency catheter ablation; Heart transplant)
Tests: Pulse oximetry; Echocardiogram; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; Chest X-ray; Cardiac MRI; Exercise stress tests; Electrophysiology study (EP study); Cardiac catheterization
Medications_Drugs: Nitric oxide (inhaled, for some babies); Medications to control irregular heartbeats; Medications to prevent fluid buildup; Medications to prevent blood clots.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is made through a combination of a pelvic exam (to identify pain/tenderness/masses), a pregnancy test (HCG blood test to confirm pregnancy and monitor levels), and an ultrasound (transvaginal or abdominal) to visualize the pregnancy location.  A pelvic exam alone is insufficient for diagnosis.
Treatments: Medication (methotrexate); Laparoscopic surgery (salpingostomy; salpingectomy); Emergency surgery (laparoscopic or laparotomy)
Tests: Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) blood test; Transvaginal ultrasound; Abdominal ultrasound; Complete blood count

Diagnosis: Routine eye exam and physical examination; assessment of eyelid muscle tone and tightness by pulling on eyelids or asking patient to forcefully close eyes; examination of surrounding tissue if ectropion is caused by scar, tumor, previous surgery, or radiation.
Treatments: Artificial tears and ointments; surgery (including removal of a small part of the lower eyelid at the outer edge with tightening of tendons and muscles; skin graft from upper eyelid or behind ear; possible second procedure for facial paralysis or significant scarring)
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Physical exam; review of medical history; blood tests; ultrasound exams; vein studies.  Further testing may be needed depending on initial findings.
Treatments: Compression garments; elevating affected limb; diuretics; treating the underlying cause;  exercise; massage; limiting salt intake.
Tests: Blood tests; ultrasound exams; vein studies

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves taking a medical history and conducting a physical exam; ruling out other conditions; and potentially using skin prick tests, blood tests, food challenges, and food tracking/elimination diets.
Treatments: Avoidance of eggs and egg products; Antihistamines; Emergency epinephrine injections
Tests: Skin prick test; Blood test; Food challenge; Food tracking or elimination diet

Diagnosis: Extremely loose joints, fragile or stretchy skin, and a family history of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome are often sufficient for diagnosis. Genetic testing on a blood sample can confirm diagnosis in rarer forms and help rule out other conditions; however, genetic testing is unavailable for hypermobile Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, the most common form.
Treatments: Pain management; Blood pressure management; Physical therapy; Surgery; Lifestyle modifications
Tests: Genetic testing; Echocardiogram; Skin biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is challenging based on symptoms alone, as they mimic other conditions.  A history of tick bite or exposure is crucial.  Diagnosis involves physical exam and blood tests revealing low white blood cell count; low platelet count; elevated liver enzymes; and detection of specific bacterial genes or antibodies.
Treatments: Antibiotic treatment
Tests: Blood tests; Physical exam

Diagnosis: Physical examination; review of symptoms and medical history; blood tests (complete blood cell count, kidney and liver function tests, iron levels); electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); chest X-ray; echocardiogram; computerized tomography (CT) scan of the lungs; magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of the lungs; cardiac catheterization; walking test.
Treatments: Medications; Blood withdrawal (phlebotomy); Heart or lung transplant; Lifestyle modifications (increased fluid intake, avoiding high altitudes and strenuous activity, flu shot, smoking cessation).
Tests: Blood tests; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Chest X-ray; Echocardiogram; Computerized tomography (CT) scan of the lungs; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of the lungs; Cardiac catheterization; Walking test
Medications_Drugs: Anti-arrhythmics; Iron supplements; Aspirin; Warfarin; Bosentan (Tracleer); Sildenafil (Revatio, Viagra); Tadalafil (Cialis, Adcirca); Antibiotics (prophylactic, for specific situations).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on the average of two or more blood pressure readings taken on separate occasions.  Elevated blood pressure is defined as a top number (systolic) of 120 to 129 mm Hg and a bottom number (diastolic) below 80 mm Hg.  Blood pressure is measured using a sphygmomanometer; Ambulatory blood pressure monitoring may be used for more comprehensive assessment.  Initial measurement is done in both arms to identify potential discrepancies.
Treatments: Healthy lifestyle changes (diet, exercise, weight management, stress reduction, alcohol limitation, smoking cessation); Blood pressure medication (if elevated blood pressure and diabetes, kidney disease, or heart disease are present).
Tests: Complete blood count; Cholesterol test (lipid profile); Blood sugar (glucose) test; Kidney function tests; Thyroid function tests; Electrocardiogram (ECG/EKG)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves review of medical history and symptoms; neurological exam assessing vision, hearing, balance, strength, coordination, and reflexes to identify affected brain areas; imaging tests (CT, MRI, perfusion MRI, magnetic resonance spectroscopy) to show tumor size, location, and pressure or fluid blockages; biopsy to remove a tissue sample for cell type analysis; spinal tap (lumbar puncture) to analyze cerebrospinal fluid for tumor cells or atypical components (performed after managing brain pressure or tumor removal).
Treatments: Surgery to remove the tumor; Surgery to relieve fluid buildup in the brain (hydrocephalus); Radiation therapy (X-rays, proton beam radiation); Chemotherapy; Clinical trials
Tests: Neurological exam; CT scan; MRI; Perfusion MRI; Magnetic resonance spectroscopy; Biopsy; Spinal tap (lumbar puncture)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing medical and family history, smoking history, exposure to lung irritants, and physical exam including lung auscultation.  Spirometry is the most common test; imaging tests (chest X-ray and CT scan) and lung function tests (including spirometry, lung volume and diffusing capacity measurements, six-minute walk test, and pulse oximetry) are used to assess lung function and identify characteristic changes.  Blood tests may help rule out other conditions or identify Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency.
Treatments: Quitting smoking; Pulmonary rehabilitation; Nutrition therapy; Oxygen therapy; Lung volume reduction surgery; Endoscopic lung volume reduction (endobronchial valve surgery); Bullectomy; Lung transplant;  Management of exacerbations with additional medications (antibiotics, oral steroids) and supplemental oxygen;
Tests: Spirometry; Chest X-ray; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Arterial blood gas analysis; Testing for AAT deficiency
Medications_Drugs: Bronchodilators; Inhaled steroids; Combination inhalers (bronchodilators and inhaled steroids, or multiple bronchodilators); Antibiotics; Oral steroids;  Nicotine replacement products (mentioned as a possibility, not a specific medication named)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam, medical history review, and may include brain imaging (MRI or CT scan) to detect swelling or other conditions; lumbar puncture (spinal tap) to analyze cerebrospinal fluid for infection and inflammation; blood, urine, or throat samples to test for infectious agents; electroencephalogram (EEG) to assess brain electrical activity; and body imaging (ultrasound, MRI, CT, or PET-CT scans) to check for tumors in cases of suspected autoimmune encephalitis; brain biopsy (rarely, if symptoms worsen despite treatment).
Treatments: Bed rest; Hydration; Anti-inflammatory medicines; Antiviral medicines; Immunomodulatory medicines; Intravenous or oral corticosteroids; Intravenous immunoglobulin; Plasma exchange; Immunosuppressive medicines; Tumor treatment (surgery, radiation, chemotherapy); Breathing assistance; Intravenous fluids; Anti-seizure medicines; Brain rehabilitation; Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Speech therapy; Psychotherapy
Tests: MRI; CT scan; Lumbar puncture; Blood tests; Urine tests; Throat culture; EEG; Ultrasound; PET-CT scan; Biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Acyclovir; Ganciclovir; Foscarnet; Azathioprine; Mycophenolate mofetil; Rituximab; Tocilizumab; Corticosteroids

Diagnosis: Physical exam focusing on symptoms, bowel movements, and eating habits to rule out physical causes; Digital rectal exam to check for impacted stool; Abdominal X-ray to confirm impacted stool; Psychological evaluation if emotional issues are suspected.
Treatments: Clearing impacted stool from the colon (using laxatives, rectal suppositories, enemas); Encouraging healthy bowel movements (dietary changes, laxatives, toilet training, potential cow's milk elimination); Behavior modification; Psychotherapy.
Tests: Physical exam; Digital rectal exam; Abdominal X-ray

Diagnosis: Assessment of medical and family history; physical and neurological exams; blood tests (measuring creatinine and urea); urine tests (checking albumin levels); imaging tests (ultrasound, MRI, CT scan); kidney biopsy.  Diagnosis of end-stage renal disease is based on a glomerular filtration rate (GFR) of less than 15% of typical kidney function.
Treatments: Kidney transplant; Dialysis (peritoneal dialysis; hemodialysis); Supportive care/Palliative care
Tests: Blood tests; Urine tests; Ultrasound; MRI; CT scan; Kidney biopsy

Diagnosis: Physical exam; review of medical history and symptoms; blood culture test; complete blood count; other blood tests; echocardiogram (transthoracic and transesophageal); electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); chest X-ray; computerized tomography (CT) scan or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) (if spread of infection suspected).
Treatments: High doses of intravenous (IV) antibiotics; Antifungal medication; Heart valve surgery; Heart valve repair; Heart valve replacement (mechanical or biologic tissue valve).
Tests: Blood culture test; Complete blood count; Other blood tests; Echocardiogram (transthoracic and transesophageal); Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Chest X-ray; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
Medications_Drugs: High doses of intravenous (IV) antibiotics; Antifungal medication

Diagnosis: Endometrial cancer diagnosis involves a pelvic exam to check reproductive organs; transvaginal ultrasound to image the uterus and endometrium; hysteroscopy for visualization of the uterine interior; and endometrial biopsy to obtain a tissue sample for cancer testing.  Dilation and curettage (D&C) may be performed if insufficient tissue is obtained via biopsy or if biopsy results are unclear.
Treatments: Surgery (hysterectomy, salpingo-oophorectomy, lymph node removal); Radiation therapy (external beam radiation; brachytherapy); Chemotherapy; Hormone therapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy; Palliative care
Tests: Pelvic exam; Transvaginal ultrasound; Hysteroscopy; Endometrial biopsy; Dilation and curettage (D&C); Chest X-ray; CT scan; Blood tests; Positron emission tomography (PET scan)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of endometriosis is primarily done through surgery (laparoscopy) where tissue samples are examined microscopically;  Symptoms such as painful periods, pelvic pain, pain during intercourse, urination, or bowel movements may suggest endometriosis, but are not definitive; Imaging (ultrasound or MRI) may detect deep infiltrating endometriosis affecting organs like the bowel or bladder, but not superficial endometriosis.
Treatments: Information not found
Tests: Pelvic exam; Transvaginal ultrasound; Ultrasound; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Laparoscopy

Diagnosis: A healthcare provider asks about symptoms and medications, and performs a physical exam of the breast tissue, stomach area, and genitals to determine if gynecomastia is present.  Further investigation aims to rule out other conditions with similar symptoms.
Treatments: Observation (often resolves spontaneously); Treatment of underlying medical condition; Medication; Liposuction; Mastectomy; Combined liposuction and mastectomy
Tests: Blood tests; Mammograms; Computerized tomography (CT) scans; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans; Testicular ultrasounds; Tissue biopsies; Chest X-rays

Diagnosis: Physical exam; Review of symptoms and medical history; Blood tests to rule out other conditions or assess heart muscle damage; Chest X-ray to visualize heart and lungs (further tests needed to confirm enlargement and determine cause); Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) to assess heart rhythm and detect hypertrophy; Echocardiogram to visualize heart size, structure, motion, and blood flow; Exercise or stress tests to assess heart response to physical activity; Cardiac CT scan or MRI to image the heart; Cardiac catheterization with possible biopsy.
Treatments: Medications; Surgery or other procedures; Pacemaker; Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD); Heart valve surgery; Coronary bypass surgery; Left ventricular assist device (LVAD)
Tests: Blood tests; Chest X-ray; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Echocardiogram; Exercise tests or stress tests; Cardiac Computerized Tomography (CT) scan; Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI); Cardiac catheterization
Medications_Drugs: Diuretics; Beta blockers; Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors; Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs); Blood thinners (anticoagulants); Heart rhythm drugs (anti-arrhythmics)

Diagnosis: Physical exam to assess liver size, shape, and texture;  Further investigation may be needed if physical exam is insufficient; Blood tests to check liver enzyme levels and identify viruses.
Treatments: Information not found
Tests: Blood tests; Computed tomography (CT) scan; Ultrasound; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Magnetic resonance elastography; Liver biopsy

Diagnosis: Usually detected during a physical exam by palpating the left upper abdomen;  Further testing, including blood tests (complete blood count and liver function tests), ultrasound, CT scan, MRI, and potentially bone marrow biopsy or aspiration, is used to confirm diagnosis and identify the underlying cause.  A splenic needle biopsy is rare due to bleeding risk; splenectomy may be performed for diagnosis if no other cause is found.
Treatments: Treatment of the underlying cause (e.g., antibiotics for bacterial infection); Watchful waiting; Splenectomy (surgical removal of the spleen)
Tests: Complete blood count; Liver function tests; Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI; Bone marrow biopsy; Bone marrow aspiration; Needle biopsy of spleen (rare); X-ray
Medications_Drugs: Penicillin;  Antibiotics (general category, specific drug not specified)

Diagnosis: Routine eye exam and physical examination; assessment of eyelid position, muscle tone, and tightness by pulling on eyelids and observing forceful blinking or eye closure; examination of surrounding tissue if entropion is suspected to be caused by scar tissue, previous surgery, or other conditions.
Treatments: Soft contact lenses; onabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) injections; eyelid sutures; skin tape; surgery (lower eyelid resection or mucous membrane graft).
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves considering symptoms and test results, including assessment for GERD.  Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying eosinophils in esophageal biopsies;  esophageal appearance during endoscopy may be typical or show inflammation, swelling, rings, furrows, strictures, or white spots.  Elevated eosinophil counts or total immunoglobulin E levels in blood tests may suggest allergy.
Treatments: Dietary therapy (elimination of trigger foods); Medication; Dilation
Tests: Upper endoscopy with biopsy; Blood tests (eosinophil count, total immunoglobulin E); Esophageal sponge test
Medications_Drugs: Proton pump inhibitor (PPI); Fluticasone; Budesonide; Dupilumab (Dupixent)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a neurological exam assessing vision, hearing, balance, coordination, strength, and reflexes; imaging tests (MRI, sometimes with magnetic resonance angiography) to show tumor location and size in the brain and/or spinal cord; cerebrospinal fluid testing (lumbar puncture) to look for tumor cells;  post-surgical laboratory testing of tumor cells to confirm diagnosis and determine cell types.
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy (conformal radiation therapy; intensity-modulated radiation therapy; proton therapy); Stereotactic radiosurgery; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Clinical trials
Tests: Neurological exam; MRI; Magnetic resonance angiography; Cerebrospinal fluid testing (lumbar puncture)

Diagnosis: Visual examination of the affected skin; Skin scraping for laboratory study.  Differentiation from sebaceous and pilar cysts is made based on origin (epidermoid cysts arise from hair follicles or epidermis, sebaceous cysts from sebaceous glands, and pilar cysts from hair follicle roots).
Treatments: Injection of steroid; Incision and drainage; Minor surgery to remove the entire cyst
Tests: Skin scraping

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on skin appearance; confirmation may require biopsy for immunofluorescence mapping (examining skin sample under a microscope to identify affected skin layers and proteins) and genetic testing (DNA analysis from a blood sample).
Treatments: Lifestyle changes and home care; Medications; Surgery (esophageal widening; feeding tube placement; skin grafting; contracture correction); Rehabilitation therapy (physical therapy; occupational therapy); Gene therapy; Bone marrow (stem cell) transplantation; Protein replacement therapies; Other cell-based therapies
Tests: Biopsy for immunofluorescence mapping; Genetic testing; Prenatal testing
Medications_Drugs: Oral antibiotics; Prescription-strength pain medication; Gabapentin

Diagnosis: Physical examination of the groin, including assessment for enlarged lymph nodes and testicles; rectal exam to check for prostate enlargement or tenderness;  patient history focusing on symptoms.
Treatments: Antibiotics; comfort measures (rest, scrotal support, ice packs, pain medication); surgery (abscess drainage, epididymectomy).
Tests: STI screening (gonorrhea and chlamydia); urine and blood tests; ultrasound (with color Doppler).

Diagnosis: Airway patency and oxygen levels are assessed initially.  Diagnosis is primarily clinical, based on symptoms and a throat exam using a flexible fiber-optic-lighted tube.  Chest X-rays may show an enlarged epiglottis ("thumbprint" sign), but aren't essential for diagnosis. Throat culture and blood cultures may be performed to identify Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) and bacteremia.
Treatments: Securing airway (oxygen mask; intubation; needle cricothyroidotomy); Intravenous antibiotics
Tests: Throat exam (using flexible fiber-optic-lighted tube); Chest X-ray; Throat culture; Blood culture
Medications_Drugs: Broad-spectrum antibiotics; More-targeted antibiotics (depending on causative agent)

Diagnosis: Epilepsy is a syndrome diagnosis based on brainwave abnormalities (EEG) and clinical presentation of seizures.  Diagnosis involves evaluating underlying causes through a combination of neurological exam, patient history, and various imaging and laboratory tests.
Treatments: Anti-seizure medication; Epilepsy surgery (for focal or certain types of generalized epilepsy); Seizure action plan
Tests: Neurological exam; Blood tests; Genetic testing; Electroencephalogram (EEG); High-density EEG; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Functional MRI (fMRI); Positron emission tomography (PET); Single-photon emission computerized tomography (SPECT)

Diagnosis: Epithelioid sarcoma can be difficult to diagnose due to its resemblance to more common conditions. Diagnosis involves imaging tests to determine location and size, and a biopsy to confirm the presence of cancer cells through lab testing.  Further tests characterize the cancer cells to inform treatment planning.
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy; Targeted therapy; Chemotherapy; Clinical trials
Tests: X-ray; MRI; CT; PET scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: A diagnosis of erectile dysfunction involves a physical exam (including examination of the penis and testicles and checking for nerve damage), a review of medical and sexual history, and consideration of duration and consistency of symptoms (lasting greater than three months and a consistent inability to obtain or maintain an erection adequate for intercourse).  Further testing may be necessary depending on the presence of underlying health conditions.
Treatments: Oral medications; Self-injection therapy (alprostadil); Intraurethral medicine; Shockwave therapy (experimental); Platelet-rich plasma therapy (experimental); Stem cell therapy (experimental)
Tests: Physical exam; Blood tests; Urine tests (urinalysis); Ultrasound (with or without injection to stimulate blood flow); Mental health exam
Medications_Drugs: Sildenafil (Revatio, Viagra); Tadalafil (Adcirca, Cialis); Vardenafil; Avanafil (Stendra); Alprostadil (Caverject, Edex); Nitroglycerin (Nitro-Dur, Nitrostat); Isosorbide mononitrate (Monoket); Isosorbide dinitrate (Isordil, Bidil)

Diagnosis: Esophageal cancer diagnosis often begins with imaging tests such as barium swallow studies to visualize the esophagus and detect growths.  Upper endoscopy allows direct visualization of the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum, with biopsy for tissue sampling and microscopic examination to confirm the presence of cancer cells.  Further tests determine the extent (stage) of cancer spread.
Treatments: Surgery (esophagectomy, esophagogastrectomy, endoscopic resection); Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy (external beam radiation, brachytherapy); Combined chemotherapy and radiation therapy; Targeted therapy
Tests: Upper endoscopy; Barium swallow study; Biopsy; Bronchoscopy; Endoscopic ultrasound; CT scan; MRI; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of esophageal spasms may involve upper endoscopy to visually examine the upper digestive system and potentially obtain a biopsy; esophagram (X-ray of the upper digestive system after drinking a contrast liquid); and esophageal manometry to measure esophageal muscle contractions during swallowing.
Treatments: Avoiding extremely hot or cold foods; Managing underlying conditions such as GERD; Proton pump inhibitor medication; Antidepressant medication (e.g., imipramine); Medications to relax swallowing muscles (e.g., peppermint oil, onabotulinumtoxinA (Botox), calcium channel blockers such as diltiazem); Myotomy; Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM)
Tests: Upper endoscopy; Esophagram (X-ray of the upper digestive system); Esophageal manometry; Biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Proton pump inhibitor; Imipramine; Peppermint oil; OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox); Diltiazem

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily through upper endoscopy, which visually identifies dilated veins in the esophagus;  Abdominal CT scans and Doppler ultrasounds of the splenic and portal veins can suggest the presence of esophageal varices; Transient elastography can measure liver scarring to assess for portal hypertension, a potential cause.
Treatments: Endoscopic band ligation; Beta-blockers to reduce portal vein pressure; Octreotide; Vasopressin; Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS); Balloon tamponade; Blood transfusion;  Antibiotics; Liver transplant;  Hemostatic powder spray (experimental); Self-expanding metal stents (SEMS, experimental)
Tests: Upper endoscopy; Abdominal CT scan; Doppler ultrasound of splenic and portal veins; Transient elastography

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a patient history review, physical exam, and potentially one or more tests, depending on suspected cause.  Esophageal appearance is assessed visually during endoscopy. Biopsies are performed to analyze tissue samples for infection, eosinophils, or abnormal cells.
Treatments: Treatment varies depending on the cause; For reflux esophagitis: antacids; H2-receptor blockers; proton pump inhibitors; fundoplication surgery; For eosinophilic esophagitis: allergen avoidance; proton pump inhibitors; swallowed steroids (budesonide, fluticasone); elimination diet; elemental diet; dupilumab; For medicine-induced esophagitis: medication change; liquid medication; altered pill-taking habits; For infectious esophagitis: medication to treat infection; Esophageal dilation
Tests: Upper endoscopy; Esophageal capsule; Barium X-ray; Biopsy; Allergy skin tests; Laboratory tests
Medications_Drugs: Maalox; Mylanta; cimetidine (Tagamet HB); lansoprazole (Prevacid 24 HR); omeprazole (Prilosec OTC);  Prescription-strength H2-receptor blockers; Prescription-strength proton pump inhibitors; esomeprazole (Nexium); lansoprazole (Prevacid); omeprazole (Prilosec); pantoprazole (Protonix); budesonide (Eohilia); fluticasone; dupilumab (Dupixent)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily based on a review of medical and family history, symptom assessment, and physical examination;  other conditions causing similar symptoms are ruled out through various tests.  There are no specific medical tests to directly diagnose essential tremor.
Treatments: Medicines; Nerve-blocking injections; Physical or occupational therapy; Nerve stimulation devices; Surgery (deep brain stimulation; focused ultrasound thalamotomy).
Tests: Neurological exam (assessing tendon reflexes, muscle strength and tone, sensation, posture, coordination, walk, and balance); Blood and urine tests (for thyroid disease, metabolic problems, medication side effects, and tremor-causing chemicals); Dopamine transporter scan (to differentiate from Parkinson's disease); Essential tremor test (e.g., drawing a spiral, drinking from a glass, holding arms outstretched, writing).
Medications_Drugs: Propranolol; Primidone; Gabapentin; Topiramate; Clonazepam; OnabotulinumtoxinA.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam focusing on the eyes, nose, and head and neck; an endoscopic exam using a camera-equipped tube inserted into the nose to visualize the tumor size; imaging tests such as MRI, CT, and PET scans to determine tumor size and spread; and a biopsy to obtain a tissue sample for laboratory analysis.  Diagnosis can be challenging due to the rarity of the condition and its similarity to other head, neck, and nose cancers.
Treatments: Surgery (endoscopic removal or craniotomy); Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy
Tests: Physical exam; Endoscopic exam; MRI scan; CT scan; PET scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam; imaging tests (X-ray, MRI, CT, bone scan, PET scan) are used to locate and size the tumor; a biopsy is required to confirm the diagnosis by examining tissue samples for cancer cells and specific DNA changes (primarily EWSR1 gene changes, often involving the fusion gene EWS-FLI1).
Treatments: Chemotherapy; Surgery; Radiation therapy; Targeted therapy
Tests: X-ray; MRI; CT; Bone scan; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves considering headache duration, onset (sudden vs. gradual), age, and presence of other symptoms (nausea, vomiting, vision disturbances). Imaging tests are recommended if headaches last > a few hours, are sudden-onset, occur in individuals >40, or are accompanied by other symptoms.  The goal is to differentiate between benign exercise headaches and those caused by structural or vascular irregularities.
Treatments: Preventative medication if no underlying structural or vascular problem is found;  Medication taken before predicted events.
Tests: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA); Computed tomography (CT) angiography; Computed tomography (CT) scan; Spinal tap (lumbar puncture)
Medications_Drugs: Indomethacin; Propranolol; Naproxen; Phenelzine; Dihydroergotamine mesylate

Diagnosis: Medical history review; Physical exam; Spirometry (to assess lung function before and after bronchodilator administration, and to rule out chronic asthma); Exercise challenge test (treadmill or other exercise inducing increased breathing rate, potentially including real-life challenges like stair climbing, with spirometry before and after); Methacholine challenge breathing test (inhaling methacholine to constrict airways, followed by spirometry).
Treatments: Pre-exercise medication; Long-term control medication; Self-care measures (warm-up, nasal breathing, face mask/scarf in cold weather, allergy avoidance, pollution avoidance)
Tests: Spirometry; Exercise challenge test; Methacholine challenge breathing test
Medications_Drugs: Albuterol (ProAir HFA, Proventil-HFA, Ventolin HFA); Levalbuterol (Xopenex HFA); Ipratropium (Atrovent HFA); Inhaled corticosteroids; Combination inhalers (containing corticosteroid and long-acting beta agonist); Leukotriene modifiers

Diagnosis: A complete eye exam, including eye dilation to better visualize the back of the eyes and the vitreous, is conducted to determine the cause of eye floaters.
Treatments: Most eye floaters don't require treatment; Treatment of any underlying medical condition causing floaters (e.g., diabetic bleeding or inflammation); Vitrectomy (surgical removal of vitreous with replacement solution); Vitreolysis (laser treatment to disrupt floaters)
Tests: Eye exam; Eye dilation

Diagnosis: Eye melanoma diagnosis begins with an eye exam, looking for unusual blood vessels and examining the eye's interior using binocular indirect ophthalmoscopy and slit-lamp biomicroscopy.  Imaging tests determine cancer size.  Biopsy may be used in some cases, but isn't typically necessary for diagnosis.
Treatments: Radiation therapy; Laser therapy; Photodynamic therapy; Surgery (melanoma removal, removal of melanoma and surrounding tissue, enucleation); Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy;  Waiting and watching for small, non-growing melanomas.
Tests: Eye exam; Binocular indirect ophthalmoscopy; Slit-lamp biomicroscopy; Fundus photography; Fundus autofluorescence; Eye ultrasound; Fluorescein angiography; Indocyanine green angiography; Optical coherence tomography; Eye melanoma biopsy; Blood tests; Liver function tests; Chest X-ray; Ultrasound; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Positron emission tomography (PET) scan
Medications_Drugs: Photosensitizer (used in photodynamic therapy);  Specific targeted therapy and immunotherapy drugs are not named.

Diagnosis: An eye specialist will ask questions about factors causing symptoms; a vision test and eye exam may be performed.
Treatments: Changes in daily habits or environment; Treatment for underlying eye condition; Glasses prescribed for specific activities (computer use or reading); Regular eye breaks; Artificial tears (nonprescription);  Improving air quality (humidifier, adjusting thermostat, avoiding smoke, moving chair);  Eye drops (preservative-free preferred);  Adjusting computer setup (monitor position, lighting, glare reduction, document holder, screen settings); Omega-3 fatty acid supplements (further study needed)
Tests: Vision test; Eye exam

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is difficult due to expert symptom faking.  Diagnosis relies on objectively identifying fabricated symptoms, not intent. Suspicion arises when medical history is inconsistent, illness lacks explanation or follows an unusual course, improvement is absent despite treatment, symptoms/lab results are contradictory, information is withheld, or self-harm/lying is observed.  Diagnostic methods include detailed interviews; review of past health records (with patient permission); collaboration with family members (with patient permission); and focusing tests only on possible physical issues.
Treatments: Talk therapy (psychotherapy and behavior therapy); family therapy;  in-hospital treatment (for severe cases); management of the condition and improved functioning as goals;  having a primary healthcare professional to manage care; addressing co-occurring mental health conditions such as depression and anxiety.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Suspected based on one or more episodes of abnormal blood clotting or a strong family history of abnormal blood clots; confirmed by a blood test.
Treatments: Blood-thinning medications (for those who have developed abnormal blood clots);  Precautions to prevent blood clots (such as blood thinners, leg wraps, compression stockings, and walking after surgery) for those with the mutation but no history of blood clots.
Tests: Blood test

Diagnosis: Family history of FAP in a parent, child, sibling; presence of numerous polyps in the colon; genetic testing to identify the causative gene.  Some, but not all, signs of FAP may warrant genetic testing.
Treatments: Polypectomy (removal of polyps); Subtotal colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis; Total proctocolectomy with a continent ileostomy; Total proctocolectomy with ileoanal anastomosis (J-pouch surgery);  Medication for desmoid tumors (NSAIDs, anti-estrogen, chemotherapy); Surgery for desmoid tumors; Surgery for duodenal and periampullary polyps; Osteoma removal.
Tests: Genetic testing (blood test); Sigmoidoscopy; Colonoscopy; Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD); Side-viewing duodenoscopy; Biopsy; CT; MRI; Thyroid exams
Medications_Drugs: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs); Anti-estrogen; Chemotherapy; Aspirin

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a detailed family history of high cholesterol or heart disease, especially in childhood; physical exam checking for cholesterol deposits in skin, thickened tendons, and corneal arcus; and cholesterol testing.  Genetic testing can confirm diagnosis but isn't always necessary.  Adults usually have LDL cholesterol >190 mg/dL (4.9 mmol/L); children >160 mg/dL (4.1 mmol/L).
Treatments: Medications;  Periodic cholesterol filtering procedures (in severe cases); Liver transplant (in severe cases); Lifestyle modifications (weight loss, heart-healthy diet, regular exercise, smoking cessation)
Tests: Cholesterol tests; Genetic testing
Medications_Drugs: Atorvastatin (Lipitor); Fluvastatin (Lescol XL); Lovastatin (Altoprev); Pitavastatin (Livalo); Pravastatin; Rosuvastatin (Crestor); Simvastatin (Zocor); Ezetimibe (Zetia); Alirocumab (Praluent); Evolocumab (Repatha)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) involves a review of family medical history (positive family history increases likelihood); physical exam; lab tests during an attack to detect elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., white blood cells) and potential amyloidosis; and genetic testing of the MEFV gene (though not solely relied upon due to potential for false negatives).
Treatments: Medications to relieve symptoms and prevent attacks; Intravenous fluids (during attacks); Medications to reduce fever and inflammation (during attacks); Medications to control pain (during attacks).
Tests: Physical exam; Review of family medical history; Blood tests; Urine tests; Genetic testing

Diagnosis: Diagnosed by a basic eye exam including a refraction assessment (determining vision problems like nearsightedness, farsightedness, astigmatism, or presbyopia) and an eye health exam (often involving pupil dilation with eye drops).  The refraction assessment involves using various instruments and lenses to test distance and close-up vision.
Treatments: Prescription lenses (eyeglasses: single vision, bifocals, trifocals, progressive multifocals; contact lenses: soft, rigid gas permeable, spherical, toric, multifocal, monovision); Refractive surgery (LASIK; PRK)
Tests: Refraction assessment; Eye health exam with pupil dilation

Diagnosis: For simple febrile seizures in vaccinated children with a first episode, diagnosis is based on history.  In children with delayed vaccination or compromised immunity, tests may include blood test; urine test; lumbar puncture (to rule out central nervous system infections). For complex febrile seizures, an EEG and/or MRI may be recommended, particularly if the child has an unusually large head, abnormal neurological evaluation, signs of increased intracranial pressure, or a prolonged seizure.
Treatments: Most seizures resolve spontaneously.  First aid includes placing the child on their side; timing the seizure; observing and comforting the child; removing hazards; loosening clothing; avoiding restraint; not placing anything in the child's mouth. For seizures lasting >5 minutes, medication may be used to stop the seizure. Hospitalization may be considered for prolonged seizures; children <6 months old; seizures accompanied by serious infection; or if the infection source is unknown.
Tests: Blood test; Urine test; Lumbar puncture; EEG; MRI

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a detailed medical history review, focusing on symptoms and diet; a physical exam including anal and rectal exams to assess anal muscle reflexes and rectal tissues; and a neurological exam to assess nervous system health.
Treatments: Diet and lifestyle changes (increased fiber, avoidance of trigger foods, exercise, weight management, smoking cessation); Medications; Kegel exercises; Biofeedback training; Bowel training; Bulking agents; Sacral nerve stimulation; Anal plug; Vaginal insert; Surgery (for underlying problems like rectal prolapse, rectocele, hemorrhoids; sphincteroplasty; colostomy)
Tests: Anal and rectal exam; Neurological exam; Anorectal manometry; Balloon expulsion test; Endoscopy; Endoscopic ultrasound; Defecography; Anorectal MRI
Medications_Drugs: Loperamide; Diphenoxylate and atropine; Bismuth subsalicylate; Methylcellulose; Psyllium; Magnesium hydroxide; Polyethylene glycol; Bisacodyl

Diagnosis: Evaluation involves a detailed medical history, physical exam, and partner evaluation.  Diagnosis is based on inability to conceive after a reasonable period.
Treatments: Medication to restore fertility; Surgery; Assisted reproductive technologies (implied, not explicitly listed)
Tests: Ovulation testing (home kit or blood test for progesterone); Hysterosalpingography; Ovarian reserve testing (blood and imaging tests); Other hormone testing (prolactin, thyroid, pituitary hormones); Pelvic ultrasound; Sonohysterogram; Hysteroscopy; Laparoscopy; Genetic testing
Medications_Drugs: Clomiphene citrate; Human menopausal gonadotropin (hMG, Menopur); Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH, Gonal-F, Follistim AQ, Bravelle); Human chorionic gonadotropin (Ovidrel, Pregnyl); Metformin (Fortamet); Letrozole (Femara); Bromocriptine (Cycloset, Parlodel)

Diagnosis: Discussion of sexual and medical history and gender identity; Pelvic exam to check for physical changes affecting sexual enjoyment (thinning genital tissues, scarring, pain).
Treatments: Talk therapy with partner; Lifestyle changes (limiting alcohol, physical activity, stress reduction); Counseling; Vaginal lubricant; Vaginal moisturizer; Maintaining sexual activity; Use of devices (e.g., vibrators); Vaginal estrogen (cream, tablet, ring); Ospemifene (Osphena); Flibanserin (Addyi); Bremelanotide (Vyleesi); Prasterone (Intrarosa); Cognitive behavioral therapy; Mindfulness; Yoga.
Tests: Blood tests; Pelvic exam
Medications_Drugs: Vaginal estrogen; Ospemifene (Osphena); Flibanserin (Addyi); Bremelanotide (Vyleesi); Prasterone (Intrarosa); Sildenafil (Revatio, Viagra) - use should be discussed with healthcare provider; Testosterone therapy (off-label use, requires discussion with healthcare provider); Tibolone (not FDA-approved in the U.S.)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a comprehensive evaluation by a healthcare professional specializing in fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS). This includes discussing the mother's alcohol consumption during pregnancy; observing the child's physical appearance for characteristic changes; monitoring physical and brain growth and development; assessing for issues with physical growth and development, thinking, learning and language development, health, social interaction, and behavior.  Differential diagnosis may involve referral to specialists (developmental pediatrician, neurologist) to rule out other conditions with similar symptoms.  FAS is diagnosed based on a combination of physical, developmental, and behavioral findings.  Pre-natal diagnosis is not possible.
Treatments: Early intervention services to lessen challenges;  Healthcare professionals for vision, hearing, or heart conditions; Medications for some symptoms; Early intervention specialists (speech therapist, physical therapist, occupational therapist) for developmental support; Special education teacher and mental health professional for learning and behavioral issues; Vocational rehabilitation services; Life skills training; Mental health professionals for family support; Counselors for substance misuse.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Fetal macrosomia is diagnosed after birth by weighing the baby.  During pregnancy, risk factors may prompt monitoring with ultrasound (measuring fetal head, abdomen, and femur to estimate weight, though accuracy is unreliable) and antenatal testing (nonstress test, fetal biophysical profile) to assess fetal well-being.  Macrosomia alone is not a reason for antenatal testing.
Treatments: Vaginal delivery (monitored closely for complications); Cesarean section (recommended for maternal diabetes and estimated fetal weight of ≥4500 grams, or weight ≥5000 grams without diabetes, or history of shoulder dystocia)
Tests: Ultrasound; Nonstress test; Fetal biophysical profile

Diagnosis: Evaluation includes asking about symptoms and medical history; performing a physical exam; taking nasal or throat samples for respiratory infection testing; ordering blood tests or chest X-rays as needed, based on medical history and physical exam.  For fevers lasting over three weeks without a clear cause (fever of unknown origin), specialist consultation and further evaluations are needed.
Treatments: For low-grade fevers, medication may not be recommended; For high fevers causing discomfort, over-the-counter medications may be recommended;  Treating the underlying cause of the fever; Hospital admission for infants under two months old for testing and treatment, potentially including IV medications and monitoring.  Rest; Drink plenty of fluids; Stay cool.
Tests: Nasal or throat samples; Blood tests; Chest X-ray
Medications_Drugs: Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Aspirin (not for children due to risk of Reye's syndrome)

Diagnosis: Fibroadenomas are often discovered during self-exams, bathing, routine medical exams, mammograms, or breast ultrasounds.  Diagnosis involves assessing the lump's characteristics (size, shape), patient age, and using imaging tests (ultrasound, mammogram) and possibly a core needle biopsy to obtain a tissue sample for pathological examination to differentiate it from other conditions like phyllodes tumors.
Treatments: Observation (no treatment); Surgical excision; Cryoablation (tissue freezing)
Tests: Breast ultrasound; Mammography; Core needle biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on clinical breast exam, patient history, and imaging studies.  If a lump is found, further tests may be necessary to differentiate between a cyst and a solid mass.  Normal breast changes may not require additional tests.
Treatments: Fine-needle aspiration; Surgical excision; Over-the-counter pain relievers (acetaminophen, ibuprofen); Oral contraceptives;  Heating pad;  Evening primrose oil; Vitamin E
Tests: Clinical breast exam; Fine-needle aspiration; Diagnostic mammogram; Ultrasound; Breast biopsy

Diagnosis: Physical examination including auscultation for irregular blood flow; Family history of fibromuscular dysplasia; Imaging tests to visualize narrowed arteries (characteristic "string of beads" appearance on some imaging).
Treatments: Regular health checkups; Medications; Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) with possible stent placement; Surgery to repair or replace damaged artery
Tests: Blood tests; Duplex ultrasound; Angiogram; CT angiogram; Magnetic resonance (MR) angiogram
Medications_Drugs: Benazepril; Enalapril; Lisinopril; Candesartan; Irbesartan; Losartan; Valsartan; Hydrochlorothiazide; Amlodipine; Nifedipine; Metoprolol; Atenolol; Aspirin

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves assessing symptoms and health history, a physical exam, and identifying widespread pain lasting at least three months in at least four of five body regions (left upper, right upper, left lower, right lower, and axial).
Treatments: Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Counseling (cognitive behavioral therapy);  Acupuncture;  Stress management;  Sleep hygiene; Regular exercise
Tests: Complete blood count (CBC); Sed rate (erythrocyte sedimentation rate); Imaging tests; Overnight sleep study (if sleep apnea suspected)
Medications_Drugs: Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Duloxetine; Milnacipran; Amitriptyline; Cyclobenzaprine; Pregabalin; Gabapentin

Diagnosis: Observation of feet from front and back; standing on toes; assessment of ankle strength; location of pain; examination of shoe wear patterns; X-rays to evaluate alignment and detect arthritis.
Treatments: Arch supports (over-the-counter and custom-designed); Stretching exercises; Physical therapy; Surgery (for pain unresponsive to nonsurgical treatments)
Tests: X-rays; CT scan; Ultrasound; MRI

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam checking for mouth and neck lumps and swollen lymph nodes; biopsy to test tissue samples for cancerous cells; imaging tests (X-rays, CT, MRI, PET scans) to determine tumor size and location.
Treatments: Surgery (to remove cancer and surrounding tissue, including parts of jaw or tongue if necessary; neck dissection to remove lymph nodes; reconstructive surgery); Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy; Photodynamic therapy; Physical therapy and rehabilitation services
Tests: Physical examination of mouth and neck; Biopsy; X-rays; CT scan; MRI scan; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; Sentinel node biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing medical history and conducting lab tests assessing kidney function.  A kidney biopsy is usually required to confirm the diagnosis.
Treatments: Medications; Dialysis; Kidney transplant; Lifestyle modifications
Tests: Urine tests (including 24-hour urine collection); Blood tests (glomerular filtration rate); Kidney imaging (ultrasound; CT scan; MRI scan; nuclear medicine studies); Kidney biopsy
Medications_Drugs: ACE inhibitors; Angiotensin II receptor blockers; Cholesterol-lowering medications; Diuretics; Corticosteroids

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam checking for swollen lymph nodes and organs (spleen, liver); blood tests to rule out infection and measure LDH levels; imaging tests (MRI, CT, PET scans) to show location and extent; lymph node biopsy to look for cancer cells; bone marrow aspiration and biopsy to determine cancer extent; lab tests on lymphoma cells to identify specific proteins, growth patterns, and DNA changes (translocations).
Treatments: Watch and wait; Radiation therapy; Immunotherapy; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; CAR-T cell therapy
Tests: Blood tests; MRI; CT scan; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; Lymph node biopsy; Bone marrow aspiration; Bone marrow biopsy

Diagnosis: Visual examination of the skin and review of medical history;  If initial treatments are ineffective, further tests may be performed.
Treatments: Antibiotic lotions or gels; Oral antibiotics (for severe or recurrent infections); Antifungal creams, shampoos, or pills; Steroid creams (for eosinophilic folliculitis); Minor surgery (incision and drainage for boils or carbuncles); Laser hair removal (for pseudofolliculitis barbae).
Tests: Skin scraping for microscopic yeast examination; Culture swab to identify infection cause; Skin biopsy (rarely).
Medications_Drugs: Antibiotic lotions or gels; Oral antibiotics; Antifungal creams, shampoos, or pills; Steroid creams.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis considers symptoms (detailed history of reactions to specific foods), family history of allergies, physical examination to rule out other conditions, skin prick test (positive reaction not conclusive), blood test (measuring IgE antibodies), elimination diet (not foolproof and potentially unsafe for severe reactions), and oral food challenge (increasing amounts of suspected food in a controlled setting).
Treatments: Avoidance of trigger foods; Antihistamines (for minor reactions); Epinephrine injection (for severe reactions); Omalizumab (Xolair, for certain adults and children); Peanut (Arachis hypogaea) Allergen Powder-dnfp (Palforzia, for children with peanut allergy); Oral immunotherapy; Sublingual immunotherapy
Tests: Skin prick test; Blood test (IgE antibody measurement); Elimination diet; Oral food challenge
Medications_Drugs: Antihistamines; Epinephrine; Omalizumab (Xolair); Peanut (Arachis hypogaea) Allergen Powder-dnfp (Palforzia)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a physical exam and a review of symptoms, recently consumed food and drinks, symptoms in those who ate with the patient, recent drug changes, and recent travel.  The exam rules out other causes and checks for dehydration.
Treatments: Fluid replacement; Antibiotics (for bacterial infections and severe cases); Antiparasitics (for parasitic infections); Probiotics; Loperamide (Imodium A-D) for non-bloody diarrhea in adults without fever; Bismuth subsalicylate (Pepto-Bismol, Kaopectate, others) for upset stomach in adults (not recommended for children); Rest; Bland diet; Fluid replacement with water, sports drinks, diluted juice, or broth; Rehydration fluids (Pedialyte, Enfalyte, others) for children or those at risk for serious illness.
Tests: Stool sample tests; Blood tests

Diagnosis: Physical exam observing gait and assessing leg muscle weakness; checking for numbness in the shin, foot, and toes.  Imaging tests may be used to identify underlying causes such as masses compressing nerves.
Treatments: Braces or splints; Physical therapy; Nerve stimulation; Nerve surgery; Tendon transfer surgery
Tests: X-rays; Ultrasound; CT scan; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Electromyography (EMG); Nerve conduction studies

Diagnosis: Review of symptoms and medical history; Physical exam; Neurological exam (assessing muscle strength, sensory skills, hearing and speech, vision, coordination and balance); Blood tests to rule out other conditions.  Brain imaging (MRI) to identify seizure source; EEG to monitor brain electrical activity; Video EEG to correlate physical seizure activity with EEG findings.
Treatments: Anti-seizure medications; Surgery (removing or isolating the focal point); Vagus nerve stimulation; Responsive neurostimulator; Deep brain stimulation; Ketogenic diet (some evidence, particularly in children).
Tests: Blood test; Neurological exam; MRI; EEG; Video EEG; SPECT; SISCOM; fMRI

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves considering symptoms and excluding other conditions; neuropsychological testing helps determine the type of dementia and distinguish FTD from other causes; brain scans (MRI, FDG-PET) reveal brain changes; blood tests rule out other conditions such as liver or kidney disease; sleep study to rule out obstructive sleep apnea.
Treatments: Speech therapy; Management of behavioral symptoms with medication; Lifestyle adjustments to aid daily living and safety
Tests: Blood tests; Sleep study; Neuropsychological testing; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tracer (FDG-PET) scan
Medications_Drugs: Trazodone; Citalopram (Celexa); Escitalopram (Lexapro); Paroxetine (Paxil, Brisdelle); Sertraline (Zoloft); Olanzapine (Zyprexa); Quetiapine (Seroquel)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on symptoms and a review of recent cold exposure; X-rays or MRI may be used to assess bone or muscle damage; full extent of tissue damage may take 2-4 days post-rewarming to assess.
Treatments: Rewarming (warm-water bath); Pain medication; Loose wrapping of the affected area; Elevation of affected area; Whirlpool bath; Antibiotic medicine (if infection); Thrombolytic injection (e.g., TPA); Iloprost; Debridement; Wound care; Surgery; Amputation (in severe cases)
Tests: X-rays; MRI
Medications_Drugs: Tissue plasminogen activator (TPA); Iloprost; Nonprescription pain relievers; Antibiotic medicine

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is usually based on signs and symptoms; imaging tests (X-rays, ultrasound, MRI) may rule out other conditions.  Assessment of active and passive range of motion is key.
Treatments: Shoulder exercises; Pain relievers; Steroid injections; Hydrodilatation; Shoulder manipulation; Surgery (arthroscopy); Heat or cold application; Acupuncture; Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS)
Tests: X-ray; Ultrasound; MRI

Diagnosis: Symptoms and physical exam; blood tests to rule out other diseases; tests for Helicobacter pylori (stool sample, breath test, or tissue samples during endoscopy); upper endoscopy to visually examine the upper digestive system and collect tissue samples.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (smaller, more frequent meals; avoiding trigger foods; stress reduction); medication; behavior therapy
Tests: Blood tests; Helicobacter pylori testing (stool sample; breath test; tissue samples during endoscopy); Upper endoscopy
Medications_Drugs: Simethicone; cimetidine (Tagamet HB); famotidine (Pepcid AC); nizatidine (Axid AR); lansoprazole (Prevacid 24HR); omeprazole (Prilosec OTC); esomeprazole (Nexium 24HR); Antibiotics (if H. pylori is present); Low-dose tricyclic antidepressants; selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors; Prokinetics; promethazine; prochlorperazine; meclizine

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on the presence of specific symptom patterns and the absence of neurological or other medical conditions that could explain the symptoms.  This involves a thorough assessment of symptoms, a physical exam, and potentially a psychiatric exam.  Diagnostic criteria in the DSM-5 (specifically criteria for conversion disorder/functional neurological symptom disorder) may be used for comparison.  There are no standard tests.
Treatments: Education and reassurance; Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Speech therapy; Stress reduction techniques; Distraction techniques; Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT); Other types of psychotherapy; Treatment of any underlying medical or neurological conditions.
Tests: Physical exam; Psychiatric exam; EEG (electroencephalogram); X-ray;  Other tests may be used to rule out other medical conditions, depending on the presenting symptoms.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of galactorrhea involves identifying the underlying cause, which can be challenging due to numerous possibilities.  Assessment includes a physical exam checking for breast lumps and thickened tissue; a blood test to measure prolactin levels (and potentially thyroid-stimulating hormone if prolactin is high); a pregnancy test; and imaging studies (mammography, ultrasound, or MRI of the brain if a pituitary tumor is suspected or other breast abnormalities are found).
Treatments: Addressing the underlying cause; Medication to block prolactin effects or lower prolactin levels; Thyroid replacement therapy (for hypothyroidism); Medication or surgery for prolactinoma (pituitary tumor);  Lifestyle changes to reduce breast stimulation
Tests: Physical exam; Blood test (prolactin level, potentially TSH); Pregnancy test; Diagnostic mammography; Ultrasound; MRI of the brain

Diagnosis: Diagnosis may begin with a discussion of symptoms.  Blood tests assess liver function; imaging tests (ultrasound, CT scan, MRI) visualize the gallbladder;  ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography) uses dye to highlight bile ducts on X-ray; further tests may include magnetic resonance cholangiography to assess bile ducts; exploratory laparoscopy may be used to assess cancer spread. Staging determines the extent of cancer spread.
Treatments: Surgery (cholecystectomy, removal of gallbladder and parts of liver/bile ducts); Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy
Tests: Blood tests; Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI; ERCP; Magnetic resonance cholangiography; Laparoscopy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of gallstones is primarily based on symptoms and the results of diagnostic testing.  The most common diagnostic test is abdominal ultrasound; other imaging tests may be used if abdominal ultrasound is inconclusive or to identify complications. Blood tests help identify any related complications like infection, jaundice, or pancreatitis.
Treatments: Surgery to remove the gallbladder (cholecystectomy); Medications to dissolve gallstones; Laparoscopic cholecystectomy
Tests: Abdominal ultrasound; Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS); Oral cholecystography; Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan; Computerized tomography (CT); Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP); Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP); Blood tests

Diagnosis: Physical exam (palpation and transillumination); Imaging tests (X-ray, ultrasound, MRI); Fluid aspiration (analysis of cyst fluid).  Fluid from a ganglion cyst is thick and clear.
Treatments: Observation; Joint immobilization (brace or splint); Aspiration (needle drainage); Surgery
Tests: Physical exam; X-ray; Ultrasound; MRI; Fluid aspiration

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of gangrene involves assessing symptoms, identifying potential causes (e.g., injury, infection, reduced blood flow), and using various tests to confirm the extent and severity of tissue damage.  A high white blood cell count may indicate infection.  Examination of fluid or tissue samples under a microscope can reveal signs of cell death and identify bacteria. Imaging tests help visualize the affected area.
Treatments: Medication; Surgery (Debridement; Vascular surgery; Amputation; Skin grafting); Hyperbaric oxygen therapy
Tests: Blood tests; Fluid or tissue culture; X-rays; CT scans; MRI scans; Surgery (for further examination)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical history, review of dietary habits, and a physical exam including abdominal palpation for tenderness and auscultation with a stethoscope to assess digestive tract function.  Additional diagnostic tests may be ordered depending on the exam findings and presence of other symptoms like weight loss, blood in stool, or diarrhea.
Treatments: Dietary changes; Lifestyle modifications; Over-the-counter medications; Treatment of underlying condition (if applicable)
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: Alpha-galactosidase (Beano, BeanAssist, others); Lactase supplements (Lactaid, Digest Dairy Plus, others); Simethicone (Gas-X, Mylanta Gas Minis, others); Activated charcoal (Actidose-Aqua, CharcoCaps, others)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is suspected based on medical history and physical exam.  Further testing may include tests for H. pylori (stool test or breath test); upper endoscopy with potential biopsy; and/or upper digestive system X-ray (barium swallow).  Endoscopy may be recommended as a first test depending on age and medical history.
Treatments: Stopping NSAID or alcohol use (if applicable); Antibiotics for H. pylori; Proton pump inhibitors; Acid blockers (histamine blockers); Antacids; Acetaminophen (as an alternative pain reliever).
Tests: Stool test for H. pylori; Breath test for H. pylori; Upper endoscopy; Biopsy; Upper digestive system X-ray (barium swallow)
Medications_Drugs: Antibiotics; Proton pump inhibitors; Acid blockers; Antacids; Acetaminophen

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a history of symptoms and physical examination.  Confirmation may involve upper endoscopy to visualize the esophagus and stomach and check for complications like Barrett's esophagus; ambulatory acid (pH) probe test to measure acid reflux; X-ray of the upper digestive system to assess swallowing difficulties and esophageal narrowing; esophageal manometry to evaluate esophageal muscle contractions and swallowing function; and transnasal esophagoscopy to examine the esophagus for damage.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes; Nonprescription medicines; Prescription medicines; Deep-breathing training; Fundoplication; LINX device; Transoral incisionless fundoplication (TIF); Weight-loss surgery
Tests: Upper endoscopy; Ambulatory acid (pH) probe test; X-ray of the upper digestive system; Esophageal manometry; Transnasal esophagoscopy; Biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Mylanta; Rolaids; Tums; cimetidine (Tagamet HB); famotidine (Pepcid AC); nizatidine (Axid); lansoprazole (Prevacid); omeprazole (Prilosec OTC); esomeprazole (Nexium); esomeprazole (Nexium); lansoprazole (Prevacid); omeprazole (Prilosec); pantoprazole (Protonix); rabeprazole (Aciphex); dexlansoprazole (Dexilant); prescription-strength famotidine; prescription-strength nizatidine; vonoprazan (Voquezna); tegoprazan (K-Cab)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with taking a medical history and performing a physical exam.  Further diagnosis involves a variety of tests to locate the source of bleeding.  The severity of the bleeding influences the choice of tests.
Treatments: Medication; Procedures during a test (e.g., treating a bleeding peptic ulcer during an upper endoscopy, removing polyps during a colonoscopy); IV fluids; Blood transfusions; Stopping blood-thinning medications
Tests: Blood tests; Stool tests; Nasogastric lavage; Upper endoscopy; Colonoscopy; Capsule endoscopy; Flexible sigmoidoscopy; Balloon-assisted enteroscopy; Angiography; CT scan of the belly
Medications_Drugs: Proton pump inhibitor (PPI); Aspirin; Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing symptoms and medical history.  Further investigation may include imaging tests (ultrasound, CT, MRI, PET scans) to locate and assess tumor size; upper endoscopy to visualize the esophagus, stomach, and the first part of the small intestine; endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) with potential fine-needle aspiration biopsy to obtain tissue samples for laboratory analysis to confirm the presence of cancer cells and determine their characteristics.  Surgery may be necessary if biopsy is insufficient.
Treatments: Surgery; Targeted therapy
Tests: Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI scan; PET scan; Upper endoscopy; Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS); Fine-needle aspiration biopsy; Laboratory tests on biopsies

Diagnosis: Gastroparesis is diagnosed primarily through gastric emptying tests, such as scintigraphy (the main diagnostic test) and breath tests, which measure how quickly the stomach empties.  Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy helps rule out other conditions with similar symptoms. Ultrasound may be used to identify other potential causes of symptoms.
Treatments: Dietary changes (smaller, more frequent meals; well-chewed food; low-fiber, low-fat foods; avoiding carbonated drinks and alcohol; separating food and drink intake; gentle exercise after meals); Medications; Surgical treatment (jejunostomy tube placement; gastric venting tube); Gastric electrical stimulation;  Alternative medicine (acupuncture, electroacupuncture).
Tests: Scintigraphy; Breath tests; Upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy; Ultrasound
Medications_Drugs: Metoclopramide (Reglan, Gimoti); Erythromycin; Domperidone; Diphenhydramine (Benadryl); Ondansetron; Prochlorperazine (Compro); Relamorelin (under study)

Diagnosis: Gaucher disease is diagnosed through a combination of physical examination (assessing organ size, movement, coordination, reflexes, and skin bruising), blood tests to analyze the enzyme associated with the disease, and genetic analysis to identify related gene changes.  Imaging tests help detect tissue and organ damage.
Treatments: Enzyme replacement therapy; Medications to reduce fatty substances; Medications to treat bone pain and limit bone loss; Splenectomy; Bone marrow transplant (rarely used due to risks); Supportive care and pain management (for types 2 and 3)
Tests: Blood tests; Genetic analysis; MRI scans; Ultrasounds; X-rays; Dual x-ray absorptiometry; Prenatal screening (for enzyme levels and gene mutations)

Diagnosis: Distress due to gender identity differing from sex assigned at birth lasting at least six months and involving two or more of the following: difference between gender identity and genitals or secondary sex characteristics; strong desire to be rid of or prevent development of secondary sex characteristics; strong desire to have genitals and secondary sex characteristics of another gender; strong desire to be or be treated as another gender; strong belief of having typical feelings and behaviors of another gender; distress impacting daily life.  In young teens, distress may be caused by a difference between gender identity and expected secondary sex characteristic development.
Treatments: Changes in gender expression (clothing, mannerisms, communication style, interests); Gender-affirming hormone therapy; Gender-affirming surgery (chest, genitals, facial features); Supportive behavioral health therapy; Voice and communication therapy; Hair removal or hair transplants; Genital tucking; Chest binding; Breast padding; Genital packing; Legal services for name and gender changes; Services to assist with appearance; Social and community services.
Tests: Review of personal and family medical history; Physical exam; Lab tests; Review of vaccinations; Screening tests for some conditions and diseases;  Assessment for tobacco use, drug use, alcohol use disorder, and HIV or other sexually transmitted infections; Evaluation of fertility and potential fertility preservation needs; Behavioral health evaluation assessing gender health goals, mental health concerns, sexual health concerns, impact of gender dysphoria on daily life, substance use, and support systems.

Diagnosis: Physical exam to rule out medical causes; detailed questioning about symptoms and medical history; use of psychological questionnaires; application of DSM-5 criteria.
Treatments: Psychotherapy (cognitive behavioral therapy); Medications
Tests: Blood or urine tests
Medications_Drugs: escitalopram (Lexapro); duloxetine (Cymbalta); venlafaxine (Effexor XR); paroxetine (Paxil, Pexeva); buspirone; benzodiazepines

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is typically made through physical examination and history of sexual activity; confirmation involves taking a sample from an active sore and testing for herpes simplex virus (HSV-1 or HSV-2); blood tests may be used less often for confirmation or ruling out other infections.
Treatments: Prescription antiviral pills to help sores heal during a first outbreak; reduce frequency of recurrent outbreaks; lessen severity and duration of symptoms in recurrent outbreaks; reduce chance of passing the virus to a partner
Tests: Sample from active sore tested for HSV-1 or HSV-2; Blood test

Diagnosis: Physical exam; Biopsy; Pap test (for women); HPV test (for women age 30 and older)
Treatments: Observation (if asymptomatic); Topical medications; Surgery; Cryotherapy; Electrocautery; Surgical excision; Laser treatment
Tests: Physical exam; Biopsy; Pap test; HPV test
Medications_Drugs: Imiquimod (Zyclara); Podophyllin (Podocon-25); Podofilox (Condylox); Trichloroacetic acid; Sinecatechins (Veregen)

Diagnosis: Geographic atrophy is diagnosed through several tests assessing visual acuity, retinal changes, and detecting damaged cells.  Visual acuity and reading tests check vision; dilated fundus exam visualizes retinal changes; optical coherence tomography (OCT) scans the retina for thinning or damage; fundus autofluorescence (FAF) images the retina to identify damaged cells; and the Amsler grid helps detect blurry spots.
Treatments: Injections of avacincaptad pegol (Izervay) and pegcetacoplan (Syfovre); Gene therapy (under study) ; Regular follow-up exams; Amsler grid monitoring at home; Lifestyle modifications (brighter lights, magnifying tools, etc.)
Tests: Visual acuity and reading tests; Dilated fundus exam; Optical coherence tomography (OCT); Fundus autofluorescence (FAF); Amsler grid

Diagnosis: Visual examination of the tongue using a lighted instrument; assessment of tongue movement and texture; checking for tenderness; ruling out other conditions such as oral lichen planus.
Treatments: Pain relievers; mouth rinses; antihistamine mouth rinses; corticosteroid ointments or rinses; vitamin B or zinc; medications for fungal infections.
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: Pain relievers; antihistamines; corticosteroids; vitamin B; zinc; medications for fungal infections.

Diagnosis: Germ cell tumors are diagnosed using imaging tests (ultrasound, CT scan, MRI) to visualize the tumor's size and location; blood tests (tumor marker tests) to detect proteins produced by cancer cells; and surgery to obtain tissue samples for biopsy and definitive diagnosis.  The appearance of lumps or masses on imaging, along with elevated tumor markers, may suggest the possibility of cancer, necessitating surgical removal for confirmation.
Treatments: Surgery; Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy
Tests: Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI; Blood test (tumor marker test); Biopsy

Diagnosis: Screening test during the second trimester (24-28 weeks) for average-risk individuals; earlier screening for high-risk individuals (potentially during the first prenatal visit). High-risk factors include pre-pregnancy obesity, family history of diabetes, and prior gestational diabetes.  Diagnosis is confirmed with either a glucose challenge test (blood sugar level ≥190 mg/dL or 10.6 mmol/L one hour post-glucose ingestion) followed by a glucose tolerance test (two of three blood sugar readings higher than expected after a higher-sugar drink) or directly with the glucose tolerance test if initial blood sugar is elevated.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (diet and exercise); Blood sugar monitoring; Insulin injections; Oral medications (though research on their efficacy and safety is ongoing)
Tests: Initial glucose challenge test; Follow-up glucose tolerance test; Ultrasound; other tests (not specified)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis can be difficult due to similar symptoms to other conditions.  Diagnosis involves reviewing symptoms and medical history, a physical exam focusing on temporal arteries (checking for tenderness, reduced pulse, and hard texture), and various tests to rule out other causes.  A temporal artery biopsy is the most definitive diagnostic method, though a negative biopsy doesn't rule out the condition.
Treatments: High doses of corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone);  Immune-suppressing drugs (e.g., methotrexate); Tocilizumab (Actemra);  Calcium and vitamin D supplements; Low-dose aspirin (75-150mg daily)
Tests: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (sed rate); C-reactive protein (CRP); Doppler ultrasound; Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA); Positron emission tomography (PET); Temporal artery biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Prednisone; Methotrexate (Trexall); Tocilizumab (Actemra); Aspirin; Calcium supplements; Vitamin D supplements

Diagnosis: Stool sample examination for the presence of parasites; Multiple stool samples may be collected over several days for accuracy;  Tests may be used to monitor treatment effectiveness.
Treatments: For severe or persistent symptoms; Medication;  In asymptomatic cases, treatment is usually not needed unless there's a risk of spreading the parasites; Many people recover on their own within weeks.
Tests: Stool examination

Diagnosis: Elevated bilirubin level in the blood; unexplained jaundice; dark urine; abdominal pain.  A complete blood count and liver function tests may be ordered to rule out other liver conditions. Genetic testing can confirm the diagnosis.  The combination of standard blood counts and liver enzymes with an elevated bilirubin level is an indicator.
Treatments: Information not found
Tests: Bilirubin test; Complete blood count (CBC); Liver function tests; Genetic testing

Diagnosis: Clinical examination of teeth, gums, mouth, and tongue for plaque, irritation, or swelling; Measurement of pocket depth between gums and teeth using a dental probe (pockets deeper than 4 mm may indicate gum disease); Review of dental and medical history; Dental X-rays to check for bone loss; Medical evaluation if the cause of gingivitis is unclear.
Treatments: Professional dental cleaning (scaling and root planing); Dental repairs (if necessary to address irritants); Ongoing care with good oral hygiene at home; Regular dental checkups.
Tests: Dental probe measurement of pocket depth; Dental X-rays

Diagnosis: Comprehensive eye exam including medical history review; measurement of intraocular pressure (tonometry); testing for optic nerve damage (dilated eye exam and imaging tests); checking for visual field loss; measurement of corneal thickness (pachymetry); inspection of the drainage angle (gonioscopy).
Treatments: Prescription eye drops; Oral medicines; Laser treatment; Surgery;  Laser trabeculoplasty; Filtering surgery (trabeculectomy); Drainage tubes; Minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS); Laser peripheral iridotomy
Tests: Tonometry; Dilated eye exam; Imaging tests; Visual field test; Pachymetry; Gonioscopy
