Medications_Drugs: latanoprost (Xalatan); travoprost (Travatan Z); tafluprost (Zioptan); bimatoprost (Lumigan); latanoprostene bunod (Vyzulta); timolol (Betimol, Istalol, Timoptic); betaxolol (Betoptic S); apraclonidine (Iopidine); brimonidine (Alphagan P, Qoliana); dorzolamide; brinzolamide (Azopt); netarsudil (Rhopressa); pilocarpine (Isopto Carpine); Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (oral)

Diagnosis: Glioblastoma is diagnosed through a neurological exam assessing vision, hearing, balance, coordination, strength, and reflexes; imaging tests such as MRI (sometimes with contrast dye), CT, and PET scans to locate and size the tumor; and a biopsy to confirm cancerous cells and glioblastoma cell type.  Further testing of cancer cells informs prognosis and treatment planning.
Treatments: Surgery to remove glioblastoma (as much as possible); Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy (oral pills, intravenous, or wafers implanted during surgery); Tumor treating fields (TTF) therapy; Targeted therapy; Palliative care; Clinical trials;  Medicine to control seizures; Steroid medicines to reduce brain swelling; Medicine to help with headaches
Tests: Neurological exam; MRI; CT scan; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; Needle biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Steroids;  Chemotherapy medications (specific names not provided); Medications to control seizures; Medications to help with headaches

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a neurological exam assessing vision, hearing, balance, coordination, strength, and reflexes; brain imaging (primarily MRI, sometimes with contrast, CT, and PET scans); and a biopsy (stereotactic needle biopsy if surgery isn't an option) to analyze tumor cells and determine glioma type and growth rate, including DNA changes.
Treatments: Surgery (including subtotal resection); Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Tumor treating fields therapy; Targeted therapy; Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Speech therapy; Tutoring (for school-age children)
Tests: Neurological exam; MRI; CT scan; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; Biopsy (including stereotactic needle biopsy)
Medications_Drugs: Steroids; Medications to control seizures; Medications to improve alertness; Medications to help with thinking and memory problems; Medications to manage chemotherapy side effects

Diagnosis: Glomerulonephritis may be identified through tests performed during acute illness or routine checkups.  Diagnosis involves assessing kidney function using urine and blood tests to detect abnormalities like red blood cells, proteins, white blood cells, and waste product levels in urine and blood. Imaging tests (X-ray, ultrasound, CT scan) may reveal kidney irregularities. A kidney biopsy confirms the diagnosis and assesses tissue damage.
Treatments: Treatment depends on disease form (acute or chronic), underlying cause, and symptom severity. Some acute cases resolve without treatment.  Treatment targets the underlying cause (e.g., high blood pressure, infection, autoimmune disease).  Dialysis (for acute kidney failure due to infection) and kidney transplant (for end-stage kidney disease) are therapies for associated kidney failure. Lifestyle changes (reduced salt and protein intake, weight management, blood sugar control, smoking cessation) are recommended.
Tests: Urine test; Blood tests; X-ray; Ultrasound exam; CT scan; Kidney biopsy

Diagnosis: A goiter is often discovered during a routine physical exam by palpating the neck for thyroid enlargement;  Additional tests are ordered to measure thyroid size, detect nodules, assess thyroid function (overactive or underactive), and determine the cause.
Treatments: Wait-and-see approach; Medication; Surgery (total or partial thyroidectomy); Radioactive iodine treatment
Tests: Thyroid function tests; Antibody test; Ultrasonography; Radioactive iodine uptake; Biopsy; Radioactive iodine scan
Medications_Drugs: levothyroxine; liothyronine; methimazole; atenolol; metoprolol; aspirin; naproxen sodium; ibuprofen

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical history and physical exam, including pressure to the affected area and range-of-motion testing of the elbow, wrist, and fingers; X-ray may rule out other causes such as fracture or arthritis; MRI is rarely used.
Treatments: Avoiding painful activities; Ice; Rest; Counterforce brace; Stretching and strengthening exercises; Progressive loading strength training;  Platelet-rich plasma injection; Surgery (TENEX procedure in cases unresponsive to conservative treatment); Gradual return to activity with technique correction.
Tests: X-ray; MRI

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves analyzing a sample of cells collected via urine test to identify bacteria in the urethra; swab of the affected area (throat, urethra, vagina, or rectum) to collect bacteria for lab identification.  At-home tests may provide preliminary results, but confirmation by a healthcare professional is necessary.
Treatments: Antibiotic treatment; Partner notification and treatment
Tests: Urine test; Swab of affected area (throat, urethra, vagina, or rectum)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on symptoms and joint appearance;  Joint fluid test to visualize urate crystals under a microscope; Blood test to measure uric acid levels (though results can be misleading); X-ray imaging to rule out other causes; Ultrasound to detect urate crystals; Dual-energy computerized tomography (DECT) to visualize urate crystals.
Treatments: Medications to reduce inflammation and pain during attacks; Medications to prevent complications by lowering uric acid levels; Lifestyle changes including diet and exercise.
Tests: Joint fluid test; Blood test; X-ray imaging; Ultrasound; Dual-energy computerized tomography (DECT)
Medications_Drugs: ibuprofen; naproxen sodium; indomethacin; celecoxib; colchicine; prednisone; allopurinol; febuxostat; probenecid

Diagnosis: Visual examination of the affected skin; Skin biopsy examined under a microscope.
Treatments: Corticosteroid creams or ointments; Corticosteroid injections; Freezing (liquid nitrogen application); Light therapy; Oral antibiotics; Oral antimalarials
Tests: Skin biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing symptoms and health history, physical exam, and various tests to confirm the presence of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA).  Key indicators include antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) in the blood and characteristic inflammation seen in tissue biopsies.
Treatments: Medications; Plasma exchange
Tests: Blood tests (including C-reactive protein, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, ANCA, and complete blood count); Urine tests; Chest X-rays; CT scans; Biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Corticosteroids; Rituximab (Rituxan); Azathioprine (Azasan, Imuran); Mycophenolate (CellCept, Myhibbin); Methotrexate (Trexall); Cyclophosphamide; Avacopan (Tavneos)

Diagnosis: Physical exam; review of medical and family history; blood tests to measure TSH and thyroid hormone levels and detect Graves' disease antibodies; radioactive iodine uptake test and scan.
Treatments: Radioactive iodine therapy; Anti-thyroid medications; Beta blockers; Surgery (thyroidectomy); Corticosteroids (for thyroid eye disease); Teprotumumab (for thyroid eye disease); Prisms (for double vision); Orbital decompression surgery (for thyroid eye disease); Orbital radiotherapy (for thyroid eye disease)
Tests: Blood tests (TSH, thyroid hormones, Graves' disease antibodies); Radioactive iodine uptake; Radioactive iodine scan; CT scan; MRI
Medications_Drugs: Propylthiouracil; Methimazole; Propranolol; Atenolol; Metoprolol; Nadolol; Corticosteroids; Teprotumumab

Diagnosis: In newborns, a blood or spinal fluid sample is tested for the bacteria.  For adults with suspected infection, a blood test is used to identify group B strep as the causative agent.  Additional tests for infants may include urine culture; lumbar puncture; chest X-ray.
Treatments: IV antibiotics (infants); antibiotics (adults); IV fluids (infants); oxygen (infants); other medications (infants); oral antibiotics (pregnant adults with GBS-related medical problems).
Tests: Blood test; spinal fluid sample; urine culture; lumbar puncture; chest X-ray

Diagnosis: A diagnosis of growing pains usually doesn't require testing.  In some cases, blood tests or X-rays may be recommended to rule out other conditions.
Treatments: No specific treatment; Self-care measures such as leg massage, heat application (heating pad or warm bath), ibuprofen, acetaminophen, and stretching exercises.
Tests: Blood test; X-ray

Diagnosis: X-rays of both the injured and uninjured limb are compared;  Sometimes X-rays may not show the fracture; tenderness over the growth plate may lead to a cast or splint; MRI, CT, or ultrasound may be used for more serious injuries;  Follow-up X-rays are recommended for several years to monitor growth plate healing.
Treatments: Cast; Splint; Surgery (for fractures crossing the growth plate or into the joint, and those not well-aligned)
Tests: X-ray; MRI; CT scan; Ultrasound

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is challenging in early stages due to similar symptoms to other conditions; involves medical history, thorough physical exam, lumbar puncture (spinal tap) to test spinal fluid for characteristic changes; electromyography (EMG) to measure nerve activity; nerve conduction studies to measure nerve signal speed.
Treatments: Plasma exchange (plasmapheresis); Immunoglobulin therapy; Pain relief medication; Blood clot prevention medication; Physical therapy; Adaptive device training;  Caregiver-assisted movement.
Tests: Lumbar puncture (spinal tap); Electromyography (EMG); Nerve conduction studies

Diagnosis: Physical exam to assess influenza symptoms; review of symptoms; influenza virus tests (e.g., polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test); tests may be used to rule out other conditions such as heart problems, lung and breathing problems, brain and nervous system problems, septic shock, or organ failure.  Testing is not always necessary.
Treatments: Symptom relief (rest, fluids, pain relievers); antiviral medications (for high-risk individuals or those with severe symptoms)
Tests: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test; other influenza virus tests
Medications_Drugs: Oseltamivir (Tamiflu); Zanamivir (Relenza); Peramivir (Rapivab); Baloxavir (Xofluza); Acetaminophen (Tylenol); Ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB)

Diagnosis: Physical exam focusing on diet, hair care routine, and medical/family history;  Assessment of hair shedding via pull test; Microscopic examination of hair roots (scalp biopsy) and hair shafts (light microscopy); Blood tests to identify underlying medical conditions.
Treatments: Medications; Hair transplant surgery; Laser therapy; Addressing underlying medical conditions; Lifestyle and home remedies (e.g., volumizing styling products, hair coloring, hairstyles, wigs, extensions, shaving).
Tests: Blood test; Pull test; Scalp biopsy; Light microscopy

Diagnosis: Physical exam to assess spleen size; Complete blood count (CBC) with differential to measure blood cell levels; Peripheral blood smear to identify hairy cell leukemia cells under a microscope; Bone marrow biopsy to examine bone marrow for leukemia cells; Lab tests to analyze leukemia cells' DNA changes; Computerized tomography (CT) scan to assess spleen and lymph node swelling.
Treatments: Chemotherapy; Targeted drug therapy; Splenectomy (implied, mentioned in "More Information" section)
Tests: Physical exam; Complete blood count (CBC) with differential; Peripheral blood smear; Bone marrow biopsy; Lab tests (DNA analysis); Computerized tomography (CT) scan

Diagnosis: A healthcare professional inspects the foot to diagnose hammertoe or mallet toe; X-rays may be used to visualize bones and joints, but are not always necessary.
Treatments: Roomier footwear; Orthotics (shoe inserts); Shoe pads; Taping; Toe exercises (e.g., picking up marbles, scrunching a towel); Surgery (tendon release; bone removal).
Tests: X-rays

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing swelling, tenderness, and pain location in the back of the thigh;  evaluation of range of motion to identify the affected muscle and potential ligament or tendon damage.
Treatments: Rest; Ice; Compression; Elevation (RICE); Pain medication; Physical therapy; Surgery (for severe tears or avulsion fractures)
Tests: X-ray; Ultrasound; MRI

Diagnosis: Evaluation of the child's age, symptoms, and rash or sores appearance; Throat swab; Stool specimen; Lab analysis to identify the causative virus.
Treatments: No specific treatment; Topical oral anesthetic for mouth sore pain relief; Over-the-counter pain medications (acetaminophen or ibuprofen) for general discomfort; Rest; Adequate fluid intake to prevent dehydration; Avoidance of irritants such as cigarette smoke;  Soothing measures like ice pops, ice cream, cold or warm drinks, soft foods, and warm salt water rinses.
Tests: Throat swab; Stool specimen

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is typically self-evident based on the presence of characteristic symptoms following alcohol consumption, such as tiredness, dry mouth, headache, nausea, cognitive impairment, and light/sound sensitivity.  A healthcare professional's consultation is only advised if hangovers significantly impact quality of life.
Treatments: Time; Hydration with water or fruit juice; Bland foods such as toast, crackers, or bouillon soup; Over-the-counter pain relievers (e.g., ibuprofen, acetaminophen - with caution); Rest.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Blood tests can reveal the presence of antibodies to a hantavirus; other laboratory tests may be used to rule out conditions with similar symptoms.
Treatments: Supportive therapy; Intubation and mechanical ventilation; Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO)
Tests: Blood tests

Diagnosis: Physical exam; Review of medical history; TSH test; T-4 tests; Antibody tests (for thyroid peroxidase antibodies and other antibodies associated with Hashimoto's disease).  Diagnosis is based on symptoms, physical exam, and blood tests revealing hypothyroidism and the presence of specific antibodies.
Treatments: T-4 hormone replacement therapy; T-3 hormone replacement therapy (in some cases);  Monitoring of TSH levels and dosage adjustments.  For mild hypothyroidism, regular TSH monitoring may suffice.
Tests: TSH test; T-4 tests; Thyroid peroxidase antibody test; Other antibody tests associated with Hashimoto's disease

Diagnosis: Physical exam; discussion of symptoms and potential triggers; skin prick test (detects allergic reaction via raised bump at allergen site); allergy blood test (measures IgE antibodies).
Treatments: Limiting exposure to triggers; nonprescription medications; prescription medications; immunotherapy; nasal saline rinses
Tests: Skin prick test; Allergy blood test
Medications_Drugs: fluticasone (Flonase Allergy Relief); budesonide (Rhinocort Allergy); triamcinolone (Nasacort Allergy 24HR); mometasone (Nasonex 24HR Allergy); azelastine and fluticasone (Dymista); mometasone and olopatadine (Ryaltris); loratadine (Claritin, Alavert); cetirizine; fexofenadine (Allegra Allergy); olopatadine (Pataday, Patanol); ketotifen (Alaway, Zaditor); azelastine (Astepro Allergy); olopatadine; pseudoephedrine (Sudafed); phenylephrine hydrochloride (Neo-Synephrine); oxymetazoline (Afrin); cromolyn sodium; montelukast (Singulair); ipratropium; prednisone

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a head and neck exam looking for sores or lumps; imaging tests (CT, MRI, PET scans) are used to show cancer size and location; a biopsy removes tissue for lab testing to confirm cancerous cells and may test for HPV.
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy; Palliative care
Tests: Head and neck exam; CT scan; MRI scan; PET scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Identification of a live nymph or adult louse through examination of wet hair lubricated with conditioner using a fine-toothed comb; Examination for nits (lice eggs), noting that nits more than 1/4 inch from the scalp are likely dead; Microscopic examination of suspect nits to determine if they are living.
Treatments: Nonprescription medication; Prescription medication; Wet-combing; Essential oils (limited evidence of effectiveness); Smothering agents (limited evidence of effectiveness).
Tests: Examination of wet hair with fine-toothed comb; Microscopic examination of nits; Wood's light examination (to visualize nits).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves detailed headache history (including frequency, severity, and triggers, potentially using a headache diary); physical exam (measuring height, weight, head circumference, blood pressure, pulse, and examining eyes, neck, head, and spine); neurological exam (checking movement, coordination, and sensation).  Further testing (MRI, CT scan, lumbar puncture) may be necessary if the child is not otherwise healthy or headaches are not the only symptom to rule out underlying conditions.
Treatments: Rest; decreased noise; plenty of fluids; balanced meals; over-the-counter pain relievers; relaxation training; biofeedback training; cognitive behavioral therapy
Tests: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Spinal tap (lumbar puncture)

Diagnosis: Hearing loss is diagnosed through a physical exam to check for earwax, infection, or structural abnormalities; screening tests like a whisper test to assess hearing sensitivity; app-based hearing tests; tuning fork tests to locate the site of hearing damage; and audiometer tests by an audiologist to determine the extent and type of hearing loss.
Treatments: Removing earwax; Surgery (e.g., tubes for ear drainage); Hearing aids; Cochlear implants
Tests: Physical exam; Whisper test; App-based hearing tests; Tuning fork tests; Audiometer tests

Diagnosis: A healthcare professional examines the patient, reviews their medical history and symptoms, and may order tests to check the heart and identify underlying conditions causing irregular heartbeat.
Treatments: Regular checkups; Medicines; Vagal maneuvers; Cardioversion; Cardiac catheter ablation; Pacemakers; Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD); Maze procedure; Coronary bypass graft surgery
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; Event recorder; Echocardiogram; Implantable loop recorder; Stress test; Tilt table test; Electrophysiological (EP) testing and mapping

Diagnosis: Screening for risk factors during regular checkups; Emergency assessment of symptoms and medical history; Checking blood pressure, pulse, and temperature; Tests to evaluate heart function and overall heart health.
Treatments: Oxygen; Clot busters (thrombolytics or fibrinolytics); Coronary angioplasty and stenting;  Surgical procedures to open blocked arteries.
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Blood tests (for cardiac markers); Chest X-ray; Echocardiogram; Coronary catheterization (angiogram); Cardiac Computerized Tomography (CT); Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)
Medications_Drugs: Aspirin; Heparin; Nitroglycerin; Morphine; Beta blockers; Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors; Statins

Diagnosis: Physical examination including listening to the heart; Review of symptoms, personal and family medical history.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (diet low in salt and saturated fat, increased exercise, smoking cessation); Medications; Heart procedures; Heart surgery
Tests: Blood tests (for heart proteins, high-sensitivity C-reactive protein, cholesterol, and blood sugar); Chest X-ray; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitoring; Echocardiogram; Exercise tests or stress tests; Cardiac catheterization; Heart CT scan; Heart magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan
Medications_Drugs: Daily aspirin therapy (mentioned as a treatment, but not specified as a medication for all heart diseases)

Diagnosis: Physical examination assessing symptoms, medical history, and risk factors (high blood pressure, coronary artery disease, diabetes); Auscultation for heart murmurs; Examination of neck veins and assessment for leg and abdominal swelling; Blood tests to diagnose associated diseases and measure heart proteins.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes; Medications; Surgery to open blocked arteries or implant cardiac devices
Tests: Blood tests; Chest X-ray; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Echocardiogram; Ejection fraction measurement; Exercise tests or stress tests; CT scan of the heart; Heart MRI scan; Coronary angiogram; Myocardial biopsy
Medications_Drugs: enalapril; lisinopril; captopril; losartan; valsartan; candesartan; sacubitril-valsartan; carvedilol; metoprolol; bisoprolol; furosemide; spironolactone; eplerenone; canagliflozin; dapagliflozin; empagliflozin; digoxin

Diagnosis: Heart murmurs may be detected during a physical exam;  A health care provider listens to the heart with a stethoscope, considering volume, location, pitch, timing (systolic, diastolic, or continuous), and sound changes with exercise or position change to determine if the murmur is innocent or worrisome.
Treatments: Monitoring; Medication; Surgery; Valve repair (patching holes, separating fused leaflets, replacing cords, removing excess tissue, tightening or reinforcing the ring); Valve replacement
Tests: Echocardiogram; Chest X-ray; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Cardiac catheterization
Medications_Drugs: warfarin (Jantoven); clopidogrel (Plavix); apixaban (Eliquis); rivaroxaban (Xarelto); dabigatran (Pradaxa); diuretics; Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors; Beta blockers; Antibiotics (in specific situations, e.g., artificial heart valves, history of heart valve infections, congenital heart defects)

Diagnosis: Physical exam including listening to the heart with a stethoscope and checking for conditions like swollen thyroid; review of medical history;  ECG/EKG to assess heart's electrical activity; Holter monitoring for 24-hour or longer heart rhythm recording; event recorder for intermittent symptoms; echocardiogram to visualize heart structure and blood flow; chest X-rays.
Treatments: Avoidance of triggers (stress, stimulants, illegal drugs); Treatment of underlying heart conditions (arrhythmias).
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitoring; Event recording; Echocardiogram; Chest X-rays

Diagnosis: Physical examination including auscultation for heart murmurs; review of symptoms and medical history; blood tests; echocardiogram; electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); chest X-ray; cardiac MRI; exercise or stress tests; cardiac catheterization (less frequently used, primarily for assessing severity).
Treatments: Regular health checkups; Lifestyle and diet changes; Medications; Surgery to repair or replace the valve; Annuloplasty; Valvuloplasty; Mechanical valve replacement; Biological valve replacement; Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR); Ross procedure
Tests: Echocardiogram; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Chest X-ray; Cardiac MRI; Exercise tests or stress tests; Cardiac catheterization

Diagnosis: To determine if heartburn is a symptom of GERD, doctors may recommend X-ray of the esophagus and stomach; endoscopy with potential biopsy; ambulatory acid probe tests; esophageal motility testing.  Diagnosis is based on a combination of symptoms and the results of these tests.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (Maintaining a healthy weight; Avoiding tight-fitting clothing; Avoiding trigger foods; Avoiding lying down after meals; Avoiding late meals; Elevating the head of the bed; Avoiding smoking and alcohol; Eating small, frequent meals); Nonprescription medications; Prescription medications (if nonprescription treatments are ineffective)
Tests: X-ray; Endoscopy; Biopsy; Ambulatory acid probe tests; Esophageal motility testing
Medications_Drugs: cimetidine (Tagamet HB); famotidine (Pepcid AC); esomeprazole (Nexium 24HR); lansoprazole (Prevacid 24HR); omeprazole (Prilosec OTC)

Diagnosis: Rectal temperature measurement to confirm diagnosis and rule out heatstroke; assessment of symptoms and progression to heatstroke.
Treatments: Rest in a cool place; Drink cool fluids (water or sports drinks); Cooling measures (cool shower, cool bath, cool water on skin, cool pond or stream); Loosen clothing; Cold water immersion; Evaporation cooling techniques; Ice packs and cooling blankets; Muscle relaxants (benzodiazepines) to stop shivering.
Tests: Blood test; Urine test; Muscle function tests; X-rays and other imaging.

Diagnosis: Clinical examination of the skin is usually sufficient for diagnosis;  A condition resembling heat rash, transient neonatal pustular melanosis (TNPM), mainly affects newborns with brown or Black skin and resolves without treatment.
Treatments: Cooling the skin; Avoiding heat exposure; Applying a cool cloth; Taking a cool shower or bath; Air drying the skin; Using a moisturizer with wool fat (anhydrous lanolin).
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Heatstroke is often diagnosed clinically based on symptoms and rectal temperature.  Laboratory tests may be used to confirm the diagnosis, rule out other causes, and assess organ damage.
Treatments: Immersion in cold water; Evaporation cooling techniques (misting with cool water and fanning); Packing with ice and cooling blankets; Muscle relaxants (e.g., benzodiazepines) to stop shivering
Tests: Rectal temperature; Blood test (sodium, potassium, blood gases); Urine test (color, kidney function); Muscle damage tests (rhabdomyolysis); X-rays and other imaging tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of heavy menstrual bleeding requires excluding other causes (menstrual disorders, medical conditions, medications) through a thorough medical history, menstrual cycle tracking, physical exam, and relevant tests.  A diagnosis is made only after ruling out other conditions.
Treatments: Medicines; Dilation and curettage (D&C); Uterine artery embolization; Focused ultrasound; Myomectomy; Endometrial ablation; Endometrial resection; Hysterectomy; Iron supplements
Tests: Blood tests; Pap test; Endometrial biopsy; Ultrasound; Sonohysterography; Hysteroscopy
Medications_Drugs: Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Tranexamic acid (Lysteda); Oral contraceptives; Oral progesterone; Progestin; Levonorgestrel (in hormonal IUDs such as Mirena, Liletta); Gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists; Gonadotropin-releasing hormone antagonists; Relugolix combined with estrogen and progestin (Myfembree); Elagolix with estrogen and progestin (Oriahnn); Elagolix (Orilissa); Iron supplements

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of H. pylori infection involves testing to determine if symptoms are caused by the bacteria.  Tests may include stool antigen test; stool PCR test; urea breath test; and upper endoscopy with biopsy.  The choice of test depends on factors such as symptom severity, patient age, and availability of testing resources.
Treatments: Treatment typically involves a combination of at least two antibiotics;  Treatment may also include proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and bismuth subsalicylate; Histamine (H-2) blockers may also be used.
Tests: Stool antigen test; Stool PCR test; Urea breath test; Upper endoscopy; Biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Omeprazole (Prilosec); Esomeprazole (Nexium); Lansoprazole (Prevacid); Pantoprazole (Protonix); Bismuth subsalicylate

Diagnosis: Visual inspection by a healthcare provider is usually sufficient for diagnosis; tests are typically not needed.
Treatments: Observation; Topical timolol gel; Oral propranolol; Corticosteroids (injection or topical application); Laser surgery
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Physical exam; MRI (may include magnetic resonance angiogram to visualize blood vessels near the facial nerve);  Imaging tests may be used if symptoms are atypical or surgery is being considered.  Diagnosis does not always require imaging.
Treatments: Botulinum toxin injections (Botox);  Other medications; Surgery (decompression, destroying parts of the facial nerve with surgery, heat, and radio waves (radiofrequency thermocoagulation))
Tests: MRI; Magnetic resonance angiogram
Medications_Drugs: Botulinum toxin (Botox); Anticonvulsant drugs (specific drug names not specified)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis can be challenging due to nonspecific early symptoms.  High iron levels in blood tests may be the first indication, often discovered incidentally during testing for other reasons.  Family history and genetic testing are also important diagnostic tools.  Further tests are used to confirm diagnosis and assess organ damage.
Treatments: Phlebotomy (regular blood removal); Chelation therapy (for those unable to undergo phlebotomy)
Tests: Serum transferrin saturation; Serum ferritin; Liver function tests; MRI; Testing for gene changes (HFE gene); Liver biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is confirmed through physical exam and lab tests showing damaged red blood cells, low platelet and red blood cell counts, and elevated creatinine levels.  Urine tests may reveal unusual protein and blood levels and signs of infection. Stool samples may identify E. coli and other bacteria.  Further testing may be needed if the cause isn't clear.
Treatments: Fluid and mineral replacement; Intravenous nutrition; Red blood cell transfusions; Platelet transfusions; Blood pressure medication; Eculizumab; Kidney dialysis; Plasma exchange; Kidney transplant
Tests: Blood tests; Urine test; Stool sample

Diagnosis: Severe hemophilia is usually diagnosed within the first year of life; mild forms may not be apparent until adulthood; diagnosis may occur after excessive bleeding during surgery; clotting-factor tests reveal clotting-factor deficiency and severity; genetic testing can identify carriers and fetal hemophilia.
Treatments: Clotting factor replacement therapy; Desmopressin; Emicizumab (Hemlibra); Clot-preserving medications (anti-fibrinolytics); Fibrin sealants; Physical therapy
Tests: Clotting-factor tests; Genetic testing
Medications_Drugs: Desmopressin; Emicizumab (Hemlibra); Acetaminophen; Aspirin; Ibuprofen; Heparin; Warfarin (Jantoven); Clopidogrel (Plavix); Prasugrel (Effient); Ticagrelor (Brilinta); Rivaroxaban (Xarelto); Apixaban (Eliquis); Edoxaban (Savaysa); Dabigatran (Pradaxa)

Diagnosis: External hemorrhoids may be visible during a physical exam; Internal hemorrhoids may require a digital rectal exam and visual inspection using an anoscope, proctoscope, or sigmoidoscopy; Colonoscopy may be indicated if symptoms suggest other digestive diseases, colorectal cancer risk factors are present, or if the patient is middle-aged and hasn't had a recent colonoscopy.
Treatments: High-fiber diet; Topical treatments (hydrocortisone cream/suppository, witch hazel pads, numbing medicine); Warm baths or sitz baths; Oral pain relievers (acetaminophen, aspirin, ibuprofen); Rubber band ligation; Sclerotherapy; Coagulation (laser, infrared light, or heat); Hemorrhoidectomy; Hemorrhoid stapling (stapled hemorrhoidopexy); External hemorrhoid thrombectomy
Tests: Digital rectal examination; Visual inspection (anoscope, proctoscope, sigmoidoscopy); Colonoscopy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical history, signs and symptoms, medication use, and results of blood tests and other tests.  Psychological exams (including animal naming tests), neuropsychological tests (like the Psychometric Hepatic Encephalopathy Score and continuous reaction time tests), and assessment of thinking, motor skills, speed, and hand coordination are used.  The West Haven criteria grade severity from 0 (no symptoms, detected only by tests) to 4 (hepatic coma, unresponsive).
Treatments: Treating the underlying cause; ICU treatment for severe cases; Bowel enema; TIPS surgery; Liver transplant; Lifestyle and dietary changes; Medication changes; Vitamin supplementation;  Regular exercise; Home modifications
Tests: Psychological exam; Neuropsychological tests; Blood tests (ammonia, electrolytes, glucose, C-reactive protein); Electroencephalogram (EEG); CT scan; MRI scan
Medications_Drugs: Lactulose; Rifaximin (Xifaxan); L-ornithine L-aspartate (LOLA); Polyethylene glycol laxatives; Zinc supplement

Diagnosis: Blood tests are used to detect the hepatitis A virus in the blood; these tests look for signs of the virus.
Treatments: Rest; Adequate food and liquid intake; Balanced healthy diet; Avoiding alcohol; Careful medication use
Tests: Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) blood test; Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) blood test

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing for symptoms of liver damage (e.g., yellowing skin, stomach pain); blood tests to detect hepatitis B virus and determine infection type (acute or chronic) and immunity status.  Liver ultrasound (transient elastography) to assess liver damage; liver biopsy to examine liver tissue for damage.
Treatments: Rest; Proper nutrition; Plenty of fluids; Close monitoring; Antiviral medications; Interferon shots; Liver transplant
Tests: Blood tests; Liver ultrasound (transient elastography); Liver biopsy
Medications_Drugs: entecavir (Baraclude); tenofovir (Viread); lamivudine (Epivir); adefovir (Hepsera); peginterferon alfa-2a (Pegasys); Immunoglobulin

Diagnosis: Screening blood tests detect hepatitis C; further blood tests measure viral load and determine genotype; liver damage assessment involves tests like magnetic resonance elastography (MRE), transient elastography, liver biopsy, and blood tests for liver scarring.
Treatments: Antiviral medicines; liver transplantation.
Tests: Blood test; viral load test; genotype test; magnetic resonance elastography (MRE); transient elastography; liver biopsy; alanine aminotransferase (ALT) blood test; aspartate aminotransferase (AST) blood test.

Diagnosis: Hepatopulmonary syndrome is diagnosed through tests that assess blood oxygen levels and rule out other heart or lung conditions.  Key diagnostic methods include arterial blood gas analysis, chest imaging (X-rays, CT scans, echocardiogram with saline contrast study), and pulse oximetry.
Treatments: Supplemental oxygen therapy; Liver transplant
Tests: Arterial blood gas; Chest X-ray; CT scan; Echocardiogram with saline contrast study; Pulse oximetry

Diagnosis: Physical exam; Imaging tests; Family history; Genetic testing.
Treatments: Treatment at HHT Center of Excellence; Ablation; Skin graft; Surgically closing the nostrils; Embolization; Surgical removal; Stereotactic radiotherapy; Liver transplant.
Tests: Ultrasound; MRI; Echocardiogram bubble study; CT scan.
Medications_Drugs: Tamoxifen (Soltamox); Raloxifene (Evista); Bevacizumab (Avastin); Pazopanib (Votrient); Pomalidomide (Pomalyst); Tacrolimus (Prograf, Protopic); Tranexamic acid (Cyklokapron, Lysteda); Iron replacement.

Diagnosis: In most cases, a physical exam and medical history are sufficient for diagnosis.  If other conditions are suspected or nerve involvement needs clarification, further testing is done.
Treatments: Conservative treatment (activity modification, pain medication); Physical therapy; Surgery (diskectomy, rarely spinal fusion or artificial disk implantation)
Tests: Physical exam; Neurological exam (checking reflexes, muscle strength, walking ability, sensation); X-ray; CT scan; MRI; Myelogram; Nerve conduction studies; Electromyogram (EMG)
Medications_Drugs: Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Gabapentin; Pregabalin; Duloxetine; Venlafaxine; Codeine; Oxycodone-acetaminophen combination; Corticosteroids

Diagnosis: Hiatal hernia is often discovered during a test or procedure for heartburn or chest/upper abdominal pain.  Diagnosis may involve X-ray of the upper digestive system; upper endoscopy; esophageal manometry.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes; Medications; Surgery
Tests: X-ray of upper digestive system; Upper endoscopy; Esophageal manometry
Medications_Drugs: Cimetidine (Tagamet HB); Famotadine (Pepcid AC); Nizatidine (Axid AR); Lansoprazole (Prevacid 24HR); Omeprazole (Prilosec, Zegerid); Antacids; Proton pump inhibitors; H-2-receptor blockers

Diagnosis: Physical exam including neurological exam (balance, coordination, muscle strength, reflexes, sight, touch);  If underlying condition suspected, further tests are recommended.
Treatments: Treating underlying condition (if present);  For hiccups lasting >2 days: medication; phrenic nerve block injection; vagus nerve stimulation device implantation; home remedies (breathing into a paper bag, gargling with ice water, holding breath, sipping cold water); lifestyle changes (avoiding carbonated beverages and gas-inducing foods, eating smaller meals); alternative medicine (hypnosis, acupuncture).
Tests: Blood tests; Chest X-ray; CT scan; MRI; Endoscopic tests (esophagoscopy)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on signs and symptoms, skin appearance, and medical history;  A dermatologist may be consulted; No specific laboratory test exists for diagnosis; Pus or drainage may be sampled for lab testing.
Treatments: Medications; Surgery;  Self-care measures (skin care routine, warm compresses, weight management, smoking cessation, dietary changes)
Tests: Pus or drainage culture
Medications_Drugs: Topical antibiotics; Doxycycline; Monodox; Clindamycin; Cleocin; Rifampin; Rimactane; Triamcinolone acetonide; Kenalog-10; Estrogen-containing combined oral contraceptives (estradiol, estradiol/norgestimate); Spironolactone; Isotretinoin; Adalimumab; Humira; Infliximab; Remicade; Oral retinoids; Stronger pain medications

Diagnosis: High blood pressure is diagnosed by measuring blood pressure using a blood pressure monitor; at least two readings should be taken one minute apart, in the morning before medication and in the evening before dinner;  considerations include which arm has higher readings and avoiding caffeine, exercise and smoking 30 minutes prior to measurement.  Erratic blood pressure (labile blood pressure) may require investigation into underlying causes such as heart, hormonal, neurological, or psychological problems.
Treatments: Lifestyle modifications including increased physical activity, weight loss, limiting alcohol, reducing sodium intake, and increasing dietary potassium intake;  Medication (specific medications not listed, but classes mentioned include diuretics and calcium channel blockers).
Tests: Blood pressure measurement

Diagnosis: Diagnosis requires blood pressure readings above normal on at least three separate visits;  determination of whether hypertension is primary or secondary through additional testing to identify underlying causes.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (heart-healthy diet, increased exercise, weight management); Blood pressure medication
Tests: Blood tests (kidney function, electrolytes, cholesterol, triglycerides); Urine sample test (urinalysis); Echocardiogram; Ultrasound of kidneys (renal ultrasound); Ambulatory blood pressure monitoring
Medications_Drugs: Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors; Angiotensin II receptor blockers; Calcium channel blockers; Diuretics

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a blood test, also called a lipid panel or lipid profile, to check cholesterol levels;  A 9-12 hour fast is usually required before the test, unless otherwise instructed by a healthcare professional.  Results show total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, and triglycerides. Interpretation uses guidelines based on mg/dL (US and some countries) or mmol/L (Canada and most of Europe).
Treatments: Lifestyle changes; Medication
Tests: Blood test (lipid panel; lipid profile)
Medications_Drugs: Atorvastatin (Lipitor); Fluvastatin (Lescol XL); Lovastatin (Altoprev); Pitavastatin (Livalo, Zypitamag); Pravastatin; Rosuvastatin (Crestor); Simvastatin (Zocor); Ezetimibe (Zetia); Bempedoic acid (Nexletol); Nexlizet; Cholestyramine (Prevalite); Colesevelam (Welchol); Colestipol (Colestid); Alirocumab (Praluent); Evolocumab (Repatha); Inclisiran (Leqvio); Fenofibrate (Lipofen); Gemfibrozil (Lopid); Niacin; Omega-3 fatty acids

Diagnosis: Physical examination during well-baby visits involves manipulating the infant's legs to assess hip joint fit;  If suspected, hip ultrasound may be ordered; In older children and adults, imaging tests such as X-rays or MRI may be used; Mild cases can be difficult to diagnose and may not cause symptoms until young adulthood.
Treatments: Pavlik harness; Spica cast; Periacetabular osteotomy; Hip replacement surgery
Tests: Hip ultrasound; X-rays; MRI

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is often based on symptoms, the abnormal position of the hip and leg; X-ray usually confirms the fracture and its location; MRI or bone scan may be used if X-ray is negative but hip pain persists.
Treatments: Prompt surgical repair; Rehabilitation; Medication to manage pain; Medication to prevent blood clots; Medication to prevent infection; Internal repair using screws; Metal screws with metal plate; Total hip replacement; Partial hip replacement
Tests: X-ray; MRI; Bone scan

Diagnosis: History taking regarding discomfort; Physical exam evaluating hip joint movement, pain, and range of motion; Observation of gait;  Anesthetic injection into the joint space to determine if pain originates within the hip joint.
Treatments: Rest; Modified activities; Arthroscopic surgery; Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs; Corticosteroid injection; Physical therapy
Tests: X-rays; Magnetic resonance arthrography (MRA)

Diagnosis: A physical exam and questions about bowel movements are performed.  Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy to identify missing nerve cells in a colon tissue sample; abdominal X-ray with contrast dye to visualize bowel narrowing; and anal manometry (in older children and adults) to assess rectal muscle control.
Treatments: Pull-through surgery; Ostomy surgery (two-step procedure involving initial ostomy creation and later closure)
Tests: Biopsy; Abdominal X-ray with contrast dye; Anal manometry
Medications_Drugs: Laxatives (only as directed by a doctor)

Diagnosis: Measurement of blood hormone levels (testosterone or testosterone-like hormones) to determine elevated androgen levels; abdominal and pelvic examination to identify potential tumors.
Treatments: Treating underlying disorders; self-care hair removal;  oral contraceptives; anti-androgens; topical cream; laser therapy; electrolysis; plucking; shaving; waxing; depilation; bleaching
Tests: Blood test measuring hormone levels; Abdominal examination; Pelvic examination

Diagnosis: Physical exam; review of medical history and travel history to areas where histoplasmosis is common; blood or urine tests; tests of saliva and mucus samples; chest X-ray; CT scan of the lungs; lung biopsy; bone marrow tests.
Treatments: Antifungal medications
Tests: Blood or urine tests; Tests of saliva and mucus sample; Chest X-ray; CT scan of the lungs; Lung biopsy; Bone marrow tests

Diagnosis: HIV diagnosis is made through blood or saliva tests, including antigen-antibody tests (detecting antigens and antibodies to HIV), antibody tests, and nucleic acid tests (NATs) which detect the virus itself.  A positive result may not show until 2-6 weeks (antigen-antibody), 3-12 weeks (antibody) or immediately (NAT) after exposure.  Follow-up tests may be needed.  AIDS is diagnosed when a person with HIV infection has a CD4 T cell count below 200.
Treatments: Antiretroviral therapy (ART)
Tests: Antigen-antibody tests; Antibody tests; Nucleic acid tests (NATs); CD4 T cell count; Viral load (HIV RNA); Medicine resistance tests; Tests for tuberculosis; Tests for hepatitis B or C; Tests for STIs; Liver function tests; Urinalysis; Tests for kidney damage; Tests for urinary tract infection; Tests for cervical and anal cancer; Tests for Cytomegalovirus; Tests for Toxoplasmosis
Medications_Drugs: efavirenz; rilpivirine (Edurant); doravirine (Pifeltro); abacavir (Ziagen); tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (Viread); emtricitabine (Emtriva); lamivudine (Epivir); zidovudine (Retrovir); emtricitabine-tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (Truvada); emtricitabine-tenofovir alafenamide fumarate (Descovy); atazanavir (Reyataz); darunavir (Prezista); lopinavir-ritonavir (Kaletra); bictegravir sodium-emtricitabine-tenofovir alafenamide fumarate (Biktarvy); raltegravir (Isentress); dolutegravir (Tivicay); cabotegravir (Vocabria); enfuvirtide (Fuzeon); maraviroc (Selzentry); ibalizumab-uiyk (Trogarzo); fostemsavir (Rukobia)

Diagnosis: Examination of welts or swelling; review of medical history; blood tests; allergy skin test.
Treatments: Avoidance of triggers; anti-itch drugs; drugs that suppress the immune system; drugs for hereditary angioedema; anti-inflammatory drugs; epinephrine injection; cool compresses; cool baths; loose clothing.
Tests: Blood tests; allergy skin test

Diagnosis: A mental health exam including questions about emotional well-being, beliefs and behaviors related to acquiring and saving items, the impact of clutter on quality of life;  interview with relatives and friends (with permission); review of pictures and videos of cluttered living spaces; assessment for co-occurring mental health conditions.
Treatments: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT); medication (for co-occurring anxiety or depression); in-home visits by therapist or professional organizer to remove clutter; family or group therapy; regular help from family, friends, and agencies to remove clutter.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Hodgkin lymphoma diagnosis begins with a physical exam checking for swollen lymph nodes; further investigation involves imaging tests and a lymph node biopsy to identify cancer cells.  The specific tests used depend on lymphoma location and symptoms.
Treatments: Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy; Immunotherapy; Targeted therapy; Bone marrow transplant (stem cell transplant)
Tests: Physical exam; Blood tests; Biopsy (lymph node; potentially liver); Chest X-ray; CT scan; MRI; PET scan; Bone marrow aspiration; Bone marrow biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on patient history and symptom assessment; an ophthalmologist may use medicated eye drops to compare pupil reactions in the affected and healthy eye to confirm nerve damage; additional tests and imaging may be used to locate the site of nerve damage.
Treatments: There's no specific treatment for Horner syndrome itself; treatment focuses on addressing the underlying medical condition.
Tests: Medicated eye drops (to assess pupil reaction); Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA); Chest X-ray; Computerized tomography (CT); Carotid ultrasound; Urinalysis

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is most often based on reported symptoms; blood tests may be done to check for cessation of periods or other potential causes.
Treatments: Estrogen therapy; Antidepressants; Anti-seizure medications; Oxybutynin; Clonidine; Fezolinetant; Stellate ganglion block
Tests: Blood tests
Medications_Drugs: Paroxetine (Brisdelle); Venlafaxine (Effexor XR); Paroxetine (Paxil); Citalopram (Celexa); Escitalopram (Lexapro); Gabapentin (Neurontin, Gralise); Pregabalin (Lyrica); Oxybutynin (Oxytrol); Clonidine (Catapres-TTS 1, Nexiclon XR); Fezolinetant (Veozah); Bazedoxifene with conjugated estrogens (Duavee)

Diagnosis: Visual inspection of warts; Acetic acid solution test (vinegar solution); Pap smear; DNA test (to identify HPV types linked to genital cancers, recommended for women 30 and older).
Treatments: Wart removal (often resolves without treatment, especially in children); Salicylic acid application; Imiquimod (Zyclara) cream; Podofilox (Condylox) application; Trichloroacetic acid application; Cryotherapy (freezing with liquid nitrogen); Electrocautery (burning with electric current); Surgical removal; Laser surgery; Colposcopy with biopsy (for cervical HPV); Cryosurgery; Laser surgical removal of precancerous lesions; Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP); Cold knife conization.
Tests: Acetic acid solution test; Pap smear; DNA test
Medications_Drugs: Salicylic acid; Imiquimod (Zyclara); Podofilox (Condylox); Trichloroacetic acid

Diagnosis: Preliminary diagnosis is based on patient history (answers to questions, family medical history), general physical exam, neurological exam (assessing motor, sensory, and psychiatric symptoms), and mental health evaluation (assessing emotional state, behavior patterns, judgment, coping skills, disordered thinking, and substance abuse).  Neuropsychological testing (memory, reasoning, mental agility, language and spatial reasoning skills) may be conducted.  Genetic testing can confirm the diagnosis, especially useful when family history is unclear or previous family diagnoses weren't genetically confirmed.
Treatments: Medication for movement and mental health symptoms; Psychotherapy; Speech therapy; Physical therapy; Occupational therapy
Tests: Neurological exam; Neuropsychological testing; MRI; CT scan; Genetic testing; EEG
Medications_Drugs: tetrabenazine (Xenazine); deutetrabenazine (Austedo); valbenazine (Ingrezza); haloperidol; fluphenazine; olanzapine (Zyprexa); aripiprazole (Abilify, Aristada); amantadine (Gocovri); levetiracetam (Keppra, Spritam); clonazepam (Klonopin); citalopram (Celexa); escitalopram (Lexapro); fluoxetine (Prozac); sertraline (Zoloft); quetiapine (Seroquel); divalproex (Depakote); carbamazepine (Tegretol, Carbatrol, Epitol); lamotrigine (Lamictal)

Diagnosis: Hurthle cell cancer diagnosis involves a physical exam checking thyroid size and lymph node swelling; blood tests to assess thyroid function; imaging tests (ultrasound and CT) to detect thyroid growths; laryngoscopy to examine vocal cords (if voice changes are present); and a fine-needle aspiration biopsy to examine thyroid tissue for cancer cells.
Treatments: Thyroidectomy (total or near-total removal of the thyroid); Radioactive iodine therapy; Radiation therapy; Targeted drug therapy
Tests: Physical exam; Blood tests; Ultrasound; CT scan; Laryngoscopy; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Physical exam including checking for scrotal pain, palpation for inguinal hernia, and transillumination of the scrotum (light shining through to assess fluid); Blood and urine tests to rule out infection; Ultrasound to rule out hernia, tumor, or other causes of scrotal swelling.
Treatments: Observation (in babies, as hydrocele may resolve spontaneously); Surgery (hydrocelectomy)
Tests: Physical examination; Transillumination; Blood test; Urine test; Ultrasound
Medications_Drugs: Pain medication (before surgery, to induce sleep-like state - specific drug name not mentioned)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on symptoms, general physical exam, neurological exam, and brain imaging tests.  The neurological exam varies by age and may include assessments of muscle condition, movement, well-being, and sensory function.
Treatments: Shunt system; Endoscopic third ventriculostomy; Supportive therapies (occupational therapy, developmental therapy, special education, etc.)
Tests: Ultrasound; MRI; CT scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a review of symptoms and a physical exam.  Referral to a urologist may occur. Diagnostic tests are used to identify the cause and extent of hydronephrosis.
Treatments: Medication; Urine drainage (catheterization); Surgery
Tests: Blood test; Urine test; Ultrasound imaging; CT urogram; MRI; MAG3 scan

Diagnosis: High calcium levels are detected through routine blood tests;  further blood tests check parathyroid hormone levels to identify potential hyperparathyroidism; imaging tests (bone or lung imaging) may be used to investigate underlying causes such as cancer or sarcoidosis.
Treatments: Observation (for mild cases); Medication; Treatment of underlying disease; Surgery; IV fluids; Loop diuretics; Hemodialysis; Peritoneal dialysis
Tests: Blood test;  Chest X-rays; CT scan; Mammogram; MRI; Parathyroid sestamibi scan; Four-dimensional CT scan; Choline PET scan
Medications_Drugs: Calcitonin (Miacalcin); Cinacalcet (Sensipar); Bisphosphonates; Denosumab (Prolia, Xgeva); Prednisone

Diagnosis: Persistent high eosinophil levels and evidence of organ damage; Diagnostic tests determine the underlying cause of eosinophilia and organ involvement.
Treatments: Reduce eosinophil levels; Lessen symptoms; Prevent further organ damage; Treatment of underlying cause (if identified).
Tests: Blood tests (for autoimmune conditions, infections, blood cancers); Allergy tests; Stool tests (for parasitic infections); Genetic tests; Bone marrow samples; Blood tests (liver and kidney function); Imaging tests; Echocardiogram; Lung function tests; Tissue samples of organs.
Medications_Drugs: Corticosteroids; Hydroxyurea; Imatinib; Mepolizumab; Vincristine; Warfarin.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing medical history and symptoms; a physical exam may be conducted; lab tests may be used to rule out underlying conditions such as hyperthyroidism or hypoglycemia; sweat tests (iodine-starch test and quantitative sweat test) may be used to pinpoint areas of sweating and assess severity.
Treatments: Treating the underlying cause (if identified); Prescription antiperspirant; Prescription creams and wipes; Nerve-blocking medications; Antidepressants; Botulinum toxin injections; Iontophoresis; Microwave therapy; Sweat gland removal; Nerve surgery (sympathectomy or sympathotomy); Lifestyle modifications (e.g., clothing choices, footwear, antiperspirant use).
Tests: Blood test; Urine test; Other lab tests; Iodine-starch test; Sweat test
Medications_Drugs: Aluminum chloride (Drysol, Xerac AC); Glycopyrrolate; Glycopyrronium tosylate (Qbrexza); Nerve-blocking medications (specific drug names not listed); Antidepressants (specific drug names not listed).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a thorough physical exam, review of health history and eating habits, and various tests to measure oxalate levels in urine and blood, analyze kidney stones, and assess kidney function.  Further tests may be needed to determine the type of hyperoxaluria and its impact on other organs.
Treatments: Reducing oxalate through medication, phosphate and citrate supplementation, increased fluid intake, and dietary changes; Kidney stone management (removal or breaking up stones); Dialysis; Kidney transplant; Liver transplant
Tests: Urine tests; Blood tests; Stone analysis; Kidney X-ray; Ultrasound; CT scan; DNA testing; Kidney biopsy; Echocardiogram; Eye exam; Bone marrow biopsy; Liver biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Lumasiran (Oxlumo); Vitamin B-6 (pyridoxine); Thiazide diuretics; Calcium supplements

Diagnosis: Elevated blood calcium levels, often detected during routine blood tests or tests for other conditions; confirmed by repeated blood tests showing high calcium and parathyroid hormone levels.  Further tests rule out other causes, identify complications, and determine severity.
Treatments: Watchful waiting; Surgery; Medications
Tests: Blood tests (calcium and parathyroid hormone levels); Bone mineral density test (DEXA); 24-hour urine test; Imaging tests of kidneys (X-ray or other imaging); Sestamibi parathyroid scan; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Ultrasound

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical history, physical exam (checking for tremor, reflexes, pulse, eye changes, skin condition, and thyroid gland size), and blood tests measuring T-4, T-3, and TSH levels.  High T-4 and low TSH are common in hyperthyroidism.  Older adults may not exhibit classic symptoms. Biotin can interfere with blood test accuracy.
Treatments: Anti-thyroid medicine; Beta blockers; Radioiodine therapy; Thyroidectomy
Tests: Blood tests (T-4, T-3, TSH); Radioiodine scan and uptake test; Thyroid ultrasound
Medications_Drugs: Methimazole; Propylthiouracil; Levothyroxine; Methylprednisolone; Prednisone; Teprotumumab (Tepezza); Tocilizumab (Actemra); Rituximab (Rituxan); Mycophenolate mofetil (Cellcept)

Diagnosis: Physical examination including listening to the heart with a stethoscope (to detect heart murmurs);  Echocardiogram (to assess heart chamber function, valve function, and muscle thickness); Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) (to assess heart's electrical activity and detect arrhythmias); Family history assessment; Genetic testing (if family history is present).
Treatments: Medications; Septal myectomy; Apical myectomy; Septal ablation; Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD); Cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) device (rarely); Ventricular assist device (VAD) (rarely); Heart transplant (for end-stage heart failure).
Tests: Echocardiogram; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; Cardiac MRI; Stress test; Cardiac CT scan (rarely).
Medications_Drugs: Metoprolol; Propranolol; Atenolol; Verapamil; Diltiazem; Mavacamten; Amiodarone; Disopyramide; Warfarin; Dabigatran; Rivaroxaban; Apixaban.

Diagnosis: Physical exam; Review of medical history; Blood glucose testing (if using insulin or other diabetes medication); Overnight or extended fast (up to 72 hours in hospital setting for non-diabetic patients without immediate symptoms); Blood sample analysis (may be done after meals if symptoms occur postprandially); Evaluation of whether symptoms disappear when blood sugar levels rise.
Treatments: Immediate treatment with 15-20 grams of fast-acting carbohydrates (glucose tablets, gel, fruit juice, regular soda, honey, sugary candy); Glucagon injection or intravenous glucose for severe hypoglycemia; Nutritional counseling; Medication adjustment, addition, change, or cessation; Tumor surgical removal (or medication/partial pancreatectomy);  Lifestyle changes (eating and exercise routines).
Tests: Blood glucose meter testing; Blood sample analysis for blood sugar levels.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of hyponatremia is based on blood tests and urine tests to confirm low blood sodium levels. A physical exam alone is insufficient due to overlapping symptoms with other conditions.
Treatments: Temporarily cutting back on fluids; Adjusting diuretic use; Intravenous fluids (IV sodium solution); Medications to manage symptoms (specific medications not listed)
Tests: Blood tests; Urine tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing medical history, physical examination, and blood and urine tests. Blood tests assess calcium, parathyroid hormone, phosphorus, and magnesium levels. Urine tests check for excessive calcium excretion.  Additional tests like electrocardiograms may be used.
Treatments: Oral calcium supplements; Vitamin D supplements (calcitriol); Magnesium supplements; Thiazide diuretics; Calcium infusion; Parathyroid hormone replacement (Natpara, although being phased out; a newer, unapproved type in clinical trials); Dietary changes (calcium-rich, phosphorus-low diet)
Tests: Blood tests; Urine test; Electrocardiogram; Bone density test; Urinalysis; X-ray
Medications_Drugs: Calcitriol; Natpara; Thiazide diuretics (specific drug names not specified)

Diagnosis: Hypopituitarism is diagnosed through assessment of hormone levels and investigation of the underlying cause.  Low hormone levels are measured through blood tests, which assess pituitary hormones and hormones from glands controlled by the pituitary.  Stimulation or dynamic testing may also be used to evaluate hormone response to medication. Brain imaging (MRI or CT scans) identifies pituitary tumors or other structural abnormalities.
Treatments: Hormone replacement; Surgery; Radiation therapy
Tests: Blood tests; Stimulation or dynamic testing; MRI; CT scan
Medications_Drugs: Hydrocortisone (Cortef); Prednisone (Rayos); Levothyroxine (Levoxyl, Synthroid); Testosterone; Estrogen; Progesterone; Somatropin (Genotropin, Humatrope); Gonadotropins

Diagnosis: Clinical examination including auscultation for heart murmurs; Pregnancy ultrasound (during second trimester); Echocardiogram (to visualize heart structures and blood flow).
Treatments: Atrial septostomy; Norwood procedure (including potential hybrid/mixed procedure); Bidirectional Glenn procedure; Fontan procedure; Heart transplant; Medications to manage symptoms before surgery; Breathing support (ventilator); Intravenous fluids; Feeding tube.
Tests: Pregnancy ultrasound; Echocardiogram

Diagnosis: Physical exam by a pediatrician; Referral to a pediatric urologist for further evaluation;  In cases of atypical genitalia (urethral opening not at penis tip and testicles not palpable), a multispecialty team evaluation is recommended.
Treatments: Surgery to reposition the urethral opening to the tip of the penis; Surgery to straighten the penis shaft (if needed);  Tissue grafts from foreskin or inside of the mouth may be used for reconstruction in severe cases.
Tests: Physical exam

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is usually clear based on symptoms and circumstances; blood tests can confirm hypothermia and severity; diagnosis may be unclear with mild symptoms, especially in older adults with confusion, incoordination, and speech problems.
Treatments: Passive rewarming (heated blankets, warm fluids); Blood rewarming (hemodialysis machine, heart bypass machines); Warm intravenous fluids (warmed saline); Airway rewarming (humidified oxygen); Irrigation (warm saltwater solution via catheters); CPR (if breathing stops or is dangerously low/shallow)
Tests: Blood tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on blood tests measuring thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and thyroid hormone T-4 levels. High TSH and low T-4 indicate hypothyroidism; high TSH with normal T-4 and T-3 indicates subclinical hypothyroidism. Symptoms alone are insufficient for diagnosis.
Treatments: Levothyroxine medication
Tests: Blood test for TSH; Blood test for T-4; Blood test for T-3 (sometimes)
Medications_Drugs: Levothyroxine (Levo-T, Synthroid); Desiccated thyroid extract (not recommended)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing symptoms and medical history, conducting a physical exam, and potentially employing several tests to rule out other conditions.  Idiopathic hypersomnia is characterized by excessive sleepiness daily for at least three months.  The Epworth Sleepiness Scale helps quantify sleepiness and its impact on daily life; a sleep diary tracks sleep patterns.
Treatments: Medication; Lifestyle modifications (regular sleep schedule, avoiding alcohol and sleep-affecting medications)
Tests: Epworth Sleepiness Scale; Sleep diary; Polysomnogram; Multiple sleep latency test
Medications_Drugs: Modafinil (Provigil); Armodafinil (Nuvigil); Sodium oxybate (Xyrem, Lumryz); Clarithromycin (Biaxin XL); Pitolisant (Wakix); Methylphenidate (Quillivant XR, Daytrana, others); Oxybate (Xywav)

Diagnosis: Often diagnosed after finding blood in the urine or through routine tests showing protein or blood in the urine.  Further testing is needed, including urinalysis showing blood or signs of glomeruli inflammation;  a kidney biopsy is the definitive diagnostic method.
Treatments: Medical tests to track disease progression; Medications to slow disease progression and manage symptoms;  Dietary changes; Lifestyle modifications;  Dialysis or kidney transplant (if kidney function severely declines)
Tests: Urine tests; Blood tests; Kidney biopsy; Iothalamate clearance test
Medications_Drugs: Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors; Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs); Corticosteroids; Other immunosuppressants; Prescription fish oil supplements; Cholesterol medicine; Diuretics

Diagnosis: Physical exam; assessment of symptoms, stressful situations, family history, fears, and concerns by a mental health professional; psychological evaluation; completion of psychological self-assessment or questionnaire; determination of whether symptoms are better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., somatic symptom disorder or generalized anxiety disorder).
Treatments: Psychotherapy (cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), behavioral stress management, exposure therapy); medications (antidepressants, such as SSRIs);  stress management and relaxation techniques; graduated activity program; avoiding internet searches for diseases; working with provider to set limits on tests and referrals.
Tests: Complete blood count (CBC)
Medications_Drugs: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs); medications to treat mood or anxiety disorders (if present).

Diagnosis: Ruling out other causes of bleeding and low platelet count; blood tests to check platelet levels; bone marrow biopsy (rarely in adults).  No single test definitively diagnoses ITP.
Treatments: Regular platelet checks; corticosteroids; immune globulin; romiplostim (Nplate); eltrombopag (Promacta); avatrombopag (Doptelet); rituximab (Rituxan, Ruxience, Truxima); fostamatinib (Tavalisse); splenectomy; platelet transfusion (emergency treatment).
Tests: Complete blood count (CBC); bone marrow biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Prednisone; immune globulin; romiplostim (Nplate); eltrombopag (Promacta); avatrombopag (Doptelet); rituximab (Rituxan, Ruxience, Truxima); fostamatinib (Tavalisse); aspirin; ibuprofen

Diagnosis: Clinical examination of teeth and mouth; Questions about dental symptoms and general health; Checks of teeth and gum condition; Dental X-rays to visualize impacted teeth and potential damage to teeth or bone.
Treatments: Surgical removal (extraction) of impacted wisdom teeth; Observation and monitoring for asymptomatic wisdom teeth;  Pain management (e.g., pain medication and cold compresses).
Tests: Dental X-rays

Diagnosis: Visual examination of sores on the face or body;  A sample of fluid from a sore may be tested for antibiotic sensitivity if sores don't clear with initial treatment.
Treatments: Prescription mupirocin antibiotic ointment or cream applied directly to sores; Oral antibiotics for ecthyma or widespread infection; Over-the-counter antibiotic cream or ointment for minor, localized infections.
Tests: Culture of fluid from sore to determine antibiotic sensitivity
Medications_Drugs: mupirocin; Oral antibiotics (specific type not specified)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is challenging, especially in first pregnancies.  It may be suspected based on history of painless cervical dilation and second-trimester delivery; advanced cervical dilation and effacement before week 24; or prolapsed fetal membranes (amniotic sac in cervical canal or vagina).  Confirmed during pregnancy via transvaginal ultrasound to assess cervical length and tissue protrusion; pelvic exam to check for cervical opening and amniotic sac prolapse; and potentially lab tests to rule out infection (e.g., amniocentesis).
Treatments: Cervical cerclage; Progesterone supplementation; Repeated ultrasounds; Pessary (further research needed to confirm efficacy)
Tests: Transvaginal ultrasound; Pelvic exam; Lab tests (including amniocentesis if indicated)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on patient symptom review (including recent meals, eating habits, medical history, life stresses, and exposures), a thorough medical exam (including abdominal palpation and auscultation), and potentially an H. pylori test (tissue sample, breath test, or stool sample).  Functional indigestion may be diagnosed based on symptoms, medical history, and exam findings. Further tests may be indicated if initial treatment is ineffective or concerning symptoms/exam findings exist.
Treatments: Diet and medication changes (avoiding fatty, acidic, or spicy foods; avoiding caffeine, alcohol, carbonated beverages, and certain pain relievers); Mental healthcare (talk therapy, prescription medications for depression/anxiety); Prescription and over-the-counter digestive medications; Alternative medicine (peppermint oil, rikkunshito, acupuncture, yoga, mindfulness practices); Lifestyle changes (eating smaller meals, regular exercise, weight management, smoking cessation, stress reduction).
Tests: H. pylori test (tissue sample, breath test, or stool sample); Blood tests; Endoscopy; Imaging tests (CT scan, X-ray)
Medications_Drugs: lansoprazole (Prevacid 24 HR); omeprazole (Prilosec OTC); esomeprazole (Nexium 24HR); cimetidine (Tagamet HB); famotidine (Pepcid AC); nizatidine (Axid AR);  Antibiotics; Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs); H-2-receptor blockers; Prokinetics; aspirin; ibuprofen; naproxen sodium.

Diagnosis: Infant jaundice is diagnosed based on the baby's appearance and a measurement of bilirubin levels in the blood.  The severity of jaundice is determined by the bilirubin level.
Treatments: Enhanced nutrition (more frequent feedings or supplementation); Light therapy (phototherapy); Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg); Exchange transfusion
Tests: Physical exam; Blood test; Transcutaneous bilirubinometer; Urinalysis (if underlying disorder suspected)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis typically begins with a physical exam and questions about symptoms.  If the infant is growing well and content, further testing is usually unnecessary.  Poor weight gain or frequent vomiting may necessitate additional testing.
Treatments: Dietary changes (smaller, more frequent feedings; upright feeding position; 30-minute upright position after feeding); Acid-blocking medication; Surgery (rarely, to tighten the lower esophageal sphincter)
Tests: Ultrasound; Blood tests; Urine tests; Esophageal pH monitoring; X-rays; Upper endoscopy
Medications_Drugs: cimetidine (Tagamet HB); famotidine (Pepcid AC); omeprazole magnesium (Prilosec)

Diagnosis: A healthcare professional will assess symptoms and medical history; a physical exam will be conducted;  tests and imaging scans may be used to determine the cause of symptoms.  Lab tests such as blood tests, urine tests, throat swabs, stool samples, and spinal taps may be performed to identify the specific germ causing the illness. Imaging scans (X-ray, CT, ultrasound, MRI) can help determine the cause of symptoms; biopsies may be necessary to check for certain organisms, such as fungi in lung tissue.
Treatments: Antibiotics; Antivirals; Antifungals; Anti-parasitics; Self-care (rest and fluids); Alternative medicine (with caution and consultation with healthcare team)
Tests: Blood tests; Urine tests; Throat swabs; Stool sample; Spinal tap; X-ray; Computerized tomography; Ultrasound; MRI; Biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Antibiotics (specific types not listed); Antivirals (for COVID-19, HIV, herpes, hepatitis B, hepatitis C, influenza); Topical antifungal medications; Oral antifungal medications; Intravenous antifungal medications; Anti-parasitics (specific types not listed)

Diagnosis: Infertility diagnosis involves understanding sexual habits and may include physical exams (male genital exam; female pelvic exam).  Testing aims to identify treatable problems in sperm production, release, transport, egg release, fallopian tube function, or uterine condition.  Unexplained infertility is diagnosed when no clear cause is found.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes; Assisted reproductive technology (ART);  Surgery (e.g., laparoscopy to remove fibroids or endometriosis tissue)
Tests: Semen analysis; Urine test for sperm; Hormone testing (testosterone and other male hormones); Genetic testing; Testicular biopsy; Ultrasound (scrotum, seminal glands, sperm duct); Brain MRI; Ovulation testing; Thyroid function test; Hysterosalpingography; Ovarian reserve testing; Other hormone tests (ovulation-controlling hormones; pituitary hormones); Pelvic ultrasound; Saline infusion sonogram (sonohysterogram); Hysteroscopy; Laparoscopy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of IBD is typically made through a combination of patient history, physical examination, and various diagnostic tests.  A biopsy obtained during endoscopy is crucial for confirming the diagnosis and differentiating IBD from other inflammatory conditions.
Treatments: Information not found
Tests: Blood tests; Stool studies (including calprotectin); Colonoscopy; Sigmoidoscopy; Upper endoscopy; Capsule endoscopy; Balloon-assisted enteroscopy

Diagnosis: Inflammatory breast cancer is clinically diagnosed through a physical exam assessing breast skin color changes and swelling; imaging tests such as mammograms, ultrasounds, and MRIs; and biopsies (needle or skin) to examine tissue samples for cancer cells.
Treatments: Chemotherapy (neoadjuvant and adjuvant); Surgery (mastectomy; axillary dissection; breast reconstruction); Radiation therapy; Targeted therapy; Hormone therapy (selective estrogen receptor modulators; aromatase inhibitors; ovary-suppressing surgery or medication); Immunotherapy; Palliative care
Tests: Physical exam; Mammogram; Ultrasound; MRI; Biopsy (needle; skin); CT scan; Bone scan; PET scan

Diagnosis: Physical exam to assess symptoms;  Flu virus detection test may be ordered, particularly if flu is not widespread; At-home tests available for those age 2 and older, but confirmation by healthcare professional may be needed.
Treatments: Antiviral medication for severe infection or high-risk individuals; Rest; Plenty of fluids; Pain relievers (acetaminophen or ibuprofen, but not aspirin for children and teens); Staying home until fever-free for 24 hours without medication; Wearing a face mask when seeking medical care.
Tests: Molecular tests (including PCR and NAAT tests); Antigen tests (including rapid influenza diagnostic tests); Tests that diagnose both flu and other respiratory illnesses (e.g., COVID-19).
Medications_Drugs: Oseltamivir (Tamiflu); Baloxavir (Xofluza); Zanamivir (Relenza); Peramivir (Rapivab); Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen.

Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis based on visual examination of the skin and assessment of hair removal habits.
Treatments: Stop shaving, tweezing, or waxing for 1-6 months; Trim beard with scissors or clippers; Medications; Laser-assisted hair removal; Electrolysis;  Release visible ingrown hairs with a sterile needle; Use a 1% hydrocortisone cream (for no more than four weeks); Chemical hair removal products (depilatory); Consistent skin care routine (shaving at least twice a week, washing the area, applying shaving cream, shaving in the direction of hair growth, using a sharp single-blade razor, rinsing the blade after each stroke, applying a cool, wet cloth, using a soothing after-shave product)
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: tretinoin (Renova, Retin-A); glycolic acid lotion; Steroid creams; Antibiotic creams; Antibiotic pills; eflornithine (Vaniqa)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a physical examination of the nail and surrounding skin, along with patient symptoms.
Treatments: Lifting the nail with cotton, dental floss, or a splint; Taping the nail; Placing a gutter splint under the nail; Partially removing the ingrown portion of the nail; Removing a portion of the nail and underlying tissue (nail bed); Soaking feet in warm, soapy water; Placing cotton or dental floss under the ingrown nail edge; Applying petroleum jelly; Wearing open-toed shoes or sandals.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: A physical exam to check for a bulge in the groin area, often with the patient standing and coughing or straining to make the hernia more prominent;  If not readily apparent, imaging tests such as abdominal ultrasound, CT scan, or MRI may be ordered.
Treatments: Watchful waiting; Supportive truss (with proper fitting and use); Manual pressure reduction (in children); Open hernia repair (with or without mesh); Minimally invasive hernia repair (laparoscopic or robotic, with mesh)
Tests: Abdominal ultrasound; CT scan; MRI

Diagnosis: Diagnosis may occur prenatally, at birth via newborn screening, or later in life after symptom onset.  Diagnosis involves physical exam, review of symptoms and family history; blood and urine tests assessing metabolic function; and genetic testing to identify the specific disorder.  Carrier testing may be offered to prospective parents.
Treatments: Special diets; Enzyme replacement; Vitamin therapy; Medications; Liver transplants
Tests: Blood tests; Urine tests; Genetic testing

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam to rule out underlying medical conditions; a review of sleep habits using questionnaires and sleep diaries; and potentially a sleep study (polysomnography) to assess brain waves, breathing, heartbeat, eye movements, and body movements if the cause is unclear or other sleep disorders are suspected.  Blood tests may be done to check for thyroid problems or other conditions.
Treatments: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT); Stimulus control therapy; Relaxation methods (progressive muscle relaxation, biofeedback, breathing exercises); Sleep restriction; Remaining passively awake (paradoxical intention); Light therapy; Prescription sleeping pills; Lifestyle changes (regular sleep schedule, regular physical activity, medication review).
Tests: Physical exam; Blood test; Sleep habits questionnaire; Sleep diary; Polysomnography (sleep study)
Medications_Drugs: Eszopiclone (Lunesta); Ramelteon (Rozerem); Temazepam (Restoril); Triazolam (Halcion); Zaleplon (Sonata); Zolpidem tartrate (Ambien, Ambien CR, Edluar); Doxepin hydrochloride (Silenor); Suvorexant (Belsomra); Over-the-counter sleep aids containing antihistamines (not for regular use).

Diagnosis: A physical exam to rule out physical problems or substance use; a mental health evaluation involving discussion of symptoms, thoughts, feelings, and behavior.  Further information on specific diagnostic criteria is not explicitly provided on the page.
Treatments: Talk therapy (psychotherapy); cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT);  relaxation techniques (deep breathing, relaxing imagery, yoga); problem-solving techniques; improved communication skills; medication.
Tests: Physical exam; lab tests; EEG (electroencephalogram)
Medications_Drugs: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs); anticonvulsant mood stabilizers; other unspecified medications.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a medical history, bladder diary (recording fluid intake and urine output), pelvic exam (examining external genitals, vagina, cervix, abdomen, anus, and rectum), urine test (checking for UTI), cystoscopy (visualizing bladder lining, possibly with hydrodistention), biopsy (tissue sample from bladder and urethra for microscopic examination), urine cytology (cell examination to rule out cancer), and a potassium sensitivity test (comparing pain/urgency responses to water and potassium chloride solutions instilled into the bladder).
Treatments: Physical therapy; Oral medications; Nerve stimulation (Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS); Sacral nerve stimulation); Bladder distention
Tests: Medical history and bladder diary; Pelvic exam; Urine test; Cystoscopy; Biopsy; Urine cytology; Potassium sensitivity test
Medications_Drugs: ibuprofen; naproxen sodium; amitriptyline; imipramine; loratadine; pentosan polysulfate sodium (Elmiron)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis can be challenging, sometimes without identifiable cause.  Diagnosis involves ruling out other conditions with similar symptoms and may utilize high-resolution CT scans (often the first test), which show lung damage and fibrosis; blood tests to detect markers of autoimmune disease or inflammatory responses; pulmonary function tests (spirometry and diffusion capacity); oximetry; and sometimes lung tissue analysis via biopsy (bronchoscopy, bronchoalveolar lavage, or surgical biopsy).
Treatments: Corticosteroid medications; Immune-suppressing drugs; Pirfenidone; Nintedanib; Medications to reduce stomach acid; Oxygen therapy; Pulmonary rehabilitation; Lung transplant
Tests: High-resolution CT scan; Blood tests; Echocardiogram; Spirometry; Diffusion capacity; Oximetry; Bronchoscopy; Bronchoalveolar lavage; Surgical biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is suspected based on physical exam and symptoms; confirmed through blood tests (e.g., high white cell count), imaging tests (X-ray, ultrasound, CT scan, MRI, angiogram using CT or MRI), endoscopy (sigmoidoscopy, colonoscopy), and angiography (dye tracking blood flow through arteries).
Treatments: Restoring blood supply to digestive tract; Antibiotics (for infection); Treatment of contributing conditions (e.g., congestive heart failure, irregular heartbeat); Cessation of vasoconstricting medications; Surgery (removal of damaged tissue, bypass of blockage); Angioplasty; Stent placement; Removal or dissolution of blood clots; Anticoagulant medication
Tests: Blood tests; X-ray; Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI; Angiogram; Sigmoidoscopy; Colonoscopy; Angiography
