Diagnosis: Diagnosis of intestinal obstruction involves a physical exam assessing abdominal swelling, tenderness, or lumps; listening for bowel sounds; and imaging studies to confirm the obstruction and identify its cause.  A standard X-ray may not reveal all obstructions; CT scans provide more detailed images; ultrasound is often preferred for children, especially those with suspected intussusception, which might show a "bull's-eye" pattern on ultrasound; air or barium enema can improve colon imaging and, in the case of intussusception, may also serve as treatment.
Treatments: Hospitalization for stabilization (including IV fluids, nasogastric tube for decompression, urinary catheter); Barium or air enema (for intussusception); Low-fiber diet (for partial obstruction); Surgery (for complete obstruction or partial obstruction not resolving); Self-expanding metal stent (for select cases, often colon cancer or high-risk patients);  Medication to stimulate muscle contractions (for paralytic ileus); Treatment of underlying cause (for paralytic ileus); Decompression (via colonoscopy or surgery for enlarged colon).
Tests: Physical exam; Abdominal X-ray; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Ultrasound; Air or barium enema

Diagnosis: Diagnosis can be challenging as initial symptoms may be absent. Loss of consciousness after head injury usually suggests intracranial hematoma until proven otherwise.  Imaging techniques are crucial for determining hematoma location and size.
Treatments: Observation for neurological changes and intracranial pressure monitoring; Repeated head CT scans; Reversal of blood thinners (vitamin K and fresh frozen plasma); Surgical drainage; Craniotomy; Occupational and physical therapy
Tests: CT scan; MRI scan; Angiogram

Diagnosis: Intracranial venous malformations may be incidentally discovered during imaging tests for other neurological conditions.  Diagnosis is primarily through imaging studies revealing the characteristic vascular abnormalities.
Treatments: Medical management; Observation; Surgery (rarely, for hemorrhage); Medications for seizures and headaches
Tests: CT scan; CT angiogram; CT venogram; MRI; MRA; MRV

Diagnosis: History taking including symptom review; physical exam (palpating a sausage-shaped lump); abdominal imaging (ultrasound, X-ray, CT scan) showing intestinal obstruction and a "bull's-eye" pattern indicative of intussusception;  assessment for intestinal perforation.
Treatments: Water-soluble contrast or air enema; Surgery
Tests: Ultrasound; X-ray; CT scan; Barium enema

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam assessing breast changes; imaging tests (mammogram, ultrasound, MRI) are used to identify abnormalities; a tissue biopsy is necessary to confirm the presence of cancer and determine its type. Invasive lobular carcinoma is less likely to be detected on mammogram or ultrasound compared to other breast cancer types.
Treatments: Surgery (lumpectomy, mastectomy); Radiation; Chemotherapy; Hormone therapy (endocrine therapy)
Tests: Clinical breast exam; Mammogram; Diagnostic mammogram; Breast ultrasound; Breast MRI; Breast biopsy; Blood tests (complete blood count, kidney and liver function tests); Bone scan; CT scan; PET scan; Sentinel node biopsy

Diagnosis: Complete eye exam including external examination with penlight observation of pupils and redness; visual acuity testing; slit-lamp examination with pupil dilation to visualize the inside of the eye;  further testing (blood tests or X-rays) may be necessary to identify underlying causes.
Treatments: Steroid eyedrops; Dilating eyedrops; Oral steroids; Oral anti-inflammatory agents
Tests: External eye examination; Visual acuity testing; Slit-lamp examination; Pupil dilation; Blood tests; X-rays

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves tests to assess red blood cell size and color, hematocrit, hemoglobin levels, and ferritin levels.  Low ferritin levels usually indicate low stored iron.  Further testing may be done to identify underlying causes.
Treatments: Iron supplements; Treatment of underlying causes (e.g., medications for ulcers or heavy menstrual bleeding, surgery to remove polyps or fibroids); Intravenous iron; Blood transfusions (for severe cases)
Tests: Red blood cell size and color analysis; Hematocrit test; Hemoglobin test; Ferritin test; Endoscopy; Colonoscopy; Pelvic ultrasound
Medications_Drugs: Oral iron tablets; Stool softeners; Oral contraceptives; Antibiotics (for peptic ulcers)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a medical history, physical exam, and exclusion of other conditions like celiac disease and IBD.  The Rome criteria, which include abdominal pain/discomfort at least one day a week for three months, often with defecation-related pain, altered stool frequency or consistency, are used. IBS is then categorized into subtypes (constipation-predominant, diarrhea-predominant, mixed, unclassified) based on symptoms.  Additional symptoms (e.g., onset after age 50, weight loss, rectal bleeding) may warrant further investigation.
Treatments: Dietary changes (avoiding trigger foods, high-fiber diet, adequate hydration); Stress management; Lifestyle changes (regular exercise, sufficient sleep); Counseling; Fiber supplements; Laxatives; Antidiarrheal medicines; Bile acid binders; Anticholinergic medicines; Tricyclic antidepressants; SSRI antidepressants; Pain medicines
Tests: Colonoscopy; CT scan; Upper endoscopy; Biopsy; Lactose intolerance tests (breath test or dietary elimination); Breath test for bacterial overgrowth; Stool tests
Medications_Drugs: psyllium husk (Metamucil); magnesium hydroxide oral (Milk of Magnesia); polyethylene glycol (Miralax); loperamide (Imodium A-D); cholestyramine (Prevalite); colestipol (Colestid); colesevelam (Welchol); dicyclomine (Bentyl); imipramine (Tofranil); desipramine (Norpramin); nortriptyline (Pamelor); fluoxetine (Prozac); paroxetine (Paxil); pregabalin (Lyrica); gabapentin (Neurontin); alosetron (Lotronex); eluxadoline (Viberzi); rifaximin (Xifaxan); lubiprostone (Amitiza); linaclotide (Linzess)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on symptoms and imaging tests to rule out other conditions like IBD.  Colonoscopy with biopsy helps confirm the diagnosis by visualizing the colon and examining tissue samples. Stool analysis helps rule out infection.
Treatments: Antibiotics; Intravenous fluids; Treatment of underlying conditions; Bowel rest; Surgery (to remove dead tissue, repair holes, or remove narrowed sections of the colon)
Tests: Abdominal CT scan; Colonoscopy; Biopsy; Stool analysis

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam and review of medical history.  Further testing may be done if a medical condition is suspected.
Treatments: Corticosteroid creams and ointments; Calcineurin inhibitors (tacrolimus, pimecrolimus); Topical anesthetics; Capsaicin cream; Doxepin cream;  Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) (fluoxetine, sertraline); Tricyclic antidepressants (doxepin); Light therapy (phototherapy);  Moisturizing; Avoiding triggers; Medicated shampoos (zinc pyrithione, ketoconazole, selenium sulfide, coal tar); Calamine lotion; Creams with menthol, camphor, capsaicin, or pramoxine; Epsom salt baths; Baking soda baths; Oatmeal baths;  Counseling; Behavior modification therapy; Acupuncture; Meditation; Yoga; Nonprescription oral allergy medicine (diphenhydramine); Humidifier use
Tests: Blood test (complete blood count); Tests of liver and kidney function; Chest X-ray
Medications_Drugs: Triamcinolone; Tacrolimus (Protopic); Pimecrolimus (Elidel); Fluoxetine (Prozac); Sertraline (Zoloft); Doxepin; Diphenhydramine

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of jaw tumors and cysts involves gathering information through imaging studies (X-ray, CT, MRI) and a biopsy to analyze tumor or cyst cells.  The pathologist examines the removed tissue during surgery to provide an immediate diagnosis.
Treatments: Surgical removal of tumor or cyst;  Reconstruction of jawbone or other structures; Medical therapy; Supportive care (nutrition, speech and swallowing assistance, tooth replacements)
Tests: X-ray; CT; MRI; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Visual inspection of the injury by a healthcare provider;  Collection of stinger samples may be done to guide treatment.
Treatments: Carefully plucking visible tentacles with tweezers; Soaking the affected skin in 110-113°F (43-45°C) water until pain eases (20-45 minutes); Applying 0.5% to 1% hydrocortisone cream or ointment twice daily; Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR); Life support; Antivenom (for box jellyfish stings); Oral antihistamines; Oral corticosteroids; Oral pain medicine; Eye flushing (for stings near the eye).
Tests: Stinger sample collection
Medications_Drugs: Hydrocortisone cream or ointment; Antihistamines; Corticosteroids; Oral pain medicine; Antivenom (for box jellyfish stings)

Diagnosis: Information not found
Treatments: Light therapy; Lifestyle and home remedies (including sunlight exposure, caffeine, and exercise); Melatonin; Nonbenzodiazepines (zolpidem, eszopiclone, zaleplon); Benzodiazepines (temazepam, midazolam)
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: zolpidem; eszopiclone; zaleplon; temazepam; midazolam; melatonin

Diagnosis: Visual examination of the rash; Skin scraping for lab testing if diagnosis is uncertain.
Treatments: Antifungal ointment; Antifungal cream; Antifungal gel; Prescription-strength creams; Prescription-strength ointments; Prescription-strength pills; Combination of prescription products.  Simultaneous treatment of athlete's foot if present.
Tests: Skin scraping

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is challenging due to overlapping symptoms with other conditions.  No single test confirms diagnosis; tests help rule out other conditions.  Evaluation includes assessment of symptoms, physical examination, and various blood tests to assess inflammation and autoantibodies. Imaging (X-ray or MRI) may be used to exclude other causes and monitor bone development/joint damage.
Treatments: Medications; Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Surgery; Lifestyle modifications (exercise, diet, heat/cold application)
Tests: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR); C-reactive protein; Antinuclear antibody; Rheumatoid factor; Cyclic citrullinated peptide (CCP); X-ray; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
Medications_Drugs: Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Methotrexate; Etanercept; Adalimumab; Golimumab; Infliximab; Abatacept; Rituximab; Anakinra; Tocilizumab; Prednisone

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is confirmed through a skin biopsy, which involves removing a small piece of a skin lesion for lab testing to look for signs of cancer.  Further testing may be needed to detect Kaposi sarcoma in other areas of the body such as the lungs or digestive tract depending on the symptoms and location of lesions.
Treatments: Monitoring; Minor surgery (excision); Cryotherapy; Radiation therapy; Vinblastine injection; Topical medicine cream or gel; Chemotherapy; Antiviral medications (for AIDS-related Kaposi sarcoma); Cessation or change of immunosuppressant medications (for transplant-related Kaposi sarcoma)
Tests: Skin biopsy; Fecal occult blood test; Endoscopy; Colonoscopy; CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis; Chest X-ray; CT scan of the chest; Bronchoscopy

Diagnosis: There is no single test; diagnosis involves ruling out other diseases with similar symptoms (scarlet fever, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic shock syndrome, measles, tick-borne illnesses) through physical exam and blood and urine tests showing signs like high white blood cell count, anemia, and inflammation.
Treatments: Gamma globulin intravenous therapy; High-dose aspirin (then lowered after fever subsides); Low-dose aspirin (for at least six weeks post-fever, potentially longer depending on heart issues); Follow-up tests for heart problems (6-8 weeks and six months post-illness); Referral to pediatric cardiologist if needed.
Tests: Blood tests; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Echocardiogram; Complete blood count (CBC)

Diagnosis: Visual examination of the affected skin; Skin biopsy to rule out skin cancer.
Treatments: Compression dressings; Corticosteroid cream; Cortisone or other steroid injections; Cryotherapy (liquid nitrogen freezing); Pulsed-dye laser treatment; Radiation therapy; Surgical removal
Tests: Skin biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a comprehensive eye exam using a penlight to assess pupil reaction and size; corneal staining to visualize damage; slit-lamp examination for detailed assessment of keratitis and its effects on other eye structures; and laboratory analysis of tear samples or corneal cells to identify the cause.
Treatments: Artificial tear drops; Topical eye medications; Antibiotic eye drops; Oral antibiotics; Antifungal eye drops; Oral antifungal medication; Antiviral eye drops; Oral antiviral medications; Antiparasitic eye drops; Cornea transplant
Tests: Eye exam; Penlight exam; Corneal staining; Slit-lamp exam; Laboratory analysis of tears or corneal cells
Medications_Drugs: Antibiotic eye drops; Oral antibiotics; Antifungal eye drops; Oral antifungal medication; Antiviral eye drops; Oral antiviral medications; Antiparasitic eye drops

Diagnosis: Review of medical and family history; eye exam; assessment of corneal shape using various tests.
Treatments: Corneal collagen cross-linking; Eyeglasses; Soft contact lenses; Hard contact lenses (rigid gas permeable); Piggyback lenses; Hybrid lenses; Scleral lenses; Intrastromal corneal ring segments (ICRS); Cornea transplant (keratoplasty)
Tests: Eye refraction; Slit-lamp examination; Keratometry; Computerized corneal mapping (including corneal tomography and corneal topography)
Medications_Drugs: Riboflavin eye drops (used in corneal cross-linking)

Diagnosis: Visual examination of the affected skin by a healthcare provider; No other testing is typically needed.
Treatments: Time; Moisturizing; Self-care measures; Medicated creams (topical exfoliants containing alpha hydroxy acid, lactic acid, salicylic acid, or urea); Topical retinoids (e.g., tretinoin, tazarotene);  Warm water bathing; Gentle skin cleansing; Moisturizing with lanolin, petroleum jelly, or glycerin; Humidifier use; Avoidance of tight clothing.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Kidney cancer diagnosis often begins with a physical exam and a discussion of health history.  Blood and urine tests may reveal clues; imaging tests (ultrasound, CT, MRI) show location and size of cancer; a biopsy (tissue sample) may be taken for lab testing, though not always necessary if imaging provides sufficient information.
Treatments: Surgery (partial nephrectomy; radical nephrectomy - open, laparoscopic, or robot-assisted); Cryoablation; Medication (mentioned post-surgery to lower recurrence risk, but no specific medications named)
Tests: Blood and urine tests; Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Imaging tests (MRI, CT, and ultrasound) are used to differentiate kidney cysts from tumors; blood tests assess kidney function.
Treatments: Observation (if asymptomatic and no kidney function impairment); Percutaneous aspiration and sclerotherapy (piercing and draining the cyst, then filling it with a solution such as alcohol or a chemical compound); Surgery (to remove the cyst, typically for large cysts causing symptoms or complex cysts).
Tests: MRI; CT; Ultrasound; Blood tests

Diagnosis: Urine sample analysis for bacteria, blood, or pus; Blood culture to check for bacteria or other organisms; Ultrasound; CT scan; Voiding cystourethrogram (X-ray of bladder during filling and urination).
Treatments: Antibiotics; Hospitalization (for severe infections); Surgery (for underlying structural problems); Fluid administration through a vein (for severe infections)
Tests: Urinalysis; Blood culture; Ultrasound; CT scan; Voiding cystourethrogram

Diagnosis: Physical exam; Blood tests to check calcium and uric acid levels and kidney health; 24-hour urine collection to assess stone-forming minerals and inhibitors; Imaging tests such as CT scans (including high-speed or dual-energy CT for uric acid stones), abdominal X-rays (less common), and ultrasound; Analysis of passed stones to determine chemical composition; Genetic testing for rare inherited conditions like cystinuria and primary hyperoxaluria.
Treatments: Increased water intake; Pain relievers; Alpha blockers; Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL); Percutaneous nephrolithotomy; Ureteroscopy; Parathyroid gland surgery
Tests: Blood tests; 24-hour urine collection; CT scan; High-speed/dual energy CT scan; Abdominal X-ray; Ultrasound; Analysis of passed stones; Genetic testing
Medications_Drugs: Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Tamsulosin; Dutasteride and tamsulosin (Jalyn)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on symptoms and a psychological evaluation; a physical exam may rule out medical causes;  assessment includes questioning about impulses, triggering situations, and consequences of the behavior; use of questionnaires and self-assessments; application of DSM-5 criteria.
Treatments: Psychotherapy (cognitive behavioral therapy including systematic desensitization, counter-conditioning, covert sensitization, aversion therapy); medication; self-help groups.
Tests: Physical exam; Psychological evaluation; Questionnaires; Self-assessments
Medications_Drugs: Naltrexone; Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI); Other unspecified medications.

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing genital area, chest, and developmental milestones; questioning about symptoms and health; hormone testing via blood tests to detect hormonal imbalances; chromosome analysis (karyotype) via blood sample to confirm chromosomal abnormality; prenatal diagnosis may be possible through tests on fetal cells or cell-free DNA in maternal blood.
Treatments: Testosterone therapy; Breast tissue removal (surgery); Speech and language therapy; Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Educational evaluation and support; Fertility treatment (ICSI); Mental health support (psychotherapy, counseling)
Tests: Hormone testing (blood test); Chromosome analysis (karyotype); Prenatal testing (fetal cells or cell-free DNA in maternal blood)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam assessing for swelling, varicose veins, port-wine stains, and bone/soft tissue growth.  Referral to a vascular malformations specialist is recommended.  Further evaluation uses several diagnostic tests to determine the type and severity of the condition.
Treatments: Compression therapy (bandages, elastic garments, intermittent pneumatic compression devices); Skin care; Physical therapy; Orthopedic devices (shoes, inserts); Epiphysiodesis; Embolization; Laser therapy; Laser or radiofrequency ablation of veins; MR-guided ablation; Sclerotherapy; Surgery (vein removal/reconstruction, tissue removal, bone overgrowth correction); Oral medications for complex vascular/lymphatic malformations; Topical sirolimus
Tests: Duplex ultrasound scanning; MRI; MR angiography; Scanogram; CT scan; CT angiography; Contrast venography; Coagulation studies; Genetic studies
Medications_Drugs: Topical sirolimus; Oral medications (unspecified, with a note about potential significant side effects)

Diagnosis: Physical exam comparing both knees, assessing for warmth, swelling, pain source, skin changes, and range of motion;  Patient medical history review.  Imaging tests may be used to rule out other conditions.
Treatments: Rest; Pain relievers; Ice application; Gentle compression; Elevation of knee; Weight loss (if needed); Physical therapy; Corticosteroid injection; Aspiration; Surgery (rarely)
Tests: X-ray; MRI; Ultrasound; Aspiration (of bursa fluid)
Medications_Drugs: Aspirin; Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Antibiotics (if infection present)

Diagnosis: Physical exam inspecting the knee for swelling, pain, tenderness, warmth, and bruising; assessment of lower leg movement range; evaluation of joint integrity.
Treatments: Physical therapy; Strengthening exercises; Exercises to correct movement patterns; Flexibility and balance exercises; Arch supports; Braces; Corticosteroid injections; Hyaluronic acid injections; Platelet-rich plasma (PRP) injections; Arthroscopic surgery; Partial knee replacement surgery; Total knee replacement; Osteotomy; Over-the-counter medications (ibuprofen, naproxen sodium); Creams with lidocaine or capsaicin; Rest; Ice; Heat; Compression; Elevation; Acupuncture
Tests: X-ray; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Ultrasound; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Blood tests; Arthrocentesis
Medications_Drugs: Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Corticosteroids; Hyaluronic acid

Diagnosis: Physical exam including assessment of spinal curvature through forward bending; Neurological exam to check reflexes and muscle strength; X-rays to determine curvature and vertebral deformities; CT scan for detailed imaging; MRI to detect recent fractures; Nerve tests to evaluate nerve impulse transmission if numbness or muscle weakness is present; Bone density tests to assess risk of compression fractures.
Treatments: Pain relievers; Osteoporosis medications; Exercises; Bracing; Spinal fusion
Tests: X-rays; CT scan; MRI; Nerve tests; Bone density tests
Medications_Drugs: acetaminophen; ibuprofen; naproxen sodium; Osteoporosis medications (specific names not listed)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is suspected based on symptoms and response to reduced dairy intake. Confirmation is done via hydrogen breath test (measuring hydrogen in breath after lactose ingestion); lactose tolerance test (measuring blood glucose levels two hours after lactose ingestion).
Treatments: Treating underlying conditions (if present); Low-lactose diet;  Using lactase enzyme tablets or drops; Gradually introducing dairy products; Choosing smaller dairy servings; Consuming dairy with meals; Experimenting with various dairy products (hard cheeses, yogurt); Using lactose-reduced or lactose-free products
Tests: Hydrogen breath test; Lactose tolerance test

Diagnosis: The most common sign is hoarseness, varying from mild to complete voice loss.  A medical history review, voice examination, and vocal cord examination are conducted.  Referral to an ENT specialist may occur. Diagnostic techniques include laryngoscopy (using a mirror or fiber-optic endoscope) and biopsy (if suspicious areas are observed).
Treatments: Voice rest; Increased fluid intake; Humidified air; Treatment of underlying causes (e.g., heartburn, smoking, alcohol overuse); Antibiotics (if bacterial infection); Corticosteroids (in urgent cases, such as croup in toddlers); Voice therapy; Surgery (in some cases)
Tests: Laryngoscopy; Fiber-optic laryngoscopy; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Physical examination; review of symptoms and medical history; skin test (positive reaction indicates allergy); blood tests (to check for latex sensitivity).
Treatments: Avoidance of latex products; Injectable epinephrine (for severe reactions); Antihistamines; Corticosteroids
Tests: Skin test; Blood tests

Diagnosis: Eye exam checking for eye health, wandering eye, vision difference between eyes, or poor vision in both eyes; eyedrops used to dilate eyes; vision testing methods vary by age and developmental stage; preverbal children: lighted magnifying device (for cataracts), gaze and object-following assessment; children age 3 and older: picture or letter tests, covering one eye at a time.
Treatments: Corrective eyewear (glasses or contact lenses); Eye patches; Bangerter filter; Atropine eyedrops; Surgery (for droopy eyelids, cataracts, or strabismus); Activity-based treatments (effectiveness unproven).
Tests: Eye exam; Eyedrops for dilation; Lighted magnifying device; Gaze and object-following assessment; Picture or letter tests.

Diagnosis: Lead poisoning is diagnosed through a simple blood test that measures lead levels in micrograms per deciliter (mcg/dL).  A level of 5 mcg/dL in children is considered possibly unsafe, requiring periodic testing. Levels of 45 mcg/dL or higher generally indicate a need for treatment.  Routine testing may be recommended for children at ages 1 and 2, and for older children who haven't been tested.
Treatments: Removing the source of lead contamination; Reducing lead exposure; Chelation therapy; EDTA chelation therapy (calcium disodium ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid)
Tests: Blood test

Diagnosis: Physical exam evaluating symptoms and family history; blood pressure check; heart auscultation with a stethoscope.
Treatments: Medications; Catheter procedures; Surgery; Management of underlying conditions such as high blood pressure and sleep apnea.
Tests: Blood and urine tests; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Echocardiogram; Heart MRI
Medications_Drugs: Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors); Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs); Beta blockers; Calcium channel blockers; Water pills (diuretics)

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing range of motion and pain response; X-rays (multiple over time to track progression, initial X-rays may not show changes immediately); MRI (can visualize bone damage more clearly than X-rays, but not always needed).
Treatments: Leg cast (to maintain bone position); Surgery (wedge-shaped cuts in thighbone or pelvis to realign joint); Conservative treatment/observation; Activity restrictions; Crutches; Physical therapy.
Tests: X-rays; MRI; Bone scan

Diagnosis: Legionnaires' disease is diagnosed similarly to other pneumonias.  A urine test detecting legionella antigens can quickly identify the bacteria; other tests may include blood tests; chest X-ray (to assess lung infection extent, not infection type); tests on sputum or lung tissue samples.
Treatments: Antibiotics
Tests: Urine antigen test; Blood tests; Chest X-ray; Sputum culture; Lung tissue culture

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam to assess symptoms and palpate for lumps; imaging tests (MRI, CT scan, PET scan) to determine size and location; and a biopsy to confirm the presence of cancer cells.  Biopsy is often needle biopsy, performed carefully to avoid compromising future surgery.
Treatments: Surgery (complete or partial resection); Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy
Tests: Physical exam; MRI; CT scan; PET scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis may begin with a routine blood test revealing abnormal levels of red or white blood cells or platelets;  Physical exam looking for signs like pale skin, swollen lymph nodes, enlarged liver/spleen; Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy to examine bone marrow for leukemia cells and their characteristics.
Treatments: Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Radiation therapy; Bone marrow transplant (stem cell transplant); Immunotherapy; CAR-T cell therapy; Clinical trials
Tests: Blood tests; Physical exam; Bone marrow aspiration; Bone marrow biopsy

Diagnosis: Visual examination of oral patches; attempt to wipe off white patches; review of medical history and risk factors; ruling out other potential causes; biopsy to rule out cancer.
Treatments: Removal of the source of irritation (e.g., cessation of tobacco or alcohol use); surgical removal of leukoplakia patches; laser removal; cryotherapy; antiviral medications (for hairy leukoplakia); topical treatments (for hairy leukoplakia)
Tests: Oral brush biopsy; Excisional biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on symptoms and ruling out other conditions;  requires gradual decline in thinking ability and at least two of the following: varying alertness and thinking function, repeated visual hallucinations, movement symptoms, REM sleep behavior disorder;  supported by autonomic nervous system problems (blood pressure, heart rate, temperature, sweating issues) and sensitivity to antipsychotic medications like haloperidol.
Treatments: Cholinesterase inhibitors; Parkinson's disease medication; Medications to treat other symptoms;  Modifying the environment; Creating daily routines and simplifying tasks; Behavioral therapy (tolerating behaviors, reassurance and validation); Lifestyle modifications (exercise, mind stimulation, social activity, bedtime rituals)
Tests: Neurological and physical exam; Test of mental abilities (short and long forms); Blood tests; Brain scans (MRI or CT); Fluorodeoxyglucose PET brain scans; Single-photon emission computerized tomography (SPECT) or PET imaging; Sleep test (polysomnogram); Autonomic function test; Myocardial scintigraphy (not used in the US); Cerebrospinal fluid alpha-synuclein test (emerging biomarker); Skin sample alpha-synuclein test (emerging biomarker)
Medications_Drugs: Rivastigmine (Exelon); Donepezil (Aricept, Adlarity); Galantamine (Zunveyl); Memantine (Namenda); Carbidopa-levodopa (Sinemet, Duopa); Quetiapine (Seroquel); Clozapine (Clozaril, Versacloz);  Diphenhydramine (avoid); Oxybutynin (Oxytrol) (avoid)

Diagnosis: Head lice diagnosis involves finding live lice or nits within 1/4 inch of the scalp; Body lice diagnosis involves finding eggs or lice in clothing seams or bedding, or lice on skin; Pubic lice diagnosis involves finding moving lice or nits on pubic or other coarse hair.  Visual inspection with or without a Wood's light is used.
Treatments: Nonprescription shampoos and lotions; Prescription shampoos and lotions; Oral prescription medication; Bathing with soap and water; Washing clothing and bedding in hot water; Vacuuming floors and furniture; Sealing unwashable items in airtight bags; Nit combing;  Hot air dehydration machine (professional treatment only).
Tests: Visual inspection; Wood's light examination

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a discussion of symptoms and medical history, a physical exam, and examination of affected tissue to identify cell patterns characteristic of lichen planus.
Treatments: No treatment if asymptomatic; Corticosteroid cream or ointment; Corticosteroid pills or injections; Hydroxychloroquine; Metronidazole; Cyclosporine; Azathioprine; Methotrexate; Mycophenolate; Sulfasalazine; Thalidomide; Antihistamines; Light therapy (phototherapy); Retinoids; Addressing underlying triggers (e.g., medication changes, allergy testing); Aloe vera gel (vulvar lichen planus); Aloe vera mouthwash (oral lichen planus); Stress reduction techniques.
Tests: Biopsy; Blood tests (e.g., for hepatitis C); Allergy skin tests
Medications_Drugs: Corticosteroids; Hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil); Metronidazole (Flagyl); Cyclosporine (Sandimmune); Azathioprine (Azasan); Methotrexate (Trexall); Mycophenolate (Cellcept); Sulfasalazine; Thalidomide (Thalomid); Antihistamines; Acitretin; Hydrocortisone cream (1% or greater, over-the-counter).

Diagnosis: Visual examination of affected skin; Biopsy to rule out cancer or if skin doesn't respond to steroid creams.  Referral to dermatologist, gynecologist, urologist, or pain medicine specialist may occur.
Treatments: Steroid ointment (clobetasol); Calcineurin inhibitor (tacrolimus ointment); Circumcision (in males with narrowed urethral opening); Petroleum jelly application; Gentle daily washing with mild unscented soap; Avoiding excessive bathing; Soaking in plain warm water; Oral antihistamines; Using soft unscented toilet paper; Avoiding irritants like tight clothing and scented detergents.
Tests: Biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam of the lip, mouth, face, and neck to look for signs of cancer; a biopsy to remove a tissue sample for laboratory analysis to determine the presence, type, and aggressiveness of cancer; and imaging tests (CT, MRI, or PET) to determine if cancer has spread.
Treatments: Surgery (including reconstructive surgery and removal of lymph nodes); Radiation therapy (including brachytherapy); Chemotherapy; Targeted drug therapy; Immunotherapy
Tests: Physical exam; Biopsy; Computerized tomography (CT); Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Positron emission tomography (PET)

Diagnosis: A healthcare professional may examine the lipoma; a tissue sample (biopsy) may be removed for lab examination; an X-ray, ultrasound, MRI, or CT scan may be ordered if the lipoma is large, has unusual features, or appears deeper than the fatty tissue.  If liposarcoma is suspected (a cancerous tumor in fatty tissue that grows rapidly, doesn't move under the skin, and is often painful), a biopsy, MRI, or CT scan is typically done.
Treatments: Surgical removal; Liposuction
Tests: Skin biopsy; X-ray; Ultrasound; MRI; CT scan

Diagnosis: Liposarcoma diagnosis involves imaging tests (X-ray, CT scan, MRI, PET scan) to visualize the tumor and a biopsy to obtain a tissue sample for pathological examination to confirm the presence of cancerous cells.  The type of biopsy depends on the cancer's location.
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Clinical trials
Tests: X-ray; CT scan; MRI; PET scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: A blood test is often used to diagnose listeria infection; spinal fluid and amniotic fluid (if pregnant) may also be tested.
Treatments: Antibiotics; For mild symptoms, treatment may not be necessary.
Tests: Blood test; Spinal fluid analysis; Amniotic fluid analysis

Diagnosis: Liver cancer diagnosis may be made through imaging studies such as CT scans or MRIs; sometimes, a liver biopsy is necessary to remove a tissue sample for microscopic examination of cancer cells.  Blood tests may reveal liver function abnormalities.
Treatments: Surgery (tumor removal; liver transplant); Radiofrequency ablation; Microwave ablation; Laser ablation; Cryoablation; Alcohol injection; Chemoembolization; Radiation therapy (external beam; stereotactic body radiotherapy); Targeted drug therapy; Immunotherapy; Chemotherapy
Tests: Blood tests; Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI; Bone scan; Liver biopsy; Chest X-rays

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a health history and physical exam.  Liver function tests are used to diagnose liver disease; other blood tests may detect specific liver problems or genetic conditions. Imaging tests (ultrasound, CT scan, MRI) can show liver damage. A liver biopsy is used to examine a tissue sample for a definitive diagnosis and assess the severity of liver damage.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (weight loss, alcohol abstinence); Medications; Surgery; Liver transplant
Tests: Liver function tests; Blood tests; Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI; Liver biopsy; Needle biopsy

Diagnosis: Liver hemangiomas are often discovered incidentally during imaging for other reasons.  Diagnosis is typically made through imaging studies that visualize the liver.  The size and location of the hemangioma, as well as the presence of multiple lesions or symptoms, inform treatment decisions.
Treatments: Surgery to remove the liver hemangioma; Surgery to remove part of the liver including the hemangioma; Procedures to stop blood flow to the hemangioma (hepatic artery ligation or arterial embolization); Liver transplant surgery; Radiation therapy (rarely used)
Tests: Ultrasound; Computerized tomography (CT) scanning; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Scintigraphy

Diagnosis: Most often diagnosed during a breast biopsy; often cannot be detected on mammogram or by breast exam;  pathologists examine cells from biopsy samples to confirm diagnosis.  Pleomorphic LCIS may be visible on mammogram.
Treatments: Close monitoring; Medication to lower breast cancer risk; Surgery to lower breast cancer risk (risk-reducing mastectomy or prophylactic mastectomy); Lumpectomy; Mastectomy.
Tests: Core needle biopsy; Surgical biopsy; Mammogram; Breast exam; Breast MRI; Molecular breast imaging; other supplemental breast imaging tests.

Diagnosis: Physical examination including assessment of symptoms and medical/family history; Electrocardiogram (ECG) to identify a prolonged QT interval.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes; Medications; Left cardiac sympathetic denervation (LCSD) surgery; Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD); Fluids or minerals (e.g., magnesium)
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG); Holter monitor; Event recorder; Exercise stress test; Genetic testing
Medications_Drugs: Nadolol (Corgard); Propranolol (Inderal LA, InnoPran XL); Mexiletine

Diagnosis: Physical exam including blood pressure check; review of medical history; home blood pressure monitoring (readings at or just below 90/60 mm Hg not always concerning, especially without symptoms).
Treatments: Increased salt intake (with healthcare professional consultation); Increased fluid intake; Compression stockings; Abdominal binders; Lifestyle modifications (small, low-carb meals; regular exercise; avoiding hot/humid exercise; attention to body position changes); Avoiding alcohol;  Medication changes (if low blood pressure is a medication side effect).
Tests: Tilt table test; Blood tests; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG)

Diagnosis: Low sex drive in women may be diagnosed through a discussion of symptoms with a healthcare professional; a pelvic exam to check for physical changes (skin diseases of the vulva, vaginal thinning, dryness, or pain); and assessment of medical and sexual history.  The diagnosis of sexual interest-arousal disorder requires at least three of specified symptoms causing sadness or anxiety: no desire for sexual activity or masturbation; few or no sexual thoughts or fantasies; unwillingness to initiate sexual activity; reduced or absent pleasure during sex; reduced or absent interest in sexual cues from a partner; few or no physical sensations during sex.
Treatments: Sex education; Counseling; Medication; Hormone therapy; Couples counseling; Lifestyle changes (exercise, stress reduction, improved communication with partner)
Tests: Blood tests (to check hormone levels, thyroid problems, diabetes, high cholesterol, and liver disorders); Pelvic exam
Medications_Drugs: Mirtazapine (Remeron); Vilazodone (Viibryd); Bupropion (Forfivo XL, Wellbutrin XL, others); Vortioxetine (Trintellix); Flibanserin (Addyi); Bremelanotide (Vyleesi); Estrogen (various forms including pills, patches, sprays, gels, creams, suppositories, and rings); Testosterone (off-label use in some cases); Prasterone (Intrarosa); Ospemifene (Osphena)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of low sperm count is typically made through a semen analysis, which involves microscopic examination of a semen sample to determine sperm count (fewer than 15 million sperm/ml or less than 39 million total).  A physical exam and review of medical history are also conducted to investigate potential underlying causes.  Two or more semen analyses are often performed over time.
Treatments: Surgery (e.g., varicocele repair, vas deferens repair, vasectomy reversal, sperm retrieval from testicles or epididymis); Treatments for infections (antibiotics); Treatments for sexual conditions (medicine or counseling); Hormone treatments and medications; Assisted reproductive technology (ART) including intrauterine insemination, in vitro fertilization, and intracytoplasmic sperm injection.
Tests: Semen analysis; Scrotal ultrasound; Hormone testing; Post-ejaculation urinalysis; Genetic tests; Testicle biopsy; Transrectal ultrasound

Diagnosis: Lung cancer diagnosis often begins with imaging tests (X-ray, CT, MRI, PET scan) to identify the location and size of the tumor.  Suspicion of lung cancer may lead to sputum cytology to examine coughed-up mucus for cancerous cells; a biopsy (bronchoscopy, mediastinoscopy, needle biopsy) is performed to obtain tissue samples for definitive diagnosis and cancer type determination.  Screening with low-dose CT scans is offered to high-risk individuals (age 50+, heavy smokers, or those who quit within the past 15 years).
Treatments: Surgery (wedge resection; segmental resection; lobectomy; pneumonectomy); Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy; Stereotactic body radiotherapy (stereotactic radiosurgery); Comfort care
Tests: X-ray; MRI; CT scan; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; Sputum cytology; Bronchoscopy; Mediastinoscopy; Needle biopsy; Bone scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosing lupus is challenging due to varying signs and symptoms that overlap with other disorders. Diagnosis relies on a combination of blood and urine test results, physical examination findings, and patient symptoms; no single test confirms lupus.
Treatments: Medication adjustments based on symptom flares and remissions
Tests: Complete blood count; Erythrocyte sedimentation rate; Kidney and liver assessment blood tests; Urinalysis; Antinuclear antibody (ANA) test; Chest X-ray; Echocardiogram; Kidney biopsy; Skin biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Naproxen sodium; Ibuprofen; Hydroxychloroquine; Prednisone; Methylprednisolone; Azathioprine; Mycophenolate; Methotrexate; Cyclosporine; Leflunomide; Belimumab; Rituximab

Diagnosis: Lupus nephritis is diagnosed through blood and urine tests (including 24-hour urine collection to assess kidney function) and a kidney biopsy, which confirms the diagnosis and assesses disease severity.  Multiple biopsies may be performed over time.
Treatments: Reduce symptoms and achieve remission; Prevent disease progression; Prevent symptom recurrence; Maintain adequate kidney function to avoid dialysis or kidney transplant; Diet changes (limiting protein and salt); Blood pressure management with ACE inhibitors, ARBs, and diuretics; Immunosuppressive medications to slow or stop the immune system's attack on healthy cells. Dialysis; Kidney transplant (for kidney failure).
Tests: Blood and urine tests; 24-hour urine collection; Kidney biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Prednisone; Cyclosporine; Voclosporin; Tacrolimus; Cyclophosphamide; Azathioprine; Mycophenolate; Rituximab; Belimumab

Diagnosis: Review of signs and symptoms; History of known or possible tick exposure; Blood tests to detect antibodies to Borrelia bacteria;  A characteristic rash may be sufficient for diagnosis in areas where Lyme disease is common.
Treatments: Oral antibiotics; Intravenous antibiotics
Tests: Blood tests to find disease-fighting antibodies to the bacteria

Diagnosis: Lymphedema diagnosis is based on signs and symptoms, particularly if there's a history of cancer surgery involving lymph nodes.  If the cause isn't obvious, imaging tests are used to visualize the lymph system.
Treatments: Exercises; Manual lymph drainage; Compression bandages; Compression garments; Sequential pneumatic compression; Lymph node transplant; Creation of new drainage paths; Removal of fibrous tissue
Tests: MRI scan; CT scan; Ultrasound; Lymphoscintigraphy

Diagnosis: Lymphoma diagnosis often begins with an exam checking for swollen lymph nodes;  Further investigations include imaging tests (CT, MRI, PET scans) and a biopsy to remove lymph nodes for testing to identify cancer cells.  The type of tests used depends on the lymphoma's location and symptoms. A bone marrow aspiration and biopsy may also be performed.
Treatments: Radiation; Chemotherapy; Immunotherapy; Targeted therapy; Bone marrow transplant (stem cell transplant);  A combination of treatments may be used.  Treatment may be delayed depending on lymphoma grade and symptoms.
Tests: Physical Exam; Biopsy; CT scan; MRI scan; PET scan; Bone marrow aspiration; Bone marrow biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis may begin with a review of family cancer history, looking for multiple relatives with Lynch-associated cancers (colon, endometrial, etc.), cancers diagnosed before age 50, multiple cancer types in one family member, or multiple generations with the same cancer type.  This may lead to genetic testing, immunohistochemistry (IHC) testing on cancer cells, and microsatellite instability (MSI) testing on cancer cells. Positive IHC or MSI results suggest genetic changes associated with Lynch syndrome, but genetic testing is needed to confirm if the changes are present in all cells.
Treatments: Colonoscopy screening;  Hysterectomy; Intrauterine device (IUD); Oophorectomy; Oral contraceptive pills; Aspirin (for cancer prevention); Surgery to remove organs (prophylactic surgery)
Tests: Immunohistochemistry (IHC) testing; Microsatellite instability (MSI) testing; Genetic testing; Colonoscopy; Endometrial biopsy; Ultrasound imaging of the uterus; Blood test for ovarian cancer; Endoscopy; Urine test for urinary system cancers; MRI for pancreatic cancer; Neurological exam; Skin exam

Diagnosis: Changes in central vision, loss of ability to see fine detail, particularly in individuals over 60, may be the first signs;  routine eye exams are important for early detection.
Treatments: Early detection and treatment may help reduce vision loss; in some instances, early treatment may recover vision.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Review of medical history and recent travel; Physical exam; Blood tests to detect the presence of malaria parasite, identify the parasite type, assess drug resistance, and check for complications.
Treatments: Prescription drugs to kill the parasite
Tests: Blood tests
Medications_Drugs: Chloroquine phosphate; Artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs), including artemether-lumefantrine (Coartem) and artesunate-mefloquine; Atovaquone-proguanil (Malarone); Quinine sulfate (Qualaquin) with doxycycline; Primaquine phosphate

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a clinical breast exam to assess lumps; imaging tests such as mammogram, ultrasound, or MRI to visualize breast tissue; and a biopsy to examine breast cells under a microscope for cancer cells, hormone receptors, and DNA changes.  Staging involves imaging tests (bone scan, CT scan, PET scan) and lab tests on cancer cells to determine grade and receptor status (estrogen, progesterone, HER2).
Treatments: Surgery (mastectomy; lumpectomy); Radiation therapy; Hormone therapy; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy
Tests: Clinical breast exam; Mammogram; Ultrasound; MRI scan; Biopsy; Bone scan; CT scan; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; Sentinel lymph node biopsy

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing sexual development (pubic hair, muscle mass, testes size); Blood test for testosterone levels (typically done early in the day); Further testing (hormone testing; semen analysis; pituitary imaging; genetic studies; testicular biopsy) if low testosterone is confirmed to determine underlying cause (testicular disorder or pituitary abnormality). Early detection in boys is important to prevent problems from delayed puberty; early diagnosis and treatment in men helps prevent osteoporosis and other related conditions.
Treatments: Testosterone replacement therapy; Treatment for pituitary problems (hormone therapy; surgery; medicine; radiation);  Infertility treatment (pituitary hormone therapy).
Tests: Blood testosterone level test; Hormone testing; Semen analysis; Pituitary imaging; Genetic studies; Testicular biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Testosterone undecanoate (Jatenzo, Tlando, Kyzatrex); Testosterone cypionate (Depo-Testosterone); Testosterone enanthate (Xyosted)

Diagnosis: Male infertility diagnosis involves a general physical examination, medical history review (including inherited conditions, health problems, illnesses, injuries, surgeries, sexual habits, and pubertal development), and semen analysis (assessing sperm count, morphology, motility, and signs of infection).  Multiple semen analyses may be performed. If the semen analysis is normal, female partner testing is recommended before further male testing.
Treatments: Surgery (varicocele repair, vas deferens repair, vasectomy reversal, sperm retrieval); Treating infections (antibiotic treatment); Treatments for sexual intercourse problems (medication or counseling for erectile dysfunction or premature ejaculation); Hormone treatments and medications; Assisted reproductive technology (ART) (including in vitro fertilization and intracytoplasmic sperm injection); Sperm donor; Adoption
Tests: General physical examination; Medical history review; Semen analysis; Scrotal ultrasound; Transrectal ultrasound; Hormone testing; Post-ejaculation urinalysis; Genetic tests; Testicular biopsy; Specialized sperm function tests

Diagnosis: Malignant hyperthermia is diagnosed based on signs and symptoms; monitoring during and immediately after anesthesia; and lab tests to identify complications. Susceptibility testing may be recommended if risk factors are present.
Treatments: Medication; Oxygen; Body cooling; Extra fluids; Supportive care
Tests: Genetic testing; Muscle biopsy (contracture test)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a neurological exam to gather clues; imaging tests such as MRI, magnetic resonance neurography, CT scan, and PET scan to visualize the tumor and assess spread; and a biopsy (needle or surgical) to examine a tissue sample for cancerous cells.  Further tests may characterize the cancer cells to inform treatment planning.
Treatments: Surgery (to remove the tumor, potentially with limb amputation); Radiation therapy (before or after surgery); Chemotherapy (if the tumor has spread); Rehabilitation (physical and occupational therapy)
Tests: Neurological exam; MRI; Magnetic resonance neurography; CT scan; PET scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on information provided by the patient and a physical exam.  Additional tests may be needed, depending on the findings.
Treatments: Antibiotics; Pain medication; Surgery (surgical removal of affected milk duct if abscess develops and other treatments fail) ; Warm compresses; Breast pads; Supportive bra; Sleeping on the opposite side; Smoking cessation
Tests: Diagnostic ultrasound of the nipple and areola; Diagnostic mammography

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam checking for swollen lymph nodes, spleen, or liver.  Further diagnosis involves blood tests (including LDH levels), imaging tests (CT and PET scans), lymph node biopsy, and bone marrow aspiration and biopsy.  Lab testing of biopsy samples examines proteins on the surface of cancer cells (CD19, CD20, CD5, SOX11) and DNA changes (translocation involving cyclin D1 and TP53 genes) to confirm mantle cell lymphoma. Staging is determined using imaging tests, blood tests, and biopsies.
Treatments: Watch and wait; Radiation therapy; Immunotherapy; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; CAR-T cell therapy; Bone marrow transplant
Tests: Blood tests; LDH blood test; CT scan; PET scan; Lymph node biopsy; Bone marrow aspiration; Bone marrow biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is challenging due to overlapping symptoms with other connective tissue disorders; diagnosis requires certain combinations of symptoms and family history; genetic testing often confirms diagnosis.
Treatments: Regular monitoring for disease progression; Aortic repair; Aortic valve replacement; Valve-sparing aortic root repair; Aortic valve and aortic root replacement; Scoliosis treatment (bracing, surgery); Breastbone corrections (surgical); Eye surgeries (retinal repair, cataract surgery); Blood pressure lowering drugs.
Tests: Echocardiogram; CT scan; MRI; Slit-lamp exam; Eye pressure test; Genetic testing

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing symptoms and medical history; breast ultrasound; aspiration of breast fluid for culture; mammogram; biopsy (if symptoms persist after antibiotics).  Differential diagnosis considers inflammatory breast cancer.
Treatments: Antibiotics; Pain relievers; Breastfeeding; Lactation consultant advice (including breastfeeding techniques and positions: cross-cradle, cradle, football, side-lying);  Warm, moist compress application; Milk expression.
Tests: Breast ultrasound; Fluid aspiration and culture; Mammogram; Biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Antibiotics (specific type determined by culture)

Diagnosis: Newborn screening via heel prick blood test; Genetic testing of blood, saliva, cheek cells, skin, or other tissue samples to identify the changed gene; Metabolic specialist and registered dietitian consultation; Lab tests to assess metabolic processes.
Treatments: Frequent feedings with complex carbohydrates for infants; Regular meals and snacks with complex carbohydrates for children and adults; Dietary management to maintain blood sugar levels and prevent hypoglycemia; Avoiding fasting longer than recommended; Increased complex carbohydrate intake during illness, stress, or increased activity; Emergency plan for hypoglycemia management including simple carbohydrates and medical care if needed.
Tests: Newborn screening blood test; Genetic testing; Metabolic function lab tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on the characteristic rash and Koplik spots (tiny white spots inside the mouth);  a healthcare professional will also inquire about measles vaccination history, recent travel to areas with measles outbreaks, and contact with individuals exhibiting rash or fever; lab tests can confirm the diagnosis by detecting viral genetic material or proteins related to the body's immune response.
Treatments: Supportive care to ease symptoms (rest, nutrition, hydration);  rehydration solutions; over-the-counter fever reducers (excluding aspirin in children and teenagers); antibiotics for secondary bacterial infections (e.g., pneumonia, ear infection); oxygen therapy or breathing support for airway inflammation; vitamin A for children (dose dependent on age and only under professional recommendation); immune globulin (for children under 11 months exposed to measles and not immune).
Tests: Genetic testing for measles virus; protein detection related to the body's immune response to the virus; nose or throat swab; urine sample; blood sample
Medications_Drugs: Antibiotics; Vitamin A (only as prescribed by a healthcare professional); Over-the-counter fever reducers (excluding aspirin in children and teenagers).

Diagnosis: Physical examination including auscultation for bruits; review of symptoms; ruling out other conditions causing similar symptoms.
Treatments: Surgery (median arcuate ligament release, decompression; laparoscopic surgery);  Nutritional counseling.
Tests: Blood tests; Ultrasound of the abdomen; Upper endoscopy; Gastric emptying studies; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Abdominal computerized tomography (CT); Celiac plexus block.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily based on patient history of headaches and medication use;  criteria include a headache condition, headaches on 15 or more days a month for more than three months, and overuse of headache medication.  Most people do not require further testing.
Treatments: Stop or reduce pain medication; bridge/transitional therapy with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs; corticosteroids; nerve blocks; anti-nausea medications; intravenous dihydroergotamine; preventive medications (anticonvulsants such as topiramate; tricyclic antidepressants such as amitriptyline or nortriptyline; beta blockers such as propranolol; calcium channel blockers such as verapamil; CGRP monoclonal antibodies such as erenumab, galcanezumab, fremanezumab, or eptinezumab); onabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) injections; cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT); acupuncture; biofeedback; mindfulness.
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: topiramate; amitriptyline; nortriptyline; propranolol; verapamil; erenumab; galcanezumab; fremanezumab; eptinezumab; onabotulinumtoxinA

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a medical history review and symptom discussion.  Key diagnostic methods include neurological exam (assessing vision, hearing, balance, coordination, and reflexes); imaging tests (CT and MRI scans to show tumor size, location, and cerebrospinal fluid pressure or blockages);  biopsy (rarely used, involves removing a tumor sample for testing); and cerebrospinal fluid testing (via spinal tap, performed after managing brain pressure or tumor removal).
Treatments: Surgery to relieve fluid buildup in the brain; Surgery to remove the medulloblastoma; Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Clinical trials
Tests: Neurological exam; CT scan; MRI; Biopsy; Cerebrospinal fluid analysis (spinal tap)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam to look for signs of melanoma; a biopsy (excisional or punch) to remove a tissue sample for lab testing; assessment of melanoma thickness under a microscope;  determination of melanoma spread to lymph nodes (potentially using sentinel node biopsy); and imaging tests (X-ray, MRI, CT, PET scan) if there's concern of spread beyond the skin.  Staging uses numbers 0-4, with higher numbers indicating deeper invasion and spread.
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy; Immunotherapy; Targeted therapy; Chemotherapy; Isolated limb perfusion
Tests: Physical exam; Excisional biopsy; Punch biopsy; Sentinel node biopsy; X-ray; MRI; CT scan; PET scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis requires two or more vertigo attacks (20 minutes to 24 hours each); hearing loss confirmed by audiometry; tinnitus or a feeling of fullness/pressure in the ear; ruling out other conditions with similar symptoms.
Treatments: Vestibular rehabilitation therapy; Hearing aid; Middle ear injections (gentamicin; steroids); Endolymphatic sac surgery; Labyrinthectomy; Vestibular nerve section;  Dietary changes (limiting salt intake);  Medication for vertigo attacks and long-term management
Tests: Audiometry; Electronystagmogram (ENG) or videonystagmography (VNG); Rotary-chair testing; Vestibular evoked myogenic potentials (VEMP) testing; Computerized dynamic posturography (CDP); Video head impulse test (vHIT); Electrocochleography (ECoG); Lab tests; Imaging scans (CT scan; MRI)
Medications_Drugs: Meclizine (Antivert); Diazepam (Valium); Promethazine; Diuretics; Betahistine; Gentamicin; Dexamethasone

Diagnosis: A thorough neurological exam is conducted, followed by imaging tests with contrast dye such as CT scan and MRI scan.  A biopsy may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other tumors.  Diagnosis can be difficult due to slow tumor growth and subtle symptoms often mistaken for other conditions or aging.
Treatments: Wait-and-see approach; Surgery; Stereotactic radiosurgery; Fractionated stereotactic radiotherapy; Intensity-modulated radiation therapy; Proton beam radiation; Radiation therapy
Tests: CT scan; MRI scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical history, physical exam, and results from various tests.  Key criteria include low sugar levels, high white blood cell count, and increased protein in spinal fluid (for meningitis).  Imaging may show swelling or irritation.
Treatments: Intravenous antibiotics (for bacterial meningitis); Corticosteroids (to reduce swelling and risk of complications); Antiviral medication (for herpes-related meningitis); Bed rest; Plenty of fluids; Pain medication (for viral meningitis); Antifungal medications (for fungal meningitis);  Combination antibiotic therapy (for tuberculous meningitis); Treatment for underlying cancer (for cancer-related meningitis)
Tests: Blood cultures; Blood smear microscopy; CT scan; MRI scan; X-ray of head, chest, or sinuses; Spinal tap (lumbar puncture); Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) amplification (for viral meningitis)
Medications_Drugs: Intravenous antibiotics; Corticosteroids; Antiviral medicine; Pain medication; Antifungal medications; Combination antibiotic therapy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily based on the presence of characteristic symptoms, such as irregular periods and hot flashes.  Blood tests to measure follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and estradiol levels may be used, but are not always necessary, and can be difficult to interpret during perimenopause. Home urine FSH tests are available but unreliable.
Treatments: Hormone therapy (estrogen, possibly with progestin); Vaginal estrogen (cream, tablet, or ring); Prasterone (Intrarosa); Low-dose antidepressants (SSRIs and SNRIs); Gabapentin; Clonidine; Fezolinetant; Oxybutynin; Medications to prevent or treat osteoporosis; Ospemifene; Lifestyle modifications (dress in layers, use fans, avoid triggers, use lubricants, maintain sexual activity, get enough sleep, relax, strengthen pelvic floor, eat a balanced diet, manage weight, don't smoke, exercise regularly)
Tests: Blood test for FSH and estradiol; Blood test for TSH; Home urine FSH test
Medications_Drugs: Estrogen; Progestin; Prasterone (Intrarosa); Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs); Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs); Gabapentin; Clonidine; Fezolinetant; Oxybutynin; Ospemifene; Vitamin D supplements; Medications to prevent or treat osteoporosis (specific medications not listed)

Diagnosis: Review of medical history and physical exam, including pelvic exam to check for abnormalities and infection;  Ultrasound to image uterus, cervix, fallopian tubes, and ovaries;  CT scan or MRI scan for detailed imaging of internal structures; Laparoscopy to detect underlying conditions like endometriosis, adhesions, fibroids, ovarian cysts, and ectopic pregnancy (though not usually necessary for diagnosis of menstrual cramps).
Treatments: Pain relievers; Hormonal birth control; Surgery; Exercise; Heat application (hot bath, heating pad); Dietary supplements (vitamin E, omega-3 fatty acids, vitamin B-1, vitamin B-6, magnesium); Acupuncture; Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS); Herbal medicine (pycnogenol, fennel); Acupressure
Tests: Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI scan; Laparoscopy
Medications_Drugs: Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Prescription nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs; Oral birth control pills

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam to rule out physical causes; lab tests such as thyroid function checks and drug/alcohol screenings; and a psychological evaluation including interviews and questionnaires to assess symptoms, thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.  Diagnostic criteria are detailed in the DSM-5.
Treatments: Combination of treatments often best; primary care provider treatment may suffice for mild, well-controlled illness; team approach (psychiatrist, psychotherapist, social worker, etc.) for severe illnesses; psychotherapy; medications.
Tests: Physical exam; Lab tests (e.g., thyroid function, drug/alcohol screening)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical history and physical exam, including assessment of thigh sensation, pain description, and tracing of numb/painful areas.  Strength and reflex testing help exclude other causes.  Imaging may rule out other conditions.
Treatments: Wearing looser clothing; Weight loss; Over-the-counter pain relievers (acetaminophen, ibuprofen, aspirin); Corticosteroid injections; Tricyclic antidepressants; Gabapentin; Phenytoin; Pregabalin; Surgery (rarely, for severe, long-lasting symptoms)
Tests: Physical exam; Imaging studies (CT scan or MRI if tumor suspected); Electromyography (EMG); Nerve conduction study; Nerve block (with ultrasound guidance)
Medications_Drugs: Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Aspirin; Corticosteroids; Tricyclic antidepressants; Gabapentin; Phenytoin; Pregabalin

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam to visually assess skin growths.  A biopsy is then performed to obtain a tissue sample for laboratory analysis to confirm the presence of cancer cells.  This can be challenging due to similarities to other skin growths.  Further tests may be used to determine if the cancer has metastasized.
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy; Immunotherapy; Chemotherapy
Tests: Physical exam; Biopsy; Sentinel node biopsy; Chest X-ray; CT scan; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan

Diagnosis: Chronic mesenteric ischemia is suspected with post-prandial pain leading to limited food intake and weight loss.  Narrowing of major arteries to the small intestine confirms the diagnosis.
Treatments: Immediate surgery (for acute mesenteric ischemia caused by blood clot); Angioplasty; Stent placement; Open surgery
Tests: Angiography; CT scan; MRI; X-ray of the belly (with contrast dye); Doppler ultrasound

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves medical history review and physical examination.  An ultrasound of the stomach area is often used; a CT scan of the stomach area may also be used. Blood tests can help identify infection type and presence.
Treatments: Mild cases often resolve on their own; Rest; Fluids; Moist heat application to the stomach; Liquid diet; Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Antibiotics (for moderate to severe bacterial infection)
Tests: Blood tests; Abdominal ultrasound; CT scan of the stomach area

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam checking for lumps; imaging tests such as chest X-ray and CT scan of the chest or abdomen may be used; a biopsy is the only definitive way to confirm mesothelioma, involving needle aspiration or surgical tissue sampling.  Further tests determine the extent of cancer spread.
Treatments: Surgery (pleurodesis, pleurectomy, lung and surrounding tissue removal); Chemotherapy; Hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC); Radiation therapy; Immunotherapy; Targeted therapy; Clinical trials
Tests: Chest X-ray; CT scan of chest and abdomen; MRI; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; Needle biopsy; Surgical biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical history, family medical history, physical exam, blood pressure measurements, and blood tests.  The National Institutes of Health defines metabolic syndrome as having three or more of the following: large waist circumference (≥35 inches for women, ≥40 inches for men); high triglyceride level (≥150 mg/dL or ≥1.7 mmol/L); low HDL cholesterol (<40 mg/dL in men, <50 mg/dL in women); high blood pressure (≥130/80 mm Hg); high fasting blood sugar (≥100 mg/dL or ≥5.6 mmol/L).  Being on medication to manage these conditions also counts.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (diet and exercise); medications to manage blood pressure, cholesterol, and blood sugar levels; weight loss; weight-loss surgery (in some cases)
Tests: Blood pressure measurement; blood tests (including triglyceride, HDL cholesterol, and fasting blood sugar levels)

Diagnosis: Physical examination (including neurological exam) and review of symptoms and medical history; assessment of psychological and cognitive abilities and behavior.  Diagnostic tests are used to confirm diagnosis and determine severity.
Treatments: Medications to reduce signs and symptoms; Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Speech therapy; Nutritional assistance; Assistive feeding devices; Wheelchair; Walker; Other assistive devices; Mechanical ventilation; Treatments to prevent or address complications; Long-term care or hospitalization;  Participation in clinical trials (gene therapy; enzyme replacement or enhancement therapy; substrate reduction therapy).
Tests: Blood tests (enzyme deficiency); Urine tests (sulfatide levels); Genetic tests (mutations in associated gene); Nerve conduction study; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves blood tests (PSA test to detect elevated PSA levels indicating potential cancer recurrence) and imaging tests to identify cancer spread to other body parts.  A rising PSA level after treatment may prompt imaging.
Treatments: Hormone therapy; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy; Radiopharmaceutical treatments
Tests: PSA test; Bone scan; CT scan; MRI; PET scan; PSMA PET scan; Choline C-11 PET scan; Biopsy
Medications_Drugs: degarelix (Firmagon); leuprolide (Camcevi, Eligard, Lupron Depot); bicalutamide (Casodex)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical examination of the foot while the patient is standing and sitting, assessing lifestyle and activities; X-rays may be used to rule out stress fractures or other foot problems.
Treatments: Rest; Wearing different shoes; Using arch support or metatarsal pad; Surgery (rarely, if self-care fails and conditions like hammertoe are present)
Tests: X-ray

Diagnosis: Head circumference measurement compared to growth charts; assessment of prenatal, birth, and family history; physical exam;  head CT scan or MRI (if developmental delay is present); blood tests (to determine underlying cause if developmental delay is present).
Treatments: Early childhood intervention programs (speech, physical, and occupational therapy); medication for complications (e.g., seizures or hyperactivity); surgery for craniosynostosis.
Tests: Head circumference measurement; Complete blood count (CBC); CT scan; MRI; blood tests

Diagnosis: Microscopic colitis is diagnosed through colonoscopy or flexible sigmoidoscopy with biopsy to examine colon tissue under a microscope;  intestinal tissues often appear typical, requiring biopsy for confirmation.
Treatments: Dietary changes (low-fat, low-fiber diet; limiting dairy, gluten, caffeine, and sugar); Stopping potentially causative medications; Anti-diarrheal medications; Steroids; Bile acid blockers; Immunosuppressants; Biologic medicines; Surgery (rarely)
Tests: Colonoscopy and biopsies; Flexible sigmoidoscopy; Stool sample study; Blood test; Upper endoscopy with biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Loperamide; Bismuth subsalicylate; Budesonide; Cholestyramine/aspartame; Cholestyramine; Colestipol; Mercaptopurine; Azathioprine; Infliximab; Adalimumab; Vedolizumab

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical history, symptoms, and a physical and neurological exam.  For complex or serious cases, tests may be used to rule out other causes.
Treatments: Pain-relieving medicines; Preventive medicines; Biofeedback; Relaxation techniques; Cognitive behavioral therapy; Onabotulinum toxin A injections; Non-medication devices
Tests: MRI scan; CT scan; Lumbar puncture (spinal tap)
Medications_Drugs: Aspirin; Ibuprofen; Caffeine, aspirin, and acetaminophen combination; Sumatriptan; Rizatriptan; Zolmitriptan; Naratriptan; Almotriptan; Eletriptan; Frovatriptan; Dihydroergotamine; Lasmiditan; Ubrogepant; Rimegepant

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on signs and symptoms, medical and family history, and physical exam.  If aura isn't followed by headache, tests may be done to rule out other conditions.
Treatments: Medications for pain relief; Preventive medications
Tests: Eye examination; Head computerized tomography (CT) scan; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
Medications_Drugs: aspirin; ibuprofen; acetaminophen; sumatriptan; rizatriptan; dihydroergotamine; lasmiditan; Ubrogepant; rimegepant; opioid medications; chlorpromazine; metoclopramide; prochlorperazine; propranolol; metoprolol tartrate; verapamil; amitriptyline; valproate; topiramate

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on patient-provided information, medical evaluation, and test results;  criteria include changes in memory or other mental abilities confirmed by patient and family/friend;  decline in mental ability over time confirmed by family/friend; daily activities remain unaffected; mental status testing shows mild changes relative to age and education;  the condition is differentiated from dementia.
Treatments: Medicines for Alzheimer's disease; addressing underlying medical conditions or medications causing symptoms;  treatment of depression; treatment of high blood pressure; treatment of sleep apnea.
Tests: Short Test of Mental Status; Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA); Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE); Neurological exam (reflexes, eye movements, walking, balance); Blood tests (vitamin B-12, thyroid hormone, Alzheimer's-related proteins);  Lumbar puncture (to check cerebrospinal fluid for Alzheimer's-related proteins); MRI; CT scan; PET scan.
Medications_Drugs: Lecanemab-irmb (Leqembi); Donanemab-azbt (Kisunla); Cholinesterase inhibitors (not routinely recommended for MCI).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves detailed questioning about symptoms; physical examination; a detailed food diary; elimination diet; skin prick test (not completely accurate); blood test measuring IgE antibodies (not completely accurate); oral food challenge (if other tests are inconclusive).
Treatments: Avoidance of milk and milk proteins; Injectable epinephrine (e.g., EpiPen, Adrenaclick) for anaphylaxis.
Tests: Skin test; Blood test (IgE antibodies); Oral food challenge

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on clinical symptoms (vaginal bleeding, cramping, cervical dilation), and confirmed through tests such as blood hCG levels (repeated after 48 hours to assess falling levels), pelvic exam (checking cervical dilation), ultrasound (assessing fetal heartbeat and growth), and tissue tests (confirming miscarriage and ruling out other causes).  Chromosomal tests may be recommended for women with recurrent miscarriages.  Diagnostic terms used include threatened, inevitable, incomplete, missed, complete, and septic miscarriage, each with specific criteria.
Treatments: Expectant management; Medical treatment (mifepristone and misoprostol); Surgical treatment (suction dilation and curettage/uterine aspiration); Rh immunoglobulin (for Rh-negative women)
Tests: Blood tests (hCG levels, blood type); Pelvic exam; Ultrasound; Tissue tests; Chromosomal tests (for recurrent miscarriages)

Diagnosis: Physical examination including auscultation for heart murmurs; echocardiogram (standard and transesophageal); electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); chest X-ray; cardiac MRI; exercise or stress tests; cardiac catheterization (less commonly used for diagnosis, but may be used if other tests are inconclusive or to rule out coronary artery disease).
Treatments: Regular health checkups; Healthy lifestyle changes; Medications to treat symptoms; Blood thinners (for atrial fibrillation); Minimally invasive heart surgery; Mitral valve repair; Mitral valve replacement; Robot-assisted heart surgery
Tests: Echocardiogram; Transesophageal echocardiogram; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Chest X-ray; Cardiac MRI; Exercise tests or stress tests; Cardiac catheterization

Diagnosis: Physical exam with auscultation for clicking sounds or heart murmurs; Echocardiogram (TTE or TEE) to confirm diagnosis and determine severity.  Chest X-ray to assess heart and lung condition; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) to detect arrhythmias; Exercise or stress tests to assess heart response to activity; Cardiac catheterization (less common, used if other tests inconclusive).
Treatments: Regular checkups (for asymptomatic patients with mitral valve regurgitation); Medications for complications (irregular heartbeats, etc.); Surgery (mitral valve repair or replacement) for severe mitral valve regurgitation; Valve-in-valve procedure (for failing biological tissue valve).
Tests: Echocardiogram (TTE, TEE); Chest X-ray; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Exercise or stress tests; Cardiac catheterization
Medications_Drugs: Beta blockers; Diuretics; Antiarrhythmics; Anticoagulants (blood thinners); Antibiotics (prophylactically before dental procedures in some cases, particularly after mechanical valve replacement).

Diagnosis: Physical exam with stethoscope to listen for a heart murmur; Echocardiogram (TTE or TEE) to visualize the valve and blood flow; Electrocardiogram (ECG) to assess heart rhythm; Chest X-ray to evaluate heart and lung condition; Cardiac MRI for detailed heart imaging; Exercise or stress tests to assess heart response to activity; Cardiac catheterization (less common, used if other tests are inconclusive).
Treatments: Healthy lifestyle changes; Regular health checkups; Medications (diuretics, anticoagulants, blood pressure medications); Mitral valve repair surgery; Mitral valve replacement surgery; Robot-assisted minimally invasive mitral valve repair
Tests: Echocardiogram (TTE, TEE); Electrocardiogram (ECG); Chest X-ray; Cardiac MRI; Exercise tests/Stress tests; Cardiac catheterization

Diagnosis: Physical examination including auscultation for heart murmurs; review of symptoms and medical history; family history assessment.  Further investigation with imaging tests if symptoms present.
Treatments: Medicine; Valve repair or replacement surgery; Balloon valvuloplasty; Open-heart surgery (open valvotomy); Mitral valve replacement
Tests: Echocardiogram; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Chest X-ray; Exercise stress tests; Cardiac CT; Cardiac MRI; Cardiac catheterization
Medications_Drugs: Diuretics; Anticoagulants; Beta blockers; Calcium channel blockers; Antiarrhythmics; Antibiotics

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a thorough review of the patient's medical history, particularly menstrual cycles; a pelvic exam may be performed to rule out other conditions.
Treatments: Pain relievers; Birth control pills (oral contraceptives)
Tests: Pelvic exam

Diagnosis: Physical exam checking for swollen hands and painful, swollen joints; blood test to check for the presence of a certain antibody associated with mixed connective tissue disease (ENA test).
Treatments: Medication; Self-care measures such as protecting hands from cold, not smoking, and stress reduction.
Tests: Blood test (ENA test)
Medications_Drugs: Prednisone; Hydroxychloroquine; Nifedipine; Amlodipine;  Other immunosuppressants (specified based on individual symptoms); Bosentan; Sildenafil; Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium.

Diagnosis: Suspicion of molar pregnancy leads to blood tests and ultrasound.  Early ultrasound (8-9 weeks) may show absence of embryo/fetus, no amniotic fluid, a thick cystic placenta filling the uterus, and ovarian cysts (complete molar pregnancy).  Partial molar pregnancy ultrasound may show a smaller than expected fetus, low amniotic fluid, and an unusual placenta.
Treatments: Dilation and curettage (D&C); Removal of the uterus (rare, if high risk of GTN and no desire for future pregnancies); HCG monitoring
Tests: Transvaginal ultrasound; Blood tests; Sonogram

Diagnosis: Diagnosis considers signs and symptoms; physical examination to rule out other problems; skin prick test with diluted allergens; blood test (radioallergosorbent test) measuring IgE antibodies.
Treatments: Avoidance of triggers; Nasal corticosteroids; Antihistamines; Oral decongestants; Decongestant nasal sprays; Montelukast; Immunotherapy; Nasal lavage
Tests: Skin prick test; Blood test (radioallergosorbent test)
Medications_Drugs: ciclesonide (Omnaris, Zetonna); fluticasone (Flonase Allergy Relief, Xhance); mometasone (Nasonex); triamcinolone; budesonide (Rhinocort); loratadine (Alavert, Claritin); fexofenadine (Allegra Allergy); cetirizine (Zyrtec Allergy); azelastine (Astelin, Astepro); olopatadine (Patanase);  Sudafed 12 Hour; Drixoral Cold and Allergy; oxymetazoline (Afrin, others); montelukast (Singulair)

Diagnosis: Visual examination of the skin by a healthcare professional;  If suspicious, a biopsy (removal of the mole for microscopic examination) is performed.
Treatments: No treatment needed for most moles; Makeup to hide moles; Clipping or plucking hair from moles; Surgical removal of moles;
Tests: Skin biopsy

Diagnosis: Visual inspection of the skin; Skin scrapings viewed under a microscope (if necessary)
Treatments: No treatment (often resolves spontaneously); Retinoic acid; Benzoyl peroxide; Cantharidin; Scraping; Cryotherapy; Laser therapy
Tests: Skin scrapings microscopy

Diagnosis: MGUS is often discovered incidentally during blood tests for other reasons.  Diagnosis involves blood tests to detect higher protein levels and rule out other causes; urine tests to check for atypical protein and kidney damage; and imaging (MRI or PET scan) and bone density tests for those with bone pain.  A bone marrow test is done for those at high risk of a more serious disease or related problems.
Treatments: Watchful waiting; Regular checkups; Medications for osteoporosis
Tests: Blood tests; Urine tests (24-hour); MRI; PET scan; Bone density test; Bone marrow test
Medications_Drugs: alendronate (Fosamax); risedronate (Actonel, Atelvia); ibandronate; zoledronic acid (Reclast, Zometa)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on signs and symptoms (duration and presentation), physical exam findings (swollen lymph nodes, tonsils, liver, or spleen), and blood tests.  A physical exam assesses for signs of infection.
Treatments: Rest; Healthy diet; Plenty of fluids; Over-the-counter pain relievers; Treatment of secondary bacterial infections (e.g., strep throat, sinus infection, tonsillitis) with antibiotics; Corticosteroids for severe airway narrowing; Avoiding vigorous activity until spleen recovery.
Tests: Antibody tests (monospot test; other antibody tests); White blood cell count; Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) blood test
Medications_Drugs: Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Antibiotics (for secondary bacterial infections, specific antibiotics not specified but Amoxicillin and penicillin-based antibiotics are discouraged due to rash risk); Corticosteroids
