Diagnosis: A physical exam to rule out other illnesses; review of symptoms, medical and family history, and history of alcohol or drug use; assessment of past mood disorder episodes (duration, frequency, severity, and influence of substances); evaluation of current and past mental health issues; referral to a mental health professional may be necessary.
Treatments: Talk therapy (psychotherapy); medication; cognitive behavior therapy (CBT); family-focused therapy; transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS); electroconvulsive therapy (ECT).
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Typically diagnosed based on symptoms;  If hyperemesis gravidarum is suspected, an exam along with urine and blood tests may be needed.
Treatments: Vitamin B-6 supplements (pyridoxine); Ginger; Doxylamine (Unisom); Prescription anti-nausea medications; Extra fluids; Fluids through a vein (for hyperemesis gravidarum);  Feeding tube (rarely, for severe weight loss); Acupressure wristbands; Acupuncture; Hypnosis; Aromatherapy;  Dietary changes (high protein, low fat, bland foods, frequent small snacks); Avoiding nausea triggers.
Tests: Urine tests; Blood tests

Diagnosis: Clinical examination of affected skin and review of signs and symptoms; Skin biopsy to reveal collagen changes in the dermis; Distinction from systemic scleroderma and other conditions may involve blood tests and specialist consultation (dermatologist or rheumatologist);  Regular comprehensive eye exams for head and neck morphea.
Treatments: Medicated creams (vitamin D cream like calcipotriene; corticosteroid cream); Light therapy (phototherapy); Oral medications (methotrexate; corticosteroid pills; hydroxychloroquine; mycophenolate mofetil); Physical therapy
Tests: Skin biopsy; Blood test; Ultrasound; Magnetic resonance imaging
Medications_Drugs: Calcipotriene; Corticosteroid cream; Methotrexate; Hydroxychloroquine; Mycophenolate mofetil

Diagnosis: Physical examination including palpation of the ball of the foot to locate pain, squeezing the foot to feel for a click between metatarsal bones, testing toe range of motion, and checking for foot irregularities; Imaging tests may be used to confirm diagnosis or rule out other causes.
Treatments: Avoiding activities that worsen symptoms; Changing footwear (avoiding high heels, wearing shoes with wide toe boxes, using shoe inserts); Corticosteroid injection (often guided by ultrasound, may include local anesthetic); Surgery (neurectomy - surgical removal of the enlarged nerve portion); Other surgical procedures (disabling the nerve without removal, creating more space for the nerve by cutting connecting tissues).
Tests: X-ray; Ultrasound; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is typically made by visual examination of the bite and discussion of recent activities; Skeeter syndrome (an allergic reaction to mosquito saliva) is diagnosed based on the presence of large areas of swelling and itching following mosquito bites.
Treatments: Applying calamine lotion; Applying a nonprescription antihistamine cream; Applying a corticosteroid cream; Applying a baking soda and water paste; Rubbing with an ice cube; Applying pressure; Taking a nonprescription oral antihistamine.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Examination of lips and mouth; tissue sample removal for testing; evaluation of lumps, irritation, white patches (leukoplakia), and sores; biopsy to check tissue for cancer signs and DNA changes.
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy; Reconstructive surgery; Physical therapy; Rehabilitation services
Tests: Biopsy; Endoscopy; X-ray; CT scan; MRI; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam, review of symptoms, and medical history.  Further testing may be necessary depending on the suspected cause and symptoms.
Treatments: Medications; Botox injections; Treatment of underlying medical conditions; Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Speech therapy; Surgery; Deep brain stimulation
Tests: Blood tests; Genetic tests; MRI; CT scan; PET scan; Electromyography (EMG); Dopamine transporter (DAT) scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is made by a neurologist reviewing symptoms, family and medical history, and performing a physical exam.  Several tests are usually needed to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other conditions.
Treatments: Medicine; Surgery; Therapy
Tests: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA); Perfusion MRI; Computerized tomography scan (CT scan); CT angiogram; Cerebral angiogram; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; Single-photon emission computerized tomography (SPECT) scan; Electroencephalogram (EEG); Transcranial Doppler ultrasound
Medications_Drugs: Aspirin; Calcium channel blockers; Anti-seizure medicines

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of MRSA involves checking a tissue sample or nasal secretions for drug-resistant bacteria;  samples are cultured to encourage bacterial growth (taking about 48 hours); newer tests detecting staph DNA in hours are becoming available.
Treatments: Antibiotics; emergency surgery to drain large abscesses; drainage of small, shallow abscesses without antibiotics.
Tests: Culture of tissue sample or nasal secretions;  newer tests that detect staph DNA.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of MEN1 involves identifying characteristic tumors in endocrine glands (parathyroid, pancreas, pituitary) and/or clinical manifestations; genetic testing for mutations in the MEN1 gene is crucial for confirmation.  The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical findings, imaging studies, and genetic testing.
Treatments: Surgical removal of tumors; Hormone replacement therapy (depending on which hormones are affected);  Medical management of symptoms.
Tests: Genetic testing for MEN1 gene mutations; Imaging studies (e.g., ultrasound, CT, MRI) to detect tumors; Blood tests to measure hormone levels.

Diagnosis: Genetic testing to identify the causative gene; Screening for medullary thyroid cancer, parathyroid tumors, and adrenal tumors (pheochromocytoma) based on family history or suspected MEN 2;  Physical examination looking for characteristic features of MEN 2B (e.g., mucosal neuromas); Blood tests to assess hormone levels (e.g., calcitonin, parathyroid hormone); Imaging studies (e.g., ultrasound, CT scan) to detect tumors.
Treatments: Early surgical removal of the thyroid gland;  Surgery to remove parathyroid or adrenal tumors; Treatment of associated conditions like primary hyperparathyroidism or pheochromocytoma.
Tests: Genetic testing; Blood tests; Ultrasound; CT scan;  Imaging studies

Diagnosis: Multiple myeloma is diagnosed through blood tests (detecting M proteins and beta-2-microglobulin, assessing kidney function, blood cell counts, calcium, and uric acid levels); urine tests (detecting Bence Jones proteins); bone marrow tests (biopsy and aspiration to identify myeloma cells and analyze genetic material via FISH); and imaging tests (X-ray, MRI, CT scan, PET scan) to identify bone lesions.
Treatments: Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy; CAR-T cell therapy; Chemotherapy; Corticosteroids; Bone marrow transplant (autologous and allogeneic); Radiation therapy; Pain medication; Dialysis; Vaccines; Bone-building medicines; Anemia medications
Tests: Blood tests; Urine tests; Bone marrow biopsy; Bone marrow aspiration; Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH); X-ray; MRI scan; CT scan; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a combination of medical history, neurological exam, MRI scans showing lesions in the brain and spinal cord, and lumbar puncture results (showing changes in antibodies linked to MS);  ruling out other conditions with similar symptoms (differential diagnosis) is also crucial.  In relapsing-remitting MS, diagnosis is often straightforward based on symptom patterns and test results; diagnosis can be more challenging in cases with unusual symptoms or progressive disease, requiring additional testing.
Treatments: Speeding recovery from attacks; Reducing relapses; Slowing disease progression; Managing MS symptoms; Corticosteroids (oral prednisone and intravenous methylprednisolone); Plasma exchange (plasmapheresis); Disease-modifying therapies (DMTs)
Tests: MRI; Lumbar puncture (spinal tap); Antibody test (kappa free light chains); Optical coherence tomography; Evoked potential tests; Blood tests; Neuropsychological testing

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is challenging due to overlapping symptoms with other diseases like Parkinson's disease.  Diagnosis involves a physical exam, review of medical history, autonomic function tests (blood pressure, sweat test, bladder/bowel function tests), blood tests, and imaging tests such as MRI.  Clinical establishment of MSA vs. probable MSA is determined based on test results.  Referral to a neurologist or specialist may be necessary.  Tilt table test assesses blood pressure control.
Treatments: Managing symptoms; Medications to raise blood pressure; Medications to reduce Parkinson's-like symptoms; Medications to treat erection problems; Steps to manage swallowing and breathing symptoms (including surgery for feeding/breathing tubes); Bladder care (including catheterization); Physical therapy; Speech-language pathology; Lifestyle and home remedies (increasing salt and fluid intake, raising head of bed, dietary changes, wearing support stockings).
Tests: Blood tests; MRI; Tilt table test; Blood pressure measurement (lying and standing); Sweat test; Bladder and bowel function tests; Electrocardiogram; Sleep study
Medications_Drugs: Fludrocortisone; Midodrine; Pyridostigmine; Droxidopa; Levodopa/carbidopa; Sildenafil; Laxatives; Stool softeners

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a child's symptoms and ruling out similar conditions like Kawasaki disease, sepsis, or toxic shock syndrome.  COVID-19 is ruled out via nasal and throat swabs; prior infection may be confirmed by antibody tests or contact tracing.
Treatments: Supportive care (fluids, oxygen, blood pressure medication, ventilator, blood clot prevention); Treatment to reduce inflammation (antibiotics, steroid therapy, intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG), targeted therapies for cytokines); Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) in rare cases.
Tests: Nasal swab; Throat swab; Blood tests; Urine tests; Chest X-ray; Echocardiogram; Abdominal ultrasound; CT scan
Medications_Drugs: Aspirin; Heparin; Antibiotics; Steroids; Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on typical symptoms and known exposure to mumps.
Treatments: Rest; Pain relievers; Cold or warm cloth for swollen salivary glands; Cold cloth or ice pack for swollen testicles; Drinking plenty of fluids; Isolation to prevent spreading infection
Tests: A test of a sample from the mouth; A blood test; A test of a sample of urine

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily based on the patient's description of symptoms and history.  Physical examination may reveal muscle tightness or tenderness.  Further investigation may be warranted if cramps are severe, frequent, or unresponsive to self-care.
Treatments: Stretching and massage; Applying heat or cold;  Drinking plenty of fluids; Muscle relaxant medication (if prescribed for frequent, sleep-disrupting cramps); Vitamin B complex (in consultation with a healthcare provider)
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Physical exam checking for swelling and tenderness; location and intensity of pain help determine extent and nature of damage; in severe cases, a visible or palpable defect may be present; ultrasound can help differentiate soft tissue injuries.
Treatments: R.I.C.E. (rest, ice, compression, elevation); physical therapy; immobilization with brace or splint; surgery (for torn tendons).
Tests: Ultrasound

Diagnosis: Evaluation includes a review of medical history and physical exam; further testing depends on suspected type of muscular dystrophy.
Treatments: Physical therapy; Occupational therapy;  Medications;  Monitoring by healthcare team (neurologist, physiatrist, etc.);  Surgery (as needed);  Other procedures (as needed);  Palliative care (as needed);  Dietary recommendations (as needed);  Support services (social work, psychology).
Tests: Enzyme tests (e.g., creatine kinase); Genetic testing; Muscle biopsy; Electrocardiography; Echocardiogram; Lung function tests; Electromyography
Medications_Drugs: Prednisone; Deflazacort (Emflaza); Eteplirsen (Exondys 51); Golodirsen (Vyondys 53); Viltolarsen (Viltepso); Casimersen (Amondys 45); Delandistrogene moxeparvovec-rokl (Elevidys); Heart medications (specified medications not listed).

Diagnosis: There is no single test to confirm ME/CFS. Diagnosis relies on the exclusion of other conditions with overlapping symptoms and the fulfillment of diagnostic criteria, such as persistent, severe fatigue interfering with pre-illness activities, new or definite onset, not substantially alleviated by rest, worsened by exertion, and at least one of: cognitive difficulties; postural orthostatic intolerance.  Symptoms must last at least six months and occur at least half the time at moderate, substantial, or severe intensity.
Treatments: Symptom relief focusing on the most disabling symptoms; pacing for post-exertional malaise; addressing sleep problems; acupuncture; massage therapy
Tests: Sleep study; blood tests
Medications_Drugs: ibuprofen; naproxen sodium; pregabalin; duloxetine; amitriptyline; gabapentin; medications to regulate blood pressure or heart rhythms; low doses of some antidepressants

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing symptoms and medical history, conducting a neurological examination (checking reflexes, muscle strength, muscle tone, senses, coordination, and balance), and utilizing tests like the ice pack test, blood analysis for atypical antibodies, repetitive nerve stimulation, single-fiber electromyography (EMG), and imaging (CT scan or MRI) to assess the thymus gland.
Treatments: Medications; Intravenous therapy (plasmapheresis; intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg)); Monoclonal antibody therapy; Surgery (thymectomy)
Tests: Ice pack test; Blood analysis; Repetitive nerve stimulation; Single-fiber electromyography (EMG); CT scan; MRI; Pulmonary function tests
Medications_Drugs: Pyridostigmine (Mestinon, Regonal); Prednisone (Rayos); Azathioprine (Azasan, Imuran); Mycophenolate mofetil (Cellcept); Cyclosporine (Sandimmune, Gengraf); Methotrexate (Trexall); Tacrolimus (Astagraf XL, Prograf); Rituximab (Rituxan); Eculizumab (Soliris)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying a typical attack (e.g., optic neuritis, transverse myelitis, ADEM) and the presence of MOG antibodies in blood or spinal fluid via cell-based assay (gold standard, but potential for false positives).  Spinal tap may reveal elevated white blood cell count and absence of oligoclonal bands (more common in MS).  Imaging (MRI of brain, spine, optic nerve) may show lesions and optic nerve inflammation; optical coherence tomography (eye exam) can show retinal changes.
Treatments: Corticosteroids; Plasma exchange; IV immune globulin; Antiseizure medicines; Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Other medications for pain, fatigue, bowel/bladder issues, erectile dysfunction; Oral immunosuppressants; IV medicines (rituximab, tocilizumab)
Tests: MOG antibody testing (cell-based assay); Spinal tap (lumbar puncture); MRI (brain, spine, optic nerve); Optical coherence tomography (eye exam)
Medications_Drugs: Corticosteroids;  Antiseizure medicines; Azathioprine; Mycophenolate mofetil; Prednisone; Rituximab; Tocilizumab

Diagnosis: Physical exam; medical history; blood tests to determine red cell, white cell, and platelet counts and examine blood cell morphology; bone marrow aspiration and biopsy for laboratory analysis to determine specific cellular characteristics, aiding in diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment planning.
Treatments: Blood transfusions; Medications to increase blood cell production (growth factors); Medications to stimulate blood cell maturation; Medications to suppress the immune system; Lenalidomide (Revlimid) for isolated del(5q) gene mutation; Treatment of infections; Bone marrow transplant (stem cell transplant).
Tests: Blood tests; Bone marrow aspiration; Bone marrow biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Lenalidomide (Revlimid); Growth factors (specific types not specified).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam assessing symptoms and spleen/liver size; blood tests (complete blood count) revealing low red blood cell counts and potentially abnormal white blood cell and platelet counts; imaging tests (CT scans, MRI scans) to visualize spleen/liver size and bone marrow scarring; bone marrow aspiration and biopsy to examine marrow for scarring and assess cells for genetic changes.
Treatments: Blood transfusions; Targeted therapy; Chemotherapy; Surgery to remove the spleen (splenectomy); Radiation therapy; Bone marrow transplant (stem cell transplant); Palliative care
Tests: Complete blood count; CT scan; MRI scan; Bone marrow aspiration; Bone marrow biopsy; Genetic testing for JAK2, CALR, and MPL mutations

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing medical history, physical exam, and potentially recommending further tests based on findings.  Diagnostic criteria are not explicitly listed but are implied through the diagnostic tests performed.
Treatments: Medications; Angioplasty and stenting; Coronary artery bypass surgery; Enhanced external counterpulsation; Lifestyle changes
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG); Stress test; Echocardiogram; Stress echocardiogram; Nuclear stress test; Coronary angiography; Cardiac CT scan; Coronary CT angiogram
Medications_Drugs: Aspirin; Nitrates; Beta blockers; Calcium channel blockers; Cholesterol-lowering medications; Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors; Ranolazine (Ranexa)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves physical examination, listening to the heart with a stethoscope, and blood and imaging tests to assess heart health. Imaging helps confirm myocarditis and determine severity.  Blood tests check for heart attack, inflammation, and infection; cardiac enzyme tests detect heart muscle damage proteins; antibody tests identify infection links. ECG assesses heart rhythm; chest X-ray shows heart and lung size and shape, detecting fluid; heart MRI provides detailed heart images; echocardiogram shows heart size and blood flow; cardiac catheterization with biopsy may be used for tissue examination.
Treatments: Rest; Medicine; Medical devices; Surgery; Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO); Ventricular assist device (VAD); Intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP); Heart transplant
Tests: Blood tests; cardiac enzyme test; antibody blood tests; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Chest X-ray; Heart MRI; Echocardiogram; Cardiac catheterization; Heart muscle biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Corticosteroids; Medications to prevent blood clots; Diuretics; Beta blockers; Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors; Angiotensin 2 receptor blockers (ARBs)

Diagnosis: Review of medical history and symptoms; Physical examination; Imaging tests (MRI) to rule out structural problems or tumors; Nerve tests (EEG, EMG, evoked potential studies); Genetic testing; Blood and urine tests to check for metabolic disorders, autoimmune disease, diabetes, and kidney or liver disease; assessment for exposure to drugs or toxins.
Treatments: Addressing the underlying cause (if identifiable); Medication to reduce symptoms; OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) injections; Surgery (for tumors, lesions, or facial/ear involvement); Deep brain stimulation.
Tests: Electroencephalography (EEG); Electromyography (EMG); Evoked potential studies; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Genetic testing; Blood tests; Urine tests.
Medications_Drugs: Clonazepam (Klonopin); Levetiracetam (Keppra, Elepsia XR, Spritam); Valproic acid; Zonisamide (Zonegran, Zonisade); Primidone (Mysoline); Piracetam.

Diagnosis: Physical exam with gentle finger pressure on affected muscle to locate painful areas and trigger points; observation of responses such as muscle twitching; use of other tests and procedures to rule out other causes of muscle pain.
Treatments: Medicines; shots into trigger points; physical therapy; stretching; massage; dry needling; acupuncture; transcutaneous electronic nerve stimulation (TENS); ultrasound; extracorporeal shock wave therapy.
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: ibuprofen; naproxen sodium; stronger pain relievers (unspecified); amitriptyline; clonazepam; benzodiazepines (unspecified).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis can be challenging as myxofibrosarcoma may resemble other cancers and non-cancerous conditions.  Diagnosis relies on a combination of physical exam, imaging tests (MRI, CT scan), and a biopsy to examine tissue samples for cancerous cells and determine the type of cancer.
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy
Tests: Physical exam; MRI; CT scan; Needle biopsy

Diagnosis: Examination of nails; nail clippings or debris scraping from under the nail sent to a lab for identification of the causative agent; differentiation from conditions mimicking fungal infection, such as psoriasis.
Treatments: Self-care; nonprescription products; oral antifungal drugs; medicated nail polish; medicated nail cream; temporary nail removal; permanent nail and root removal (surgery); trimming and thinning nails; soaking nails; applying urea-containing creams to soften nails.
Tests: Nail clipping analysis; debris scraping analysis

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on symptoms and their impact on life; a physical exam to rule out physical causes; a thorough psychological evaluation, potentially including questionnaires; and the DSM-5 guidelines.
Treatments: Psychotherapy (talk therapy)
Tests: Physical exam; Psychological evaluation; Questionnaires

Diagnosis: Suspicion based on daytime sleepiness and cataplexy; referral to sleep specialist; overnight sleep study (polysomnography); multiple sleep latency test (MSLT); evaluation of sleep history and Epworth Sleepiness Scale; actigraphy; genetic testing (occasionally); lumbar puncture (occasionally to check hypocretin levels).
Treatments: Medications; Lifestyle changes
Tests: Polysomnography; Multiple Sleep Latency Test (MSLT); Actigraphy; Epworth Sleepiness Scale; Genetic testing; Lumbar puncture
Medications_Drugs: Modafinil; Armodafinil; Solriamfetol; Pitolisant; Methylphenidate; Amphetamines (Adderall XR, Desoxyn); Venlafaxine; Fluoxetine; Duloxetine; Sertraline; Protriptyline; Imipramine; Clomipramine; Sodium oxybate; Oxybate salts (Xywav)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of nasal and paranasal tumors involves nasal endoscopy (visual examination using a thin tube with a light and camera); biopsy (tissue sample collection for microscopic examination); and imaging tests such as X-rays, CT scans, MRI scans, and PET scans to determine tumor size, location, and characteristics.
Treatments: Surgery (to remove the tumor and surrounding tissue, accessed via incision or endoscopically); Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Immunotherapy
Tests: Nasal endoscopy; Biopsy; X-rays; CT scan; MRI scan; PET scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with symptom evaluation, medical history review, and physical examination.  Further diagnosis may involve nasal endoscopy and imaging studies (CT scans) to assess polyp size and location, ruling out other causes of nasal blockage. Allergy testing (skin prick test or blood test) and cystic fibrosis testing (sweat test) may also be conducted, particularly in children. Blood tests may also identify associated conditions like immune system problems.
Treatments: Nasal steroid sprays; Oral steroids; Steroid injections; Biologic medicines; Aspirin desensitization; Endoscopic sinus surgery; Balloon ostial dilation; Saltwater rinse
Tests: Nasal endoscopy; CT scan; Allergy skin test; Blood test; Sweat test
Medications_Drugs: Fluticasone; Budesonide; Mometasone; Triamcinolone; Beclomethasone; Ciclesonide; Prednisone; Dupilumab; Mepolizumab; Omalizumab; Antihistamines; Antibiotics

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam including examination of the nose and throat, and palpation of lymph nodes.  Nasal endoscopy is used to visualize the nasopharynx. A biopsy (tissue sample) is taken for lab testing, possibly during endoscopy, or from swollen lymph nodes using a needle.
Treatments: Radiation therapy (external beam radiation, brachytherapy); Chemotherapy; Immunotherapy; Surgery (lymph node removal, removal of cancer from nasopharynx)
Tests: Physical exam; Nasal endoscopy; Biopsy; CT scan; MRI scan; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; X-ray

Diagnosis: Nearsightedness is diagnosed with a basic eye exam including a medical history review, visual acuity test (reading an eye chart), and phoroptor test (assessing vision with different lenses);  additional tests may assess pupil response to light, eye movement, peripheral vision, intraocular pressure, and the condition of the cornea, pupil, lens, and eyelids; examination of the retina and optic nerve may be performed using a special lens with a light and pupil dilation drops.
Treatments: Prescription lenses (eyeglasses; contact lenses); Refractive surgery (LASIK; LASEK; PRK; SMILE); Atropine eye drops; Increased time outdoors; Dual focus contact lenses; Orthokeratology
Tests: Visual acuity test; Phoroptor test; Examination of pupil response to light; Assessment of eye movement; Peripheral vision assessment; Intraocular pressure measurement; Examination of cornea, pupil, lens, and eyelids; Examination of retina and optic nerve

Diagnosis: Medical history review; physical exam including assessment of tenderness, numbness, muscle weakness, and range of motion; imaging tests may be used to identify underlying causes.
Treatments: Self-care (pain relievers, heat); Physical therapy; Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS); Soft neck collar; Steroid injections; Surgery
Tests: X-rays; CT scan; MRI; Electromyography (EMG); Blood tests
Medications_Drugs: ibuprofen; naproxen sodium; acetaminophen; prescription NSAIDs; muscle relaxers

Diagnosis: Physical exam for signs and symptoms; evaluation for history of MRI with gadolinium-based contrast agent in the presence of advanced kidney disease; skin and muscle biopsy; other tests as needed to indicate muscle and internal organ involvement.
Treatments: Hemodialysis (post-gadolinium contrast); Physical therapy; Kidney transplant; Extracorporeal photopheresis with ultraviolet A.
Tests: Physical exam; Biopsy (skin and muscle);  Other tests (to assess muscle and internal organ involvement)
Medications_Drugs: Imatinib (Gleevec); Pentoxifylline (Pentoxil); Sodium thiosulfate; High-dose intravenous immune globulin.

Diagnosis: Nephrotic syndrome is diagnosed through urine tests (urinalysis to detect high protein levels, potentially requiring 24-hour urine collection); blood tests (to assess albumin levels, overall blood protein levels, cholesterol, triglycerides, creatinine, and urea nitrogen to evaluate kidney function); and kidney biopsy (to examine kidney tissue for abnormalities).
Treatments: Treatment of underlying medical conditions; Medications to control symptoms and complications; Dietary changes.
Tests: Urine tests; Blood tests; Kidney biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Lisinopril; Benazepril; Captopril; Enalapril; Losartan; Valsartan; Furosemide; Spironolactone; Hydrochlorothiazide; Metolazone; Atorvastatin; Fluvastatin; Lovastatin; Pravastatin; Rosuvastatin; Simvastatin; Heparin; Warfarin; Dabigatran; Apixaban; Rivaroxaban; Rituximab; Cyclosporine; Cyclophosphamide; Corticosteroids.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis may begin with a physical exam and patient history.  Further diagnosis involves urine and blood tests (checking for catecholamines); imaging tests (X-ray; ultrasound; CT scan; MRI; MIBG scan); and biopsy (tissue sample removal for lab testing, including DNA analysis). Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy may be performed to check for spread to the bone marrow.  Staging (L1, L2, M, MS) is determined based on test results.
Treatments: Surgery; Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy; Bone marrow transplant; Immunotherapy
Tests: Physical exam; Urine test; Blood test; X-ray; Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI; MIBG scan; Biopsy; Bone marrow aspiration; Bone marrow biopsy

Diagnosis: Examination of the skin by a healthcare provider to assess symptoms; Skin biopsy may be performed to rule out other conditions.
Treatments: Anti-itch creams; Stronger corticosteroid creams; Nonsteroidal anti-itch products with calcineurin inhibitors (tacrolimus, pimecrolimus); Corticosteroid injections; Prescription antihistamines; Anti-anxiety drugs; Medicated lidocaine or capsaicin patches; OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) injection; Light therapy; Talk therapy; Cognitive behavioral therapy; Applying cool, wet cloths; Applying cooling lotions (calamine lotion, lotions with camphor or menthol); Nonprescription anti-itch creams or lotions (hydrocortisone cream); Oral antihistamines (diphenhydramine); Covering the affected area with bandages or dressings; Keeping nails trimmed; Wearing mittens during sleep; Short, warm baths with oatmeal-based products; Using mild soaps; Moisturizing; Avoiding triggers; Stress management techniques
Tests: Skin biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis depends on tumor location and may involve physical exam (checking for swollen lymph nodes and signs of hormone excess); blood and urine tests for excess hormones; imaging tests such as ultrasound, CT, MRI, and PET scan; biopsy (obtained via bronchoscopy, endoscopy, colonoscopy, or surgery).  Further tests may determine cancer spread.
Treatments: Surgery; Chemotherapy; Targeted drug therapy; Peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT); Medications to control excess hormones; Radiation therapy
Tests: Physical exam; Blood tests; Urine tests; Ultrasound; CT; MRI; PET scan; Biopsy; Bronchoscopy; Endoscopy; Colonoscopy

Diagnosis: Physical exam; Review of medical history; Imaging tests (CT, MRI, PET scan); Biopsy.  A PET scan helps determine if the tumor is cancerous (benign vs. malignant).
Treatments: Monitoring; Surgery; Medicine for plexiform neurofibroma; Physical rehabilitation; Clinical trials
Tests: CT scan; MRI scan; PET scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of NF1 requires at least two characteristic symptoms;  a physical exam checking for cafe au lait spots is crucial;  genetic testing can support the diagnosis; diagnosis is usually made by age 4;  children with only one symptom and no family history are monitored for further symptoms.
Treatments: Monitoring; Surgery to remove tumors; Cancer treatment (surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy); Selumetinib (Koselugo) for plexiform neurofibroma in children; Clinical trials of similar medications
Tests: Eye exam; X-rays; CT scans; MRIs; Genetic tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam, neurological exam (including evaluation by an eye doctor), review of medical history and symptoms, and ruling out other conditions with similar symptoms.  The 2015 International Panel for NMO Diagnosis criteria are used to diagnose neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD).
Treatments: Corticosteroid therapy (e.g., methylprednisolone); Plasma exchange;  Lower dose corticosteroids for long-term prevention; Monoclonal antibodies (eculizumab, satralizumab, inebilizumab, ravulizumab, rituximab); Immunosuppressant medications (azathioprine, mycophenolate, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, tocilizumab); Intravenous immunoglobulins
Tests: Neurological exam; MRI; Blood tests (for AQP4-IgG, GFAP, neurofilament light chain, and MOG-IgG); Lumbar puncture; Evoked potentials test; Optical coherence tomography
Medications_Drugs: methylprednisolone; eculizumab; satralizumab; inebilizumab; ravulizumab; rituximab; azathioprine; mycophenolate; methotrexate; cyclophosphamide; tocilizumab

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is usually based on skin appearance and recent nickel exposure; if the cause isn't apparent, a patch test (contact hypersensitivity allergy test) may be recommended by a doctor or specialist (allergist or dermatologist).
Treatments: Avoiding contact with nickel; Corticosteroid creams (e.g., clobetasol, betamethasone dipropionate); Nonsteroidal creams (e.g., tacrolimus); Oral corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone); Oral antihistamines; Phototherapy; Soothing lotions (e.g., calamine lotion); Moisturizing; Wet compresses; Avoidance of certain over-the-counter ointments (e.g., those containing neomycin).
Tests: Patch test (contact hypersensitivity allergy test)
Medications_Drugs: clobetasol; betamethasone dipropionate; tacrolimus; prednisone; Oral antihistamines

Diagnosis: A healthcare professional assesses nicotine dependence through questions and questionnaires evaluating the number of cigarettes smoked daily and the time to the first cigarette after waking; higher numbers indicate greater dependence.
Treatments: Medicines and counseling; nicotine replacement therapy (patches, gums, lozenges, nasal sprays); bupropion (Wellbutrin SR); varenicline;  electronic cigarettes (only if other treatments fail and recommended by a healthcare professional); support groups; telephone counseling; text messaging and mobile apps; web-based programs.
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: Nicotine patches; nicotine gums; nicotine lozenges; nicotine nasal sprays; bupropion (Wellbutrin SR); varenicline

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing for hepatosplenomegaly;  assessment of symptoms and family history; measurement of sphingomyelinase levels in white blood cells (types A and B); measurement of oxysterol levels in blood (type C);  genetic testing to identify gene changes; MRI of brain, liver, and spleen; eye exam.
Treatments: Enzyme replacement therapy (olipudase alfa-rpcp for type B); miglustat (for type C, neurological symptoms, not FDA approved in US for this use); speech therapy; physical therapy; occupational therapy; nutrition therapy; oxygen therapy; treatment of secondary symptoms (infections, seizures, uncontrolled muscle movements, sleep problems).
Tests: Blood test (sphingomyelinase and oxysterol levels); skin biopsy (sphingomyelinase and cholesterol storage analysis); genetic testing; MRI; eye exam; ultrasound (prenatal); amniocentesis; chorionic villus sampling.

Diagnosis: Nightmare disorder is diagnosed based on the patient's description of their nightmares;  disturbing dreams are only considered a disorder if they cause distress or sleep disturbance. A physical exam may be performed to rule out contributing medical conditions; a review of medical history and sleep behaviors is also conducted; a nocturnal sleep study (polysomnography) may be used to rule out other sleep disorders if sleep is severely disturbed.  Family history of sleep problems is considered.
Treatments: Treatment of the underlying medical condition (if present); Stress-reduction techniques; Counseling; Therapy; Imagery rehearsal therapy
Tests: Physical exam; Nocturnal sleep study (polysomnography)
Medications_Drugs: Medication is rarely used but may be recommended for severe nightmares associated with PTSD;  no specific medications are named.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam checking for swollen lymph nodes;  imaging tests and a lymph node biopsy are used to detect cancer cells and determine the type of lymphoma; blood and urine tests help rule out other diseases; bone marrow aspiration and biopsy may be performed; a lumbar puncture may be done if spinal cord involvement is suspected.
Treatments: Chemotherapy; Immunotherapy; Targeted therapy; CAR-T cell therapy; Bone marrow transplant; Radiation therapy
Tests: Physical exam; Blood test; Urine test; CT scan; MRI; PET scan; Lymph node biopsy; Bone marrow aspiration; Bone marrow biopsy; Lumbar puncture

Diagnosis: NAFLD is often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally through liver enzyme elevation on routine blood tests.  Diagnosis involves blood tests (to assess liver enzymes, iron levels, blood sugar, lipid profile, and screen for viral hepatitis and celiac disease), imaging (abdominal ultrasound, MRI, CT scan, transient elastography, magnetic resonance elastography), and potentially a liver biopsy (to assess inflammation and scarring, particularly for NASH or unclear results).
Treatments: Weight loss (through diet and exercise); Weight-loss surgery; Medications (Resmetirom); Liver transplant (for cirrhosis)
Tests: Blood tests (complete blood count; iron studies; liver enzyme and liver function tests; tests for chronic viral hepatitis; celiac disease screening test; fasting blood sugar; hemoglobin A1c; lipid profile); Abdominal ultrasound; MRI; CT scan; Transient elastography; Magnetic resonance elastography; Liver biopsy

Diagnosis: Physical exam; Review of symptoms; Allergy testing (skin prick test; blood test for IgE antibodies); Imaging tests to rule out sinus problems (nasal endoscopy; CT scan); Trial of medication to assess symptom improvement.  Diagnosis is based on the presence of nasal congestion and rhinorrhea without identifying an alternative cause like allergies or sinus issues.
Treatments: Home treatment (avoiding triggers, nasal irrigation); Saline nasal spray; Antihistamine nasal sprays (azelastine; olopatadine hydrochloride); Oral antihistamines (diphenhydramine; cetirizine; fexofenadine; loratadine); Ipratropium nasal spray; Decongestants (pseudoephedrine; phenylephrine); Steroid nasal sprays (fluticasone; triamcinolone); Surgery (polypectomy; septoplasty)
Tests: Allergy skin test; Blood test (IgE antibodies); Nasal endoscopy; Computerized Tomography (CT) scan
Medications_Drugs: azelastine; olopatadine hydrochloride; diphenhydramine; cetirizine; fexofenadine; loratadine; ipratropium; pseudoephedrine; phenylephrine; fluticasone; triamcinolone

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam to assess skin for signs of nonmelanoma skin cancer; a biopsy is performed to remove a tissue sample for laboratory analysis to confirm the presence and type of cancer.  Further tests may be needed if cancer has spread beyond the skin.
Treatments: Surgery; Cryosurgery (freezing with liquid nitrogen); Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy (topical creams/lotions or systemic); Photodynamic therapy; Immunotherapy
Tests: Physical exam; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on observable signs and symptoms; however, some features may be subtle and difficult to identify.  Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis.  Diagnosis may occur in adulthood following a child's diagnosis.  A cardiologist assesses any heart problems.
Treatments: Heart treatment (medication or surgery); Growth hormone therapy; Infant stimulation programs; Physical therapy; Speech therapy; Special education; Eye exams (with glasses or surgery for cataracts); Hearing screenings; Treatment for bleeding and bruising (avoiding aspirin; blood clot medication); Treatment for fluid buildup (as needed); Surgery for undescended testicles; Ongoing medical follow-up
Tests: Echocardiogram; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Genetic testing
Medications_Drugs: Growth hormone; Blood clot medication; Aspirin (to be avoided)

Diagnosis: Usually diagnosed based on symptoms; stool sample can identify norovirus; stool test may be recommended for those with weakened immune systems or other medical conditions.
Treatments: Oral rehydration solutions; intravenous fluids (if dehydration occurs); over-the-counter anti-diarrheal medication; medication to reduce nausea; self-care measures including dietary changes and fluid intake.
Tests: Stool sample
Medications_Drugs: Over-the-counter anti-diarrheal medication; medication to reduce nausea

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam including height and vital sign measurements (heart rate, blood pressure, temperature);  assessment of health history (weight history, weight-loss efforts, physical activity, eating patterns, appetite control, other medical conditions, medications, stress levels, family history); calculation of BMI (≥30 considered obesity); and measurement of waist circumference (women >35 inches, men >40 inches indicate increased risk).
Treatments: Dietary changes (calorie reduction, healthier food choices, portion control, meal replacements); Increased physical activity (at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity activity per week); Behavior modification program (counseling, support groups).
Tests: BMI calculation; Waist circumference measurement; Cholesterol test; Liver function tests

Diagnosis: Psychological evaluation to assess thoughts, feelings, symptoms, and behavior patterns; physical exam to rule out other conditions; diagnosis can be challenging due to symptom overlap with other mental health disorders.
Treatments: Psychotherapy (cognitive behavioral therapy, exposure and response prevention); medication; Intensive outpatient and residential treatment programs; Deep brain stimulation; Transcranial magnetic stimulation
Tests: Psychological evaluation; Physical exam

Diagnosis: Evaluation by a healthcare team based on symptoms, physical exam (examining throat, mouth, nose; measuring neck and waist circumference; checking blood pressure), and sleep studies; referral to a sleep specialist for further evaluation and diagnosis; overnight polysomnography or home sleep apnea testing may be used.
Treatments: Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP); Autotitrating positive airway pressure (APAP); Bilevel positive airway pressure (BPAP); Oral device
Tests: Polysomnography (sleep study); Home sleep apnea testing

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves confirming asthma through lung function tests (spirometry, showing improved lung function after inhaling asthma medicine); identifying a workplace substance as the cause through assessment of symptom timing and potential workplace irritants; and ruling out other causes with allergy skin prick tests, blood tests, and chest X-rays.
Treatments: Avoiding the workplace substance;  Medication management
Tests: Spirometry; Peak flow measurement; Allergy skin tests; Challenge test; Chest X-ray; Blood tests
Medications_Drugs: Inhaled corticosteroids; Leukotriene modifiers; Long-acting beta agonists (LABAs); Combination inhalers; Short-acting beta agonists; Oral and intravenous corticosteroids; Antihistamines; Decongestants

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on symptoms, medical history, and examination of the eyes, eyelids, and facial skin; no specific tests are used.
Treatments: Medication; Home eye care
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: Tetracycline; Doxycycline; Erythromycin; Minocycline; Artificial tears

Diagnosis: Oligodendroglioma is diagnosed through a neurological exam assessing symptoms and neurological function; imaging tests such as MRI (potentially with functional MRI and magnetic resonance spectroscopy) to determine tumor location and size; and a biopsy to analyze a tissue sample for cellular characteristics and genetic alterations (DNA changes).  The biopsy may be obtained during tumor removal surgery or via needle aspiration depending on tumor location.
Treatments: Surgery to remove the tumor (potentially awake brain surgery); Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy; Clinical trials; Supportive/palliative care
Tests: Neurological exam; MRI; Functional MRI; Magnetic resonance spectroscopy; Biopsy

Diagnosis: A thorough psychological exam by a mental health provider assesses overall health; behavior frequency and severity; emotions and behavior in various settings and relationships; family situations and interactions; effectiveness of past management strategies; impact of problem behaviors on the child and family; and other potential mental health, learning, or communication problems.  Difficulty differentiating ODD symptoms from those of co-occurring conditions is acknowledged.
Treatments: Family-based interventions; parenting skills training; parent-child interaction therapy (PCIT); individual therapy; family therapy; problem-solving training (cognitive and collaborative); social skills training.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical history and ophthalmologic exam, including routine eye exam assessing vision, color perception, and peripheral vision; ophthalmoscopy to examine the optic disk; pupillary light reaction test.  Further tests may include MRI with contrast to identify brain lesions and rule out other causes; blood tests for infections, neuromyelitis optica antibodies, and MOG antibodies; optical coherence tomography (OCT) to measure retinal nerve fiber layer thickness; visual field test; visual evoked response test. Follow-up exams are conducted 2-4 weeks after symptom onset to confirm diagnosis.
Treatments: Steroid medication (intravenously); Plasma exchange therapy (for severe vision loss when steroid therapy fails)
Tests: Routine eye exam; Ophthalmoscopy; Pupillary light reaction test; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Blood tests; Optical coherence tomography (OCT); Visual field test; Visual evoked response
Medications_Drugs: Interferon beta-1a; Interferon beta-1b; Steroid medications

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical and dental history review, symptom assessment (oral and elsewhere), and oral examination; a biopsy may be performed for microscopic examination of tissue samples, potentially including tests for immune system proteins; cultures may be taken to rule out secondary infections; blood tests may be used to assess for associated conditions like hepatitis C or lupus.
Treatments: Symptomatic treatment (e.g., numbing agents); Corticosteroids (topical mouthwash, ointment, gel; oral pills; injection); Immunosuppressants (topical ointments/gels such as tacrolimus and pimecrolimus; systemic medications); Lifestyle modifications (oral hygiene, diet changes, stress management, avoidance of irritants).
Tests: Biopsy; Cultures; Blood tests

Diagnosis: Visual inspection of the mouth for white patches or spots; microscopic examination of scrapings from affected areas; for esophageal involvement, endoscopic exam and biopsy may be necessary; physical exam and blood tests may be ordered to identify underlying causes.
Treatments: Antifungal medicine (lozenges, tablets, or mouthwash); Antifungal cream (for breastfeeding mothers and babies); Addressing underlying causes such as poorly disinfected dentures or inhaled steroid use; warm saltwater rinses; good oral hygiene practices
Tests: Microscopic examination of scrapings; Endoscopic exam; Biopsy; Blood tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a medical history and physical exam, checking for enlarged lymph nodes in the groin and an enlarged testicle. A rectal exam may also be performed to assess the prostate.  The diagnosis is confirmed based on the results of diagnostic tests.
Treatments: Antibiotics for bacterial orchitis; Rest; Scrotal support with athletic strap; Cold packs; Pain medication; Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medicines
Tests: STI screen; Urine test; Ultrasound; Ultrasound with color Doppler

Diagnosis: Evaluation involves reviewing medical history, medications, and symptoms; conducting a physical exam; and potentially performing blood pressure monitoring (a drop of 20 mm Hg systolic or 10 mm Hg diastolic within 2-5 minutes of standing is indicative); blood tests (to assess overall health, including for hypoglycemia and anemia); electrocardiogram (ECG); echocardiogram; stress test; tilt table test; and Valsalva maneuver.  The goal is to identify the underlying cause.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (increased fluid intake, avoiding alcohol, increasing salt intake with physician consultation);  sitting or lying down when feeling lightheaded; medications to increase blood pressure or blood volume.
Tests: Blood pressure monitoring; Blood tests; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Echocardiogram; Stress test; Tilt table test; Valsalva maneuver

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing joint tenderness, swelling, and flexibility; X-rays to show cartilage loss and bone spurs; MRI for detailed bone and soft tissue imaging in complex cases; Blood tests to rule out other conditions; Joint fluid analysis to differentiate from inflammatory arthritis or infection.
Treatments: Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS); Cortisone injections; Lubrication injections (hyaluronic acid); Osteotomy; Joint replacement
Tests: X-rays; MRI; Blood tests; Joint fluid analysis

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing joint swelling, tenderness, and range of motion; palpation for loose fragments; X-rays to detect bone abnormalities; MRI for detailed bone and soft tissue imaging; CT scan for high-detail bone imaging and detection of loose fragments.
Treatments: Rest and joint protection; crutches; splint, cast, or brace; physical therapy; surgery (depending on fragment presence, bone maturity, and response to conservative treatment).
Tests: X-rays; MRI; CT scan

Diagnosis: Physical examination for tenderness, swelling, or warmth;  evaluation of foot sores for proximity to bone; blood tests to detect elevated white blood cells and infection markers (though not definitive for osteomyelitis); imaging tests (X-ray, MRI, CT scan, bone scan) to visualize bone damage and infection; bone biopsy to identify the infecting germ.
Treatments: Surgery (drainage of infected area; debridement of diseased bone and tissue; restoration of blood flow; removal of foreign objects); Intravenous antibiotics; Oral antibiotics (if infection is serious).
Tests: Blood tests; X-ray; MRI scan; CT scan; Bone scan; Bone biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Antibiotics (specific antibiotic chosen based on infecting germ)

Diagnosis: Bone density is measured using a machine with low-level X-rays to determine mineral proportion in bones; usually focuses on hip and spine bones; screening recommended for women over 65 and men over 70 (especially with relevant health issues); bone density testing may be important if a bone is broken after a minor injury.
Treatments: Modifying risk factors for bone loss and falls; Bisphosphonates; Denosumab; Hormone-related therapy (estrogen, Raloxifene, testosterone replacement); Bone-building medicines (Teriparatide; Abaloparatide; Romosozumab); Lifestyle modifications (e.g., avoiding smoking and excessive alcohol, fall prevention).
Tests: Bone density test; CT scan; Ultrasound
Medications_Drugs: Alendronate (Binosto, Fosamax); Risedronate (Actonel, Atelvia); Ibandronate; Zoledronic acid (Reclast, Zometa); Denosumab (Prolia, Xgeva); Estrogen; Raloxifene (Evista); Testosterone; Teriparatide (Bonsity, Forteo); Abaloparatide (Tymlos); Romosozumab (Evenity)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam; further investigation involves imaging tests to determine location and size of the osteosarcoma, followed by a biopsy to confirm the presence of cancer cells.  The biopsy may involve a needle through the skin or surgery.
Treatments: Surgery (limb-sparing surgery, amputation, rotationplasty); Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy (rarely used, as an alternative to surgery if surgery is not possible)
Tests: X-ray; MRI; CT; Bone scan; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a pelvic exam to palpate pelvic organs and visually examine genitalia; imaging tests like ultrasound or CT scans to assess ovary size and structure; blood tests including organ function tests and tumor markers like CA 125; surgery may be necessary for definitive diagnosis through tissue examination; genetic testing can identify gene changes increasing risk.
Treatments: Surgery (removal of one or both ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus, lymph nodes, omentum); Chemotherapy (intravenous or oral, hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy); Targeted therapy; Hormone therapy; Immunotherapy; Palliative care
Tests: Pelvic exam; Ultrasound; CT scan; Blood tests (organ function tests; CA 125); Genetic testing

Diagnosis: Ovarian cysts are diagnosed through a pelvic exam or imaging tests like pelvic ultrasound.  The size and composition (fluid-filled or solid) of the cyst influence further testing to determine the type and need for treatment.  Solid cysts developing after menopause raise concern for malignancy.
Treatments: Watchful waiting; Hormonal contraceptives; Surgery (cystectomy; oophorectomy; potentially including hysterectomy, salpingectomy); Chemotherapy; Radiation
Tests: Pelvic exam; Pelvic ultrasound; Laparoscopy; Pregnancy test; Tumor marker tests (e.g., CA 125)

Diagnosis: Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) diagnosis is based on a physical exam assessing weight gain, increased waist size, and abdominal pain; an ultrasound to visualize enlarged ovaries with fluid-filled cysts; and blood tests to detect blood abnormalities and impaired kidney function.
Treatments: Increased fluid intake; Frequent physical exams and ultrasounds; Daily weigh-ins and waist measurements; Monitoring urine production; Drainage of excess abdominal fluid; Anticoagulant medications; IV fluids; Cabergoline; Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (Gn-RH) antagonist; Letrozole (Femara); Surgery for ruptured ovarian cyst; Intensive care for liver or lung complications.
Tests: Physical exam; Ultrasound; Blood test
Medications_Drugs: Cabergoline; Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (Gn-RH) antagonist; Letrozole (Femara); Anticoagulants; Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves evaluating urinary urgency, checking for urinary tract infection or blood in urine, assessing bladder emptying, and conducting a medical history, neurological exam (checking for sensory or reflex issues), physical exam (including rectal and pelvic exams in women), and urinalysis.  Urodynamic tests may be used to assess bladder function but aren't always necessary for diagnosis or treatment.
Treatments: Behavioral therapies (biofeedback, bladder training, weight loss); Pelvic floor muscle exercises (Kegel exercises); Intermittent catheterization; Vaginal estrogen therapy (post-menopause); Bladder injections (OnabotulinumtoxinA); Sacral nerve stimulation
Tests: Urinalysis; Urodynamic tests (measuring postvoid residual urine via ultrasound or catheter, measuring urine flow rate with uroflowmeter, cystometry to measure bladder and surrounding pressures); Neurological exam; Physical exam (including rectal and pelvic exams);
Medications_Drugs: Fesoterodine (Toviaz); Mirabegron (Myrbetriq); Oxybutynin (Ditropan XL, Oxytrol, Gelnique); Solifenacin (Vesicare); Tolterodine (Detrol); Trospium; Vibegron (Gemtesa)

Diagnosis: Physical exam of painful areas; X-rays to reveal bone abnormalities, enlargement, and deformities; Bone scan to identify affected areas using radioactive material; Blood test to measure alkaline phosphatase levels.
Treatments: Medication; Surgery; Self-care (fall prevention, dietary changes, exercise)
Tests: X-rays; Bone scan; Blood test
Medications_Drugs: Zoledronic acid (Zometa, Reclast); Pamidronate (Aredia); Ibandronate (Boniva); Alendronate (Fosamax, Binosto); Risedronate (Actonel, Atelvia); Calcitonin (Miacalcin)

Diagnosis: Paget's disease of the breast is diagnosed through a combination of physical examination (breast exam, checking for lumps and abnormalities in breasts and armpit lymph nodes), imaging techniques (mammogram, breast ultrasound, breast MRI), and biopsy to analyze suspicious tissue for cancerous cells and determine characteristics like cell type, grade, and receptor status.
Treatments: Mastectomy (total/simple, or other variations); Lumpectomy; Sentinel node biopsy; Axillary lymph node dissection; Contralateral prophylactic mastectomy; Breast reconstruction; Adjuvant therapy with anti-cancer drugs
Tests: Breast exam; Mammogram; Breast ultrasound; Breast MRI; Biopsy; Sentinel node biopsy; Axillary lymph node dissection

Diagnosis: A thorough medical history focusing on pain onset, location, characteristics, and association with partners and positions; a pelvic exam to check for skin irritation, infection, anatomical problems, and pain localization;  visual vaginal exam using a speculum.
Treatments: Treating underlying infections or medical conditions; changing medications causing lubrication problems; topical estrogen; desensitization therapy; counseling or sex therapy; cognitive behavioral therapy; lifestyle changes such as changing positions during intercourse, improved communication, longer foreplay, use of lubricants.
Tests: Pelvic exam; Pelvic ultrasound

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves imaging tests (ultrasound, CT scans, MRI scans, PET scans); endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) to visualize the pancreas and obtain a tissue sample (biopsy or fine-needle aspiration); blood tests (e.g., CA19-9 tumor marker); and genetic testing if indicated by family history or other factors.  Staging determines the extent of the cancer.
Treatments: Surgery (Whipple procedure, other surgeries for head, body, and tail of pancreas); Radiation; Chemotherapy; Combination therapy.  For advanced cancer, treatment focuses on symptom relief and improving quality of life.
Tests: Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI scan; PET scan; Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS); Biopsy; Fine-needle aspiration; Blood tests (CA19-9); Genetic testing

Diagnosis: Pancreatic cysts are diagnosed using a combination of medical history, physical exam, and imaging tests.  The type of cyst is determined by its characteristics (size, structure, location), patient age and sex, and fluid analysis (if obtained via endoscopic ultrasound). Improved imaging technology leads to more frequent diagnoses.
Treatments: Watchful waiting; Drainage; Surgery
Tests: Computerized tomography (CT) scan; MRI scan; Endoscopic ultrasound; Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves blood tests (to detect excess hormones or DNA changes); urine tests (to detect hormone breakdown products); and imaging tests such as X-ray, MRI, CT, PET scan (alone or combined with CT or MRI), and endoscopic ultrasound (which may also include biopsy).  A tissue biopsy is often needed to confirm the diagnosis and characterize the cancer cells.
Treatments: Surgery (distal pancreatectomy, Whipple procedure); Peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT) with lutetium Lu 177 dotatate (Lutathera); Targeted therapy; Radiofrequency ablation; Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Liver surgery (partial hepatectomy, liver transplant); Hepatic artery embolization (slowing blood flow to the liver); Radiofrequency ablation of liver metastases
Tests: Blood tests; Urine tests; X-ray; MRI; CT scan; PET scan; Endoscopic ultrasound; Biopsy; Nuclear medicine tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing the patient's health history and symptoms, performing a physical exam focusing on abdominal pain/tenderness, and utilizing various diagnostic tests to assess pancreatic and related organ function and identify underlying causes.
Treatments: Hospital stay for symptom and complication management; Pain medication; IV fluids; Nutritional support (including feeding tube if necessary); ERCP (to remove gallstones or clear bile ducts); Procedures to open bile ducts; Cholecystectomy (gallbladder removal); Pancreas procedures (fluid drainage or tissue removal); Treatment for alcohol dependence; Changes in medications; Pain management (for chronic pancreatitis); Pancreatic enzyme supplements; Dietary changes
Tests: Blood tests; Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI; Endoscopic ultrasound; Stool tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a complete physical exam; blood tests (thyroid and other conditions); electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); psychological evaluation assessing symptoms, fears, stressors, relationships, avoidance behaviors, and family history; psychological self-assessment or questionnaire; assessment of alcohol or substance use.  Panic disorder specifically requires frequent, unexpected panic attacks, with at least one attack followed by one month or more of worry about future attacks, fear of attack consequences, or significant behavioral changes (avoidance).  Panic attacks must not be caused by substance use, medical conditions, or other mental health conditions.
Treatments: Psychotherapy (cognitive behavioral therapy); Medications
Tests: Complete physical exam; Blood tests; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Psychological evaluation; Psychological self-assessment or questionnaire
Medications_Drugs: Fluoxetine (Prozac); Paroxetine (Paxil, Pexeva); Sertraline (Zoloft); Venlafaxine (Effexor XR); Alprazolam (Xanax); Clonazepam (Klonopin)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with blood and urine tests to detect excess hormones (e.g., catecholamines) or markers like chromogranin A.  Imaging tests and genetic testing may be used if symptoms, family history, or initial tests suggest paraganglioma.
Treatments: Surgery; Medications to control hormones; Radiation therapy; Stereotactic radiosurgery; Ablation therapy (radiofrequency ablation; cryoablation); Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT); Watchful waiting
Tests: Blood and urine tests; MRI; CT scan; MIBG scan; PET scan; Genetic testing
Medications_Drugs: Alpha blockers; Beta blockers; Calcium channel blockers; Lutetium Lu 177 dotatate (Lutathera)

Disease_Name_English: Paraneoplastic syndromes of the nervous system
Disease_Name_Spanish: Paraneoplastic syndromes of the nervous system
Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical and neurological exam assessing reflexes, muscle strength, tone, touch, vision, hearing, coordination, balance, mood, and memory; blood tests to identify paraneoplastic antibodies and check for infection, hormone imbalances, or metabolic conditions; spinal tap (lumbar puncture) to analyze cerebrospinal fluid for antibodies; imaging tests (CT, MRI, PET, PET-CT) to detect tumors or other causes of symptoms.  The presence of paraneoplastic antibodies in both blood and CSF strongly suggests the syndrome.
Treatments: Treating the underlying cancer; Suppressing the immune response; Plasmapheresis; Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg); Physical therapy; Speech therapy
Tests: Blood tests; Spinal tap (lumbar puncture); CT scan; MRI; PET scan; PET-CT scan
Medications_Drugs: Prednisone; Azathioprine; Mycophenolate; Rituximab; Cyclophosphamide; Methotrexate; Cyclosporine; Tacrolimus; Eculizumab; Ravulizumab; Efgartigimod; Anti-seizure medications; Pyridostigmine

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical history, symptom review, and neurological and physical exam;  a DAT scan may support suspicion but isn't necessary;  response to Parkinson's medications can aid in confirmation;  alpha-synuclein test may detect disease before symptoms.
Treatments: Medications; Surgery (when medicine is no longer effective); Aerobic exercise; Physical therapy (balancing and stretching); Speech therapy.
Tests: Physical and neurological exam; Blood and lab tests; MRI; Brain ultrasound; PET scan; Dopamine transporter (DAT) scan; Genetic testing; Alpha-synuclein seed amplification assay (spinal fluid or skin).
Medications_Drugs: Carbidopa-levodopa (Rytary, Sinemet); Inhaled levodopa (Inbrija); Carbidopa-levodopa infusion (Duopa); Pramipexole (Mirapex ER); Rotigotine (Neupro); Apomorphine (Apokyn); Selegiline (Zelapar); Rasagiline (Azilect); Safinamide (Xadago); Entacapone (Comtan); Opicapone (Ongentys); Tolcapone (Tasmar); Benztropine; Trihexyphenidyl.

Diagnosis: Physical exam to palpate for lumps or swelling; Needle biopsy to collect tissue for cell type and cancer determination (results may not always be accurate); Imaging tests (ultrasound, MRI, CT scan) to assess tumor size, location, and potential spread.  Surgical biopsy may be performed if needle biopsy is not done beforehand.
Treatments: Surgery (partial parotidectomy, total parotidectomy); Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy
Tests: Physical exam; Needle biopsy; Ultrasound; MRI; CT scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam, often identifying the infection based on symptoms like a "slapped cheek" rash.  Blood tests may be used to assess natural immunity or recent infection, especially in those at risk of complications.  Pregnant individuals may undergo additional tests, including ultrasound and amniotic fluid analysis.
Treatments: Rest; Home care; Blood transfusion (for severe anemia); Immune globulin shots (for weakened immune systems)
Tests: Blood tests; Ultrasound imaging; Amniotic fluid analysis

Diagnosis: Physical examination to locate pain (often on the front of the knee below the kneecap); imaging tests may be used to rule out other conditions but are not always necessary.
Treatments: Limiting painful activities; Pain relievers; Physical therapy (stretching and strengthening exercises); Strapping or taping; Iontophoresis; Corticosteroid injection; Platelet-rich plasma injection; Oscillating needle procedure (Tenex) or water debridement (Tenjet); Surgery (in rare cases)
Tests: X-rays; Ultrasound; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)

Diagnosis: History taking regarding knee problems; Physical examination including palpation and range of motion assessment; Imaging tests may be used to identify underlying causes.
Treatments: Rest; Avoidance of pain-inducing activities (climbing stairs, kneeling, squatting); Pain relievers; Physical therapy (rehabilitation exercises, supportive braces, taping, icing, orthotics); Knee-friendly sports; Arthroscopy; Realignment surgery.
Tests: X-rays; CT scans; MRI; Ultrasound

Diagnosis: Physical exam including auscultation for a heart murmur; review of medical history.
Treatments: Regular health checkups (for small PDAs); Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs for premature infants); Catheter procedure with plug or coil; Open-heart surgery
Tests: Echocardiogram; Chest X-ray; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Cardiac catheterization (may be used if other heart conditions are present)

Diagnosis: Patent foramen ovale (PFO) is usually diagnosed incidentally during testing for other health concerns.  If suspected, imaging tests of the heart, such as echocardiograms, are performed.  A neurologist may be consulted if a PFO is found in conjunction with a stroke.
Treatments: Medications; Catheter procedure to close the hole; Surgery to close the hole
Tests: Echocardiogram (transthoracic echocardiogram, including color-Doppler and saline contrast study); Transesophageal echocardiogram

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing symptoms and medical history; a physical exam may be performed; additional diagnostic steps may include a food diary, skin prick test, blood test (measuring IgE antibodies), and an elimination diet (though not recommended after severe reactions).  These methods help confirm a peanut allergy or identify other causes.
Treatments: Peanut avoidance; Oral immunotherapy (OIT); Antibody treatment (e.g., omalizumab)
Tests: Skin test; Blood test (IgE antibody measurement); Food diary; Elimination diet

Diagnosis: Physical examination of the chest;  Further tests may be conducted to assess the severity and impact on heart and lungs.
Treatments: Physical therapy; Sternal suction; Nuss procedure; Ravitch technique; Dermal fillers; Silicone implants
Tests: Chest X-ray; CT scan; MRI; Electrocardiogram; Echocardiogram; Lung function tests; Exercise function test

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with assessment of symptoms and a neurological exam evaluating vision, hearing, balance, coordination, strength, and reflexes.  Imaging tests (MRI, CT, PET) determine tumor location and size; a biopsy (surgical or stereotactic needle) confirms diagnosis and characterizes tumor cells, including DNA analysis.  A lumbar puncture may be performed to check for cerebrospinal fluid involvement.
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy (X-ray radiation; Proton radiation); Radiosurgery (Linear accelerator radiosurgery; Gamma Knife radiosurgery; Proton radiosurgery); Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Palliative care; Clinical trials
Tests: Neurological exam; MRI; Functional MRI; Magnetic resonance spectroscopy; CT scan; PET scan; Biopsy; Stereotactic needle biopsy; Lumbar puncture

Diagnosis: Review of symptoms and health history; Physical exam of head, neck, nose, mouth, and tongue; Polysomnogram (overnight sleep test recording brain waves, breathing patterns, snoring, oxygen levels, heart rate, and muscle activity).
Treatments: Adenotonsillectomy; Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP); Bilevel positive airway pressure (BPAP); Oral appliances; Topical nasal steroids; Watchful waiting; Weight loss (including weight-loss surgery for obese teenagers); Upper airway surgery (other than adenotonsillectomy).
Tests: Polysomnogram

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a detailed medical history, physical exam, and blood tests; other tests may be ordered depending on suspected cause.
Treatments: Treatment depends on the type of condition, white blood cell count (high or low), and underlying cause; treatment for infection might involve antibiotics; antiviral or antifungal medicines.
Tests: Complete blood count (CBC)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis relies on a combination of medical history (sexual habits, STI history, birth control method), signs and symptoms, pelvic exam (checking for tenderness and swelling, taking fluid samples from vagina and cervix), blood and urine tests (for pregnancy, HIV, STIs, white blood cell count, inflammation markers), and ultrasound imaging of reproductive organs.  If diagnosis remains unclear, laparoscopy (viewing pelvic organs) and endometrial biopsy (testing endometrial tissue for infection and inflammation) may be used.
Treatments: Antibiotics; Treatment of sexual partners; Temporary abstinence; Hospitalization (with intravenous and oral antibiotics); Surgery (for abscess drainage or if no response to antibiotics)
Tests: Pelvic exam; Vaginal and cervical fluid sample analysis; Blood test; Urine test; Ultrasound; Laparoscopy; Endometrial biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a medical history and pelvic organ exam to determine the type of prolapse.  Pelvic floor strength tests assess the strength of muscles and ligaments supporting pelvic organs.  Bladder function tests evaluate bladder leakage and emptying.  Imaging (MRI or ultrasound) may be used for complex cases.
Treatments: No treatment; Treatment without surgery; Surgery; Pelvic floor exercises with biofeedback; Pessary use
Tests: Pelvic floor strength tests; Bladder function tests; MRI; Ultrasound

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a discussion of medical history and symptoms, followed by examination of the affected area.  A skin biopsy of a blister is taken for lab testing; blood tests are conducted to detect pemphigus-related antibodies.  Referral to a dermatologist may occur.
Treatments: Steroids;  Immune-system targeting medications;  Discontinuation of causative medications (if applicable); Hospital stay for fluids, nutrition, or other treatments; Wound care; Gentle skin washing with mild soap and lotion; Skin protection from heat and sun; Avoiding irritating foods; Careful teeth and gum care
Tests: Skin biopsy; Blood tests
Medications_Drugs: Prednisone; Azathioprine (Imuran, Azasan); Mycophenolate (Cellcept); Cyclophosphamide; Dapsone; Intravenous immunoglobulin; Rituximab-pvvr (Ruxience); Antibiotics (for infections)

Diagnosis: A thorough physical examination; review of symptoms; additional tests (potentially performed by an allergist); skin tests to assess for allergic reaction; graded drug challenge if diagnosis is uncertain.
Treatments: Withdrawal of penicillin; Antihistamines; Corticosteroids; Treatment of anaphylaxis; Drug desensitization
Tests: Skin tests; Graded drug challenge

Diagnosis: Diagnosis may involve a medical history and physical exam;  Laboratory tests for H. pylori (blood, stool, or breath test); Upper endoscopy (visual examination of the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum, possibly with biopsy); Upper gastrointestinal series (barium swallow X-ray).  Endoscopy is more likely if the patient is older, has signs of bleeding, or has experienced recent weight loss or difficulty eating/swallowing.
Treatments: Killing H. pylori (if present); Stopping or reducing NSAID use; Medications to heal ulcers; Endoscopy for bleeding ulcers; Surgery (rare).
Tests: Laboratory tests for H. pylori (blood, stool, or breath test); Upper endoscopy; Biopsy; Upper gastrointestinal series (barium swallow).
Medications_Drugs: Amoxicillin; Clarithromycin; Metronidazole; Tinidazole; Tetracycline; Levofloxacin; Omeprazole; Lansoprazole; Rabeprazole; Esomeprazole; Pantoprazole; Famotidine; Cimetidine; Nizatidine; Sucralfate; Misoprostol; Acetaminophen.

Diagnosis: Physical exam evaluating symptoms and medical history; Auscultation of the heart with a stethoscope;  Echocardiogram to assess fluid amount and heart function; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) to check for cardiac tamponade; Chest X-ray to assess heart size;  CT and MRI scans may incidentally detect the effusion but are not typically used for initial diagnosis.
Treatments: Medications to treat inflammation; Fluid drainage (pericardiocentesis); Open-heart surgery; Creation of a drainage passageway into the abdominal cavity; Removal of the pericardium (pericardiectomy)
Tests: Echocardiogram; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Chest X-ray; Computerized Tomography (CT) scan; Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) scan

Diagnosis: Physical examination including auscultation for pericardial rub; review of symptoms and medical history.
Treatments: Pain relievers; Pericardiocentesis; Pericardiectomy; Rest; Avoidance of strenuous activity; Antibiotics (if bacterial infection)
Tests: Blood tests; Electrocardiogram (ECG); Chest X-ray; Echocardiogram; Cardiac computerized tomography (CT) scan; Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
Medications_Drugs: Aspirin; Ibuprofen; Colchicine; Prednisone; Immunosuppressants; Interleukin 1 blocker

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of perimenopause is based on a combination of factors including age, menstrual history, and reported symptoms; there is no single definitive test.  Hormone testing is rarely necessary except for checking thyroid function.
Treatments: Hormone therapy (systemic estrogen, vaginal estrogen); Antidepressants (SSRIs); Gabapentin; Fezolinetant; Lifestyle modifications (diet, exercise, stress reduction); Over-the-counter vaginal lubricants and moisturizers
Tests: Thyroid function test
Medications_Drugs: Systemic estrogen; Progestin; Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs); Gabapentin (Neurontin); Fezolinetant (Veozah)

Diagnosis: Review of medical history for risk factors (smoking, dry mouth medications); Examination of mouth for plaque, tartar, and bleeding gums; Measurement of pocket depth between gums and teeth using a dental probe (pockets >4mm may indicate periodontitis, >5mm difficult to clean); Dental X-rays to check for bone loss.  Periodontitis is staged and graded based on severity, treatment complexity, risk factors, and overall health.
Treatments: Scaling; Root planing; Topical antibiotics; Oral antibiotics; Flap surgery (pocket reduction surgery); Soft tissue grafts; Bone grafting; Guided tissue regeneration; Tissue-stimulating proteins
Tests: Dental probe measurement of gum pockets; Dental X-rays

Diagnosis: Physical examination assessing for weak or absent pulses in affected areas; review of symptoms and medical history; Ankle-brachial index (ABI) comparing ankle and arm blood pressure, potentially with exercise testing.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (no smoking, regular exercise, healthy diet); Medications; Surgery; Thrombolytic therapy; Angioplasty and stent placement; Bypass surgery; Supervised exercise therapy.
Tests: Blood tests; Ankle-brachial index (ABI); Treadmill exercise test; Ultrasound of legs or feet; Doppler ultrasound; Angiography.
Medications_Drugs: Statins; Blood pressure medicines; Diabetes medicine; Aspirin; Clopidogrel (Plavix); Cilostazol.

Diagnosis: Review of medical history (including accidents and surgeries) and symptoms; Physical and neurological examination;  Electromyography (EMG); Nerve conduction study; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Ultrasound.
Treatments: Rest; Surgery; Medications; Corticosteroid injections; Physical therapy; Braces or splints; Electrical stimulator; Exercise; Nerve repair; Nerve graft; Nerve transfer; Tendon transfer
Tests: Electromyography (EMG); Nerve conduction study; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Ultrasound

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing symptoms and medical history, a physical and neurological exam, and utilizing imaging and biopsy techniques to confirm the presence and characteristics of the tumor.  The location, size, and growth rate of the tumor influence diagnostic approach.
Treatments: Monitoring; Surgery; Stereotactic radiosurgery (including Gamma Knife radiosurgery); Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy; Physical rehabilitation
Tests: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Computerized tomography (CT); Electromyogram (EMG); Nerve conduction study; Tumor biopsy; Nerve biopsy

Diagnosis: A full medical history including symptoms, lifestyle, toxin exposure, drinking habits, and family history of neurological diseases; Neurological exam assessing tendon reflexes, muscle strength and tone, sensation, balance, and coordination.
Treatments: Watchful waiting; Pain relievers; Anti-seizure medications; Topical treatments; Antidepressants; Scrambler therapy; Spinal cord stimulation; Plasma exchange; Steroids; Intravenous immune globulin; Physical therapy; Surgery; Acupuncture; Alpha-lipoic acid; Amino acids; Lifestyle modifications (foot care, exercise)
Tests: Blood tests; CT scan; MRI scan; Electromyography (EMG); Nerve conduction study; Autonomic reflex screen; Sweat test; Sensory tests; Nerve biopsy; Skin biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Gabapentin; Pregabalin; Lidocaine; Amitriptyline; Nortriptyline; Duloxetine; Venlafaxine; Desvenlafaxine; Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical history, physical exam, and symptoms;  For peritoneal dialysis-related peritonitis, symptoms may be sufficient;  Further tests may include blood tests (white blood cell count, blood culture), imaging tests (X-ray, ultrasound, CT scan), and peritoneal fluid analysis (white blood cell count, culture).
Treatments: Antibiotics; Surgery; Intravenous fluids; Pain medications; Oxygen; Blood transfusion;  Alternative dialysis methods (if related to peritoneal dialysis)
Tests: Blood tests; Blood culture; X-ray; Ultrasound; CT scan; Peritoneal fluid analysis; Peritoneal fluid culture

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam, in-depth health questions to rule out underlying physical problems, and lab tests (e.g., thyroid function tests).  A psychological evaluation assesses thoughts, feelings, and behavior, often including questionnaires, to differentiate persistent depressive disorder from other mood disorders (major depression, bipolar disorder, seasonal affective disorder).  For adults, depressed mood must occur most of the day for at least two years; for children, depressed mood or irritability must occur most of the day for at least one year.
Treatments: Talk therapy; Antidepressant medications
Tests: Physical exam; Lab tests (e.g., blood test for thyroid function); Psychological evaluation
Medications_Drugs: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs); Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs); Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs)

Diagnosis: No single test can diagnose persistent post-concussive symptoms. Diagnosis involves a comprehensive medical history; neurological exam assessing thinking, memory, senses, strength, coordination, and reflexes; neurological testing for concentration, memory, language, thinking, and planning skills; and brain imaging (CT or MRI scans) if concerning symptoms (severe headache, memory loss, vomiting) are present.  Imaging checks for structural brain changes, but doesn't directly visualize persistent post-concussive symptoms.  Referral to other specialists may be necessary depending on symptoms.
