Treatments: Time; Notebook or visual cues; Cognitive therapy; Focused rehabilitation; Occupational therapy; Speech therapy; Stress management; Relaxation therapy; Physical therapy for dizziness and balance; Sleep hygiene; Exposure therapy; Psychotherapy; Medication for depression, anxiety, headaches;  Physical activity.
Tests: Neurological exam; Neurological testing; CT scan; MRI scan
Medications_Drugs: Medicines for migraines or tension-type headaches; Medicines for depression; Medicines for high blood pressure; Medicines for seizures; Medicines to improve sleep.

Diagnosis: Physical exam to rule out physical causes; mental health evaluation including discussion of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors, possibly questionnaires; comparison of symptoms to DSM-5-TR guidelines; neuropsychological testing may be used to assess cognitive function and world view;  diagnosis can be challenging due to symptom overlap with other conditions.
Treatments: Dialectical behavioral therapy (DBT); hospital and residential treatment programs; day hospital program; residential program; outpatient treatment;  lifestyle changes (physical activity, avoiding drugs and alcohol).
Tests: Complete blood count (CBC); alcohol and drug screening; neuropsychological testing
Medications_Drugs: Antidepressants; mood stabilizers; antipsychotic medications; anti-anxiety medications (use may be limited due to potential for increased impulsivity).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on symptoms, nasal examination (checking for swollen, pale, or bluish nasal lining), and patient history; Allergy skin test may be used to identify specific allergens.
Treatments: Avoiding the allergen; Allergy medications; Immunotherapy; Nasal irrigation
Tests: Allergy skin test; Blood test for allergy-causing antibodies
Medications_Drugs: azelastine (Astelin, Astepro); olopatadine (Patanase); fexofenadine (Allegra Allergy); loratadine (Claritin, Alavert); cetirizine (Zyrtec Allergy); levocetirizine (Xyzal); desloratadine (Clarinex); fluticasone propionate (Flonase Allergy Relief); mometasone furoate (Nasonex); triamcinolone (Nasacort Allergy 24HR); ciclesonide (Omnaris); montelukast (Singulair)

Diagnosis: Physical exam to assess scar tissue location and amount, penile length, and degree of curvature;  patient-provided photos of erect penis may be used;  ultrasound may be used to visualize scar tissue, blood flow, and other irregularities.
Treatments: Penile traction therapy; Oral medications; Injections into scar tissue (Collagenase clostridium histolyticum, Verapamil, Interferon);  Watchful waiting; Surgery (Plication; Graft repair)
Tests: Physical exam; Ultrasound

Diagnosis: Newborn screening identifies almost all cases; additional blood and urine tests may confirm diagnosis; genetic testing can identify the gene change.
Treatments: Lifetime diet with very limited phenylalanine intake; PKU formula (phenylalanine-free nutritional supplement); Medications (sapropterin (Kuvan); pegvaliase-pqpz (Palynziq) for some adults).
Tests: Blood test; Urine test; Genetic testing

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves measuring levels of adrenaline, noradrenaline, and metanephrines (through blood and 24-hour urine tests); elevated metanephrine levels are a key indicator.  Imaging tests (CT scan, MRI, MIBG imaging, PET scan) are used to locate tumors if lab tests are positive. Genetic testing may be used to identify underlying genetic conditions.
Treatments: Surgery to remove the tumor;  Blood pressure medications before surgery (alpha blockers; beta blockers; calcium channel blockers); Targeted therapies; Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy; Ablation
Tests: 24-hour urine test; Blood test; CT scan; MRI; M-iodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) imaging; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; Genetic testing
Medications_Drugs: alpha blockers; beta blockers; calcium channel blockers; steroid medicines (for cases where both adrenal glands are removed)

Diagnosis: Physical examination of the affected skin; review of symptoms and medical history; assessment of personal habits.
Treatments: Incision and drainage; Surgery with wound left open and packed; Surgery with wound closed with stitches.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing patient symptoms and conducting a physical exam.  Further tests may be ordered based on suspicion of a pinched nerve.
Treatments: Rest; Splint; Collar; Brace; Physical therapy; Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs); Anti-seizure medications; Tricyclic medicines; Corticosteroids; Surgery
Tests: Blood tests (fasting blood glucose and thyroid levels); Spinal tap (lumbar puncture); X-rays; Nerve conduction study; Electromyography (EMG); Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); High-resolution ultrasound
Medications_Drugs: ibuprofen; naproxen sodium; gabapentin; nortriptyline; amitriptyline; Corticosteroids

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves imaging tests (MRI, often with perfusion MRI and magnetic resonance spectroscopy; CT scans; PET scans) to locate and size the tumor; a biopsy (needle biopsy before surgery or during surgery) to analyze tissue samples for cell type and growth rate; and a lumbar puncture (spinal tap) to examine cerebrospinal fluid for pineoblastoma cells.
Treatments: Surgery (to remove as much of the tumor as possible, and potentially to relieve fluid buildup in the brain); Radiation therapy (often to the entire brain and spinal cord); Chemotherapy (often after surgery or radiation therapy, sometimes concurrently or before surgery to shrink the tumor); Radiosurgery (for recurrent tumors).
Tests: MRI; Perfusion MRI; Magnetic resonance spectroscopy; CT scan; PET scan; Biopsy; Lumbar puncture

Diagnosis: Clinical examination of the eyes; review of recent health history and symptoms; in severe cases or suspected high-risk causes (foreign body, serious bacterial infection, STI), a culture of eye drainage may be performed.
Treatments: Artificial tears; eyelid cleaning with wet cloth; cold or warm compresses; discontinuation of contact lens use (disposal of soft lenses, disinfection of hard lenses);  avoidance of allergens; antiviral medications (if herpes simplex virus is the cause); antihistamines; mast cell stabilizers; decongestants; steroids; anti-inflammatory drops.
Tests: Eye drainage culture
Medications_Drugs: Antiviral medications; antihistamines; mast cell stabilizers; decongestants; steroids; anti-inflammatory drops.

Diagnosis: Pinworm infection is diagnosed by identifying pinworms or eggs.  A tape test, where adhesive tape is pressed against the skin around the anus to collect eggs, is used; microscopic examination of the tape reveals the presence of pinworm eggs.  The test should be performed for three consecutive days for best results.
Treatments: Over-the-counter pyrantel pamoate; Prescription medication for all household members to prevent infection and reinfection.
Tests: Tape test

Diagnosis: Diagnosis often relies on symptoms (or lack thereof),  patient history, physical exam, and imaging.  Blood tests assess hormone levels; high levels may indicate adenoma, while low levels require further imaging.  Urine tests may be used for ACTH/cortisol assessment (Cushing's disease). MRI is preferred imaging method; CT scans may aid surgical planning. Vision testing assesses potential visual impairment.
Treatments: Surgery (endoscopic transnasal transsphenoidal surgery; craniotomy); Medication; Radiation therapy
Tests: Blood tests; Urine tests; MRI scan; CT scan; Vision testing

Diagnosis: Visual examination of the rash by a healthcare provider is usually sufficient for diagnosis; a skin scraping or biopsy may be necessary to differentiate pityriasis rosea from other similar rashes.
Treatments: Self-care measures (antihistamines, lukewarm baths with oatmeal, moisturizer, calamine lotion, corticosteroid cream, sun protection); Medications (corticosteroids; antihistamines); Light therapy
Tests: Skin scraping; Skin biopsy

Diagnosis: Placenta accreta is suspected based on risk factors such as placenta previa or prior uterine surgery.  Diagnosis is confirmed through ultrasound or MRI to evaluate the depth of placental implantation in the uterine wall.
Treatments: Cesarean section; Cesarean hysterectomy (removal of uterus); Pelvic rest; Hospitalization (for vaginal bleeding)
Tests: Ultrasound; MRI

Diagnosis: Placenta previa is diagnosed through ultrasound, either during a routine prenatal appointment or after vaginal bleeding;  A transvaginal ultrasound may be used for more accurate images.  Most cases are diagnosed during a second-trimester ultrasound.
Treatments: Frequent ultrasound monitoring;  C-section delivery; Blood transfusion;  Avoidance of sexual intercourse, strenuous exercise, heavy lifting, and prolonged standing; Corticosteroids (if delivery is planned before 37 weeks).
Tests: Ultrasound; Transvaginal ultrasound

Diagnosis: Physical exam to check for uterine tenderness or rigidity; blood and urine tests; ultrasound (though placental abruption isn't always visible on ultrasound).
Treatments: Close monitoring in hospital (for mild abruption, baby not close to full term); rest at home (if bleeding stops and baby's condition is stable); medication to mature baby's lungs and protect brain (if early delivery necessary); closely monitored vaginal delivery (after 34 weeks, minimal abruption); immediate delivery (usually C-section, if abruption worsens or jeopardizes health); blood transfusion (for severe bleeding).
Tests: Blood test; urine test; ultrasound

Diagnosis: Probable diagnosis is based on symptoms, possible exposure (outdoor activity, travel, contact with dead/sick animals, flea bite, rodent exposure).  Laboratory tests confirm diagnosis by identifying *Yersinia pestis* bacteria from samples.
Treatments: Hospitalization; Antibiotic treatment
Tests: Fluid from buboes; Blood; Mucous from the lungs; Fluid surrounding the brain and spinal cord
Medications_Drugs: Gentamicin; Doxycycline; Ciprofloxacin; Levofloxacin; Moxifloxacin; Chloramphenicol

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical history and physical examination, checking for areas of tenderness in the foot; the location of pain helps determine the cause.
Treatments: Icing; stretching; modifying or avoiding pain-causing activities; physical therapy; athletic taping; night splints; orthotics; walking boot; canes; crutches; steroid injections; platelet-rich plasma injections; extracorporeal shock wave therapy; ultrasonic tissue repair; surgery.
Tests: X-ray; MRI

Diagnosis: Visual inspection of the wart; examination of the top layer of the wart for tiny clotted blood vessels (dots); microscopic examination of a small sample of the growth.
Treatments: Freezing medicine (cryotherapy); Stronger peeling medicine (salicylic acid); Minor surgery (excision or electrodesiccation and curettage); Blistering medicine (cantharidin); Immune therapy; Laser treatment; HPV vaccine (off-label use).  Self-care: salicylic acid (over-the-counter), cryotherapy (over-the-counter), duct tape.
Tests: Microscopic examination of a tissue sample

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a review of medical history and physical exam, including listening to the chest with a stethoscope.  Further diagnosis involves identifying the underlying cause through various tests to determine if pleurisy is present and its cause.
Treatments: Treatment targets the underlying cause (e.g., antibiotics for bacterial pneumonia); Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs); Steroid medication
Tests: Blood tests; Chest X-ray; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Ultrasound; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Thoracentesis; Thoracoscopy

Diagnosis: Physical exam including lung auscultation for abnormal sounds; Chest X-ray to diagnose and determine extent/location of infection; Blood tests to confirm infection and identify the causative organism (though precise identification isn't always possible); Pulse oximetry to measure blood oxygen levels; Sputum test to identify the causative organism.  Further tests (CT scan; pleural fluid culture) may be ordered for older adults, hospitalized patients, or those with severe symptoms/conditions.
Treatments: Antibiotics (for bacterial pneumonia); Cough medicine; Fever reducers/pain relievers; Hospitalization (for severe cases or high-risk individuals)
Tests: Blood tests; Chest X-ray; Pulse oximetry; Sputum test; CT scan; Pleural fluid culture

Diagnosis: Review of medical and family history; assessment of symptoms, medications, and environmental exposures (dusts, chemicals, birds, mold); physical exam with lung auscultation; avoidance of suspected environmental substance to observe symptom improvement; blood tests (to detect infection and allergen-specific antibodies); arterial blood gas test; chest X-ray; CT scan; pulmonary function tests (spirometry, lung volume test, lung diffusion test); pulse oximetry; six-minute walking test; bronchoscopy (with lavage and potential biopsy); surgical lung biopsy.
Treatments: Avoidance of triggering substance; wearing protective gear; improving ventilation; limiting mold growth; corticosteroid medications; other immune-suppressing medications; inhaled corticosteroids; bronchodilators; oxygen therapy; pulmonary rehabilitation; lung transplant.
Tests: Blood tests; arterial blood gas test; chest X-ray; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Spirometry; Lung volume test; Lung diffusion test; Pulse oximetry; Bronchoscopy; Surgical lung biopsy

Diagnosis: Pneumothorax is generally diagnosed using a chest X-ray; a CT scan may be used for more detailed images; ultrasound imaging may also be used.
Treatments: Observation; Needle aspiration; Chest tube insertion; Nonsurgical repair (using a substance to irritate tissues, autologous blood patch, bronchoscope with one-way valve); Surgery; Supplemental oxygen therapy
Tests: Chest X-ray; CT scan; Ultrasound imaging

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves medical history review, physical exam, and neurological exam.  POEMS syndrome is challenging to diagnose due to complex and multi-organ involvement.
Treatments: Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Bone marrow transplant (bone marrow stem cell transplant); Physical therapy
Tests: Electromyographic (EMG) studies; Nerve biopsy; CT scan; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; Complete blood count (CBC); Peripheral blood smear; 24-hour urine collection
Medications_Drugs: Hydroxyurea (mentioned in a forum discussion, not as a direct treatment recommendation in the article)

Diagnosis: Visual inspection by a doctor; Diagnosis is usually made based on the characteristic appearance of the rash.  Further testing is usually not needed.
Treatments: Self-care at home; Oral corticosteroid (e.g., prednisone) for widespread rash or many blisters; Oral antibiotic for bacterial infection
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is often based on symptoms like neck and back stiffness, abnormal reflexes, or muscle weakness; Stool sample lab test to detect poliovirus (most reliable); Throat sample (less reliable, only useful during the first week of illness); Cerebrospinal fluid test may help rule out other nervous system diseases.
Treatments: Bed rest; Pain relievers; Hot moist packs; Portable ventilators; Physical therapy; Splints or other devices to improve spine and limb alignment
Tests: Stool sample analysis; Throat sample analysis; Cerebrospinal fluid analysis

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves assessing kidney cyst size and number, and evaluating the amount of healthy kidney tissue remaining.  This is done using imaging techniques to assess the severity of the disease's impact on the kidneys, liver, and pancreas.
Treatments: Managing symptoms and complications; Slowing cyst growth with medication (tolvaptan); Controlling high blood pressure; Maintaining a healthy weight and BMI; Managing pain with medication (acetaminophen); Cyst fluid aspiration and sclerosing agent injection; Cyst fenestration surgery; Treating infections with antibiotics; Managing blood in urine with increased fluid intake; Dialysis or kidney transplant (for kidney failure); Aneurysm screening and surgical clipping (if applicable); Preemptive kidney transplantation.
Tests: MRI scan; Ultrasound; CT scan
Medications_Drugs: Tolvaptan; Acetaminophen; Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors; Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs); Antibiotics

Diagnosis: There is no single test to diagnose PCOS. Diagnosis involves a discussion of symptoms, medications, medical conditions, menstrual periods, and weight changes; a physical exam checking for excess hair growth, insulin resistance, and acne; a pelvic exam to check reproductive organs; blood tests to measure hormone levels and assess cholesterol, triglycerides, and glucose tolerance; and an ultrasound to examine ovaries and uterine lining.
Treatments: Weight loss through diet and exercise; Combination birth control pills; Progestin therapy; Clomiphene; Letrozole; Metformin; Gonadotropins; Spironolactone; Eflornithine; Hair removal (electrolysis, laser); Acne treatments; In vitro fertilization
Tests: Pelvic exam; Transvaginal ultrasound; Blood tests (hormone levels, cholesterol, triglycerides, glucose tolerance test)
Medications_Drugs: Combination birth control pills; Progestin; Clomiphene; Letrozole; Metformin; Spironolactone; Eflornithine

Diagnosis: Medical history review and physical exam; Blood tests (revealing increased red blood cells, sometimes platelets and white blood cells, higher hematocrit and hemoglobin); Bone marrow aspiration or biopsy; Gene testing to identify associated gene changes.
Treatments: Blood withdrawals (phlebotomy); Medications to reduce itching (antihistamines, ultraviolet light therapy, SSRIs like paroxetine and fluoxetine); Medications to lower red blood cell count (hydroxyurea, interferon alfa-2b, ruxolitinib, busulfan); Medications to control heart and blood vessel disease risk factors; Low-dose aspirin; Exercise; Lifestyle modifications (avoiding tobacco, high altitudes, hot temperatures, and scratching).
Tests: Blood tests; Bone marrow aspiration; Bone marrow biopsy; Gene testing
Medications_Drugs: Paroxetine; Fluoxetine; Hydroxyurea; Interferon alfa-2b; Ruxolitinib; Busulfan; Aspirin

Diagnosis: Fetal ultrasound measuring maximum vertical pocket (MVP) of amniotic fluid (≥8 cm) or amniotic fluid index (AFI) (≥24 cm);  Further tests may be done to determine the cause, including blood tests for infectious diseases and amniocentesis for genetic testing and further fluid analysis.
Treatments: Drainage of amniotic fluid via amniocentesis; Medication (e.g., indomethacin); Delivery at 39-40 weeks (mild to moderate cases);  Delivery timing adjusted based on severity (severe cases).
Tests: Fetal ultrasound; Blood tests; Amniocentesis; Nonstress test; Biophysical profile

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is typically made based on a physical exam and patient history; laboratory tests may be used to confirm the diagnosis or rule out other conditions.  A dermatologist may conduct phototesting to assess photosensitivity.
Treatments: Anti-itch medication (corticosteroid cream or pill); Phototherapy; Self-care measures (anti-itch cream; oral antihistamines; cold compresses; avoiding blisters; pain relievers; sun protection).
Tests: Skin biopsy; Blood tests; Phototesting
Medications_Drugs: Corticosteroid cream; Corticosteroid pill; Oral antihistamines

Diagnosis: Physical exam including neurological exam and joint range of motion assessment; Blood tests (erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein, complete blood count); Ultrasound to assess joint and soft tissue inflammation; MRI or PET scan may be used to rule out other causes;  Diagnosis may evolve during treatment, with some initially diagnosed with polymyalgia rheumatica later diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis or giant cell arteritis.
Treatments: Corticosteroids; Methotrexate; Sarilumab; Physical therapy; Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen and naproxen sodium; Calcium and Vitamin D supplements
Tests: Blood tests (ESR, CRP, complete blood count); Ultrasound; MRI; PET scan; Artery biopsy (for suspected giant cell arteritis)
Medications_Drugs: Prednisone; Methotrexate (Trexall); Sarilumab (Kevzara); Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Calcium and Vitamin D supplements

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is suspected based on symptoms and confirmed through blood tests showing elevated muscle enzymes and specific autoantibodies; electromyography (EMG) to assess muscle electrical activity; magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to visualize muscle inflammation; and muscle biopsy to examine muscle tissue for abnormalities.
Treatments: Medications; Physical therapy; Speech therapy; Dietetic assessment; Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg)
Tests: Blood tests; Electromyography (EMG); Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Muscle biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Prednisone; Azathioprine; Methotrexate; Mycophenolate mofetil; Cyclosporine; Tacrolimus; Rituximab

Diagnosis: Physical exam checking for swelling, tenderness, and skin color/temperature changes on the lower leg and behind the knee; review of medical history and health habits (e.g., smoking).
Treatments: Regular health checkups with ultrasound tests; open surgery; endovascular repair (stent placement)
Tests: Duplex ultrasound; CT angiography; MR angiography
Medications_Drugs: Aspirin; blood thinners; blood pressure medicine; cholesterol medicine

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of popliteal artery entrapment syndrome (PAES) can be challenging due to the generally good health of affected individuals and often unremarkable physical exams.  Diagnosis involves evaluating symptoms and health history, and ruling out other causes of leg pain (muscle strains, stress fractures, peripheral artery disease).  Key diagnostic methods include assessment of ankle-brachial index (ABI) during and after exercise; duplex ultrasound of the calf; magnetic resonance angiography (MRA); CT angiography; and, if needed, catheter-based angiography.  A drop in ankle pressure during exercise, as measured by ABI, is indicative of PAES.  Imaging tests visualize the artery entrapment by calf muscles.
Treatments: Surgery to release the calf muscle and free the trapped artery; Artery bypass (for severe, long-standing cases)
Tests: Ankle-brachial index (ABI) measurement; Duplex ultrasound of the calf; Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA); CT angiography; Catheter-based angiography

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is challenging due to overlapping symptoms with common diseases.  Diagnosis relies on lab tests (blood, urine, or stool) to measure porphyrin levels; genetic testing may confirm diagnosis and type.
Treatments: Treatment varies by porphyria type and symptom severity; avoiding triggers (medications, drugs, fasting, dieting, sun exposure, stress); symptom relief; hemin injections; intravenous or oral glucose; phlebotomy; hydroxychloroquine; beta-carotene; afamelanotide.
Tests: Blood testing; Urine testing; Stool testing; Genetic testing
Medications_Drugs: Hemin (Panhematin); Glucose; Givosiran (Givlaari); Hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil); Beta-carotene; Afamelanotide (Scenesse)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a medical history showing a previous polio diagnosis and a long interval (at least 15 years) after recovery, followed by a gradual onset of new weakness in previously affected muscles.  Other conditions are excluded.
Treatments: Energy conservation; Assistive devices; Physical therapy; Speech therapy; Sleep disorder treatment
Tests: Electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction studies; MRI; CT scan; Muscle biopsy; Blood tests; Muscle ultrasound (investigational)

Diagnosis: A diagnosis of PTSD involves a physical exam to rule out other medical conditions; a mental health evaluation including discussion of symptoms and the triggering trauma; and questionnaires assessing experiences and symptoms.  A key criterion is exposure to a traumatic event (direct experience, witnessing, learning about a close one's experience, or repeated exposure to graphic details) resulting in symptoms lasting over a month and significantly impairing social, occupational, and interpersonal functioning.
Treatments: Psychotherapy (including exposure therapy and cognitive therapy); Medications; Stress management skills training; Individual therapy; Group therapy; Stellate ganglion block (research study, not FDA-approved)
Tests: Physical exam; Mental health evaluation; Questionnaires
Medications_Drugs: Sertraline (Zoloft); Paroxetine (Paxil); Venlafaxine (Effexor XR); Anti-anxiety medications; Prazosin (Minipress)

Diagnosis: Physical exam checking for testicular and epididymal tenderness and swelling; assessment for sperm granuloma; ruling out other causes of testicle pain through further investigation.
Treatments: Pain medications; Supportive underwear; Ice or heat; Physical therapy; Nerve block; Removal of sperm granuloma; Microdenervation of the spermatic cord (MDSC); Epididymectomy; Vasectomy reversal (vasovasostomy); Orchiectomy; Acupuncture
Tests: Sexually transmitted infections (STI) screening; Urine and blood tests; Ultrasound; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
Medications_Drugs: Ibuprofen; Prescription pain medications; Tricyclic antidepressants; Anticonvulsants

Diagnosis: Review of medical history and symptoms (including vision problems); Physical exam; Neurological exam; Mental status and neuropsychological tests to assess cognitive skills and screen for depression or other mental disorders.  Diagnostic tests may also rule out other conditions causing similar symptoms.
Treatments: Medicines to treat symptoms such as depression or anxiety; Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Cognitive therapy; Cognitive behavioral therapy
Tests: Mental status and neuropsychological tests; Blood tests; Ophthalmology exam; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) PET imaging; Single-photon emission computerized tomography (SPECT); Spinal fluid test

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is often made during a pelvic exam, which may involve bearing down to reveal the prolapse, assessing pelvic muscle strength by tightening muscles as if stopping urination, and completing a questionnaire to assess symptom severity and bulge extent.  Rarely, MRI, X-ray, or defecography (combining contrast agent with X-ray or MRI) may be used.
Treatments: Observation; Kegel exercises; Pessary; Surgery
Tests: Pelvic exam; MRI; X-ray; Defecography

Diagnosis: Physical examination of the skin to determine the affected area; In most cases, no further tests are needed.
Treatments: Lidocaine skin patches; Capsaicin skin patch (Qutenza); Anticonvulsants (gabapentin, pregabalin); Antidepressants (nortriptyline, amitriptyline, duloxetine, venlafaxine); Opioid painkillers (tramadol, oxycodone, morphine); Steroid shots; Capsaicin cream
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: Lidocaine; Gabapentin; Pregabalin; Nortriptyline; Amitriptyline; Duloxetine; Venlafaxine; Tramadol; Oxycodone; Morphine

Diagnosis: Clinical interview assessing feelings, thoughts, and mental health to differentiate between postpartum baby blues and postpartum depression; depression screening questionnaires may be used; other tests may be ordered to rule out other causes.
Treatments: Psychotherapy (cognitive-behavioral therapy, interpersonal psychotherapy); antidepressants; antianxiety medications (short-term, if anxiety or insomnia present); Brexanolone (Zulresso) for intravenous administration;  Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) for severe cases with psychosis; family or relationship therapy. Lifestyle modifications including physical activity, sufficient rest, healthy diet, avoiding alcohol, realistic expectations, self-care, social interaction, and seeking help.
Tests: Depression screening questionnaires
Medications_Drugs: Antidepressants; antianxiety medications; Brexanolone (Zulresso); antipsychotic medicines; mood stabilizers; benzodiazepines

Diagnosis: Postpartum preeclampsia is usually diagnosed with blood tests (to assess liver and kidney function, and platelet count) and urinalysis (to detect protein in urine, potentially via a 24-hour urine collection).  Hospital readmission may be necessary for diagnosis if the condition is suspected after discharge.
Treatments: Medication to lower high blood pressure; Medication to prevent seizures
Tests: Blood tests; Urinalysis (24-hour urine collection may be used)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a medical history review and physical examination.  Confirmation may include blood tests to rule out other conditions; stool tests to identify infection; endoscopy with potential biopsy; and imaging tests such as MRI or CT scan to determine the cause of symptoms.
Treatments: Antibiotics; Surgery (ileostomy in rare cases); Probiotics (for prevention of recurrence)
Tests: Blood tests; Stool tests; Endoscopy with biopsy; MRI; CT scan

Diagnosis: Suspected based on symptoms; confirmed by genetic testing (blood test) which identifies chromosomal problems.
Treatments: Good nutrition; Human growth hormone (HGH) treatment; Sex hormone treatment (testosterone for males; estrogen and progesterone for females); Weight management (diet, exercise); Treatment of sleep disturbances; Physical therapy; Speech therapy; Occupational therapy; Developmental therapy; Behavior management (schedules, limits, medication); Mental healthcare (therapy, medication); Surgery (for undescended testicles); Management of specific symptoms/complications (vision issues, scoliosis, hypothyroidism, diabetes).
Tests: Blood test (genetic testing)
Medications_Drugs: Human growth hormone (HGH); Testosterone; Estrogen; Progesterone; Medications for behavioral problems; Medications to ease mental health symptoms.

Diagnosis: Review of child and family medical history; Physical exam; Blood tests to measure hormone levels; X-rays of hands and wrists to assess bone growth; Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) stimulation test to determine type (central vs. peripheral); MRI of the brain (for central precocious puberty); Thyroid testing (if hypothyroidism symptoms present); Ultrasound (for peripheral precocious puberty to check for ovarian cysts or tumors).
Treatments: GnRH analogue therapy (leuprolide acetate, triptorelin); Histrelin implant; Treatment of underlying medical condition (e.g., tumor removal).  Observation for several months (if no cause is found and puberty progression is slow).
Tests: Blood tests; X-rays of hands and wrists; Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) stimulation test; MRI; Thyroid testing; Ultrasound
Medications_Drugs: Leuprolide acetate (Lupron Depot); Triptorelin (Trelstar, Triptodur Kit)

Diagnosis: Prediabetes is diagnosed based on blood tests.  An A1C test measuring average blood sugar over 2-3 months (5.7% to 6.4%); a fasting blood sugar test (100 to 125 mg/dL or 5.6 to 6.9 mmol/L); or an oral glucose tolerance test (140 to 199 mg/dL or 7.8 to 11.0 mmol/L)  are used.  Diagnosis requires two separate tests confirming results.  For children, the same blood sugar level ranges apply, along with consideration of risk factors like obesity, family history, ethnicity, low birth weight, or a mother's gestational diabetes.
Treatments: Healthy lifestyle changes including a diet high in fruits, vegetables, nuts, whole grains, and olive oil; increased physical activity (at least 150 minutes of moderate or 75 minutes of vigorous aerobic activity per week); weight loss (5% to 7%); smoking cessation.  For high-risk individuals, metformin may be recommended.
Tests: Glycated hemoglobin (A1C) test; Fasting blood sugar test; Oral glucose tolerance test

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of preeclampsia requires high blood pressure after 20 weeks of pregnancy and at least one of the following: protein in urine (proteinuria); other signs of kidney problems; low blood platelet count; elevated liver enzymes; fluid in the lungs (pulmonary edema); new persistent headaches; new vision disturbances. High blood pressure is defined as systolic pressure ≥ 140 mm Hg or diastolic pressure ≥ 90 mm Hg.  A second blood pressure reading four hours later may be taken to confirm diagnosis.
Treatments: Delivery of the baby; Frequent provider visits to monitor blood pressure and symptoms; Hospitalization for severe preeclampsia;  Preterm delivery (after 37 weeks for non-severe, before 37 weeks for severe, depending on complications and baby's health); Vaginal or Cesarean delivery (method depends on severity and gestational age)
Tests: Blood tests; Urine analysis (24-hour or single sample); Fetal ultrasound; Nonstress test; Biophysical profile

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of premature birth is based on gestational age at birth (less than 37 weeks).  Further diagnostic testing is done in the NICU to identify potential health problems associated with prematurity.
Treatments: Supportive care in NICU (incubator, kangaroo care, ventilator/CPAP support, feeding tube, fluid management, bilirubin lights); Blood transfusion; Surgery
Tests: Breathing and heart rate monitoring; Blood pressure readings; Fluid input and output measurement; Blood tests; Echocardiography; Ultrasound; Eye exam
Medications_Drugs: Surfactant; Fine-mist or intravenous medications to strengthen breathing and heart rate; Antibiotics; Diuretics; Medication to stop growth of new blood vessels (retinopathy); Medication to close patent ductus arteriosus

Diagnosis: Health history review; Physical exam; Blood tests (to check hormone levels if erectile dysfunction is also present). Referral to a urologist or mental health professional specializing in sexual problems may be recommended.
Treatments: Behavioral techniques (masturbation before intercourse; avoiding intercourse temporarily; focusing on other sexual activities; pelvic floor exercises (Kegel exercises); pause-squeeze technique; stop-start technique); Medications; Counseling; Relationship counseling; Sex therapy
Tests: Blood tests
Medications_Drugs: Paroxetine (Paxil, Pexeva, Brisdelle); Escitalopram (Lexapro); Citalopram (Celexa); Sertraline (Zoloft); Fluoxetine (Prozac); Dapoxetine (not available in the US); Clomipramine (Anafranil); Tramadol (Ultram, Conzip, Qdolo); Sildenafil (Viagra); Tadalafil (Cialis, Adcirca); Avanafil (Stendra); Vardenafil; Benzocaine; Lidocaine; Prilocaine; Creams, gels, and sprays containing benzocaine, lidocaine, or prilocaine;  EMLA cream (lidocaine and prilocaine combination)

Diagnosis: Auscultation with a stethoscope; review of lifestyle habits and medical history; electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; event monitor; exercise stress test.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (eliminating triggers like caffeine or tobacco); Medications; Radiofrequency catheter ablation
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; Event monitor; Exercise stress test
Medications_Drugs: Beta blockers; Calcium channel blockers; Drugs to control heart rhythm (specific drug names not listed)

Diagnosis: There are no unique physical findings or lab tests to diagnose PMS definitively. Diagnosis is based on a predictable premenstrual symptom pattern recorded over at least two menstrual cycles;  Tests may be done to rule out other conditions mimicking PMS, such as thyroid disorders or mood disorders.
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (diet modification, exercise, stress reduction); Medication
Tests: Thyroid function test; Mood screening tests
Medications_Drugs: fluoxetine (Prozac); paroxetine (Paxil, Pexeva); sertraline (Zoloft); ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB); naproxen sodium (Aleve); spironolactone (Aldactone); Hormonal contraceptives (combination birth control pills; minipill)

Diagnosis: Presbyopia is diagnosed through a basic eye exam including a refraction assessment (to determine nearsightedness, farsightedness, astigmatism, or presbyopia) and an eye health exam (often involving pupil dilation).  The refraction assessment involves testing distance and close-up vision using various instruments and lenses.
Treatments: Corrective eyeglasses (including prescription reading glasses, bifocals, trifocals, progressive multifocals, and office progressives); Contact lenses (bifocal, monovision, modified monovision); Refractive surgery (conductive keratoplasty, LASIK, LASEK, PRK); Lens implants; Corneal inlays
Tests: Refraction assessment; Eye health exam

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical history, answers to questions, and sometimes, signs and symptoms; Blood or urine tests can detect many types of drugs and track treatment progress.
Treatments: Counseling; Withdrawal (detoxification); Addiction medicine; Recovery support; Opioid tapering; Medication to manage withdrawal symptoms (e.g., clonidine, buprenorphine, buprenorphine-naloxone, methadone, naltrexone);  Long-term medications (e.g., naltrexone (Vivitrol), buprenorphine (Sublocade));  Treatment for stimulant withdrawal focusing on tapering and symptom relief.
Tests: Blood test; Urine test
Medications_Drugs: Clonidine (Catapres); Buprenorphine; Buprenorphine-naloxone (Suboxone); Methadone; Naltrexone (Vivitrol); Buprenorphine (Sublocade)

Diagnosis: Regular uterine contractions and cervical softening, thinning, and dilation (opening) before 37 weeks of pregnancy;  Diagnosis is based on a review of medical history, risk factors, and symptoms; Pelvic exam assesses uterine firmness, tenderness, cervical dilation, and bleeding (if water hasn't broken and placenta previa is not suspected); Transvaginal ultrasound measures cervical length, assesses fetal size and position, and checks for fetal/placental issues and amniotic fluid volume; Uterine monitoring assesses contraction duration and frequency; Vaginal swab checks for infections and fibronectin; Urine sample checks for bacteria.
Treatments: Cervical cerclage; Vaginal progesterone; Corticosteroids; Magnesium sulfate; Tocolytics; Bed rest (note: not shown to be effective in reducing preterm birth risk)
Tests: Pelvic exam; Transvaginal ultrasound; Uterine monitoring; Vaginal swab; Urine sample

Diagnosis: An erection lasting more than four hours requires emergency care.  The doctor will determine if it's ischemic or nonischemic priapism through a medical history, genital/abdominal/groin/perineum exam, and assessment of pain and penile rigidity.  The type of priapism may be evident from these factors.  Further tests may be needed to confirm the type and identify underlying causes.
Treatments: Aspiration decompression (draining blood from the penis, possibly with saline flush); Medication injection (e.g., phenylephrine); Surgery (to drain blood, reroute blood flow);  Watch-and-wait approach (for nonischemic priapism); Ice packs and perineum pressure (for nonischemic priapism); Surgery to insert temporary blood flow blocking material; Surgery to repair arteries or tissue damage.
Tests: Penile blood gas measurement; Blood tests (red blood cell and platelet counts); Doppler ultrasonography; Toxicology test (blood or urine)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a review of health and family history, physical exam, and various tests to detect liver disease and bile duct injury;  key diagnostic criterion is the presence of anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMAs), although some patients may be AMA-negative;  imaging and liver biopsy may be used to confirm diagnosis and assess disease extent.
Treatments: Ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA); Obeticholic acid; Fibrates; Budesonide; Liver transplant;  Treatment for fatigue (including thyroid disease exclusion); Treatment for itching (antihistamines, cholestyramine, rifampin, opioid antagonists, sertraline); Treatment for dry eyes and mouth; Vitamin and mineral supplements; Cholesterol-lowering medication; Treatment for bone loss; Treatment for portal hypertension (diet modification, diuretics, paracentesis).
Tests: Blood tests (liver tests; antibody tests for AMAs; cholesterol test); Ultrasound; FibroScan; MRCP; MRE; Liver biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA or ursodiol); Obeticholic acid (Ocaliva); Fibrates (e.g., Tricor); Budesonide;  Antihistamines (diphenhydramine; hydroxyzine hydrochloride; loratadine); Cholestyramine; Rifampin; Opioid antagonists (containing naloxone and naltrexone); Sertraline; Statins;  Diuretics; Calcium; Vitamin D; Vitamin A; Vitamin E; Vitamin K; Folic acid; Iron.

Diagnosis: A review of medical history, including family history of inherited immune system disorders; physical examination; blood tests to assess levels of infection-fighting proteins (immunoglobulins), blood cells, and immune system cells; prenatal testing (amniotic fluid, blood, or chorionic villus sampling) and possibly DNA testing for genetic defects in pregnancies where a child has already been diagnosed with primary immunodeficiency.
Treatments: Treating infections with antibiotics (potentially long-term or intravenous); Preventing infections with long-term antibiotics; Immunoglobulin therapy (IV or subcutaneous infusion); Stem cell transplantation; Gene therapy; Enzyme replacement therapy; Thymus transplantation
Tests: Blood tests; Prenatal testing (amniotic fluid, blood, or chorion sampling); DNA testing

Diagnosis: There is no single test to confirm PLS; diagnosis relies on ruling out other conditions through medical history review, neurological exam, and various tests;  a definitive diagnosis may take 3-4 years due to symptom overlap with ALS.  Genetic testing may be used in cases of juvenile PLS.
Treatments: Medication to relieve symptoms; Physical and occupational therapies; Speech and language therapy; Nutrition support; Assistive devices
Tests: Bloodwork; MRI; Electromyogram (EMG); Nerve conduction studies; Lumbar puncture

Diagnosis: Irregular periods or difficulty conceiving; physical exam including pelvic exam; review of menstrual cycle, toxin exposure (chemotherapy, radiation), and previous ovarian surgery.
Treatments: Estrogen therapy; Progesterone therapy (if uterus present); Calcium and vitamin D supplements; In vitro fertilization (using donor eggs)
Tests: Pregnancy test; Hormone level blood test (FSH, estradiol, prolactin); Karyotype analysis; FMR1 gene test; Bone density test
Medications_Drugs: Estrogen; Progesterone; Calcium supplements; Vitamin D supplements

Diagnosis: Progressive communication difficulties worsening over 2-3 years without significant changes in thinking or behavior; neurological exam; speech-language evaluation; neuropsychological evaluation assessing speech, language comprehension, object recognition, naming, recall, and other cognitive factors.
Treatments: Speech and language therapy; Physical therapy; Occupational therapy
Tests: Neurological exam; Speech-language evaluation; Neuropsychological evaluation; Blood tests; Lumbar puncture; Genetic tests; Brain MRI; FDG PET scan; Other PET scans (for Alzheimer's-related proteins)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of primary sclerosing cholangitis is primarily achieved through magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP), which visualizes the liver and bile ducts.  Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) may be used if MRCP is unavailable or inconclusive, or if symptoms persist despite normal MRCP findings.  Liver biopsy may be used to assess the extent of liver damage if the diagnosis remains uncertain after less invasive testing.
Treatments: Treatment for itching (bile acid sequestrants; rifampin; antihistamines; opioid antagonists; ursodeoxycholic acid); Treatment for infections (antibiotics); Nutrition support (vitamin supplements; calcium and vitamin D supplements); Treatment for bile duct blockages (balloon dilation; stent placement); Liver transplant
Tests: Liver function blood test; MRI of bile ducts (MRCP); X-rays of bile ducts (ERCP); Liver biopsy

Diagnosis: Proctitis is diagnosed through a combination of patient symptoms (rectal pain, bleeding, frequent bowel movements), physical examination, and various diagnostic tests to identify the underlying cause of inflammation.
Treatments: Medications to treat infection (antibiotics or antivirals); Medications to control inflammation (sucralfate, mesalamine, sulfasalazine, metronidazole); Stool softeners; Dilation; Ablation procedures (argon plasma coagulation, cryoablation, electrocoagulation); Surgery (for inflammatory bowel disease); Corticosteroids (prednisone, budesonide); Immunosuppressants (azathioprine, infliximab)
Tests: Blood tests; Stool test; Flexible sigmoidoscopy; Colonoscopy; Tests for sexually transmitted infections; Needle biopsy
Medications_Drugs: doxycycline; acyclovir; sucralfate; mesalamine; sulfasalazine; metronidazole; prednisone; budesonide; azathioprine; infliximab

Diagnosis: Suspicion based on symptoms; confirmation via genetic testing for LMNA gene changes; thorough physical exam including height/weight measurement, growth curve charting, hearing and vision testing, vital signs measurement, and observation of visible symptoms.
Treatments: Regular monitoring for heart and blood vessel disease; Lonafarnib; low-dose aspirin; other medications (as needed for complications, including dietary therapy, statins, blood thinners); physical therapy; occupational therapy; nutrition management (including supplements); hearing aids; eye and vision care; dental care; coronary angioplasty and stents; coronary artery bypass surgery.
Tests: Genetic test for LMNA gene; electrocardiograms; echocardiograms; X-ray; MRI; vision exams; hearing exams.
Medications_Drugs: Lonafarnib (Zokinvy); low-dose aspirin; statins; blood thinners.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is challenging due to symptom overlap with Parkinson's disease.  Suspicion arises if the patient lacks tremors, experiences frequent falls, shows little or no response to Parkinson's medications, and has difficulty moving their eyes downward. Brain shrinkage in specific regions may be visible on MRI.  MRI also helps rule out mimicking disorders like stroke.  PET scan may detect early brain changes not apparent on MRI.
Treatments: Parkinson's disease medications; OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) injections; Antidepressants; Eyeglasses with bifocal or prism lenses; Speech and swallowing evaluations; Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Facial exercises; Gait and balance training
Tests: MRI; PET scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves assessing signs and symptoms suggestive of prolactinoma; blood tests to measure prolactin and other pituitary hormones; pregnancy test for females of childbearing age; brain MRI to detect the tumor; and vision tests to assess visual impact.  Referral to an endocrinologist may be necessary for additional testing.
Treatments: Medications; Surgery
Tests: Blood tests; Pregnancy test; MRI scan; Vision tests

Diagnosis: Prostate cancer diagnosis often begins with a digital rectal exam and a prostate-specific antigen (PSA) blood test.  If these tests reveal concerning results, imaging tests (ultrasound, MRI) may be used to visualize the prostate. A prostate biopsy is performed to confirm the presence of cancer cells.
Treatments: Information not found
Tests: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) blood test; Digital rectal exam; Prostate ultrasound; Prostate MRI (including contrast-enhanced MRI, MRI with endorectal coil, multiparametric MRI); Prostate biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam, review of symptoms and medical history, and diagnostic tests to assess for infection and other potential causes.  A urologist may be consulted.
Treatments: Antibiotics (for bacterial prostatitis); Alpha-blockers (to relax bladder neck and muscle fibers); Pain medication;  Acupuncture; Biofeedback;  Sitz baths; Lifestyle modifications (limiting alcohol, caffeine, spicy foods; increased water intake)
Tests: Digital rectal exam; Urine test; Blood test; Prostatic specimen test (prostate fluid sample after massage); Urodynamic tests; Imaging tests
Medications_Drugs: Antibiotics; Alpha-blockers; Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Rye grass pollen extract (Cernilton)

Diagnosis: Diagnosed during a neurological evaluation by internists, neuropsychologists, neurologists, and psychiatrists;  Diagnosis involves assessing the characteristics of emotional outbursts, differentiating PBA from other conditions like depression, bipolar disorder, and anxiety.  Key information includes details about the emotional outbursts (voluntary or involuntary, duration, appropriateness, trigger, reflection of true emotions, impact on social interactions).
Treatments: Medication; Occupational therapy
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: Dextromethorphan hydrobromide and quinidine sulfate (Nuedexta); Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs); Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs)

Diagnosis: Suspected when problems with muscle control and breathing occur after succinylcholine administration; confirmed by blood test measuring pseudocholinesterase enzyme levels; genetic testing identifies the gene change causing inherited deficiency.
Treatments: Avoiding succinylcholine; using alternative muscle relaxants; mechanical ventilation support; sedation.
Tests: Blood test; Genetic testing

Diagnosis: Symptoms mimic gout and other arthritis types; lab and imaging tests confirm diagnosis; joint aspiration (arthrocentesis) to analyze joint fluid for crystals; X-rays reveal joint damage and crystal deposits.
Treatments: Medications; Joint drainage; Rest; Ice; Over-the-counter NSAIDs
Tests: Blood tests for thyroid, parathyroid issues, and mineral imbalances; Joint aspiration (arthrocentesis); X-rays
Medications_Drugs: Naproxen; Indomethacin; Colchicine; Prednisone; Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on stool sample tests for *Clostridioides difficile* (C. difficile); blood tests may show leukocytosis (high white blood cell count) indicating infection; colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy visualizes characteristic lesions (raised yellow plaques) and swelling in the colon; imaging tests (abdominal X-ray or CT scan) may be used to identify complications like toxic megacolon or colon rupture.
Treatments: Stopping the causative antibiotic if possible; Antibiotic treatment (e.g., vancomycin, fidaxomicin, metronidazole); Fecal microbial transplantation (FMT); Surgery (total or subtotal colectomy; loop ileostomy and colonic lavage); Bezlotoxumab (Zinplava)
Tests: Stool sample; Blood tests; Colonoscopy; Sigmoidoscopy; Abdominal X-ray; Abdominal CT scan

Diagnosis: Review of symptoms and medical history; physical examination; eye exams (assessing optic nerve swelling, visual field testing, retinal thickness measurement via optical coherence tomography); brain imaging (MRI or CT scan to rule out other conditions); lumbar puncture (to measure intracranial pressure and analyze spinal fluid).
Treatments: Low-sodium weight-loss diet; Weight-loss programs; Gastric surgery; Optic nerve sheath fenestration; Spinal fluid shunt; Venous sinus stenting
Tests: Eye exam; Visual field test; Optical coherence tomography; MRI; CT scan; Lumbar puncture

Diagnosis: Physical examination of skin, scalp, and nails; skin biopsy to determine type of psoriasis and rule out other disorders.
Treatments: Topical therapy; Light therapy; Oral or injected medications
Tests: Skin biopsy
Medications_Drugs: hydrocortisone; triamcinolone; clobetasol; calcipotriene; calcitriol; tazarotene; tacrolimus; pimecrolimus; salicylic acid; coal tar; anthralin; acitretin; etanercept; infliximab; adalimumab; ustekinumab; risankizumab-rzaa; ixekizumab; guselkumab; apremilast; bimekizumab-bkzx; secukinumab; methotrexate

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam checking joints for swelling/tenderness and fingernails for abnormalities;  no single test confirms psoriatic arthritis, but tests rule out other conditions like rheumatoid arthritis or gout.  X-rays pinpoint joint changes; MRI assesses tendons and ligaments;  rheumatoid factor (RF) blood test differentiates from rheumatoid arthritis; joint fluid test helps distinguish from gout.
Treatments: Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs); NSAIDs; Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Massage therapy; Steroid injections; Joint replacement surgery; Self-care strategies (joint protection, weight management)
Tests: X-rays; MRI; Rheumatoid factor (RF) blood test; Joint fluid test
Medications_Drugs: methotrexate (Trexall, Otrexup); leflunomide (Arava); sulfasalazine (Azulfidine); adalimumab (Humira); certolizumab (Cimzia); etanercept (Enbrel); golimumab (Simponi); infliximab (Remicade); ustekinumab (Stelara); secukinumab (Cosentyx); ixekizumab (Taltz); guselkumab (Tremfya); abatacept (Orencia); tofacitinib (Xeljanz); apremilast (Otezla); ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB); naproxen sodium (Aleve)

Diagnosis: Visual examination of the pubic area to identify moving lice; presence of lice eggs (nits), although nits may remain after successful treatment.
Treatments: Over-the-counter lotions or shampoos with 1% permethrin (Nix) or pyrethrin; prescription lotions such as malathion; oral medication ivermectin (Stromectol); petroleum jelly application for eyelashes and eyebrows; nit comb or fingernails to remove lice and nits; topical ointment (if needed); washing contaminated items in hot, soapy water; dry cleaning or sealing unwashable items.
Tests: Visual examination

Diagnosis: Pulmonary atresia is usually diagnosed soon after birth; diagnosis relies primarily on echocardiogram which shows blood flow through the heart and heart valves; pulse oximetry may indicate low blood oxygen levels suggesting a heart or lung problem; chest X-ray assesses heart and lung size and shape; electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) records the heart's electrical activity.
Treatments: Balloon atrial septostomy; Stent placement in the ductus arteriosus; Shunting; Glenn procedure; Fontan procedure; Heart transplant; Surgery to patch ventricular septal defect (VSD) and create a connection from the right pumping chamber to the pulmonary artery (potentially using an artificial valve); IV medication to keep the ductus arteriosus open (short-term).
Tests: Pulse oximetry; Chest X-ray; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Echocardiogram (including fetal echocardiogram); Cardiac catheterization

Disease_Name_English: Pulmonary atresia with ventricular septal defect
Disease_Name_Spanish: Pulmonary atresia with ventricular septal defect
Diagnosis: Pulmonary atresia with ventricular septal defect (PA-VSD) is often diagnosed during pregnancy or soon after birth using tests such as pulse oximetry, chest X-ray, echocardiogram (including fetal echocardiogram), electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG), cardiac catheterization, and heart CT scan.  The presence of major aortopulmonary collateral arteries (MAPCAs) is also assessed as it influences treatment planning.
Treatments: Catheter procedure (including stent placement in patent ductus arteriosus); Systemic-to-pulmonary artery shunt (e.g., Blalock-Taussig shunt); Complete repair; Unifocalization
Tests: Pulse oximetry; Chest X-ray; Echocardiogram; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Cardiac catheterization; Heart CT scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on symptoms, physical exam, and results of diagnostic tests.  A history of cardiovascular or lung disease is considered once the condition is more stable.
Treatments: Oxygen therapy; Mechanical ventilation; Positive airway pressure; Diuretics; Blood pressure drugs; Inotropes; Morphine;  Descending to lower elevation (for HAPE); Stopping exercise and staying warm (for HAPE)
Tests: Chest X-ray; Chest computerized tomography (CT) scan; Pulse oximetry; Arterial blood gas test; B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) blood test; Complete blood count; Metabolic panel; Thyroid function test; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; Echocardiogram; Cardiac catheterization and coronary angiogram; Ultrasound of the lungs
Medications_Drugs: Furosemide (Lasix); Nitroglycerin (Nitromist, Nitrostat, others); Nitroprusside (Nitropress); Inotropes; Morphine (MS Contin, Infumorph, others)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis can be challenging, especially in patients with pre-existing heart or lung conditions.  Diagnosis involves reviewing medical history, physical examination, and utilizing various diagnostic tests to identify the presence of a pulmonary embolism.  High D-dimer levels may suggest increased likelihood, but are not definitive.
Treatments: Blood thinners (anticoagulants); Clot dissolvers (thrombolytics); Clot removal; Vein filter; Ongoing care with anticoagulants and monitoring
Tests: Blood test (D-dimer, oxygen and carbon dioxide levels, inherited clotting disorder); Chest X-ray; Duplex ultrasonography; CT pulmonary angiography; Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scan; Pulmonary angiogram; MRI
Medications_Drugs: Heparin; Warfarin (Jantovin); Newer oral anticoagulants (specific names not provided); Thrombolytics (specific names not provided)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing medical and family history, physical exam (listening to lung sounds for crackling), and various tests to confirm the presence of scar tissue and assess lung function.  If other tests are inconclusive, a lung biopsy may be necessary.
Treatments: Oxygen therapy; Pulmonary rehabilitation;  Anti-acid medications (for GERD);  Antibiotics; Corticosteroid medicines; Mechanical ventilation; Lung transplant.
Tests: Chest X-ray; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Echocardiogram; Spirometry; Lung volume test; Lung diffusion test; Pulse oximetry; Six-minute walking test; Exercise stress test; Arterial blood gas test; Biopsy (surgical biopsy, including VATS and thoracotomy; bronchoscopy); Blood tests (liver and kidney function).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is challenging due to similar symptoms to other heart and lung conditions; diagnosis involves a physical exam, review of medical and family history, and various tests to confirm the presence of pulmonary hypertension and identify its cause.
Treatments: Medications; Blood thinners
Tests: Blood tests; Chest X-ray; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Echocardiogram (with optional exercise stress testing); Right heart catheterization; Exercise stress tests; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Lung function test; Sleep study; Ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) scan; Lung biopsy; Genetic testing
Medications_Drugs: epoprostenol (Flolan, Veletri); treprostinil (Remodulin, Tyvaso, others); iloprost; selexipag (Uptravi); riociguat (Adempas); bosentan (Tracleer); macitentan (Opsumit); ambrisentan (Letairis); sildenafil (Revatio, Viagra); tadalafil (Adcirca, Alyq, Cialis); amlodipine (Norvasc); diltiazem (Cardizem, Tiazac, others); nifedipine (Procardia); warfarin (Jantoven); digoxin (Lanoxin); diuretics

Diagnosis: Diagnosis may be made at birth or later in life.  A heart murmur (whooshing sound) detected with a stethoscope is a potential indicator.  Further testing is required for confirmation.
Treatments: Regular health checkups; Surgery to repair or replace the valve; Balloon valvuloplasty; Pulmonary valve replacement surgery; Transcatheter pulmonary valve replacement; Valve-in-valve procedure
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Echocardiogram; Chest X-ray; Cardiac catheterization; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Computerized tomography (CT) scan

Diagnosis: Pulmonary valve stenosis is often diagnosed in childhood but may be detected later. Diagnosis involves listening for a heart murmur using a stethoscope; electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) to assess heart rhythm and potential heart muscle thickening; echocardiogram to visualize the valve and assess the degree of narrowing; cardiac catheterization with coronary angiogram to measure pressure differences and visualize blood flow; and potentially MRI or CT scans for further imaging.
Treatments: Balloon valvuloplasty; Pulmonary valve replacement;  Occasional health checkups (for mild cases without symptoms)
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Echocardiogram; Cardiac catheterization; Coronary angiogram; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Computed tomography (CT) scan

Diagnosis: Physical exam to palpate an olive-shaped lump (enlarged pyloric muscle) in the baby's belly; observation of wavelike contractions in the baby's belly, particularly after feeding or before vomiting; ultrasound (standard diagnostic tool) to show enlargement of the pyloric valve; specialized X-ray to create a video of stomach function (less common than ultrasound); blood tests to detect electrolyte imbalances and dehydration.
Treatments: Pyloromyotomy (surgical procedure); Atropine sulfate (medication - rarely used)
Tests: Ultrasound; X-ray; Blood tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily based on clinical presentation and ruling out other conditions with similar symptoms.  No single test confirms pyoderma gangrenosum.  A skin biopsy may be used to help rule out other conditions.
Treatments: Corticosteroids; Wound care; Surgery (skin graft for large, non-healing sores);  Steroid-sparing medicines; Pain medication
Tests: Blood tests; Chest X-ray; Colon exam; Skin biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Prednisone; Cyclosporine; Mycophenolate (Cellcept); Immunoglobulins; Dapsone; Infliximab (Remicade); Tacrolimus (Protopic)

Diagnosis: There is no definitive test to immediately determine if rabies has been transmitted after a bite.  Many tests may be ordered to detect the virus, but confirmation may require repeated testing. Diagnosis often relies on the circumstances of exposure and the animal's status.
Treatments: Rabies immune globulin (given near bite site if not previously vaccinated); Series of rabies vaccinations (four injections over 14 days if unvaccinated, two injections over three days if previously vaccinated). Observation of the biting animal for 10 days (if a pet) to see if it develops symptoms.
Tests: Tests to detect the rabies virus; Animal testing for rabies virus (brain tissue analysis).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a review of medical history and physical exam.  Imaging tests such as X-rays, CT scans, and MRI scans may be used; endoscopy (including colonoscopy and capsule endoscopy) may be used to visualize the intestines.
Treatments: Dietary changes; Medications for diarrhea and pain; Antibiotics; Feeding tube; Surgery (to bypass irritated intestine)
Tests: Endoscopy; Colonoscopy; Capsule endoscopy; X-rays; CT scan; MRI scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves determining the absorbed radiation dose based on known exposure (distance from source, duration), onset and severity of symptoms (e.g., vomiting time), blood tests (white blood cell counts, DNA changes in blood cells), dosimeter readings (if available), and survey meter results to identify radioactive particle location and type of radiation.
Treatments: Decontamination (removing clothing, washing); Treatment for damaged bone marrow (granulocyte colony-stimulating factor, blood transfusions); Treatment for internal contamination (potassium iodide, Prussian blue, DTPA); Supportive treatment for infections, headache, fever, diarrhea, nausea/vomiting, dehydration, burns, sores/ulcers; End-of-life care (pain management, psychological/pastoral care)
Tests: Blood tests; Dosimeter; Survey meter (e.g., Geiger counter)
Medications_Drugs: filgrastim (Neupogen); sargramostim (Leukine); pegfilgrastim (Neulasta); potassium iodide; Prussian blue (Radiogardase); Diethylenetriamine pentaacetic acid (DTPA)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical history, physical exam, and characteristic signs and symptoms;  Confirmation may involve testing a fluid sample from a rash blister.
Treatments: Antiviral drugs; Corticosteroids; Anti-anxiety medications; Pain relievers; Keeping the rash clean; Applying cool, wet compresses; Using over-the-counter pain relievers or anti-inflammatory drugs; Using moisturizing eyedrops and applying ointment/eye patch if facial weakness affects eye closure.
Tests: Fluid sample from rash blister
Medications_Drugs: acyclovir (Zovirax); famciclovir (Famvir); valacyclovir (Valtrex); prednisone; diazepam (Valium); ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on symptoms and medical history, and a physical exam; additional tests may rule out other conditions causing similar symptoms. Nailfold capillaroscopy can differentiate between primary and secondary Raynaud's.
Treatments: Dressing warmly in layers and wearing gloves or socks; Medications; Nerve surgery; Chemical injection (numbing medicine or onabotulinumtoxinA); Lifestyle modifications (avoiding smoking, managing stress, avoiding rapid temperature changes, regular exercise).
Tests: Nailfold capillaroscopy; Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) test; Erythrocyte sedimentation rate; Blood tests to rule out other conditions affecting blood vessels
Medications_Drugs: nifedipine (Procardia); amlodipine (Norvasc); felodipine; isradipine; losartan (Cozaar); sildenafil (Viagra, Revatio); fluoxetine (Prozac); prostaglandins; fish oil supplements; ginkgo supplements.

Diagnosis: Physical exam checking joints for swelling, warmth, tenderness, and range of motion;  eye examination for inflammation; skin examination for rashes; assessment of past or current infection evidence, inflammation signs, antibodies associated with other arthritis types, and a genetic marker linked to reactive arthritis via blood tests; joint fluid analysis for white blood cell count, infections, and crystals; X-rays of the low back, pelvis, and joints to identify characteristic signs and rule out other arthritis types.
Treatments: Antibiotics (if persistent infection present); Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs); Steroid injections; Steroid eye drops; Steroid creams; Sulfasalazine; Methotrexate; Etanercept; Physical therapy
Tests: Blood tests; Joint fluid tests; X-rays

Diagnosis: A pediatric psychiatrist or psychologist conducts a thorough examination, including direct observation of child-caregiver interactions, behavioral pattern assessment across various situations, and information gathering on home environment and caregiving styles.  The DSM-5 criteria are used, considering a consistent pattern of emotionally withdrawn behavior, persistent social and emotional problems, and lack of emotional needs met by caregivers; other disorders (intellectual disability, adjustment disorders, autism spectrum disorder, depressive disorders, PTSD) are ruled out. Diagnosis is typically not made before 9 months of age.
Treatments: Early intervention;  a safe and stable living situation; development of positive interactions and strengthened attachment with parents/caregivers; education and coaching in skills to improve symptoms; nurturing, responsive and caring environment; consistent caregivers; positive, stimulating, and interactive environment; addressing medical, safety, and housing needs; individual and family psychological counseling; education of parents/caregivers; parenting skills classes.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Rectal cancer diagnosis often begins with imaging tests (e.g., colonoscopy) to visualize the rectum and colon.  A biopsy is performed to obtain a tissue sample for lab testing to confirm the presence of cancer cells.  Diagnosis may also be suspected based on patient symptoms.  Staging tests determine the extent of cancer spread.
Treatments: Surgery (transanal local excision, low anterior resection, colorectal anastomosis, coloanal anastomosis, abdominoperineal resection [APR], colostomy); Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy (external beam radiation); Targeted therapy; Combined chemotherapy and radiation therapy
Tests: Colonoscopy; Biopsy; Complete blood count (CBC); Blood tests to measure organ function (chemistry panel); Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) test; CT scan of chest, abdomen, and pelvis; MRI of the pelvis

Diagnosis: Distinguishing rectal prolapse from hemorrhoids can be difficult. Diagnosis involves a digital rectal exam to assess sphincter muscle strength and check for rectal prolapse (patient bears down during exam); anal manometry to measure anal sphincter tightness and rectal function; and colonoscopy to rule out other conditions like hemorrhoids, polyps, or colon cancer. Defecography (with X-ray or MRI) may be used to visualize structural changes in the lower digestive tract and assess rectal muscle function.
Treatments: Surgery; Treatment for constipation with stool softeners and suppositories
Tests: Digital rectal exam; Anal manometry; Colonoscopy; Defecography

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam to locate the fistula and check for tumors, infections, or abscesses; this may include visual inspection of the vagina, anus, and perineum, using tools like a speculum and proctoscope; a biopsy may be taken if cancer is suspected.  If not readily visible, further tests may be necessary.
Treatments: Waiting (3-6 months to allow for spontaneous closure); Seton placement (drainage); Surgery (fistula removal, tissue graft, anal sphincter repair, colostomy);  Antibiotics; Infliximab
Tests: Physical exam; Biopsy; CT scan; MRI; Colonoscopy; Exam under anesthesia; Barium enema (implied)

Diagnosis: Suspicion of recurrent breast cancer may arise from mammogram, physical exam, or signs/symptoms.  Confirmation requires biopsy to examine cells and determine cancer type and hormone/targeted therapy sensitivity.
Treatments: Surgery (lumpectomy, mastectomy, lymph node removal); Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Hormone therapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy (for triple-negative breast cancer); Bone-building drugs
Tests: Mammogram; MRI; CT scan; X-ray; Bone scan; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing medical history and symptoms; physical and neurological exam to rule out other sleep disorders;  interviewing the sleeping partner about observed behaviors; and a nocturnal sleep study (polysomnogram) to monitor physiological activity and behavior during sleep, confirming increased muscle activity during REM sleep and excluding other sleep disorders. Diagnostic criteria include repeated arousals with talking, noises, or complex motor behaviors related to dream content; dream recall associated with these behaviors; alertness upon awakening; increased muscle activity during REM sleep on polysomnography; and exclusion of other sleep disorders, mental health conditions, medications, or substance abuse.
Treatments: Physical safeguards (padding the floor, removing dangerous objects, placing barriers on the bed, moving furniture); Medications
Tests: Physical and neurological exam; Nocturnal sleep study (polysomnogram)

Diagnosis: Physical exam (auscultation over kidneys); Review of medical history; Blood and urine tests (kidney function and hormone levels).  Imaging tests may include Doppler ultrasound, CT scan (with possible contrast injection), magnetic resonance angiography (MRA, with contrast injection), and renal arteriography (with contrast injection, often used before stent placement).
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (diet, exercise, weight management, smoking cessation); Medication; Renal angioplasty and stenting; Renal artery bypass surgery
Tests: Physical exam; Blood tests; Urine tests; Doppler ultrasound; CT scan; Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA); Renal arteriography
Medications_Drugs: ACE inhibitors; Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs); Diuretics; Beta blockers; Alpha-beta blockers; Calcium channel blockers; Aspirin; Cholesterol-lowering medication

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves identifying the cause of residual limb pain through a physical exam checking for skin or bone issues, infection, and lumps; imaging tests (MRI, CT, X-ray, ultrasound) to rule out bone breaks, bruises, tumors, infections, or other bone problems; and blood tests to rule out other potential causes.
Treatments: Pain relievers; Antidepressants; Anticonvulsants; N-methyl-D-aspartic acid agonists; Physical and occupational therapy; Compression garments; Massage; Hypnosis; Nerve blocks; Neuromodulation (SCS, PNS, TENS); Osseointegration; Regenerative peripheral nerve interface (RPNI)
Tests: Physical exam; MRI; CT scan; X-ray; Ultrasound; Blood tests
Medications_Drugs: Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Opioids; Tricyclic antidepressants; Selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors; Gabapentin; Pregabalin; Topical ketamine

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily based on physical examination findings (listening to the lungs for wheezing), the timing of symptoms, and consideration of the time of year.  Laboratory and imaging tests are usually not necessary but may be used to diagnose complications or rule out other conditions.
Treatments: Supportive care (acetaminophen for fever, nasal saline drops and suctioning, plenty of fluids); Hospital care (IV fluids; humidified oxygen; mechanical ventilation in rare cases); Antibiotics (if bacterial complication).
Tests: Blood tests; Chest X-rays; Swab of secretions from the mouth or nose; Pulse oximetry

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on the International Restless Legs Syndrome Study Group criteria: strong urge to move legs with uncomfortable sensations, symptoms worsening at rest and improving with activity, worse at night, symptoms not explained by another condition; a physical and neurological exam are conducted.
Treatments: Correcting iron deficiency (oral or intravenous iron supplements); electrical nerve stimulation; lifestyle changes; medication
Tests: Blood tests (for iron deficiency)
Medications_Drugs: Gabapentin; gabapentin enacarbil; pregabalin; rotigotine; pramipexole; ropinirole; carbidopa-levodopa; oxycodone; hydrocodone; buprenorphine

Diagnosis: Retinal detachment is diagnosed through a retinal exam using an instrument with a bright light and special lenses to visualize the retina for holes, tears, or detachments; ultrasound imaging may be used if bleeding obscures the retina.  Both eyes are typically examined even if symptoms are present in only one.  A follow-up visit may be necessary to rule out delayed retinal tears.
Treatments: Laser surgery (laser photocoagulation or retinopexy); Freezing (cryopexy); Pneumatic retinopexy (air or gas injection into the vitreous cavity); Scleral buckling (silicone implant to indent the eye); Vitrectomy (removal of vitreous and potentially replacement with air, gas, or silicone oil).
Tests: Retinal exam; Ultrasound imaging

Diagnosis: Ophthalmologist performs a thorough eye exam looking for irregularities; Amsler grid test assesses central vision clarity and distortion; location and extent of disease determined by various tests.
Treatments: Laser surgery; Scatter laser photocoagulation; Cryopexy; Pneumatic retinopexy; Scleral buckling; Vitrectomy; Injecting medicine into the eye; Implanting a retinal prosthesis
Tests: Amsler grid test; Optical coherence tomography (OCT); Fundus autofluorescence (FAF); Fluorescein angiography; Indocyanine green angiography; Ultrasound; CT; MRI

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a thorough eye exam, potentially involving vision testing and using a special light to examine the inside of the eye; imaging tests (ultrasound, MRI, CT scan) help determine cancer size and extent.  Genetic testing analyzes the RB1 gene for variations.
Treatments: Chemotherapy (systemic, intra-arterial, intravitreal); Cold therapy (cryotherapy); Laser therapy (transpupillary thermotherapy); Radiation therapy (plaque radiotherapy; external beam radiation); Eye removal surgery (enucleation)
Tests: Eye exam; Ultrasound; MRI; CT scan; Genetic testing (RB1 gene analysis)

Diagnosis: The doctor will locate the testicle in the groin and attempt to gently guide it into the scrotum.  A retractile testicle will move relatively easily and will not immediately retract; in contrast, an undescended testicle will immediately retreat to its original location.  Annual evaluations monitor changes in testicle position.  A pediatric urologist may be consulted if there is any question about the diagnosis or need for immediate treatment.
Treatments: No treatment is required for retractile testicles; annual monitoring of testicle position.
Tests: Physical examination

Diagnosis: A physical exam including examination of the penis, testicles, and rectum; questioning about symptoms, medical history, surgeries, cancers, and medications; urinalysis to check for semen in the urine after orgasm.  High sperm volume in urine confirms retrograde ejaculation; absence of semen suggests a problem with semen production.
Treatments: Medications to keep the bladder neck muscle closed during ejaculation; assisted reproductive technology (ART) including intrauterine insemination (IUI) or more advanced techniques if medication is ineffective.
Tests: Urinalysis
Medications_Drugs: Imipramine; Midodrine; Chlorpheniramine; Brompheniramine; Ephedrine; Pseudoephedrine; Phenylephrine

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves observing child's growth and development, reviewing medical and family history, and ruling out other conditions with similar symptoms (e.g., other genetic disorders, autism spectrum disorder, cerebral palsy).  Core symptoms of classic Rett syndrome include partial or complete loss of purposeful hand skills; partial or complete loss of spoken language; walking problems; and repetitive purposeless hand movements. Genetic testing (DNA analysis for MECP2 gene changes) confirms diagnosis.  Atypical Rett syndrome has similar symptoms with varying severity.
Treatments: Regular medical care; Medications; Physical therapy; Assistive devices (walker, wheelchair); Occupational therapy; Speech-language therapy; Nutritional support (including gastrostomy tube feeding); Behavioral intervention; Support services (early intervention programs, school, social, and job training services)
Tests: Blood tests; Urine tests; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Computerized tomography (CT) scans; Hearing tests; Eye and vision exams; Electroencephalograms (EEGs)

Diagnosis: There is no specific test to diagnose Reye's syndrome. Diagnosis is usually based on clinical findings, including blood and urine tests, and often involves ruling out other conditions with similar symptoms through additional testing.  Fatty acid oxidation disorders and other disorders may also be tested for.
Treatments: Intravenous (IV) fluids; Diuretics; Vitamin K; Plasma; Platelets; Cooling blankets; Ventilator
Tests: Blood test; Urine test; Spinal tap (lumbar puncture); Liver biopsy; CT scan; MRI

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam.  Further tests may include imaging tests (X-rays, CT scans, MRI scans, PET scans, bone scans) and a biopsy (needle biopsy or surgical biopsy) to obtain a tissue sample for pathological examination.  The biopsy needs to be performed carefully to avoid compromising future surgery.
Treatments: Surgery; Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy; Clinical trials
Tests: X-rays; CT scans; MRI scans; PET scans; Bone scans; Needle biopsy; Surgical biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical history, physical exam, and results of specific tests;  there is no single test for rheumatic fever.  Tests assess inflammation and the presence of antibodies related to strep bacteria.
Treatments: Treat the infection; Ease symptoms; Control inflammation; Prevent recurrence; Bed rest (as recommended); Activity restrictions (until symptoms improve)
Tests: Blood tests (CRP, ESR, antibody tests); Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Echocardiogram
Medications_Drugs: Penicillin; Other antibiotics; Aspirin; Naproxen; Corticosteroids; Valproic acid; Carbamazepine

Diagnosis: Physical exam checking joints for swelling, redness, and warmth; checking reflexes and muscle strength; blood tests for ESR, CRP, rheumatoid factor, and anti-CCP antibodies; X-rays to track joint changes; MRI and ultrasound to assess disease severity.  Early diagnosis can be difficult due to overlapping symptoms with other conditions.
Treatments: Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs); NSAIDs; Steroids; Physical therapy; Surgery; Lifestyle modifications (exercise, heat/cold application, stress reduction, smoking cessation).
Tests: Blood tests (ESR, CRP, rheumatoid factor, anti-CCP antibodies); X-ray; MRI; Ultrasound
