Medications_Drugs: ibuprofen; naproxen sodium; prednisone; methotrexate; leflunomide; hydroxychloroquine; sulfasalazine; abatacept; adalimumab; anakinra; certolizumab; etanercept; golimumab; infliximab; rituximab; sarilumab; tocilizumab; baricitinib; tofacitinib; upadacitinib; fish oil (supplement).

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing bone irregularities (skull softness, bowed legs, chest deformities, thickened wrists/ankles); X-rays of affected bones to reveal deformities; blood and urine tests to confirm diagnosis and monitor treatment progress.  In infants, assessment of growth, breathing, and muscle tone is also considered.
Treatments: Vitamin D and calcium supplements; bracing for bowleg or spinal deformities; surgery for more serious skeletal deformities; phosphorus supplements and medications for rare inherited disorders causing low phosphorus.
Tests: X-rays; Blood tests; Urine tests

Diagnosis: Visual examination by a doctor; Skin scraping examination under a microscope.
Treatments: Over-the-counter antifungal lotions, creams, or ointments; Prescription-strength antifungal lotions, creams, or ointments; Prescription antifungal pills.
Tests: Skin scraping examination

Diagnosis: Visual examination of the affected skin; Questions about symptoms; Microscopic examination of a hair or skin sample to identify fungus.
Treatments: Oral prescription-strength antifungal medication; Medicated shampoo.
Tests: Microscopic examination of hair or skin sample

Diagnosis: Clinical examination of the skin by a doctor or healthcare professional, assessing symptoms and ruling out other conditions like psoriasis or lupus;  Symptoms may be less visible on brown and Black skin, requiring attention to swelling, bumps, stinging, and dry skin.  Eye examination by an ophthalmologist if eye symptoms are present.
Treatments: Prescription gel or cream; Prescription pills; Laser treatment; Self-care tips (avoiding triggers, sun protection, gentle skin care); Makeup to reduce redness; Massage; Stress management.
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: Brimonidine (Mirvaso); Oxymetazoline (Rhofade); Azelaic acid (Azelex, Finacea); Metronidazole (Metrogel, Noritate); Ivermectin (Soolantra); Doxycycline (Oracea); Isotretinoin (Amnesteem, Claravis).

Diagnosis: Roseola is often diagnosed based on characteristic symptoms, which are initially similar to other childhood illnesses like measles.  A rash, typically starting on the chest or back (differing from a measles rash that begins on the head), is a key indicator.  Blood tests may be used for confirmation.
Treatments: Supportive care including rest, fluids, and cool compresses to manage fever;  For immunocompromised individuals, ganciclovir may be prescribed.
Tests: Blood test

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing shoulder palpation, range of motion, and muscle strength; imaging tests (X-ray, ultrasound, MRI) to visualize bone spurs, arthritis, and soft tissue structures.
Treatments: Rest; Ice; Physical therapy; Injection into shoulder joint; Arthroscopic rotator cuff repair; Open tendon repair; Tendon transfer; Shoulder replacement; Reverse shoulder arthroplasty
Tests: Physical examination; X-ray; Ultrasound; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)

Diagnosis: Often diagnosed based on symptoms and physical exam; stool sample analysis may be used to confirm diagnosis.
Treatments: Preventing dehydration; oral rehydration fluids (Pedialyte or Enfalyte); intravenous fluids (for severe dehydration); bland foods; plenty of liquids; rest.  Anti-diarrheal medications are not recommended.
Tests: Stool sample analysis
Medications_Drugs: None specifically recommended; antibiotics and antivirals are ineffective.

Diagnosis: Rubella is usually confirmed with lab tests, such as virus culture or blood tests to detect rubella antibodies, indicating recent or past infection or vaccination.  The rubella rash can resemble other viral rashes.
Treatments: Isolation from others (especially pregnant women) for at least seven days after the rash disappears; Supportive care (bed rest, acetaminophen for fever and aches)
Tests: Virus culture; Blood test (for rubella antibodies)

Diagnosis: Clinical evaluation of symptoms and medical history; observation of behavior; sometimes high-resolution esophageal manometry and impedance measurement to confirm diagnosis and rule out increased abdominal pressure and irregular function.
Treatments: Habit-reversal behavior therapy; Diaphragmatic breathing; Biofeedback; Environmental and behavioral changes (for infants); Medications to relax the stomach
Tests: High-resolution esophageal manometry; Impedance measurement; Upper endoscopy; Biopsy; Gastric emptying

Diagnosis: Visual inspection using an otoscope or microscope;  Additional tests may be conducted to determine the cause of symptoms or presence of hearing loss.
Treatments: Most heal without treatment; Antibiotic drops (if infection present); Eardrum patch; Surgery (tympanoplasty)
Tests: Laboratory tests (for ear discharge); Tuning fork evaluation; Tympanometry; Audiology exam

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam assessing spleen size and tenderness; blood tests evaluating platelet count and blood clotting; and imaging (ultrasound, CT scan with or without contrast) to detect blood in the abdominal cavity or rule out other causes.  In emergency situations, abdominal fluid sampling may be performed.
Treatments: Surgery (spleen repair, partial splenectomy, splenectomy); Nonsurgical care (observation, blood transfusions); Vaccinations (meningitis, pneumonia, Hib); Oral antibiotics
Tests: Physical exam; Blood tests; Ultrasound; Abdominal fluid sampling; CT scan

Diagnosis: Physical exam during a baby's first exam.  Larger dimples or those with associated hair tufts, skin tags, lumps, or specific skin discolorations may warrant further imaging.
Treatments: Treatment is unnecessary for a simple sacral dimple.
Tests: Ultrasound; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)

Diagnosis: Physical exam with palpation of hips and buttocks to locate pain; gentle movement of legs to stress sacroiliac joints; numbing injection into sacroiliac joint to assess pain relief.  X-ray of pelvis to show joint damage; MRI to assess damage related to ankylosing spondylitis.
Treatments: Sacroiliac injection (corticosteroids or numbing medicine); stretching and strengthening exercises; nonsteroidal antiinflammatory pain relievers;  radiofrequency denervation; electrical stimulation; joint fusion.
Tests: X-ray of the pelvis; MRI; CT scan; Ultrasound; Numbing injection into sacroiliac joint
Medications_Drugs: ibuprofen; naproxen sodium; cyclobenzaprine; secukinumab; ixekizumab; etanercept; adalimumab; infliximab; golimumab; tofacitinib; upadacitinib; acetaminophen

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam checking for lumps and swelling in the jaw, neck, and throat; imaging tests (MRI, CT, PET scan) pinpoint tumor location and size; a biopsy (fine-needle aspiration or core needle biopsy) determines cell type and cancer presence; further tests assess cancer spread (staging) if cancer is diagnosed.
Treatments: Surgery (partial or complete salivary gland removal; lymph node removal; reconstructive surgery); Radiation therapy (external beam radiation); Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy; Palliative care
Tests: Physical exam; MRI; CT scan; PET scan; Fine-needle aspiration; Core needle biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is usually based on signs and symptoms; Stool sample testing can detect Salmonella infection, but results often return after symptoms resolve; Blood sample testing may be necessary if bloodstream infection is suspected.
Treatments: Adequate fluid intake to prevent dehydration; Oral rehydration solutions for severe dehydration; Anti-diarrheal medications (e.g., loperamide); Antibiotics (in specific cases such as bloodstream infection, severe infection, or weakened immune system).
Tests: Stool sample testing; Blood sample testing

Diagnosis: Sarcoidosis diagnosis is challenging due to often subtle early symptoms mimicking other conditions.  Diagnosis relies on ruling out other conditions and identifying affected body systems through various tests.  No single test definitively diagnoses sarcoidosis; a biopsy showing granulomas is supportive.
Treatments: No treatment if asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic; Corticosteroids;  Immunosuppressants; Physical therapy; Pulmonary rehabilitation; Implanted cardiac pacemaker or defibrillator; Organ transplant (lung, heart, liver)
Tests: Blood and urine tests; Chest X-ray; CT scan of the chest; Lung function tests; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Cardiac ultrasound; Eye exam; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Biopsy (skin, lungs, lymph nodes)
Medications_Drugs: Corticosteroids; Methotrexate (Trexall); Azathioprine (Azasan, Imuran); Hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil); Tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) inhibitors

Diagnosis: Sarcoma diagnosis begins with a physical exam and review of symptoms and health history.  Further diagnosis involves imaging tests (X-rays, MRIs, ultrasounds, CT scans, bone scans, PET scans) to determine sarcoma size and location; and a biopsy to obtain a tissue sample for lab testing. The specific tests used depend on the location and characteristics of the suspected sarcoma.
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy; Ablation therapy (radiofrequency ablation, microwave ablation, cryoablation, alcohol ablation)
Tests: Physical exam; X-rays; MRI; Ultrasound; CT scan; Bone scan; PET scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Examination of skin for mite symptoms; Skin sample microscopic analysis for mites and eggs.
Treatments: Medicated cream application to the whole body (neck down) for 8-14 hours;  Possible second application; Treatment of household members and close contacts; Oral medication for crusted scabies or weakened immune system; Other skin care treatments as needed.
Tests: Microscopic examination of skin sample

Diagnosis: Information not found
Treatments: Antibiotic prescription; Use of ibuprofen or acetaminophen for fever and throat pain; Rest; Increased fluid intake; Saltwater gargling (for older children and adults); Humidifying the air; Use of saline nasal spray; Honey (for children over 12 months); Soothing foods; Avoidance of irritants.
Tests: Throat swab; Rapid strep test; Strep throat culture

Diagnosis: Ruling out other mental health conditions and substance use/medical condition causes; physical exam to rule out other problems and check for complications; tests and screenings to rule out conditions with similar symptoms and screen for alcohol and drug use; potential imaging studies (MRI or CT scan); mental health evaluation assessing mental status, thoughts, moods, delusions, hallucinations, substance use, suicide potential, and family/personal history.
Treatments: Medications; Talk therapy (individual, family, or group); Life skills training (social skills training; work rehabilitation and supported work); Hospital stay; Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)
Tests: Physical exam; Tests to rule out conditions with similar symptoms; Alcohol and drug screenings; MRI; CT scan
Medications_Drugs: Paliperidone (Invega); Other antipsychotic drugs; Mood-stabilizing medicine; Antidepressants

Diagnosis: A physical exam to rule out other medical problems;  interview with a mental health professional to discuss symptoms, medical and personal history; assessment of symptoms and behaviors consistent with diagnostic criteria.
Treatments: Talk therapy (cognitive behavioral therapy); Group therapy
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Ruling out other mental health conditions and substance misuse; Physical exam to rule out other problems causing similar symptoms; Mental health evaluation assessing mental status, thoughts, moods, delusions, hallucinations, substance use, and potential for violence or suicide, including family and personal history; Tests and screenings to rule out conditions with similar symptoms and screen for alcohol and drug use;  Imaging studies such as MRI or CT scan may be used.
Treatments: Lifelong treatment with medicines and psychosocial therapy; Hospital stay during crises; Individual therapy; Social skills training; Family therapy; Vocational rehabilitation and supported employment; Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)
Tests: Physical exam; Tests to rule out conditions with similar symptoms; Alcohol and drug use screening; MRI; CT scan
Medications_Drugs: Aripiprazole (Abilify); Asenapine (Saphris); Brexpiprazole (Rexulti); Cariprazine (Vraylar); Clozapine (Clozaril); Iloperidone (Fanapt); Lumateperone (Caplyta); Lurasidone (Latuda); Olanzapine (Zyprexa); Paliperidone (Invega); Quetiapine (Seroquel); Risperidone (Risperdal); Xanomeline and trospium chloride (Cobenfy); Ziprasidone (Geodon); Chlorpromazine; Fluphenazine; Haloperidol (Haldol); Perphenazine (Trilafon); Aripiprazole (Abilify Maintena, Abilify Asimtufii, Aristada); Fluphenazine decanoate; Haloperidol decanoate; Paliperidone (Invega Sustenna, Invega Trinza, Invega Hafyera); Risperidone (Risperdal Consta, Perseris, others); Antidepressants; Mood stabilizers; Antianxiety drugs

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a thorough discussion of symptoms and difficulties, personal and medical history, including past treatments.  A physical exam is performed to rule out other medical conditions; referral to a mental health professional is common.
Treatments: Talk therapy (psychotherapy including cognitive behavioral therapy and supportive therapy); family therapy;  work and social activities tailored to personality style
Tests: Physical exam

Diagnosis: Review of personal and family medical history; physical exam;  additional tests may be needed to diagnose NF2-related, SMARCB1-related, or LZTR1-related schwannomatosis.
Treatments: Surgery to remove tumors; stereotactic radiosurgery; auditory brain stem implants; cochlear implants; cancer treatment (surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy); pain management
Tests: Eye exam; audiometry; electronystagmography; brain stem auditory evoked response; X-rays; CT scans; MRIs; genetic tests
Medications_Drugs: gabapentin; pregabalin; amitriptyline; duloxetine; topiramate; carbamazepine

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing muscle strength and reflexes (e.g., walking on toes/heels, rising from squatting, lifting legs);  evaluation of pain severity and duration.
Treatments: Self-care measures (rest, cold/hot packs, stretching); Medications; Physical therapy; Steroid injections; Surgery
Tests: X-ray; MRI; CT scan (may include CT myelogram); Electromyography (EMG)
Medications_Drugs: Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Anti-inflammatories; Corticosteroids; Antidepressants; Anti-seizure medications; Opioids

Diagnosis: Physical exam; Blood tests to check for elevated levels of certain antibodies; Other blood tests; Imaging; Organ function tests to assess digestive system, heart, lungs, and kidneys.
Treatments: Medicines to dilate blood vessels; Medicines to suppress the immune system; Medicines to reduce digestive symptoms; Preventative vaccinations; Pain relievers; Physical or occupational therapy; Hand therapy; Stem cell transplant; Organ transplant (lung, kidney)
Tests: Blood tests; Imaging; Organ function tests
Medications_Drugs: Blood pressure medicines (to dilate blood vessels); Immune suppressants; Pills to reduce stomach acid; Antibiotics; Medicines to help move food through intestines; Pain relievers; Antacids

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam to check for an abdominal mass; imaging tests like CT or MRI scans to visualize the mesentery; and a biopsy to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other conditions, such as cancer.  A biopsy may be obtained surgically or via needle aspiration.
Treatments: Observation with periodic imaging; Medications; Surgery (if intestinal blockage occurs)
Tests: Physical exam; CT scan; MRI; Biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Prednisone; Tamoxifen; Aspirin; Progesterone; Azathioprine; Colchicine; Cyclophosphamide; Thalidomide

Diagnosis: Physical exam to observe spinal curvature (bending forward test); Neurological exam to check for muscle weakness, numbness, and reflexes; X-rays to confirm diagnosis and measure curve.
Treatments: Bracing (for moderate curves in growing children); Surgery (spinal fusion, vertebral body tethering, expanding/growing rods, for large curves or rapidly progressing curves); Physical therapy (to strengthen back, ease pain, improve posture)
Tests: X-rays; MRI (if underlying condition suspected); Hand X-ray (to assess growth plate status)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is usually based on the patient's history and symptoms.  For serious symptoms, blood or imaging tests may be used to assess the venom's effects on organs.
Treatments: Most stings don't require treatment; Hospital care for serious symptoms; Intravenous pain medication; Scorpion antivenom (for children and adults with serious symptoms)
Tests: Blood tests; Imaging tests
Medications_Drugs: Scorpion antivenom; Intravenous pain medication; Ibuprofen

Diagnosis: Physical exam of the scrotum and groin; Transillumination to assess size, location, and makeup of the mass; Ultrasound to determine size, location, makeup, and condition of testicles (often needed); Urine test to detect infection or blood/pus; Blood test to detect infection or elevated proteins linked to testicular cancer; CT scan if testicular cancer is suspected to check for spread.
Treatments: Antibiotics for bacterial infections (e.g., epididymitis); Rest, ice, and pain relief for viral epididymitis or orchitis; Surgery, repair, or drainage for benign masses (depending on discomfort, infertility risk, or infection); Radical inguinal orchiectomy (surgical removal of affected testicle and spermatic cord, possibly lymph nodes) for testicular cancer; Chemotherapy for testicular cancer that has spread; Radiation therapy for testicular cancer that has spread to lymph nodes.
Tests: Physical exam; Transillumination; Ultrasound; Urine test; Blood test; Computerized tomography (CT) scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis can be challenging due to overlapping symptoms with other depression types.  A thorough evaluation includes a physical exam to rule out underlying physical health issues; lab tests such as a complete blood count (CBC) and thyroid function tests; and a psychological evaluation assessing symptoms, thoughts, feelings, and behavior patterns, often involving questionnaires.
Treatments: Light therapy (phototherapy); Psychotherapy (cognitive behavioral therapy); Medications
Tests: Complete blood count (CBC); Thyroid function tests

Diagnosis: Sebaceous carcinoma is diagnosed through a skin exam, potentially including an eye exam if the carcinoma is on the eyelid; a skin biopsy is performed to confirm the presence of cancer cells through specialized lab tests.
Treatments: Surgery; Mohs surgery; Radiation therapy; Clinical trials
Tests: Skin exam; Eye exam; Skin biopsy

Diagnosis: Clinical evaluation of symptoms and visual examination of the skin; skin biopsy may be performed to rule out other conditions.
Treatments: Medicated shampoos; creams and lotions; antifungal gels, creams, lotions, foams, or shampoos; corticosteroid creams, lotions, shampoos, or ointments; creams or ointments with a calcineurin inhibitor (tacrolimus or pimecrolimus); oral antifungal medication; lifestyle changes and home remedies; nonprescription anti-dandruff shampoos; application of mineral oil, peanut oil, or olive oil to soften scales; regular washing with warm water and gentle cleanser; application of medicated cream (mild corticosteroid or ketoconazole); avoiding styling products and alcohol-containing products; regular shampooing of facial hair or shaving; gentle eyelid cleansing; regular washing of infant's scalp with mild baby shampoo and optional use of mineral or olive oil.
Tests: Skin biopsy

Diagnosis: Visual examination by a doctor is usually sufficient; If there's uncertainty, a skin biopsy may be recommended for microscopic examination.
Treatments: Removal is an option if the keratosis is irritated, bleeds, or is aesthetically unappealing; Cryotherapy (freezing with liquid nitrogen); Curettage (scraping) or shaving; Electrocautery (burning with electric current).
Tests: Skin biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves multiple blood pressure readings (3-6) at separate appointments, potentially including home and ambulatory monitoring.  Further testing aims to identify the underlying cause of hypertension.
Treatments: Treating the underlying medical condition with medications or surgery; Continuing blood pressure medication may be necessary.
Tests: Blood tests; Urine test (urinalysis); Ultrasound of the kidneys; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing symptoms, medical history, and conducting a physical exam.  Further investigation may include neurological exam to assess behavior and motor abilities; blood tests to check blood sugar, infections, gene conditions, and electrolyte levels; spinal tap to check for infection; EEG to record brain electrical activity and identify seizure patterns; MRI and CT scans to visualize brain structure and detect abnormalities like tumors or bleeding; PET and SPECT scans to show brain activity and blood flow during seizures; and subtraction ictal SPECT coregistered with MRI (SISCOM) for more detailed results.
Treatments: Antiseizure medications; Implanted vagus nerve stimulation; Deep brain stimulation
Tests: Neurological exam; Blood tests; Spinal tap (lumbar puncture); Electroencephalogram (EEG); MRI; CT scan; Positron emission tomography (PET); Single-photon emission computerized tomography (SPECT); Subtraction ictal SPECT coregistered with MRI (SISCOM)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a blood test measuring immunoglobulin levels, specifically IgA levels, which can show complete or partial deficiency.  The test may be ordered due to frequent illnesses or as part of a broader diagnostic workup.
Treatments: Antibiotic treatment (as needed for bacterial infections); Antibiotic prophylaxis (for long-term illnesses like chronic bronchitis)
Tests: Immunoglobulin blood test

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a physical and psychological evaluation; a mental health professional assesses life, thoughts, feelings, and behaviors; evaluation for linked mental health conditions such as depression or personality disorders.  There is no specific test.
Treatments: Psychotherapy (CBT, Dialectical behavior therapy, Mindfulness-based therapies); Family therapy; Group therapy; Inpatient psychiatric care; Mental health day-treatment programs;  Medication for co-occurring mental health conditions (e.g., depression, anxiety).
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: Antidepressants; Other medications to treat linked mental health conditions (specific medications not listed).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves differentiating typical developmental stages from diagnosable separation anxiety disorder; a pediatrician may refer to a mental health professional specializing in childhood anxiety; a structured interview (psychological evaluation) assessing thoughts, feelings, and behaviors is conducted with the child and parent(s), often separately and together.
Treatments: Psychotherapy (including Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and exposure therapy); medication (in combination with CBT if needed).
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Doctors order several tests to pinpoint the underlying infection.  Tests include blood tests (checking for infection, blood clotting problems, abnormal liver or kidney function, low oxygen levels, and electrolyte imbalances); and other lab tests on urine, wound fluid, and respiratory tract samples to identify the infection source.  Imaging tests like X-ray, ultrasound, CT scan, and MRI may be used if the infection site isn't readily apparent.
Treatments: Close monitoring and treatment in a hospital intensive care unit; Medications; Intravenous fluids; Vasopressors; Supportive care (oxygen, breathing machines, dialysis); Surgery (to remove infection sources)
Tests: Blood tests; Urinalysis; Wound fluid analysis; Respiratory tract sample analysis; X-ray; Ultrasound; Computerized tomography (CT); Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
Medications_Drugs: Antibiotics (broad-spectrum initially, then targeted based on blood test results); Intravenous fluids; Vasopressors; Insulin (for blood sugar control); Painkillers

Diagnosis: Septic arthritis is diagnosed through joint fluid analysis (assessing color, consistency, volume, and makeup of joint fluid to identify the infecting organism); blood tests (detecting signs of infection in the blood); and imaging tests (X-rays and other imaging to assess joint damage or prosthetic joint loosening; specialized scans may be used for prosthetic joint infections).
Treatments: Joint drainage (needle aspiration, arthroscopy, open surgery); Antibiotic treatment (intravenous initially, then potentially oral); Removal of replacement joint (with temporary spacer and later replacement); Joint cleaning and tissue removal (if joint removal isn't feasible).
Tests: Joint fluid analysis; Blood tests; X-rays; Other imaging tests; Specialized scan (for prosthetic joint infections >1 year post-surgery)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is made by ruling out other conditions;  The doctor will assess symptoms, medical history, and medications; Physical examination is conducted; Tests may be used to measure drug levels, check for infection, and assess body functions affected by serotonin syndrome.
Treatments: Stopping the causative medication (for minor symptoms); Hospitalization (for concerning symptoms or severe cases); Muscle relaxants; Benzodiazepines (diazepam, lorazepam); Serotonin antagonists (cyproheptadine); Oxygen and intravenous (IV) fluids; Medications to control heart rate and blood pressure (esmolol, nitroprusside, phenylephrine, epinephrine); Breathing tube and machine; Medication to paralyze muscles (for high fever).
Tests: Blood and urine tests; Chest X-ray; Computerized Tomography (CT) scan; Spinal tap (lumbar puncture)
Medications_Drugs: diazepam; lorazepam; cyproheptadine; esmolol; nitroprusside; phenylephrine; epinephrine

Diagnosis: Various tests can help detect the SARS virus, including blood, stool, nose, and throat tests.  However, no known spread of the virus has occurred since 2004.
Treatments: Supportive care, such as intravenous fluids and supplemental oxygen as needed.
Tests: Blood test; Stool test; Nose and throat tests

Diagnosis: Brain imaging (MRI, CT) is used to rule out underlying causes;  A spinal tap (lumbar puncture) may be performed if the headache is sudden, recent, and brain imaging is normal to check for bleeding or infection.  Diagnosis is based on symptom presentation and exclusion of other causes.
Treatments: Preventive medications;  Pain relievers (implied, as the text mentions some headaches resolve before medication can work)
Tests: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Computerized tomography (CT); Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA); Computerized tomography (CT) angiography; Cerebral angiogram; Spinal tap (lumbar puncture)
Medications_Drugs: propranolol (Inderal, Innopran XL); metoprolol (Lopressor, Toprol-XL); verapamil hydrochloride (Calan SR); indomethacin; triptans (class of medication, specific drug not named)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a review of sexual history and current symptoms.  Physical or pelvic exams may be performed to identify signs of infection such as rash, warts, or discharge.
Treatments: Antibiotics; Antiviral drugs
Tests: Blood tests; Urine samples; Fluid samples from genital sores; Pap test; HPV test

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a multidisciplinary team including medical specialists and child abuse experts, who examine the child, review medical history, and order various tests to detect injuries and rule out other conditions with similar symptoms.  The evaluation aims to differentiate accidental from intentional injuries.
Treatments: Breathing support; Surgery to stop brain bleeding; Medications to reduce brain swelling and prevent seizures
Tests: Skeletal survey (X-rays of arms, hands, legs, feet, spine, ribs, and skull); Eye exam; Blood tests; MRI scan; CT scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a history of allergic reactions shortly after shellfish exposure and confirmed through allergy testing, which may include a skin prick test or a blood test measuring IgE antibodies.  Medically supervised food challenges may be used if the diagnosis remains unclear after initial testing.
Treatments: Avoidance of shellfish; Emergency injection of epinephrine (for severe reactions)
Tests: Skin prick test; Blood test (measuring IgE antibodies); Medically supervised food challenge

Diagnosis: Physical exam; Stool sample analysis for Shigella germs or toxins.  Many conditions can cause similar symptoms, so testing is crucial to confirm diagnosis.
Treatments: Fluid and salt replacement (oral rehydration solutions like Pedialyte; intravenous hydration in severe cases);  Bismuth subsalicylate (Pepto-Bismol, Kaopectate) for mild cases (not recommended for children, pregnant/breastfeeding individuals, or those with aspirin allergy); Antibiotics for severe infections, infants, older adults, immunocompromised individuals, or high risk of spread.
Tests: Stool sample analysis
Medications_Drugs: Bismuth subsalicylate; Antibiotics (specific antibiotic not specified)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily based on medical history and physical examination;  X-ray or other imaging studies may be used to rule out other causes of pain, such as stress fractures.
Treatments: Rest; Ice application (15-20 minutes, 3-4 times daily); Low-impact exercise (swimming, bicycling, water running); Over-the-counter pain relievers; Gradual return to usual activities.
Tests: X-ray

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on the history of unilateral pain, characteristic rash, and blisters;  A tissue sample or culture of blisters may be sent to a lab for confirmation.
Treatments: Early treatment with antiviral drugs; Pain management with topical capsaicin patch; Anticonvulsants; Tricyclic antidepressants; Numbing agents (lidocaine cream, gel, spray, or patch); Corticosteroids and local anesthetics injection; Cool baths or compresses
Tests: Tissue sample; Culture of blisters

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves assessing nutrient levels via blood or stool tests; imaging procedures such as barium X-ray, CT scan, MRI, CT enterography, and MRI enterography may be used to visualize blockages or intestinal changes.
Treatments: Nutritional therapy (special diet, nutritional supplements, parenteral nutrition, enteral nutrition); Medications (to control stomach acid, reduce diarrhea, improve intestinal absorption); Surgery (procedures to slow nutrient passage, intestinal lengthening, autologous gastrointestinal reconstruction, small bowel transplantation)
Tests: Blood test; Stool test; Barium X-ray; CT scan; MRI; CT enterography; MRI enterography

Diagnosis: Physical exam; review of symptoms and medical history; electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) to assess heart rate and rhythm; Holter monitor for 24-72 hour monitoring; event recorder for up to 30 days of monitoring or until symptoms occur; implantable loop recorder for long-term monitoring of infrequent symptoms; electrophysiologic (EP) testing (rarely used for screening, but may be used to assess sinus node function and other electrical properties of the heart).

Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; Event recorder; Implantable loop recorder; Electrophysiologic (EP) testing

Diagnosis: A blood test checks for the sickle cell form of hemoglobin; newborn screening is routine in the US;  additional tests may be suggested to check for complications; genetic counseling may be recommended if the sickle cell gene is present.  Stroke risk assessment may be done via ultrasound.  Prenatal diagnosis is possible via amniotic fluid sampling.

Tests: Blood test for sickle hemoglobin; Ultrasound to assess stroke risk; Amniotic fluid sampling for prenatal diagnosis

Diagnosis: Provider questioning about headaches and physical exam; imaging tests such as CT scan and MRI may be performed to determine the cause.  The cause of headaches can be difficult to determine.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is challenging due to variable symptoms mimicking other conditions and medication side effects.  Diagnosis involves ruling out other conditions and using blood tests, eye tests, imaging, and biopsy to identify characteristic features of Sjogren's syndrome, such as presence of specific antibodies and inflammatory cell clusters.
Treatments: Over-the-counter eyedrops and increased water intake; Prescription medications; Punctal occlusion;  Self-care measures to manage dry eyes and mouth; Treatment of specific complications (arthritis, yeast infections); Treatment of systemic symptoms

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing medical history and symptoms; physical exam assessing vision, hearing, balance, coordination, sensation, strength, and reflexes to determine brain areas affected; imaging tests (CT scan, MRI, PET scan) to visualize tumor size, location, and effects on cerebrospinal fluid; biopsy for tissue sample analysis; blood tests for hormone levels and other relevant markers.
Treatments: Surgery (including endoscopic surgery and use of intraoperative MRI); Radiation therapy (stereotactic radiosurgery, fractionated radiation therapy, proton therapy); Chemotherapy; Watchful waiting
Tests: CT scan; MRI; PET scan; Biopsy; Blood tests; Hearing tests; Vision tests

Diagnosis: Evaluation based on symptoms and sleep history (potentially with input from a bed partner); referral to a sleep disorder center for overnight or home sleep testing; polysomnography may be recommended, especially if central sleep apnea is suspected;  further testing may be unnecessary if results are typical;  referral to ENT specialist to rule out airway blockage (for obstructive sleep apnea); referral to cardiologist or neurologist may be necessary (for central sleep apnea).
Treatments: Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP); Auto-CPAP; Bilevel positive airway pressure (BPAP); Oral appliances;  Lifestyle changes (weight loss, smoking cessation, sleep position changes, allergy treatment); Surgery (uvulopalatopharyngoplasty, radiofrequency ablation, maxillomandibular advancement, implants, hypoglossal nerve stimulation, tracheostomy, tonsillectomy/adenoidectomy, bariatric surgery); Treatment of associated medical problems (for central sleep apnea).
Tests: Nocturnal polysomnography; Home sleep tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves consultation with sleep specialists, review of patient concerns and bed partner input (if applicable), physical examination, and completion of a sleep log detailing daily activities and sleep patterns.  Further evaluation may involve various diagnostic tests.
Treatments: Healthy lifestyle choices (weight loss if needed, good sleep habits, regular physical activity, reduced alcohol/caffeine near bedtime, avoidance of recreational drugs); Treatment of underlying medical and mental health conditions; Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I); Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy; Bilevel positive airway pressure (BPAP) therapy; Oral appliances; Surgeries (nose, jaw, upper airway soft tissue surgery; upper airway nerve stimulation therapy);
Tests: Actigraphy; Sleep study (polysomnography); Home sleep apnea test; Multiple sleep latency test (MSLT); Maintenance of wakefulness test (MWT); Upper airway nerve stimulation therapy evaluation; Overnight oximetry test

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is typically based on a description of the events provided by the patient or bed partner; a physical exam may be performed to rule out other conditions;  a family history of sleep problems may be considered;  a video recording of an episode can be helpful; polysomnography (sleep study) may be recommended in some cases.
Treatments: Treatment usually isn't necessary for infrequent episodes;  Addressing underlying conditions (e.g., obstructive sleep apnea); Addressing stress (cognitive behavioral therapy; hypnosis; relaxation therapy); Anticipatory awakening;  Safety measures to prevent injury during episodes.
Tests: Polysomnography (sleep study); Physical exam

Diagnosis: Review of medical history and symptoms; Physical exam to rule out other conditions (seizures, other sleep disorders, panic attacks); Discussion of sleepwalking episodes with patient and sleep partner, possibly including questionnaires; Polysomnography (sleep study) in some cases.
Treatments: Treating underlying conditions; Adjusting medication; Anticipatory awakenings;  Benzodiazepines; Certain antidepressants; Self-hypnosis; Therapy or counseling; Promoting safety measures to prevent injury.
Tests: Polysomnography (sleep study); Physical exam

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is difficult and often requires multiple tests to locate the cancer or rule it out.  Diagnostic methods include blood tests (to assess overall health and detect potential bleeding), imaging tests (MRI, CT, PET scans to show location and size), and biopsy (tissue sample examination to confirm cancer).  Further tests such as upper endoscopy, capsule endoscopy, and enteroscopy allow examination of the small intestine and collection of tissue samples.  Surgery may be necessary to visualize and sample hard-to-reach cancers.
Treatments: Surgery; Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy
Tests: Blood tests; Complete blood count; Kidney function tests; Liver function tests; MRI; CT scan; PET scan; Biopsy; Upper endoscopy; Capsule endoscopy; Enteroscopy; Laparotomy; Laparoscopy

Diagnosis: A pelvic exam is performed; during the exam, the patient may be asked to perform a Valsalva maneuver (deep breath and bear down) to make the prolapse more visible; the exam may be repeated while the patient is standing if necessary.
Treatments: Observation; Kegel exercises; Pessary (silicone, plastic, or rubber device); Surgery (vaginal or abdominal, with or without robotic assistance, may involve synthetic mesh).
Tests: Pelvic exam

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves tests to check for bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine, poor fat absorption, or other contributing problems.  Common tests include breath testing (measuring hydrogen or methane after glucose consumption) and, less commonly now due to potential inaccuracies, small intestine aspirate and fluid culture. Blood tests for vitamin deficiencies and stool evaluations for fat malabsorption may also be used; imaging tests (X-rays, CT scans, MRI) may be used to identify structural abnormalities.
Treatments: Addressing underlying problems (e.g., surgically repairing intestinal loops, strictures, or fistulas); Antibiotic therapy; Nutritional support (nutritional supplements, including vitamin B-12 injections; oral vitamins, calcium, and iron supplements; lactose-free diet)
Tests: Breath testing; Small intestine aspirate and fluid culture; Blood testing; Stool evaluation; X-rays; Computerized tomography (CT) scanning; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)

Diagnosis: Physical exam; review of medical and family history;  stress test with imaging (echocardiogram or nuclear imaging); coronary angiogram; CT coronary angiogram; positron emission tomography (PET) scan.
Treatments: Medications; heart-healthy lifestyle changes;  potentially L-arginine supplementation (with healthcare provider consultation).
Tests: Stress test with imaging (echocardiogram or nuclear imaging); Coronary angiogram; CT coronary angiogram; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan
Medications_Drugs: Nitroglycerin; Beta blockers; Calcium channel blockers; Statins; ACE inhibitors; ARBs; Ranolazine; Aspirin; Metformin

Diagnosis: Most healthcare providers would likely not recognize smallpox in its early stages; Definitive diagnosis requires laboratory testing of tissue samples by specialized labs, such as those at the CDC.
Treatments: New antiviral medications may be used; Research continues to study other antiviral drugs.
Tests: Tissue sample testing

Diagnosis: Review of signs and symptoms; medical history review; physical examination; partner interview regarding snoring severity (for adult patients); assessment of child's snoring severity (for child patients).
Treatments: Lifestyle changes (weight loss; avoiding alcohol before bed; treating nasal congestion; avoiding sleep deprivation; avoiding sleeping on back); continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP); oral appliances; upper airway surgery (uvulopalatopharyngoplasty [UPPP]; maxillomandibular advancement [MMA]; radiofrequency tissue ablation; hypoglossal nerve stimulation); nasal strips; external nasal dilator; prescription steroid spray.
Tests: X-ray; computerized tomography (CT) scan; magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); polysomnography (sleep study).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a physical exam to rule out medical causes; discussion of symptoms, frequency, and situations; review of anxiety-provoking situations; self-report questionnaires; and application of DSM-5 criteria, including persistent intense fear/anxiety in social situations due to fear of negative judgment, avoidance of social situations or enduring them with intense fear, excessive anxiety disproportionate to the situation, anxiety interfering with daily life, and anxiety not explained by medical conditions, medication, or substance abuse.
Treatments: Psychotherapy (including Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and exposure-based CBT); Medications
Tests: Physical exam; Self-report questionnaires
Medications_Drugs: Paroxetine (Paxil); Sertraline (Zoloft); Venlafaxine (Effexor XR); Other antidepressants; Benzodiazepines; Beta blockers

Diagnosis: Physical examination of the mouth and neck using a mirror or tiny camera to identify lumps, sores, or other signs of cancer; palpation of the neck for swollen lymph nodes; biopsy (tissue sample removal and microscopic examination) to confirm the presence of cancerous cells and potentially identify HPV.
Treatments: Surgery (to remove cancer and surrounding tissue, potentially including neck dissection or sentinel node biopsy); Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy; Reconstructive surgery; Physical therapy and rehabilitation services
Tests: Examining mouth and neck; Biopsy; X-ray; CT; MRI; Positron emission tomography (PET); Sentinel node biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves imaging tests (X-rays; CT scans; MRI scans; PET scans) to visualize the tumor's size and location, followed by a biopsy (core needle biopsy; surgical biopsy) to obtain tissue samples for pathological examination to confirm the presence and type of cancer cells.  Seeking care at a center experienced in treating soft tissue sarcoma is recommended to ensure optimal biopsy technique.
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy (before, during, or after surgery); Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy
Tests: X-rays; CT scans; MRI scans; PET scans; Core needle biopsy; Surgical biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves identifying a rectal ulcer through tests such as sigmoidoscopy (with possible tissue biopsy), ultrasound, defecation proctography, or magnetic resonance defecography to differentiate from other conditions and assess for prolapse or muscle dysfunction.

Tests: Sigmoidoscopy; Ultrasound; Defecation proctography; Magnetic resonance defecography

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam and recommended tests to rule out other medical conditions; a psychological evaluation by a mental health professional assessing symptoms, fears, stressful situations, relationship problems, avoidance behaviors, and family history;  application of DSM-5 criteria including one or more distressing somatic symptoms impacting daily life, excessive thoughts about symptom seriousness or high anxiety about health, and persistent symptoms (typically over six months) despite variations.
Treatments: Psychotherapy (specifically CBT);  medication (antidepressants); family therapy
Tests: Physical exam

Diagnosis: Physical examination of the throat, ears, and nose using a light; Palpation of the neck to check for swollen lymph nodes; Auscultation of breathing with a stethoscope; Throat swab for rapid antigen test to detect streptococcal bacteria; Throat culture for more sensitive detection of strep throat.
Treatments: Rest; Increased fluid intake; Avoiding caffeine and alcohol; Warm liquids (broth, tea, warm water with honey); Cold treats (ice pops); Salt water gargles; Humidifier use; Sucking on hard candy or cough drops; Avoiding irritants;  Antibiotics for bacterial infections.

Diagnosis: Prenatal diagnosis is primarily achieved through ultrasound examination, ideally during the second trimester (18-22 weeks), which can visualize an open spine or brain abnormalities.  Elevated maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) in blood tests may suggest spina bifida, but requires confirmation with ultrasound due to potential false positives. Amniocentesis may be used to confirm the diagnosis and rule out genetic disorders if spina bifida is suspected on ultrasound.
Treatments: Surgery before birth (fetal surgery); Cesarean birth; Surgery after birth (to close the opening in the back within 72 hours);  Shunt placement for hydrocephalus; Endoscopic third ventriculostomy (for hydrocephalus); Walking and mobility aids; Bowel and bladder management (including medications, suppositories, enemas, catheters, surgery); Physical therapy
Tests: Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) test; Ultrasound; Amniocentesis

Diagnosis: Spinal AVMs can be difficult to diagnose due to similar symptoms to other spinal conditions (spinal dural arteriovenous fistula, spinal stenosis, multiple sclerosis, spinal cord tumor). Diagnosis involves ruling out other conditions using advanced imaging and techniques.  MRI can show the AVM as a mass of irregularly connected blood vessels; angiography is often needed to visualize the AVM's location and vascular characteristics.
Treatments: Pain-relieving medicines; Surgery (conventional surgery; endovascular embolization; radiosurgery)
Tests: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Angiography

Diagnosis: Neurological exam assessing sensory function and movement; evaluation for neck pain, altered consciousness, weakness, or neurological injury; X-rays to reveal vertebral damage, tumors, fractures, or spinal changes; CT scan for clearer imaging of bone, disk, and other changes; MRI to visualize the spinal cord for herniated disks, blood clots, or compressing masses.  A more comprehensive neurological exam may be done days later to assess injury level and completeness.
Treatments: Immobilization of the spine (neck collar, rigid carrying board); Maintaining breathing; Preventing shock; Avoiding complications (e.g., stool/urine retention, respiratory/cardiovascular issues, deep vein blood clots); Surgery (to remove bone fragments, foreign objects, herniated disks, or fractured vertebrae); Traction to stabilize/align the spine; Experimental treatments (e.g., hypothermia); Rehabilitation (physical therapy, occupational therapy, etc.);  Prostheses; Medications to manage side effects (pain, muscle spasticity, bladder/bowel control, sexual functioning); Functional electrical stimulation; Locomotor training.
Tests: X-rays; CT scan; MRI; Neurological exam

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with assessment of symptoms and a neurological exam to evaluate nerve function.  Imaging tests and biopsy are crucial for confirmation.  MRI is the preferred imaging modality.
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy
Tests: Physical exam; Neurological exam; MRI scan; Spinal CT scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Provider interview regarding headache history and recent procedures (especially spinal tap or spinal anesthesia); Physical exam; MRI may be used to rule out other causes.

Diagnosis: Symptoms and medical history review; Physical exam; Imaging tests to assess spinal canal narrowing.

Diagnosis: SCAD is usually diagnosed in an emergency setting, involving a review of personal and family medical history and cardiac tests.  Diagnosis is similar to that of a heart attack. Coronary angiogram is a key diagnostic test, often with additional tests such as optical coherence tomography (OCT) and intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) to confirm SCAD and guide treatment.
Treatments: Medicines; Coronary angioplasty and stent placement; Coronary artery bypass surgery; Cardiac rehabilitation
Tests: Blood tests; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Coronary angiogram; Optical coherence tomography (OCT); Intravascular ultrasound (IVUS)
Medications_Drugs: Aspirin; Blood pressure medicines; Nitrates; Calcium channel blockers

Diagnosis: Physical examination of the ankle, foot, and lower leg, checking for tenderness and range of motion;  Imaging scans (X-ray, MRI, CT scan, ultrasound) may be used to rule out fractures and assess ligament damage.
Treatments: R.I.C.E. (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation); Over-the-counter pain relievers; Crutches; Elastic bandage; Sports tape; Ankle support brace; Cast; Walking boot; Physical therapy; Surgery (in rare cases)
Tests: X-ray; MRI; CT scan; Ultrasound; Physical examination

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing swelling, tenderness, pain location and intensity to determine extent and nature of damage; X-rays to rule out fractures or bone injuries; MRI to diagnose injury extent.
Treatments: R.I.C.E. (rest, ice, compression, elevation); Over-the-counter pain medications;  Gentle use of injured area after two days; Physical therapy; Immobilization with brace or splint; Surgery (for some injuries, such as torn ligaments).
Tests: X-ray; MRI

Disease_Name_English: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin
Disease_Name_Spanish: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin
Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam to assess skin lesions; a biopsy is performed to confirm the presence of squamous cell carcinoma and determine its characteristics.
Treatments: Curettage and electrodessication; Laser therapy; Cryosurgery; Photodynamic therapy; Simple excision; Wide excision; Mohs surgery; Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy
Tests: Physical exam; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Metastatic colon cancer is diagnosed through a combination of imaging tests (CT, MRI, PET), lab tests (CEA blood test, genetic testing), and tissue biopsies (often obtained via colonoscopy or surgery).  Biopsy results determine cancer type and presence of gene changes influencing treatment.
Treatments: Chemotherapy (including FOLFOX, FOLFIRI, and others); Hepatic artery infusion pump (HAIP) chemotherapy; Cytoreductive surgery and hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC); Pressurized intraperitoneal aerosol chemotherapy (PIPAC); Surgery (to remove primary tumor or metastatic sites); Targeted therapy
Tests: Biopsy; CT scan; MRI scan; PET scan; Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) blood test; Genetic testing
Medications_Drugs: 5-fluorouracil (5-FU); leucovorin; oxaliplatin; irinotecan; Bevacizumab (Avastin); Cetuximab (Erbitux); panitumumab (Vectibx)

Diagnosis: Physical exam of skin sores or reddened areas and review of symptoms; Collection and testing of blood, urine, skin, infected material, or nasal secretions for staph bacteria;  Echocardiogram (if indicated).
Treatments: Antibiotics; Wound drainage (incision and cleaning); Device removal (may require surgery).
Tests: Blood test; Urine test; Skin culture; Culture of infected material; Nasal secretion culture; Echocardiogram; Other imaging tests (depending on symptoms and exam results).
Medications_Drugs: Cefazolin; Nafcillin; Oxacillin; Vancomycin; Daptomycin; Linezolid.

Diagnosis: Stevens-Johnson syndrome is often diagnosed based on medical history (including recent medications) and physical examination.  A skin biopsy is performed to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other causes; a skin, tissue, or fluid culture may be done to rule out infection; imaging (e.g., chest X-ray) may be used depending on symptoms; and blood tests may help confirm infection or other possible causes.
Treatments: Stopping nonessential medications; Fluid replacement and nutrition (possibly via nasogastric tube); Wound care (cool compresses, dead skin removal, petroleum jelly or medicated dressings); Eye care (ophthalmologist consultation); Pain medication; Topical steroids; Antibiotics (if infection present); Corticosteroids; Intravenous immune globulin; Cyclosporine (Neoral, Sandimmune); Etanercept (Enbrel)
Tests: Skin biopsy; Culture; Chest X-ray (if indicated); Blood tests
Medications_Drugs: Cyclosporine (Neoral, Sandimmune); Etanercept (Enbrel); Topical steroids; Antibiotics; Corticosteroids; Intravenous immune globulin; Pain medication

Diagnosis: Stomach cancer diagnosis involves visual examination of the stomach via upper endoscopy to identify suspicious areas; biopsy of suspicious tissue for histological examination to confirm cancer; staging tests to determine the extent of cancer spread (blood tests, including circulating tumor DNA tests; ultrasound; CT scans; PET scans; surgery may be necessary for definitive staging).
Treatments: Endoscopic procedure; Surgery; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapies
Tests: Upper endoscopy; Biopsy; Blood tests; Circulating tumor DNA test; Stomach ultrasound; CT scan; PET scan

Diagnosis: Visual examination of the stomach's interior using a scope (endoscopy); Tissue sample (biopsy) analysis in a laboratory.
Treatments: Periodic monitoring; Removal of large polyps during endoscopy; Removal of adenomas during endoscopy; Removal of polyps associated with familial adenomatous polyposis; Treatment of H. pylori infection with antibiotics (combination therapy).
Tests: Endoscopy; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Physical exam to observe signs and symptoms; Rapid antigen test (detects strep bacteria antigens); Throat culture (cultures throat secretions for bacteria); Molecular (PCR) test (detects strep bacteria using a throat swab).
Treatments: Oral antibiotics; Over-the-counter pain relievers; Rest; Hydration; Soothing foods; Warm salt water gargling (for older children and adults); Honey (for those over 12 months); Humidifier use; Saline nasal spray; Avoidance of irritants.
Tests: Rapid antigen test; Throat culture; Molecular (polymerase chain reaction, or PCR) test

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a health history review and physical exam; imaging tests are often necessary.  Stress fractures may not be immediately visible on X-ray.
Treatments: Resting the affected limb; Wearing a walking boot or brace; Using crutches; Surgery (in some cases, particularly for poor blood supply, elite athletes, or laborers); Acetaminophen (for pain relief); Avoiding NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen sodium).
Tests: X-rays; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); CT scan; Bone scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing a voiding diary, medical history, and physical exam (including pelvic or rectal exam); urine sample analysis for infection or blood; brief neurological exam of pelvic nerves; and a urinary stress test (observing urine loss during coughing or bearing down).
Treatments: Pelvic floor muscle exercises (Kegel exercises with biofeedback);  Dietary and fluid adjustments;  Lifestyle changes (weight loss, smoking cessation, cough treatment); Bladder training; Vaginal pessary; Vaginal inserts; Midurethral sling procedure; Bladder neck sling procedure; Bulking agents injection; Retropubic colposuspension; Inflatable artificial sphincter
Tests: Voiding diary; Urinalysis;  Pelvic exam; Rectal exam; Neurological exam; Urinary stress test; Measurement of residual urine (ultrasound or catheterization); Bladder pressure measurement (urodynamics); Pressure-flow study; Cystoscopy

Diagnosis: Stretch marks usually don't require diagnosis; a healthcare provider may examine the skin and review medical history; further tests may be offered if increased cortisol levels are suspected.
Treatments: Retinoid cream (e.g., tretinoin); Light and laser therapies; Microneedling.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a combination of physical exam (including neurological exam), patient history (including symptom onset and duration), and imaging studies to identify the type of stroke (ischemic or hemorrhagic) and location of the affected brain area.  FAST acronym (Facial weakness, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call 911) helps identify potential stroke symptoms.  Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs), or temporary symptoms, are also considered significant and warrant immediate evaluation.
Treatments: Emergency IV medicine (recombinant tissue plasminogen activator [TPA], alteplase (Activase), tenecteplase (TNKase)); Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Speech therapy
Tests: Physical exam; Neurological exam; Blood tests; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Computerized tomography angiography (CTA); Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA); Magnetic resonance venography (MRV); Carotid ultrasound; Cerebral angiogram; Echocardiogram

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is made by a speech-language pathologist who observes and interacts with the individual (child or adult) in various situations; assessment includes questioning about health history (onset, frequency, impact on life), evaluating communication skills (comprehension and speech sound production), and possibly asking the child to read aloud.  Clues are sought to differentiate between typical childhood development and a persistent condition.
Treatments: Speech therapy; Electronic devices (delayed auditory feedback, speech-copying devices); Cognitive behavioral therapy; Parent-child interaction techniques.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Usually diagnosed by visual examination of the eyelid; a light and magnifying device may be used.
Treatments: Warm compresses; antibiotic eyedrops; topical antibiotic cream; oral antibiotics; surgical incision and drainage
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: Antibiotic eyedrops; topical antibiotic cream; oral antibiotics

Diagnosis: Subarachnoid hemorrhage is diagnosed through imaging tests (CT scan, MRI, cerebral angiography) to detect bleeding in the brain.  A lumbar puncture may be performed if initial imaging is negative to analyze cerebrospinal fluid for the presence of blood.
Treatments: Surgery (clipping of aneurysm); Endovascular embolization (coil placement); Other endovascular treatments (stent-assisted or balloon-assisted coiling, flow diversion devices); Treatment for complications (e.g., vasospasm management with medication and blood pressure elevation, hydrocephalus treatment with drains); Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Speech therapy
Tests: CT scan; CT angiogram; MRI; MR angiogram; Cerebral angiography; Lumbar puncture

Disease_Name_English: Subconjunctival hemorrhage (broken blood vessel in eye)
Disease_Name_Spanish: Subconjunctival hemorrhage (broken blood vessel in eye)
Diagnosis: Visual examination of the eye by a doctor or ophthalmologist;  For recurrent cases, additional assessment may include questions about general health and symptoms, a complete eye examination, blood pressure measurement, and a routine blood test to rule out bleeding disorders.
Treatments: Artificial tears (eye drops);  The condition typically resolves on its own within 1-2 weeks without specific treatment.
Tests: Blood pressure test; Routine blood test

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of sudden cardiac arrest is primarily made based on clinical presentation (sudden collapse and loss of consciousness) and is confirmed through post-resuscitation testing to determine the underlying cause.  Tests are performed to assess heart function, identify underlying heart conditions, and check for electrolyte imbalances.
Treatments: CPR; Defibrillation; Medications to treat irregular heartbeats; Heart procedure or surgery to place heart devices or treat a blockage; Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD); Coronary angioplasty; Coronary artery bypass surgery; Radiofrequency catheter ablation; Corrective heart surgery
Tests: Blood tests; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Echocardiogram; Ejection fraction; Chest X-ray; Nuclear scan; Cardiac catheterization
Medications_Drugs: Anti-arrhythmic drugs; Beta blockers; Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors; Calcium channel blockers

Diagnosis: Information not found
Treatments: Safe sleep practices (back sleeping; firm mattress; no loose bedding; no toys or stuffed animals in crib; pacifier use; avoiding overheating; room sharing but not bed sharing); breastfeeding for at least six months to a year; vaccinations.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Physical exam; in-depth questioning about mental and physical health; assessments for mental health conditions; assessments for physical health conditions; assessment of alcohol and drug misuse; review of current medications.  Suicidal thoughts are often linked to underlying mental health issues or physical health problems.
Treatments: Psychotherapy; Antidepressants; antipsychotic medications; anti-anxiety medications; addiction treatment (detoxification, addiction treatment programs, self-help groups); family support and education; hospitalization (in emergency situations)
Tests: Blood tests; other unspecified tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily clinical, based on examination of the skin.  Further testing may be done to determine the specific type of sun allergy and rule out other conditions.
Treatments: Avoiding sun exposure; Application of corticosteroid creams; Prescription corticosteroid pills (e.g., prednisone); Hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil); Phototherapy
Tests: Ultraviolet (UV) light testing (phototesting); Photopatch testing; Blood tests; Skin biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis generally involves a physical exam and questions about symptoms, medications, UV exposure, and sunburn history.  Phototesting may be suggested if sunburn occurs after short sun exposure to assess photosensitivity.
Treatments: Home remedies (pain relievers, cooling the skin, moisturizer, extra water intake, blister care, gentle peeling skin care, anti-itch medication, medicated cream application, sunburned eye care, sun protection); Prescription corticosteroid cream; Hospital admission (for severe cases)
Tests: Phototesting
Medications_Drugs: Ibuprofen; Acetaminophen; Diphenhydramine; 1% hydrocortisone cream; Benzocaine (use with caution and under provider supervision, especially in children under 2, due to risk of methemoglobinemia)

Diagnosis: Physical examination including listening to the heart and checking blood pressure; review of symptoms, health habits, and medical history.
Treatments: Carotid sinus massage; Vagal maneuvers; Medications; Cardioversion; Catheter ablation; Pacemaker
Tests: Blood tests; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; Event recorder; Implantable loop recorder; Echocardiogram; Exercise stress test; Tilt table test; Electrophysiological (EP) study

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam of the breasts, chest wall, underarms, and neck; imaging tests such as diagnostic mammogram, focused ultrasound, and MRI may be used; if imaging is inconclusive, a biopsy may be necessary.
Treatments: Pain medications (e.g., nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medicine); Prescription hormone therapy (e.g., birth control pills); Fine-needle aspiration for cyst drainage; Surgery to remove breast tissue (for cysts or fibroadenomas); Antibiotics (for infections); Incision and drainage (for abscesses); Liposuction (for lipomas); Surgery to remove intraductal papilloma; Surgery; Chemotherapy; Hormone therapy (e.g., anti-estrogen medicines); Radiation therapy; Clinical trials
Tests: Diagnostic mammogram; Focused or directed ultrasound; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Fine-needle aspiration; Core needle biopsy; Stereotactic biopsy; Surgical biopsy (lumpectomy or wide local excision)
Medications_Drugs: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medicine; Birth control pills; Antibiotics

Diagnosis: A medical history review and physical examination are conducted; blood and urine tests may be performed to rule out underlying medical conditions such as infection, diabetes, or hyperthyroidism.
Treatments: Antiperspirants; Deodorants; Stronger prescription antiperspirants; Laser hair removal; Botulinum toxin A injections; Regular washing with antibacterial soap; Choosing breathable fabrics; Stress reduction techniques (yoga, meditation); Cooling measures; Dietary changes (avoiding spicy or strong-smelling foods); Hair removal; Weight loss; Charcoal-based products; Herbal extracts; Essential oils; Astringents
Tests: Blood test; Urine test

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is typically made during an office visit based on symptoms, patient history, and a physical examination using an otoscope to visualize the ear canal and eardrum.  Further testing may involve sending a fluid sample for bacterial or fungal culture if the infection is advanced or persistent;  referral to an ENT specialist may occur if the eardrum is damaged or the infection doesn't improve with treatment.
Treatments: Cleaning the ear canal with suction or curettage; Ear drops containing acidic solution, steroid, antibiotic, and/or antifungal medication; Oral antibiotics (if ear drops are ineffective or the infection is severe); Pain relievers.
Tests: Otoscopic examination; Fluid culture for bacteria or fungus
Medications_Drugs: Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Acetaminophen;  Antibiotic ear drops; Antifungal ear drops; Steroid ear drops.

Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis based on skin examination and patient history of swimming or wading in affected waters;  no specific tests are available.  The rash may resemble other skin conditions.
Treatments: Self-limiting; prescription-strength lotions or creams; corticosteroid cream; anti-itch lotion (e.g., calamine); oral nonprescription antihistamine (e.g., Benadryl); oral antihistamine with loratadine (e.g., Alavert, Claritin);  applying a clean, damp washcloth to affected areas; soaking in a bath with Epsom salts, baking soda, or oatmeal-based bath product (e.g., Aveeno); baking soda and water paste applied to affected skin.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a detailed history and physical examination.  Further evaluation involves imaging tests and joint aspiration to identify the underlying cause of the swollen knee, such as injury, infection, or arthritis.
Treatments: Physical therapy; Knee brace; Arthrocentesis (with possible corticosteroid injection); Arthroscopy; Knee replacement; Rest; Ice and elevation; Compression; Pain relievers
Tests: X-ray; Ultrasound; MRI; Joint aspiration (arthrocentesis)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing medical history (including symptom onset and other symptoms), physical exam (checking lymph node location, size, tenderness, and warmth), blood tests (complete blood count and other tests to identify the cause), imaging studies (chest X-ray, CT scan, or mammogram to identify infection or tumors), and lymph node biopsy (examining a lymph node sample).
Treatments: Treatment depends on the cause; For viral infections, no specific treatment is needed, the swelling resolves as the infection clears; Antibiotics for bacterial infections; HIV treatment for HIV-related swollen lymph nodes; Treatment targeting the underlying cause for immune disorders (e.g., lupus, rheumatoid arthritis); Cancer treatment (surgery, radiation, or chemotherapy) as needed.
Tests: Complete blood count (CBC); Chest X-ray; CT scan; Mammogram; Lymph node biopsy

Diagnosis: Synovial sarcoma is diagnosed through imaging tests (MRI, X-rays, CT scans) to locate and assess the size and spread of the tumor; a biopsy is performed to obtain a tissue sample for laboratory analysis to confirm the presence of cancer and characterize the cancer cells.  Initial misdiagnosis as arthritis or bursitis can occur.
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Cell therapy (afamitresgene autoleucel); Clinical trials
Tests: MRI scans; X-rays; CT scans; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves testing blood samples for syphilis antibodies; examining fluid from a sore under a microscope; and, if nervous system involvement is suspected, testing cerebrospinal fluid via lumbar puncture.  At-home tests may provide an initial indication, but confirmation requires professional evaluation.
Treatments: Penicillin; Alternative antibiotics (for penicillin allergy); Penicillin desensitization
Tests: Blood test; Microscopic examination of fluid from a sore; Cerebrospinal fluid analysis (lumbar puncture)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a complete physical exam and review of medical history.  Suspected syringomyelia is confirmed primarily through MRI of the spine and spinal cord, which visualizes the syrinx (fluid-filled cavity).  A CT scan may be used to rule out other spinal conditions.
Treatments: Monitoring; Surgery (treating Chiari malformation; draining the syrinx with a shunt; removing obstructions like tumors or bone spurs; correcting spinal irregularities like tethered cord); Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Pain management
Tests: MRI of the spine and spinal cord; CT scan

Diagnosis: Review of symptoms and medical history; evaluation of affected organs; tests to detect high levels of mast cells or substances they release.
Treatments: Controlling symptoms; treating the disease; regular monitoring; identifying and avoiding triggers; medications to treat symptoms, reduce stomach acid, counteract mast cell substance effects, and inhibit the KIT gene; chemotherapy (for aggressive systemic mastocytosis, systemic mastocytosis with another blood disorder, or mast cell leukemia); stem cell transplant (for mast cell leukemia).
Tests: Blood tests; urine tests; bone marrow biopsy; skin biopsy; X-ray; ultrasound; bone scan; CT scan; biopsy of affected organs (e.g., liver); genetic testing

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam, review of medical history, and assessment of symptoms;  Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) is a key diagnostic test.
Treatments: Vagal maneuvers; Medications; Cardioversion; Catheter ablation; Pacemaker implantation; Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) implantation; Maze procedure; Open-heart surgery
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; Event monitor; Echocardiogram; Chest X-ray; MRI scan of the heart; CT scan of the heart; Coronary angiogram; Electrophysiological (EP) study; Stress tests; Tilt table test

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing signs and symptoms, conducting a physical exam, and obtaining medical history.  Further diagnostic tests are used to rule out other conditions and confirm the diagnosis, and to monitor progress during treatment.  These tests may reveal multiple areas of stenosis in blood vessels.
Treatments: Medications; Surgery
Tests: Blood tests; Angiography; Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA); Computerized tomography (CT) angiography; Ultrasonography (Doppler ultrasound); Positron emission tomography (PET)
Medications_Drugs: Prednisone; Methotrexate; Azathioprine; Leflunomide; Mycophenolate mofetil; Etanercept; Infliximab; Tocilizumab; Calcium supplement; Vitamin D

Diagnosis: Intestinal tapeworm infection is diagnosed via stool sample analysis for tapeworm segments or eggs; larval cyst infection is diagnosed using imaging tests (CT scans, MRI scans, ultrasound) to locate cysts, and blood tests to detect antibodies to the cysts.
Treatments: Anti-parasitic drugs; Corticosteroids; Surgery; Fluid removal from cyst with injection of treatment; Shunt placement; Anti-epileptic medicine
Tests: Stool sample analysis; CT scan; MRI scan; Ultrasound; Blood test
Medications_Drugs: Praziquantel (Biltricide); Albendazole; Nitazoxanide (Alinia); Corticosteroids; Anti-epileptic medicine

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing symptoms and family history; physical examination by a healthcare provider, possibly including a neurologist and ophthalmologist; and diagnostic testing.  A cherry-red spot in the eyes may be observed.
Treatments: Supportive care focusing on symptom management and complication prevention; medication to reduce symptoms and prevent complications; respiratory care (chest physiotherapy, exercise, medications to reduce saliva production, positioning techniques); nutritional and hydration support (potentially including feeding tubes); physical therapy; occupational therapy; speech and language therapy.
Tests: Diagnostic blood test (measuring hexosaminidase A enzyme levels); Genetic testing (HEXA gene analysis); Eye exam

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam to rule out underlying physical health problems; in-depth questioning about the teenager's health; a psychological evaluation including discussions about thoughts, feelings, and behaviors, potentially using questionnaires to pinpoint a diagnosis and identify related complications.  The evaluation also helps distinguish teen depression from other disorders with overlapping symptoms.
Treatments: Psychotherapy (cognitive behavioral therapy or interpersonal therapy); Medication; Hospitalization; Outpatient treatment programs; Day treatment programs
Tests: Physical exam; Complete blood count; Thyroid function tests

Diagnosis: Regular dental exams checking for signs of bruxism; Evaluation of changes in teeth and mouth; Assessment of jaw muscle and joint tenderness, stiffness, or pain; Examination for dental changes (flattened, broken, or missing teeth);  X-rays of teeth and jaw;  Assessment of sleep habits, daily routines, and medical history to determine potential causes.
Treatments: Splints and mouth guards; Dental correction (reshaping teeth or using crowns); Stress or anxiety management; Behavior change (mouth and jaw position training); Jaw relaxation exercises; Biofeedback;  Muscle relaxants; Botox injections; Antidepressants; Anti-anxiety medications; Treatment of underlying medical conditions (sleep apnea, Parkinson's disease, etc.);  Changes in medication dosage or alternative medication if bruxism is a side effect.
Tests: X-rays of teeth and jaw; Sleep study
Medications_Drugs: Muscle relaxants; Botox; Antidepressants; Anti-anxiety medications

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing symptoms and medical history;  neurological exam assessing behavior, motor abilities, and mental function; EEG to record brain electrical activity and identify seizure patterns; CT scan and MRI to visualize brain structures and identify potential causes (tumors, bleeding, cysts); PET and SPECT scans to pinpoint seizure origin and map brain activity during seizures.  High-density EEG can help localize the seizure focus.
Treatments: Medications; Ketogenic diet; Low glycemic index diet; Atkins diet; Surgery; Vagus nerve stimulation; Responsive neurostimulation; Deep brain stimulation
Tests: Neurological exam; Blood tests; Electroencephalogram (EEG); Computerized tomography (CT); MRI; Positron emission tomography (PET); Single-photon emission computerized tomography (SPECT); High-density EEG

Diagnosis: TEN is diagnosed when individuals with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) develop severe disease affecting more than 30% of the body.
Treatments: Stop implicated medication; Hospitalization (possibly burn center or ICU); Fluid replacement and nutrition; Wound care (cleansing, special dressings); Breathing support (tests, procedures, intubation, ventilation); Pain control (oral and systemic analgesics); Eye care (artificial tears, corticosteroid eye drops).
Tests: Information not found
Medications_Drugs: cyclosporine (Neoral, Sandimmune); etanercept (Enbrel); intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG); lidocaine

Diagnosis: Usually diagnosed through physical examination; X-rays or other imaging tests may be used to rule out other conditions.
Treatments: Self-care (rest, ice, pain relievers); Steroid shot; Platelet-rich plasma injection; Physical therapy; Dry needling; Surgery
Tests: X-ray
Medications_Drugs: Aspirin; Naproxen sodium (Aleve); Ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB); Acetaminophen (Tylenol)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis often involves a medical history and physical exam, including palpation of the affected joint and assessment of joint movement.  Imaging tests may be used to rule out other conditions or identify contributing factors.
Treatments: Self-care (rest, ice, pain relievers); Physical therapy; Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medicines; Pain-relieving creams or gels; Steroid injections; Dry needling; Shockwave therapy; Ultrasound therapy; Barbotage; Tenotomy; Platelet-rich plasma therapy; Surgery
Tests: X-rays; Ultrasound; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
Medications_Drugs: Aspirin; Naproxen sodium (Aleve); Ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB); Acetaminophen (Tylenol)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is often made through medical history and physical examination, which may include pressing on the affected area and assessing range of motion in the elbow, wrist, and fingers.  Imaging tests (X-rays, sonograms) may be used if other conditions are suspected.
Treatments: Physical therapy; Corticosteroid injections; Platelet-rich plasma injections; Botulinum toxin A injections; Prolotherapy (sugar water or salt water injections); Dry needling; Needle fenestration; Ultrasonic tenotomy (TENEX procedure); Extracorporeal shock wave therapy; Surgery (open or arthroscopic); Forearm strap or brace
Tests: X-rays; Sonograms; Electromyography (EMG); MRI

Diagnosis: Physical and neurological exams; assessment of pain description (location, intensity, characteristics); ruling out serious causes through patient history and potentially imaging tests.
Treatments: Pain relievers; combination medicines; triptans; preventive medicines; acupuncture; massage; deep breathing; biofeedback; behavior therapies; rest; ice packs; hot showers; managing stress; improving posture.
Tests: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Computerized tomography (CT)
Medications_Drugs: Aspirin; ibuprofen; naproxen sodium; acetaminophen; caffeine; triptans; amitriptyline; nortriptyline; protriptyline; venlafaxine; mirtazapine; gabapentin; topiramate; tizanidine.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis may begin with self-detection of lumps or swelling, followed by a healthcare provider exam.  Further testing is required to confirm diagnosis.  Diagnostic tests help determine if lumps are cancerous and whether cancer has spread. Lumps inside the testicle are more likely to be cancerous.  Elevated tumor markers (beta-human chorionic gonadotropin, alpha-fetoprotein, and lactate dehydrogenase) in blood tests may indicate cancer.  Surgical removal of a testicle with subsequent lab testing is definitive.
Treatments: Surgery to remove the testicle (radical inguinal orchiectomy); Surgery to remove nearby lymph nodes; Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy; Immunotherapy
Tests: Testicular ultrasound; Blood tests (tumor marker tests including beta-human chorionic gonadotropin, alpha-fetoprotein, and lactate dehydrogenase); Surgery to remove a testicle; Computerized tomography (CT) scan

Diagnosis: Physical exam of the scrotum, testicles, abdomen, and groin; assessment of cremasteric reflex (absence suggests torsion); urine test to rule out infection; scrotal ultrasound to assess blood flow (though not always definitive); surgery may be necessary for definitive diagnosis if other methods are inconclusive or symptoms suggest torsion.
Treatments: Surgery (manual detorsion may be attempted initially, but surgery is always needed to prevent recurrence);  Surgical fixation of one or both testicles to the scrotum.
Tests: Urine test; Scrotal ultrasound

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on physical exam; medical and vaccination history; and signs and symptoms of muscle spasms, muscle rigidity, and pain.  Laboratory tests are used only if another condition is suspected.
