Treatments: Emergency and long-term supportive care; wound care (cleaning, removal of dead tissue); antitoxin therapy (passive immunization); sedatives; tetanus vaccination; antibiotics; medications to regulate involuntary muscle activity; breathing assistance; feeding tube; management of care environment to reduce stimuli.
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Often diagnosed soon after birth based on symptoms such as cyanotic (blue or gray) skin and a heart murmur; confirmed through diagnostic tests.
Treatments: Temporary surgery (palliative surgery with shunt placement); Open-heart surgery (complete repair); Medications (to maintain blood flow to the lungs while awaiting surgery)
Tests: Pulse oximetry; Echocardiogram; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Chest X-ray; Cardiac catheterization

Diagnosis: Blood tests reveal the number of red blood cells and irregular changes in their size, shape, or color; Blood tests can also detect gene changes in DNA; Prenatal testing (chorionic villus sampling and amniocentesis) can diagnose thalassemia before birth.  Symptoms in moderate to severe cases typically appear within the first two years of life.
Treatments: Frequent blood transfusions; Chelation therapy;  Luspatercept (Reblozyl); Hydroxyurea (Hydrea, Droxia); Stem cell transplant (bone marrow transplant)
Tests: Complete blood count (CBC); Genetic testing; Hemoglobin test; Chorionic villus sampling; Amniocentesis
Medications_Drugs: Deferasirox (Exjade, Jadenu); Deferiprone (Ferriprox); Deferoxamine (Desferal); Luspatercept (Reblozyl); Hydroxyurea (Hydrea, Droxia); Folic acid (supplemental)

Diagnosis: Thoracic aortic aneurysms often present without symptoms and are frequently discovered incidentally during imaging tests performed for other reasons.  Family history may be considered as aneurysms can be familial.
Treatments: Regular health checkups (watchful waiting); Medications; Open-chest surgery; Aortic root surgery (valve-sparing or valve and root replacement); Endovascular aortic aneurysm repair (EVAR); Emergency surgery
Tests: Echocardiogram (standard and transesophageal); CT scan; Heart MRI; Chest X-ray
Medications_Drugs: losartan (Cozaar); valsartan (Diovan); olmesartan (Benicar); atorvastatin (Lipitor); lovastatin (Altoprev); simvastatin (Zocor, FloLipid); Beta blockers; Angiotensin 2 receptor blockers (ARBs); Statins

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is typically an exclusionary process starting with a thorough physical examination and patient history.  This is followed by imaging studies, vascular studies, provocative tests (assessing symptoms with specific movements), and consultation with a multidisciplinary team to rule out other, more common conditions.  The diagnosis considers the type of TOS (neurogenic, vascular, or non-specific), based on whether nerves, vessels, or both are compressed.
Treatments: Physical therapy; Sports medicine; Medications; Injections; Surgery; Lifestyle modification; Ergonomic movement; Posture correction
Tests: Ultrasound; X-ray; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; CT angiography; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Arteriography; Venography
Medications_Drugs: Muscle relaxant (specific drug name not mentioned)

Diagnosis: Throat cancer diagnosis involves using a lighted scope (endoscopy) or a laryngoscope to visually examine the throat and voice box for abnormalities; a biopsy is performed if abnormalities are found, and the sample is tested for cancer cells and HPV; imaging tests (CT, MRI, PET) may be used to determine the extent of the cancer.
Treatments: Radiation therapy (external beam radiation; brachytherapy); Surgery (endoscopic surgery for small cancers; laryngectomy; pharyngectomy; neck dissection); Chemotherapy; Targeted drug therapy (e.g., cetuximab); Immunotherapy; Palliative care
Tests: Endoscopy; Laryngoscopy; Biopsy; CT scan; MRI; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; X-ray

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves assessing symptoms, health history, medications, and conducting a physical exam to look for signs of bleeding and organomegaly (enlarged spleen, liver, lymph nodes).  A complete blood count (CBC) determines platelet count; a blood smear examines platelet morphology and other blood cells under a microscope. Further tests may be necessary to identify the underlying cause.
Treatments: Treating the underlying cause (e.g., stopping causative medications, treating infection or cancer); Corticosteroids; Platelet transfusions; Plasma exchange; Splenectomy
Tests: Complete blood count (CBC); Blood smear;  Other tests and procedures to determine cause (not specified)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily made through a complete blood count (CBC) revealing an elevated platelet count.  Further testing may include blood tests to check iron levels, markers of inflammation, and for undiagnosed cancer; genetic testing may also be performed. A bone marrow biopsy may be necessary.  The diagnosis also considers the presence or absence of symptoms and risk factors.
Treatments: Observation (for asymptomatic essential thrombocythemia or reactive thrombocytosis where the underlying cause is treatable); Low-dose aspirin (for essential thrombocythemia patients at risk of blood clots); Platelet-lowering medications; Plateletpheresis (in emergencies).  Treatment for reactive thrombocytosis focuses on addressing the underlying cause (e.g., infection, inflammation, blood loss).
Tests: Complete blood count (CBC); Blood tests for iron levels; Blood tests for markers of inflammation; Blood tests for undiagnosed cancer; Gene mutation testing; Bone marrow biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Aspirin; Hydroxyurea (Droxia, Hydrea); Anagrelide (Agrylin); Interferon alfa (Intron A)

Diagnosis: Physical examination to assess for affected veins near the skin's surface and patient discomfort; Ultrasound to confirm diagnosis and differentiate between superficial and deep vein thrombosis; Blood test (D-dimer) to check for elevated levels of clot-dissolving substance, though not conclusive on its own and useful for ruling out DVT and identifying risk of recurrent thrombophlebitis.
Treatments: Heat application; Leg elevation; Over-the-counter NSAIDs; Compression stockings; Blood-thinning medications (low molecular weight heparin, fondaparinux, apixaban, warfarin, rivaroxaban); Clot-dissolving medications (alteplase); Vena cava filter placement; Varicose vein stripping.
Tests: Ultrasound; Blood test (D-dimer)
Medications_Drugs: ibuprofen; naproxen sodium; low molecular weight heparin; fondaparinux (Arixtra); apixaban (Eliquis); warfarin (Jantoven); rivaroxaban (Xarelto); alteplase (Activase); aspirin (mentioned as a potential interaction).

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing symptoms, swelling, lumps; palpation of the thumb joint with pressure against the wrist bone to detect grinding, pain, or gritty feeling; X-rays to reveal bone spurs, worn-down cartilage, and loss of joint space.
Treatments: Non-surgical therapies (early stages); Splint; Corticosteroid injections; Surgery (joint fusion, osteotomy, trapeziectomy, joint replacement); Physical therapy; Adaptive equipment; Cold/heat application.
Tests: X-ray; Bone scan; CT scan; MRI
Medications_Drugs: Capsaicin; Diclofenac; Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Celecoxib; Tramadol

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of thunderclap headaches involves determining the underlying cause through a combination of patient history (including symptom onset, severity, and associated factors), neurological examination, and imaging studies.  The urgency often necessitates emergency room evaluation.
Treatments: Treatment targets the underlying cause of the headache, if identified.
Tests: CT scan of the head; Spinal tap (lumbar puncture); MRI; Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA)

Diagnosis: Physical exam to palpate for nodules; Thyroid function blood tests (TSH and thyroid hormone levels); Ultrasound imaging to visualize nodules and lymph nodes; Fine-needle aspiration biopsy for cytological examination;  Radioactive iodine scan to detect remaining cancer cells after surgery;  Molecular marker testing to identify gene changes;  CT and MRI scans may be used to determine if cancer has spread.  Diagnosis considers nodule characteristics (e.g., microcalcifications, irregular borders), size, and results from biopsy and other imaging tests.
Treatments: Surgery (lobectomy or total thyroidectomy with lymph node removal); Levothyroxine (Synthroid) replacement therapy;  Treatment may not be needed for very small papillary thyroid cancers.
Tests: Physical exam; Thyroid function blood tests; Ultrasound imaging; Fine-needle aspiration biopsy; Radioactive iodine scan; CT scan; MRI scan; Molecular marker testing; Lymph node mapping

Diagnosis: A healthcare professional checks for lumps or nodules in the neck; Thyroid function tests measure TSH and thyroid hormone levels to assess thyroid function; Ultrasound imaging visualizes the shape and structure of nodules; Fine-needle aspiration biopsy obtains a cell sample for cancer detection; Thyroid scan using radioactive iodine differentiates hot (rarely cancerous) and cold (potentially cancerous) nodules.
Treatments: Watchful waiting; Surgery; Radioactive iodine; Anti-thyroid medications; Alcohol ablation
Tests: Thyroid function tests; Ultrasound; Fine-needle aspiration biopsy; Thyroid scan

Diagnosis: Visual examination by a doctor; Skin scraping viewed under a microscope if there is doubt.
Treatments: Over-the-counter antifungal lotions, creams, ointments, or shampoos; Prescription-strength topical or oral medications;  Prevention medication in persistent cases.
Tests: Skin scraping microscopy
Medications_Drugs: Ketoconazole; Ciclopirox; Fluconazole; Itraconazole; Selenium sulfide; Clotrimazole; Miconazole; Terbinafine; Zinc pyrithione.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is typically based on the patient's reported symptoms.  Further testing aims to identify underlying causes, which may not always be found.  The description of the tinnitus sound (e.g., clicking, pulsing, ringing) helps identify potential causes.
Treatments: Earwax removal; Treatment of underlying blood vessel conditions (medication, surgery, or other treatments); Hearing aids; Medication changes; White noise machines; Masking devices; Tinnitus retraining therapy (TRT); Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) or other counseling; Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS); Deep brain stimulation (potential future treatment)
Tests: Hearing (audiological) exam; Movement assessment (examining changes in tinnitus with movement); CT scan; MRI scan; Blood tests (to check for anemia, thyroid problems, heart disease, or vitamin deficiencies)

Diagnosis: Clinical evaluation including listening to and feeling the jaw, observing jaw range of motion, palpating for pain; Dental X-rays; CT scan; MRI; TMJ arthroscopy.
Treatments: Self-care (heat/ice application, avoiding clenching/chewing, proper jaw posture); Oral splints/mouth guards; Physical therapy (exercises, ultrasound, TENS, moist heat, stretching); Counseling; Arthrocentesis; Corticosteroid injections; Botulinum toxin type A injections; TMJ arthroscopy; Modified condylotomy; Open-joint surgery
Tests: Dental X-rays; CT scan; MRI; TMJ arthroscopy
Medications_Drugs: Prescription-strength ibuprofen; Nortriptyline; Muscle relaxants (specific names not provided)

Diagnosis: Physical exam; Gait analysis; Electromyography (EMG); Neurological exam (if cerebral palsy or autism suspected); Testing for developmental delays (if cerebral palsy or autism suspected).
Treatments: Observation (for habitual toe walking); Physical therapy; Leg braces or splints; Serial casting; OnabotulinumtoxinA injections; Surgery (to lengthen muscles or tendons).
Tests: Gait analysis; Electromyography (EMG); Neurological exam; Testing for developmental delays.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis typically begins with a physical exam of the mouth, throat, and neck to check for lumps and swollen lymph nodes.  Further evaluation may involve endoscopy (using a thin tube with a camera), and biopsy (tissue sample removal for microscopic examination). Imaging tests such as X-rays (potentially with barium swallow), CT, MRI, PET scans, and ultrasound may be used to assess cancer size, location, and spread to lymph nodes.
Treatments: Surgery (glossectomy, neck dissection, sentinel node biopsy, reconstructive surgery, transoral surgery, transoral robotic surgery); Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy; Clinical trials; Physical therapy and rehabilitation
Tests: Physical exam of mouth, throat, and neck; Endoscopy; Biopsy; X-ray; CT scan; MRI scan; PET scan; Ultrasound; Barium swallow

Diagnosis: Physical exam; For infants, a screening tool may be used to score aspects of tongue appearance and movement.
Treatments: Wait-and-see approach; Consultation with lactation consultant; Speech therapy; Frenotomy; Frenuloplasty
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a thorough review of symptoms and medical history, often followed by several tests to determine the cause and likelihood of recurrence.  Diagnostic methods include neurological exam assessing behavior, movement, and cognitive function; and various imaging and electrophysiological tests to identify the seizure focus and underlying causes.
Treatments: Anti-seizure medications; Surgery; Vagus nerve stimulation; Responsive neurostimulation; Deep brain stimulation
Tests: Neurological exam; Blood tests; Lumbar puncture; Electroencephalogram (EEG); CT scan; MRI; Positron emission tomography (PET); Single-photon emission computerized tomography (SPECT); Subtraction ictal SPECT coregistered to magnetic resonance imaging (SISCOM)

Diagnosis: Examination of the mouth and throat using a mirror or tiny camera; palpation of the neck to check for swollen lymph nodes; biopsy to obtain a tissue sample for laboratory analysis, including testing for HPV.
Treatments: Surgery (transoral surgery or neck incision); Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy; Reconstructive surgery; Rehabilitation (speech therapy, swallowing therapy, dietetics, physical therapy, occupational therapy)
Tests: Throat and neck examination; Biopsy; Computerized tomography (CT); Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Positron emission tomography (PET)

Diagnosis: Physical exam including throat, ear, and nose examination; checking for scarlatina rash; palpation of neck for swollen lymph nodes; listening to breathing; checking for spleen enlargement; throat swab for streptococcal bacteria; complete blood cell count (CBC) may be used if strep test is negative.  Diagnosis is based on clinical presentation and test results.
Treatments: At-home care (rest, fluids, comforting foods/drinks, saltwater gargle, humidified air, lozenges, avoidance of irritants, pain/fever management with ibuprofen or acetaminophen); Antibiotics (e.g., penicillin or alternative if penicillin allergy); Tonsillectomy (surgical removal of tonsils)
Tests: Throat swab; Complete blood cell count (CBC)

Diagnosis: Clinical examination of the tooth and surrounding area; Palpation of teeth to assess sensitivity; X-ray to identify the abscess and assess spread of infection; Computerized tomography (CT) scan if infection has spread to the neck.
Treatments: Incision and drainage of the abscess; Root canal; Tooth extraction; Antibiotics
Tests: X-ray; Computerized tomography (CT) scan
Medications_Drugs: acetaminophen; ibuprofen; Antibiotics (if infection has spread beyond the abscess or patient has a weakened immune system)

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing knee movement and gait; X-rays to rule out other bone problems; MRI for detailed imaging of soft and hard tissues; Arthroscopy for direct visualization and potential surgical intervention.
Treatments: Rest; Ice; Over-the-counter pain relievers; Physical therapy; Surgery (repair or trimming of meniscus; possible knee replacement or meniscus transplant).
Tests: X-rays; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Arthroscopy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on the history of signs and symptoms, meeting criteria including: presence of both motor and vocal tics (not necessarily simultaneously); tics occurring several times daily, nearly every day or intermittently, for over a year; onset before age 18; tics not caused by medications, substances, or other medical conditions; and tics changing over time in location, frequency, type, complexity, or severity.  Other conditions mimicking Tourette's are considered and ruled out.
Treatments: Medication; Botulinum toxin injections; Behavior therapy (Cognitive Behavioral Interventions for Tics, habit-reversal training); Psychotherapy; Deep brain stimulation (DBS - early research stages)
Tests: Blood tests; MRI
Medications_Drugs: Fluphenazine; Haloperidol; Risperidone; Pimozide; Tetrabenazine; Methylphenidate; Dextroamphetamine; Clonidine; Guanfacine; Fluoxetine; Topiramate

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam, review of medical history (including medication use and potential toxin exposure), and blood tests to check liver enzyme levels. Imaging tests (ultrasound, CT, MRI, magnetic elastography, transient elastography) may be used. A liver biopsy can confirm the diagnosis and rule out other causes.
Treatments: Stopping exposure to the toxin; Supportive care (IV fluids, anti-nausea medication); Acetylcysteine (for acetaminophen overdose); Treatments to remove or reduce the toxic effect of other medications; Liver transplant
Tests: Physical exam; Blood tests; Ultrasound; Computerized tomography (CT); Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Magnetic elastography; Transient elastography; Liver biopsy

Diagnosis: There is no single test for toxic shock syndrome. Diagnosis involves assessing symptoms and conducting tests to identify the underlying infection (often staph or strep).  Blood and urine samples are tested for infection; vaginal, cervical, and throat swabs are cultured.  Additional tests like CT scans, lumbar punctures, or chest X-rays may be used to assess organ involvement.
Treatments: Hospitalization; Antibiotics; Removal of tampons, diaphragms, and other foreign bodies; Wound drainage; Removal of damaged tissue; Treatment for low blood pressure; Intravenous fluids; Dialysis (if kidney failure occurs); Surgery (to remove dead tissue or drain infection)
Tests: Blood test; Urine test; Vaginal swab culture; Cervical swab culture; Throat swab culture; CT scan; Lumbar puncture; Chest X-ray

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on blood tests detecting antibodies indicative of active or past infection;  additional tests depend on symptoms, patient health, and other factors; eye symptoms require ophthalmological exam; brain and nervous system symptoms may necessitate brain imaging (MRI or CT scan), cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) test, and rarely, brain tissue biopsy;  prenatal diagnosis relies on maternal blood tests, fetal ultrasound, and amniotic fluid testing; newborn diagnosis uses blood tests, often followed by brain imaging (ultrasound or CT), CSF tests, eye tests, hearing tests, and electroencephalogram (EEG).
Treatments: Medication; Anti-inflammatory steroids (glucocorticosteroids for eye disease)
Tests: Blood tests; MRI; CT scan; Cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) test; Brain tissue biopsy; Ophthalmological exam with special lenses or cameras; Ultrasound; Amniocentesis; EEG
Medications_Drugs: Pyrimethamine (Daraprim); Leucovorin calcium; Sulfadiazine; Clindamycin (Cleocin); Azithromycin (Zithromax)

Diagnosis: Physical examination; Laboratory testing of bacterial samples from the eyes (though not always available).
Treatments: Antibiotics; Surgery (bilamellar tarsal rotation, corneal transplantation, epilation); Community-wide antibiotic treatment (if >10% of children affected).
Tests: Bacterial culture of eye sample

Diagnosis: Ruling out more serious conditions such as stroke, seizure, or head injury; neurological exam checking reflexes, muscle tone, muscle strength, sensory function, gait, posture, coordination, and balance; assessment of thinking, judgment, and memory; brain imaging tests to detect abnormalities in brain electrical activity and blood flow.
Treatments: No specific treatment is needed; the condition typically resolves without intervention.
Tests: Computerized tomography (CT); Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Electroencephalogram (EEG)

Diagnosis: Prompt evaluation of symptoms; Physical exam including neurological exam (assessing vision, eye movements, speech, language, strength, reflexes, and sensory system); Assessment of carotid artery via stethoscope (listening for bruits); Ophthalmoscopic exam (checking for emboli in retinal blood vessels); Risk factor assessment (high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes, high homocysteine).
Treatments: Medications; Carotid endarterectomy; Carotid angioplasty and stent placement.
Tests: Physical exam; Neurological exam; Carotid ultrasonography; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Computerized tomography angiography (CTA) scan; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA); Echocardiography (TTE and TEE); Arteriography.
Medications_Drugs: Aspirin; Clopidogrel (Plavix); Cilostazol; Ticagrelor (Brilinta); Dipyridamole; Heparin; Warfarin (Jantoven); Apixaban (Eliquis); Rivaroxaban (Xarelto); Edoxaban (Savaysa); Dabigatran (Pradaxa).

Diagnosis: Often diagnosed prenatally via routine ultrasound; diagnosed shortly after birth by auscultation (detecting a heart murmur); confirmed by echocardiogram (showing transposition of great arteries), chest X-ray (assessing heart and lung condition), and electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) (assessing heart rhythm).
Treatments: Surgery (arterial switch operation; atrial septostomy; Rastelli operation; double switch procedure); Medications; Atrial switch operation
Tests: Echocardiogram (including fetal echocardiogram); Chest X-ray; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Pulse oximetry

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on patient history, clinical assessment of nerve function, and test results indicating spinal cord inflammation while ruling out other disorders.
Treatments: Intravenous steroids; Plasma exchange therapy; Antiviral medication; Pain medication; Physical therapy; Occupational therapy; Psychotherapy; Medications to treat muscle spasticity, urinary or bowel dysfunction, depression, or other complications; Medications to prevent recurrent attacks (corticosteroids and/or immunosuppressants)
Tests: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Lumbar puncture (spinal tap); Blood tests (including antibody tests for neuromyelitis optica and tests for infections)
Medications_Drugs: Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Naproxen sodium; Sertraline; Gabapentin; Pregabalin; Corticosteroids; Immunosuppressants

Diagnosis: Assessment of initial severity using the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), which evaluates eye, verbal, and motor responses; gathering information about the injury mechanism, loss of consciousness duration, and observed changes in alertness, speech, or coordination; imaging tests such as CT scans to visualize fractures, hemorrhages, hematomas, contusions, and swelling; MRI scans for more detailed brain imaging after stabilization.
Treatments: Rest; Over-the-counter pain relievers; Monitoring for worsening symptoms;  Emergency care focusing on oxygenation, blood pressure maintenance, and preventing further head/neck injury; Minimizing secondary damage from inflammation, bleeding, or reduced oxygen; Surgery to remove hematomas or repair skull fractures; Relative rest (limiting physical and cognitive activities that worsen symptoms); Gradual return to normal routines.
Tests: Glasgow Coma Scale; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Intracranial pressure monitor

Diagnosis: Diagnosis typically involves a medical and travel history, and a physical exam to check for dehydration.  If symptoms are severe or don't resolve, a stool sample may be tested for microorganisms.
Treatments: Hydration with safe liquids (e.g., bottled water, oral rehydration solution); Anti-motility agents (loperamide, diphenoxylate-containing drugs); Bismuth subsalicylate; Antibiotics
Tests: Stool sample

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves discussing symptoms and conducting a physical exam;  provider may inquire about consumption of raw or undercooked meat; blood tests may check for increased eosinophils or antibodies; muscle biopsy may be performed to examine muscle tissue for Trichinella larvae under a microscope.
Treatments: Trichinosis often resolves on its own; anti-parasitic medication for severe cases or early infection; pain relievers for muscle aches; steroid medication for allergic reactions.
Tests: Blood tests; Muscle biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Albendazole (Albenza); Mebendazole (Emverm); pain relievers; steroid medication

Diagnosis: Examination of genitals; Microscopic examination of vaginal or penile fluid sample; Genetic testing of fluid sample; Culture test of genital discharge or urine.  If the parasite is seen microscopically, no further tests are needed.  If not, further tests may be performed.
Treatments: Oral antibiotic medication; Single large dose of medication; Multiple lower doses of medication over seven days.  Treatment of all sexual partners is necessary.
Tests: Microscopic examination of vaginal or penile fluid; Genetic testing of fluid sample; Culture test of genital discharge or urine; Pelvic exam

Diagnosis: Physical exam; Referral to mental health professional; Examination of hair loss; Checking for medical causes of hair loss; Discussion about hair loss behaviors and emotions; Identification of co-occurring physical or mental health conditions.
Treatments: Habit reversal training; Decoupling; Acceptance and commitment therapy; Cognitive therapy; Therapies for co-occurring mental health conditions (depression, anxiety, substance use disorders).
Tests: Lab tests

Diagnosis: Prenatal diagnosis may occur via routine ultrasound; postnatal diagnosis involves physical examination (assessing cyanosis, respiratory distress, heart murmur);  Echocardiogram is crucial to visualize the absent tricuspid valve and abnormal blood flow.  Electrocardiogram assesses heart rhythm. Pulse oximetry measures blood oxygen levels; Chest X-ray evaluates heart and lung condition. Cardiac catheterization is rarely used for diagnosis, but may be performed pre-surgery.
Treatments: Surgery (shunting; Glenn procedure; Fontan procedure; pulmonary artery band placement; atrial septostomy); Medications; Supplemental oxygen
Tests: Echocardiogram; Electrocardiogram; Pulse oximetry; Chest X-ray; Cardiac catheterization

Diagnosis: Physical examination of the heart and lungs; review of medical history;  diagnostic tests to assess heart health; referral to a cardiologist for complex cases.  Some types of tricuspid valve disease may be difficult to diagnose.
Treatments: Regular health checkups; Medications; Surgery to fix or replace the valve; Balloon valvotomy; Tricuspid valve repair; Tricuspid valve replacement; Oxygen therapy (for lung condition-related cases); Antibiotics (for infection-related cases);  Catheter-based valve replacement (for failing biological tissue valve).
Tests: Chest x-ray; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Echocardiogram; Right-sided heart catheterization; Heart MRI

Diagnosis: Physical examination including auscultation for heart murmurs; Echocardiogram (TTE or TEE); Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Chest X-ray; Cardiac MRI; Cardiac catheterization (less common).
Treatments: Medications; Heart procedures; Surgery to repair or replace the heart valve (open-heart or minimally invasive); Valve-in-valve replacement (catheter procedure); Supplemental oxygen (for pulmonary hypotension)
Tests: Echocardiogram (TTE, TEE); Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Chest X-ray; Cardiac MRI; Cardiac catheterization
Medications_Drugs: Diuretics; Potassium-sparing diuretics (aldosterone antagonists); Other medications to treat heart failure; Medications to control irregular heartbeats

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily based on the patient's description of pain (sudden, electric shock-like, brief) and its location on the face, indicating trigeminal nerve involvement;  triggers such as eating, talking, or light touch are also considered. Neurological exam assesses pain location and affected nerve branches; reflex tests help differentiate from other conditions.  MRI may be used to identify underlying causes like MS or tumors.
Treatments: Medications; Botox injections; Microvascular decompression; Brain stereotactic radiosurgery (Gamma Knife); Rhizotomy (glycerol injection; balloon compression; radiofrequency thermal lesioning); Treatment for underlying conditions (e.g., multiple sclerosis).
Tests: Neurological exam; Reflex tests; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI);  Sometimes an MRI with dye injection to view blood vessels.
Medications_Drugs: Carbamazepine (Tegretol, Carbatrol); Oxcarbazepine (Trileptal, Oxtellar XR); Lamotrigine (Lamictal); Phenytoin (Dilantin, Phenytek, Cerebyx); Topiramate (Qudexy XR, Topamax); Pregabalin (Lyrica); Gabapentin (Neurontin, Gralise, Horizant); Baclofen (Gablofen, Fleqsuvy); OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox).

Diagnosis: A healthcare provider will ask the patient to open and close their hand, checking for pain, smoothness of motion, and locking.  Physical examination is the primary diagnostic method.
Treatments: Rest; Splint; Stretching exercises; Steroid injection; Needle procedure; Surgery
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Often undiagnosed; may be discovered incidentally during investigation of other issues; prenatal testing may reveal increased risk, followed by amniocentesis or chorionic villus sampling for confirmation; genetic testing (after birth or prenatally) confirms the presence of an extra X chromosome.
Treatments: Periodic screenings; Early intervention services (speech, occupational, physical, or developmental therapy); Educational assistance; Supportive environment and counseling; Assistance and support in daily functioning
Tests: Amniocentesis; Chorionic villus sampling; Genetic testing

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is usually made soon after birth;  signs include cyanosis (blue or gray appearance), breathing difficulties, and possibly fluid in the lungs detected by auscultation; echocardiogram is the main diagnostic test, showing a single large vessel from the heart and a hole between the lower heart chambers.
Treatments: Surgery to improve blood flow and oxygen levels;  medications before surgery to improve heart health; lifelong regular health checkups after surgery; balloon angioplasty (in some cases); catheter-based procedures to replace tubes or valves.
Tests: Pulse oximetry; Chest X-ray; Echocardiogram
Medications_Drugs: Water pills (diuretics); Positive inotropes; Antibiotics (to prevent infective endocarditis).

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam (listening to breathing, checking lymph nodes, and questioning symptoms);  TB tests are ordered if TB is suspected, likely exposure occurred, or health risks for active TB are present; tests may include skin tests (tuberculin injection, checking for swelling after 48-72 hours), blood tests (checking immune cell response to tuberculosis), chest X-rays (to detect lung irregularities), and sputum tests (to detect TB bacteria).
Treatments: Treatment for latent TB infection (often 3-4 months); Treatment for active TB disease (4, 6, or 9 months); Directly observed therapy (DOT); Self-administered medication with tracking forms.
Tests: Skin test; Blood test; Chest X-ray; Sputum test; Breath test; Procedure to remove sputum; Urine test; Cerebrospinal fluid test
Medications_Drugs: Isoniazid; Rifampin (Rimactane); Rifabutin (Mycobutin); Rifapentine (Priftin); Pyrazinamide; Ethambutol (Myambutol)

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing for growths (tumors); review of symptoms and family history; blood tests; genetic tests; seizure evaluation (EEG); brain, lung, kidney, and liver evaluation (MRI, CT scan, ultrasound); heart evaluation (echocardiogram, electrocardiogram); eye exam; dental exam (including X-rays); developmental/mental health evaluation.  Genetic testing confirms diagnosis.
Treatments: Anti-seizure medications; medications for heart rhythm problems, behavior problems, or other symptoms; everolimus (Afinitor, Zortress) for brain and kidney growths; sirolimus (Hyftor) topical ointment for skin growths; surgery to remove growths affecting organ function; dermabrasion; laser treatment; occupational, physical, or speech therapy; educational and vocational services; mental health services.
Tests: Electroencephalogram (EEG); MRI; CT scan; Ultrasound; Echocardiogram; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Eye exam; Dental exam (including X-rays)

Diagnosis: Suspicion based on signs and symptoms; chromosome analysis of blood sample (karyotype); sometimes buccal smear or skin sample; prenatal diagnosis may involve ultrasound, prenatal cell-free fetal DNA screening, chorionic villus sampling, or amniocentesis.
Treatments: Hormone therapy (growth hormone; estrogen therapy);  treatment for specific problems as needed; regular checkups;  transition planning from pediatric to adult care.
Tests: Blood sample chromosome analysis (karyotype); buccal smear; skin sample; Ultrasound; Prenatal cell-free fetal DNA screening; Chorionic villus sampling; Amniocentesis

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of type 1 diabetes involves assessing glycated hemoglobin (A1C) levels;  an A1C level of 6.5% or higher on two separate tests confirms diabetes.  Alternative tests include a random blood sugar test (≥200 mg/dL or 11.1 mmol/L) and a fasting blood sugar test (≥126 mg/dL or 7 mmol/L on two separate tests).  The presence of autoantibodies and ketones in urine further supports a diagnosis of type 1 over type 2 diabetes.
Treatments: Insulin therapy; Carbohydrate, fat, and protein counting; Blood sugar monitoring; Eating healthy foods; Regular exercise; Maintaining a healthy weight; Insulin pump; Insulin injections (using syringes or insulin pens).
Tests: Glycated hemoglobin (A1C) test; Random blood sugar test; Fasting blood sugar test; Autoantibody tests; Urinalysis for ketones; Blood tests for cholesterol, thyroid, liver, and kidney function.
Medications_Drugs: Humulin R; Novolin R; Afrezza; glulisine (Apidra); lispro (Humalog, Admelog, Lyumjev); aspart (Novolog, FiAsp); insulin NPH (Novolin N, Humulin N); glargine (Lantus, Toujeo Solostar, Basaglar); detemir (Levemir); degludec (Tresiba);  Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors; Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) (partial mention, details not provided).

Diagnosis: Type 1 diabetes in children is diagnosed using blood tests.  A random blood sugar level of 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) or higher, along with symptoms, is suggestive; an A1C level of 6.5% or higher on two separate tests confirms diabetes; a fasting blood sugar level of 126 mg/dL (7.0 mmol/L) or higher also suggests diabetes.  Additional antibody blood tests may help distinguish type 1 from type 2 diabetes.
Treatments: Insulin; Blood sugar monitoring; Healthy eating; Regular exercise
Tests: Random blood sugar test; Glycated hemoglobin (A1C) test; Fasting blood sugar test; Antibody blood tests
Medications_Drugs: lispro (Humalog, Admelog); aspart (NovoLog, Fiasp); glulisine (Apidra); human insulin (Humulin R, Novolin R); NPH insulin (Humulin N, Novolin N); glargine (Lantus, Toujeo, other); detemir (Levemir); degludec (Tresiba)

Diagnosis: Type 2 diabetes is most often diagnosed using the glycated hemoglobin (A1C) test; an A1C level of 6.5% or higher on two separate tests indicates diabetes.  Alternative diagnostic tests include a random blood sugar test (≥200 mg/dL or 11.1 mmol/L), a fasting blood sugar test (≥126 mg/dL or 7 mmol/L on two tests), and an oral glucose tolerance test (≥200 mg/dL or 11.1 mmol/L after two hours).  The American Diabetes Association recommends routine screening for adults 35 and older, as well as younger adults with risk factors.
Treatments: Healthy eating; Regular exercise; Weight loss (if needed); Diabetes medicine; Insulin therapy (if needed); Continuous glucose monitoring
Tests: A1C test; Random blood sugar test; Fasting blood sugar test; Oral glucose tolerance test
Medications_Drugs: Metformin (Fortamet, Glumetza); Glipizide (Glucotrol XL); Glimepiride (Amaryl); Glyburide (DiaBeta, Glynase); Repaglinide; Nateglinide; Pioglitazone (Actos); Rosiglitazone; Alogliptin (Nesina); Sitagliptin (Januvia); Saxagliptin; Linagliptin (Tradjenta); Dulaglutide (Trulicity); Exenatide (Byetta, Bydureon Bcise); Liraglutide (Saxenda, Victoza)

Diagnosis: Type 2 diabetes in children is diagnosed using blood tests.  A random blood sugar level of 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) or higher; a fasting blood sugar level of 126 mg/dL (7.0 mmol/L) or higher; an A1C level of 6.5% or higher; or a blood sugar level of 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) or higher two hours after an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) suggests diabetes.  Additional tests may be used to differentiate from type 1 diabetes.
Treatments: Healthy eating; Regular physical activity; Insulin; Metformin; Liraglutide; Weight-loss surgery (in some cases); Blood sugar monitoring
Tests: Random blood sugar test; Fasting blood sugar test; Glycated hemoglobin (A1C) test; Oral glucose tolerance test

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is suspected based on symptoms and travel history; confirmed by culturing *Salmonella enterica* serotype Typhi from blood, stool, urine, or bone marrow samples; antibody detection tests and typhoid DNA tests may also be used.
Treatments: Antibiotic therapy; Fluid intake (to prevent dehydration); Surgery (if intestinal damage occurs)
Tests: Body fluid or tissue culture (blood, stool, urine, bone marrow); Antibody detection test; Typhoid DNA test

Diagnosis: Definitive diagnosis of ulcerative colitis is made through endoscopic procedures (colonoscopy or flexible sigmoidoscopy) with tissue biopsy.  Other tests help rule out complications or other IBDs like Crohn's disease.  Blood tests may check for anemia and inflammation markers; stool studies can detect white blood cells or proteins indicative of the condition and rule out infections.
Treatments: Drug therapy; Surgery (proctocolectomy with ileoanal anastomosis [J-pouch])
Tests: Blood tests; Stool studies; Colonoscopy; Flexible sigmoidoscopy; X-ray; CT scan; CT enterography; MR enterography
Medications_Drugs: Sulfasalazine (Azulfidine); Mesalamine (Delzicol, Lialda, others); Balsalazide (Colazal); Olsalazine (Dipentum); Prednisone; Budesonide; Azathioprine (Azasan, Imuran); Mercaptopurine (Purinethol, Purixan); Cyclosporine (Gengraf, Neoral, Sandimmune); Infliximab (Remicade); Adalimumab (Humira); Golimumab (Simponi); Vedolizumab (Entyvio); Ustekinumab (Stelara); Mirikizumab (Omvoh); Risankizumab (Skyrizi); Tofacitinib (Xeljanz); Upadacitinib (Rinvoq); Filgotinib (Jyseleca); Ozanimod (Zeposia); Loperamide (Imodium A-D); Acetaminophen (Tylenol, others); Iron supplements

Diagnosis: Physical exam assessing wrist and hand movement, range of motion, and grip strength;  Imaging tests may be used to identify underlying causes.
Treatments: Pain relievers; Physical therapy; Immobilization (cast, brace, or splint); Surgery (including minimally invasive options)
Tests: X-ray; CT scan; MRI; Ultrasound
Medications_Drugs: ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB); acetaminophen (Tylenol); Stronger pain relievers (prescription)

Diagnosis: Diagnosed during a physical exam; sometimes abdominal ultrasound or CT scan used to screen for complications.
Treatments: Most umbilical hernias in babies close on their own;  surgical repair for painful hernias, those larger than 1-2 centimeters in diameter, large hernias that don't decrease in size over two years, those that don't disappear by age 5, or those that become trapped or block the intestine; surgery typically recommended for adults to avoid complications, especially if the hernia gets bigger or becomes painful.  Surgery involves returning herniated tissue to the abdominal cavity and stitching the abdominal wall opening closed; mesh may be used in adults.
Tests: Abdominal ultrasound; CT scan

Diagnosis: Physical examination to assess the location of the testicles;  If testicles are not in the scrotum by 6 months, further investigation may be needed to determine if they are absent or undescended;  Ultrasound and MRI may be used in some cases, particularly if the testicles are not palpable.
Treatments: Surgery (orchiopexy); Hormone treatment (human chorionic gonadotropin injections); Testicular prostheses; Inguinal hernia repair (if present)
Tests: Physical examination; Ultrasound; MRI

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a review of symptoms and physical examination; other cancers are ruled out; a biopsy is performed to confirm diagnosis by examining tumor tissue for cell type and aggressiveness.
Treatments: Surgery (limb-sparing operations or amputation); Radiation therapy (external beam radiation; intraoperative radiation therapy [IORT]); Chemotherapy; Targeted drug therapy; Immunotherapy
Tests: Physical exam; X-rays; CT scan; MRI; PET scan; Biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam, review of symptoms, and procedures to visualize the urinary tract (e.g., ureteroscopy, cystoscopy).  Urine tests (urinalysis, cytology) and imaging tests (intravenous pyelogram; CT urogram; MR urogram; PET scan) are used to assess the extent of cancer. Biopsy is performed to confirm the diagnosis and assess cellular characteristics.
Treatments: Surgery (including nephroureterectomy); Chemotherapy; Immunotherapy; Targeted therapy
Tests: Physical exam; Urinalysis; Urine cytology; Intravenous pyelogram; Computerized tomography urogram (CT urogram); Magnetic resonance urogram (MR urogram); Positron emission tomography scan (PET scan); Ureteroscopy; Biopsy; Cystoscopy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis may occur prenatally via ultrasound.  Postnatal diagnosis involves evaluating blood and urine for infection and creatinine levels; ultrasound (retroperitoneal); bladder catheterization with dye injection and X-rays; renal nuclear scan; cystoscopy; CT scan; and MRI.
Treatments: Drainage procedures (ureteral stent; percutaneous nephrostomy; catheter); Surgical procedures (endoscopic surgery; open surgery; laparoscopic surgery; robot-assisted laparoscopic surgery); Antibiotics
Tests: Blood and urine tests; Ultrasound (retroperitoneal); Bladder catheterization; Renal nuclear scan; Cystoscopy; Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); CT urogram

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing symptoms and medical history, and performing a physical exam.  Further diagnostic tests are used to determine the stricture's location, length, and cause.
Treatments: Catheterization; Antibiotics; Self-catheterization; Dilation; Urethroplasty; Endoscopic urethrotomy; Implanted stent or long-term catheter
Tests: Urine tests; Urinary flow test; Urethral ultrasound; Pelvic ultrasound; Pelvic MRI scan; Retrograde urethrogram; Cystoscopy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves determining the type of urinary incontinence through a thorough history, physical exam (including a cough maneuver to demonstrate incontinence), and urinalysis to check for infection, blood, or other abnormalities.  A bladder diary tracks fluid intake, urination frequency and volume, urgency, and incontinence episodes. Postvoid residual measurement assesses leftover urine in the bladder.  Urodynamic testing and pelvic ultrasound may be used for further evaluation, particularly before surgery.
Treatments: Bladder training; Double voiding; Scheduled toilet trips; Fluid and diet management; Pelvic floor muscle exercises (Kegel exercises); Medications; Electrical stimulation; Urethral insert; Pessary; Bulking material injections; OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) injections; Nerve stimulators; Surgery
Tests: Urinalysis; Bladder diary; Postvoid residual measurement; Urodynamic testing; Pelvic ultrasound
Medications_Drugs: oxybutynin (Ditropan XL); tolterodine (Detrol); darifenacin (Enablex); fesoterodine (Toviaz); solifenacin (Vesicare); trospium chloride; mirabegron (Myrbetriq); tamsulosin (Flomax); alfuzosin (Uroxatral); silodosin (Rapaflo); doxazosin (Cardura); Topical estrogen

Diagnosis: Urine sample analysis for white blood cells, red blood cells, and bacteria; Urine culture to identify causative bacteria and guide medication selection; Ultrasound, CT scan, or MRI to rule out structural urinary tract problems; Cystoscopy to visualize the urethra and bladder in cases of recurrent UTIs.
Treatments: Antibiotics; Pain relievers; Low-dose antibiotics (for frequent UTIs); Single-dose antibiotic after sex (for sex-related UTIs); Vaginal estrogen therapy (for postmenopausal women); IV antibiotics (for severe UTIs)
Tests: Urine sample analysis; Urine culture; Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI; Cystoscopy
Medications_Drugs: Trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole (Bactrim, Bactrim DS); Fosfomycin (Monurol); Nitrofurantoin (Macrodantin, Macrobid, Furadantin); Cephalexin; Ceftriaxone; Ciprofloxacin (Cipro); Levofloxacin; Warfarin (Jantovin)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on a patient's health history, physical exam, and results from urinalysis and blood tests.  Urinalysis checks for kidney or urinary tract problems and bacteria; blood tests assess waste product levels (indicating kidney function), liver function, and other conditions like diabetes.  The color of the urine itself is a key observation, considered in conjunction with other symptoms.
Treatments: Information not found
Tests: Urinalysis; Blood tests

Diagnosis: Uterine fibroids are often found incidentally during a routine pelvic exam by palpating irregular changes in the uterine shape.  Symptoms may prompt further investigation.
Treatments: Watchful waiting; Medicines; Focused ultrasound surgery
Tests: Pelvic exam; Ultrasound (transabdominal and transvaginal); Lab tests (complete blood count, tests for bleeding disorders and thyroid problems); Hysterosonography; Hysterosalpingography; Hysteroscopy; MRI
Medications_Drugs: leuprolide (Lupron Depot, Eligard, others); goserelin (Zoladex); triptorelin (Trelstar, Triptodur Kit); elagolix (Oriahnn); relugolix (Myfembree);  progestin-releasing intrauterine device (IUD); tranexamic acid (Lysteda, Cyklokapron); low-dose birth control pills; ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others); naproxen sodium (Aleve); vitamins; iron

Diagnosis: Uterine polyps are diagnosed using transvaginal ultrasound (potentially with saline infusion hysterosonography); hysteroscopy; and endometrial biopsy.  A tissue sample of a removed polyp is analyzed for cancer.  Most polyps are benign, but some may show precancerous changes (endometrial hyperplasia) or cancer.
Treatments: Watchful waiting; Medication; Surgical removal (often via hysteroscopy)
Tests: Transvaginal ultrasound; Hysterosonography; Hysteroscopy; Endometrial biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is often made during a pelvic exam, which may include bearing down to assess uterine descent and tightening pelvic muscles to assess muscle strength; a questionnaire assesses the impact of prolapse on daily life; severe urinary incontinence may warrant urodynamic testing.
Treatments: Self-care measures (Kegel exercises, weight loss, constipation treatment); Pessary; Surgery (hysterectomy; uterus-sparing procedures; surgical repair of pelvic floor structures; colpocleisis; mesh placement)
Tests: Pelvic exam; Urodynamic testing

Diagnosis: Complete eye exam including assessment of vision and pupil response; tonometry; slit-lamp examination; ophthalmoscopy; color photography of the retina; optical coherence tomography (OCT) imaging; fluorescein angiography or indocyanine green angiography; analysis of aqueous or vitreous fluid; blood tests; imaging tests (CT or MRI scans); referral to another doctor for general medical examination and laboratory tests if an underlying condition is suspected.
Treatments: Corticosteroid eye drops; corticosteroid injection; oral corticosteroid tablets; pupil-dilating eye drops; antibiotics; antiviral medications; immunosuppressive drugs; vitrectomy; medication-releasing implant.
Tests: Assessment of vision; pupil response to light; tonometry; slit-lamp examination; ophthalmoscopy; color photography of the retina; optical coherence tomography (OCT) imaging; fluorescein angiography; indocyanine green angiography; analysis of aqueous or vitreous fluid; blood tests; CT scan; MRI scan.
Medications_Drugs: Corticosteroids; antibiotics; antiviral medications; immunosuppressive drugs.

Diagnosis: Diagnosed during puberty if menstruation doesn't start despite breast development and pubic/underarm hair; may be diagnosed earlier if other problems are evaluated or a lack of vaginal opening is noted at birth.  Diagnosis is confirmed through medical history, physical exam, and blood tests to assess chromosomes and hormone levels to rule out other conditions.
Treatments: Self-dilation; Surgery (vaginoplasty using tissue graft, Vecchietti procedure, balloon vaginoplasty, bowel vaginoplasty)
Tests: Blood tests; Ultrasound; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI);  Tests to examine hearing, heart and skeleton

Diagnosis: Pelvic exam to visually examine external genitalia, vagina, and cervix and palpate pelvic organs; Urine test if urinary symptoms are present; Acid balance test of vaginal fluids using a sample or indicator strip.
Treatments: Vaginal moisturizers; Water-based lubricants; Topical estrogen (cream, suppositories, ring, tablet); Ospemifene; Prasterone; Systemic estrogen therapy (pills, patches, gel, higher-dose ring); Vaginal dilators; Pelvic floor physical therapy; Topical lidocaine.
Tests: Pelvic exam; Urine test; Acid balance test; Pap smear (mentioned in more information section,  assumed to be part of the diagnostic process).
Medications_Drugs: Estrace; Premarin; Imvexxy; Estring; Femring; Vagifem; Ospemifene (Osphena); Prasterone (Intrarosa); Topical lidocaine.

Diagnosis: Pelvic exam to inspect reproductive organs and vagina; Colposcopy to magnify the vaginal surface; Biopsy to remove and test vaginal tissue for cancer cells; Imaging tests (X-rays, CT, MRI, PET) to determine cancer stage; Cystoscopy to examine the bladder; Proctoscopy to examine the rectum.
Treatments: Radiation therapy (external beam radiation, brachytherapy); Chemotherapy (low-dose during radiation); Surgery (vaginectomy, pelvic exenteration, vaginal reconstruction); Immunotherapy; Palliative care; Clinical trials
Tests: Pelvic exam; Colposcopy; Biopsy; X-ray; CT scan; MRI; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; Cystoscopy; Proctoscopy

Diagnosis: Physical exam (including pelvic exam checking for scarring, irregular discharge, leaking urine/stool, abscesses); Dye test; Cystoscopy; Retrograde pyelogram; Fistulogram; Flexible sigmoidoscopy; Computerized tomography (CT) urogram; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Colonoscopy; Biopsy; Blood and urine tests.
Treatments: Placement of urinary catheter; Ureteral stenting; Dietary changes (for simple fistula between vagina and rectum); Supplements (to soften stool); Antibiotics (for infection); Biologics (for inflammation due to conditions like Crohn's disease); Surgery (to remove fistula tract and stitch healthy tissue, possibly using a tissue flap; laparoscopic surgery or robotic-assisted surgery may be used); Colostomy (temporary or permanent, before surgery for some recto-vaginal fistulas).
Tests: Dye test; Cystoscopy; Retrograde pyelogram; Fistulogram; Flexible sigmoidoscopy; Computerized tomography (CT) urogram; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Colonoscopy; Biopsy; Blood tests; Urine tests

Diagnosis: Review of medical history (including history of vaginal or sexually transmitted infections); Pelvic exam with speculum to visualize inflammation and discharge; Collection of cervical or vaginal discharge sample for lab testing; Vaginal pH testing (though not reliable alone).
Treatments: Treatment varies depending on the cause (bacterial vaginosis, yeast infection, trichomoniasis, genitourinary syndrome of menopause, noninfectious vaginitis);  For bacterial vaginosis: metronidazole tablets or gel; clindamycin cream, tablets, or vaginal capsules; tinidazole or secnidazole tablets; For yeast infections: over-the-counter antifungal creams or suppositories (miconazole, clotrimazole, butoconazole, tioconazole); prescription oral antifungal medication (fluconazole); For trichomoniasis: metronidazole or tinidazole tablets; For genitourinary syndrome of menopause: estrogen vaginal creams, tablets, or rings; For noninfectious vaginitis: identify and avoid irritants.
Tests: Pelvic exam; Vaginal discharge sample collection; Vaginal pH test
Medications_Drugs: Metronidazole; Clindamycin; Tinidazole; Secnidazole; Miconazole; Clotrimazole; Butoconazole; Tioconazole; Fluconazole; Estrogen

Diagnosis: Evaluation of medical history and signs/symptoms;  Diagnosis is difficult based on symptoms alone; Sputum smear or culture to check for Coccidioides organisms; Blood tests to check for antibodies against the fungus; Imaging tests (CT scan, MRI, chest X-ray) may be ordered, especially if pneumonia is suspected; Tissue sample from lungs may be taken for testing; Skin test may be done to determine past infection and immunity.
Treatments: Supportive care; Antifungal medications
Tests: Sputum smear or culture; Blood tests; Computed tomography (CT) scan; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Chest X-ray; Tissue sample from lungs; Skin test
Medications_Drugs: Fluconazole; Itraconazole; Amphotericin B; Voriconazole; Posaconazole; Isavuconazonium sulfate

Diagnosis: Visual inspection of the scrotum and palpation while lying down and standing; Valsalva maneuver may be used to enhance palpation.
Treatments: Surgery (microscopic varicocelectomy; laparoscopic varicocelectomy); Embolization; Annual checkups (for teenagers and young adults without fertility issues); Observation (if asymptomatic); Pain medication (acetaminophen; ibuprofen)
Tests: Ultrasound

Diagnosis: Physical examination of the legs while standing, observing for swelling; assessment of leg pain and aching.
Treatments: Self-care measures (exercise, leg elevation, compression stockings); compression stockings; sclerotherapy; laser treatment; catheter-based procedures using radiofrequency or laser energy; high ligation and vein stripping; ambulatory phlebectomy
Tests: Venous Doppler ultrasound of the leg

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on clinical judgment considering patient-reported symptoms, medical history of stroke or cardiovascular disorders, and results of various tests to rule out other causes of cognitive decline.  There is no single definitive test for vascular dementia.
Treatments: Managing contributing health conditions and risk factors; Medications to lower blood pressure; Medications to reduce cholesterol; Medications to prevent blood clotting; Medications to control blood sugar (if diabetic); Regular physical activity; Healthy diet; Weight management; Social engagement; Cognitive stimulation activities
Tests: Blood pressure test; Cholesterol test; Blood sugar test; Thyroid function tests; Vitamin level tests; Neurological exam; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Computerized tomography (CT) scan; Neuropsychological tests

Diagnosis: Diagnosis starts with a medical history and physical exam, followed by tests and procedures to diagnose vasculitis or rule out other conditions with similar symptoms.  Diagnostic tests may include blood tests (to look for inflammation markers like C-reactive protein and ANCA antibodies, and to assess red blood cell count), imaging tests (X-rays, ultrasounds, CT scans, MRIs, PET scans, and angiography), and biopsy of affected tissue.
Treatments: Medication; Surgery
Tests: Blood tests; Imaging tests (X-rays; ultrasounds; CT scans; MRIs; PET scans; angiography); Biopsy; Urinalysis
Medications_Drugs: Prednisone; methotrexate; azathioprine; mycophenolate mofetil; cyclophosphamide; tocilizumab; rituximab

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam including heart auscultation and blood pressure measurement; carotid sinus massage may be performed; further tests are done to rule out other causes, particularly cardiac conditions.
Treatments: Avoidance of triggers; Fludrocortisone acetate; Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors; Foot exercises; Compression stockings; Leg muscle tensing; Increased dietary salt (if not hypertensive); Avoiding prolonged standing, especially in hot, crowded places; Increased fluid intake; Pacemaker implantation (rarely)
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG); Echocardiogram; Exercise stress test; Blood tests; Tilt table test
Medications_Drugs: Fludrocortisone acetate; Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors

Diagnosis: Ventricular fibrillation is always diagnosed in an emergency situation; a pulse check will reveal no pulse.  Diagnosis is confirmed using an electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) which shows a rapid heartbeat (about 300-400 beats per minute) during an episode.  Further tests determine the underlying cause.
Treatments: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR); Defibrillation; Medications; Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD); Cardiac ablation; Coronary angioplasty and stent placement
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Blood tests; Chest X-ray; Echocardiogram; Coronary catheterization (angiogram); Cardiac computerized tomography (CT); Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
Medications_Drugs: Drugs to control the heart rhythm (anti-arrhythmics)  (Specific drug names not listed)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis may occur shortly after birth, later in life, or prenatally via ultrasound.  A heart murmur may be detected by auscultation.
Treatments: Regular health checkups; Medications; Surgery;  Extra nutrition (for babies); Catheter procedure; Open-heart surgery
Tests: Echocardiogram; Electrocardiogram (ECG); Chest X-ray; Pulse oximetry; Cardiac catheterization; Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan; Computerized tomography (CT) scan
Medications_Drugs: Water pills (diuretics); Oxygen; Antibiotics (for endocarditis prevention)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a thorough physical exam, medical history review, and various tests to confirm ventricular tachycardia (V-tach) and identify any underlying causes.  Diagnosis may occur during an emergency medical situation at a hospital.
Treatments: Medications; Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD); Subcutaneous implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (S-ICD);  Surgery; Treatment of underlying medical conditions
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; Cardiac event monitor; Implantable loop recorder; Exercise stress test; Chest X-ray; Echocardiogram; Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); Cardiac computerized tomography (CT); Coronary angiogram; Electrophysiological (EP) study; Tilt table test

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam and review of symptoms and health history, focusing on past cancer diagnoses or treatments. Imaging tests (X-ray, MRI, CT scan, PET scan) determine tumor size and location. A needle biopsy confirms the diagnosis by analyzing a tissue sample for tumor type and cancerous nature.
Treatments: Surgery; Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Vertebroplasty; Kyphoplasty; Ablation (radiofrequency ablation, microwave ablation, cryoablation); Careful monitoring
Tests: Physical exam; Neurological exam; X-ray; MRI; CT scan; PET scan; Needle biopsy
Medications_Drugs: Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy (specific medications not named)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a urine test to detect UTIs;  further investigation may include kidney and bladder ultrasound to identify irregularities or swollen kidneys; a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) uses X-rays to visualize the bladder and urethra during filling and emptying to detect reflux; a nuclear scan with radioisotope tracer assesses urinary tract function.  The degree of reflux is graded (1-5) based on the extent of urine backflow and kidney involvement.
Treatments: Wait-and-see approach (for mild cases); Antibiotics (for UTIs and prevention); Surgery (open surgery; robot-assisted laparoscopic surgery; endoscopic surgery; nephrectomy in severe cases); Pelvic floor rehabilitation and biofeedback (for bladder and bowel dysfunction contributing to VUR).
Tests: Urine test; Kidney and bladder ultrasound; Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG); Nuclear scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily based on symptoms and physical examination;  A rapid stool test can detect rotavirus or norovirus; A stool sample may be submitted to rule out bacterial or parasitic infection.
Treatments: Self-care measures (hydration, rest, dietary changes); Oral rehydration solutions; Loperamide (Imodium A-D); Bismuth subsalicylate (Pepto-Bismol)
Tests: Rapid stool test; Stool sample for culture

Diagnosis: Diagnosing viral hemorrhagic fevers in the early stages can be difficult due to overlapping symptoms with other conditions.  Diagnosis relies on considering medical and travel history, animal exposure (mosquitoes, ticks, rodents, nonhuman primates, bats),  and lab tests using blood samples.  These tests are often conducted in specialized labs due to the contagious nature of the fevers.
Treatments: Supportive care; IV fluids; Kidney dialysis (in some cases)
Tests: Blood sample

Diagnosis: Vitamin deficiency anemias are diagnosed through blood tests that check red blood cell count and appearance; vitamin B-12 and folate levels; and the presence of antibodies to intrinsic factor (indicative of pernicious anemia).
Treatments: Vitamin B-12 injections; Vitamin B-12 pills; Vitamin B-12 sublingual tablets or liquids; Vitamin B-12 nasal gel or sprays; Folate pills; Intravenous folate
Tests: Blood tests to check red blood cell count and appearance; Blood tests to measure vitamin B-12 and folate levels; Antibody test for intrinsic factor

Diagnosis: A medical history review and skin examination, possibly using a special lamp;  a skin biopsy and blood tests may also be included.
Treatments: Self-tanning products; makeup; Corticosteroid cream; Corticosteroid pills or injections; Calcineurin inhibitor ointments (tacrolimus, pimecrolimus); Narrow band ultraviolet B (UVB) phototherapy; Psoralen and light therapy (photochemotherapy); Depigmenting agent; Skin grafting; Blister grafting
Tests: Skin biopsy; Antinuclear antibody (ANA) test; Complete blood count (CBC)

Diagnosis: Assessment of symptoms and voice; Laryngoscopy (using a mirror, laryngoscope, endoscope, or videostrobolaryngoscopy); Laryngeal electromyography; Blood tests; X-rays; MRI; CT scans.
Treatments: Voice therapy; Bulk injections (with substances like body fat, collagen, or other approved fillers); Surgery (including thyroplasty, medialization laryngoplasty, laryngeal framework surgery, vocal cord repositioning, reinnervation, tracheotomy);  Electrical stimulation (emerging treatment)
Tests: Laryngoscopy; Videostrobolaryngoscopy; Laryngeal electromyography; Blood tests; X-rays; MRI; CT scan

Diagnosis: A health care provider will ask about voice problems and perform an examination, potentially using a mirror, flexible laryngoscope, rigid laryngoscope, or videostroboscope to visualize the vocal cords.  Sound analysis and laryngeal electromyography may also be used.
Treatments: Rest; Liquids; Voice therapy; Allergy treatments; Smoking cessation; Medication; Removal of growths (microsurgery, carbon-dioxide laser surgery, KTP laser treatment); Injections of botulinum toxin; Fat or collagen injection; Thyroplasty
Tests: Mirror examination; Flexible laryngoscopy; Rigid laryngoscopy; Videostroboscopy; Sound analysis; Laryngeal electromyography
Medications_Drugs: Botulinum toxin (specific medications within this class are not specified)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis of mild von Willebrand disease can be challenging due to common bleeding not always indicating the disease.  A hematologist may be consulted. Diagnosis involves detailed medical history review, examination for bruises and bleeding signs, and blood tests.
Treatments: Desmopressin (DDAVP); Replacement therapies (infusions of concentrated blood-clotting factors containing von Willebrand factor and factor VIII); Recombinant von Willebrand factor product; Oral contraceptives; Clot-stabilizing medications (aminocaproic acid, tranexamic acid); Fibrin sealant (Tisseel);  Treatment only during surgery, dental work, or trauma for mild cases.
Tests: Von Willebrand factor antigen; Von Willebrand factor activity; Factor VIII clotting activity; Von Willebrand factor multimers
Medications_Drugs: Desmopressin (DDAVP); Aminocaproic acid (Amicar); Tranexamic acid (Cyklokapron, Lysteda); Oral contraceptives; Acetaminophen (Tylenol); Aspirin; Ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB); Naproxen sodium (Aleve)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis begins with a physical exam and health history review; a colposcope may be used for close inspection; a biopsy (skin sample) is performed for lab testing.
Treatments: Surgery (partial or radical vulvectomy, wide local excision, radical excision); Radiation therapy; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy
Tests: Physical exam of vulva; Colposcopy; Biopsy; Examination of pelvic area for cancer spread; X-ray; MRI; CT scan; Positron emission tomography (PET) scan; Sentinel node biopsy

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a pelvic exam to check for infection or other causes; questions about medical and sexual history and prior surgeries; a cotton swab test to identify painful areas; and potentially a biopsy if vulvar skin appears abnormal.
Treatments: Medications; Physical therapy (pelvic floor therapy, biofeedback); Talk therapy (cognitive behavioral therapy, couples therapy, sex therapy); Surgery (vestibulectomy); Alternative medicine (acupuncture, hypnosis, mindfulness/meditation, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation)
Tests: Pelvic exam; Cotton swab test; Biopsy; Blood test (for hormone levels)
Medications_Drugs: Antidepressants; Anticonvulsants; Local anesthetics (e.g., lidocaine ointment); Estrogen cream; Testosterone cream; Antihistamines

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam, medical history review, and blood tests to detect abnormally low healthy blood cells and elevated IgM protein levels; bone marrow biopsy to identify cancer cells; imaging tests (CT scans or PET scans) to assess disease spread.
Treatments: Watchful waiting; Plasma exchange; Chemotherapy; Targeted therapy; Immunotherapy; Bone marrow transplant; Supportive care
Tests: Blood tests; Bone marrow biopsy; CT scans; PET scans

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a physical exam, detailed medical history, and various tests.  A positive skin test showing a reaction to wheat protein extracts suggests allergy; a blood test can detect wheat-specific allergy antibodies if a skin test isn't possible; a food diary and elimination diet help identify triggers; and a food challenge test, under supervision, confirms diagnosis by gradually introducing wheat while monitoring for reactions.
Treatments: Avoiding wheat proteins; Antihistamines; Epinephrine for anaphylaxis; Immunotherapy (potential future treatment)
Tests: Skin test; Blood test; Food diary; Elimination diet; Food challenge testing

Diagnosis: Healthcare professional assessment of the event and symptoms; evaluation of symptom severity and frequency; assessment of ability to perform daily tasks; physical examination including range of motion testing, pain assessment during movement, palpation for tenderness, and assessment of reflexes, strength, and sensation in limbs.
Treatments: Rest; Heat or cold application; Pain medicines available without a prescription; Prescription medicines; Muscle relaxants; Numbing shots; Stretching and movement exercises; Physical therapy; Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS); Foam collar (short-term use, under professional guidance).; Acupuncture; Chiropractic adjustment; Massage; Mind-body therapies (Tai chi, Qigong, Yoga)
Tests: X-rays; CT scan; MRI
Medications_Drugs: Acetaminophen; Ibuprofen; Antidepressant drugs (for nerve pain); Muscle relaxants; Lidocaine

Diagnosis: Diagnosis typically involves a physical exam looking for symptoms like stomach tenderness and skin darkening; a small intestine biopsy via upper endoscopy to examine tissue for *Tropheryma whipplei* bacteria and lesions;  a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test to detect *T. whipplei* in biopsy or spinal fluid samples; and blood tests to check for anemia and low albumin.  Additional biopsies from lymph nodes or capsule endoscopy may be used if initial tests are inconclusive.
Treatments: Long-term antibiotic treatment; Vitamin and mineral supplementation
Tests: Physical exam; Biopsy (small intestine, lymph node); Upper endoscopy; Capsule endoscopy; Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test; Complete blood count
Medications_Drugs: Ceftriaxone; Penicillin; Sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim (Bactrim, Septra); Doxycycline (Vibramycin, Doryx); Hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil)

Diagnosis: Diagnosis may involve reviewing symptoms and conducting a physical exam;  a nose or throat culture to check for the bacteria; blood tests to check for antibodies (though not specific to whooping cough); a chest X-ray to check for pneumonia.
Treatments: Hospitalization for infants;  Intravenous fluids for infants unable to keep down food or liquids; Isolation to prevent spread; Home treatment for older children and adults; Antibiotics
Tests: Nose or throat culture; Blood test; Chest X-ray

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a family history review, physical exam for signs of Wilms tumor, blood and urine tests to assess kidney function, and imaging tests (ultrasound, CT scans, MRI, chest X-rays) to identify kidney tumors.  Staging involves additional tests (chest X-ray, chest CT scan, bone scan) to determine cancer spread.
Treatments: Surgery (partial nephrectomy, radical nephrectomy); Chemotherapy; Radiation therapy; Proton beam therapy
Tests: Physical exam; Blood tests; Urine tests; Ultrasound; CT scan; MRI; Chest X-ray; Bone scan

Diagnosis: Diagnosis can be challenging due to overlapping symptoms with other liver diseases. Diagnosis relies on symptoms and test results, including blood and urine tests to assess liver function, ceruloplasmin and copper levels; eye exam for Kayser-Fleischer rings and sunflower cataracts; liver biopsy for copper levels; and genetic testing to identify the causative gene.
Treatments: Copper chelating agents; Liver transplant; Dietary copper restriction
Tests: Blood and urine tests; Eye exam (slit-lamp exam); Liver biopsy; Genetic testing
Medications_Drugs: Penicillamine (Cuprimine, Depen); Trientine (Cuvrior, Syprine); Zinc acetate (Galzin)

Diagnosis: Physical examination including listening to the heart with a stethoscope and review of medical history and symptoms; Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) to identify heartbeat patterns suggestive of an extra electrical pathway.
Treatments: Vagal maneuvers (coughing, bearing down, ice pack on face); Medications; Cardioversion; Catheter ablation
Tests: Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG); Holter monitor; Event recorder; Electrophysiological (EP) study

Diagnosis: Visual examination of skin to assess lines and creases; review of medical history and patient preferences to determine appropriate treatment.
Treatments: Prescription creams and serums (retinoids); Botox injections; Chemical peel; Facial fillers (calcium hydroxylapatite, poly-L-lactic acid, hyaluronic acid); Laser resurfacing (ablative, nonablative, fractional); Deoxycholic acid injections; Face-lift; Neck lift
Tests: Information not found

Diagnosis: Physical exam checking for tenderness, swelling, deformity, range of motion, grip strength, and forearm strength; imaging tests (X-ray, CT, MRI, ultrasound) to visualize bones and soft tissues; arthroscopy for detailed evaluation of long-term pain; electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction studies if carpal tunnel syndrome is suspected.
Treatments: Nonprescription pain relievers; Prescription pain relievers; Corticosteroid injections; Physical therapy; Ergonomic evaluation; Cast or splint immobilization; Surgery (for bone fractures, carpal tunnel syndrome, tendon or ligament repair)
Tests: X-ray; CT scan; MRI; Ultrasound; Arthroscopy; Electromyography (EMG); Nerve conduction studies

Diagnosis: Medical history of recurrent infections; physical exam; blood tests; genetic testing.
Treatments: Boosting the immune system to prevent infections; quick treatment of infections as they occur.
Tests: Blood tests; genetic testing

Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves reviewing medical history (including past vaginal or sexually transmitted infections) and conducting a pelvic exam to visually inspect the genitals and vagina using a speculum;  Vaginal fluid is tested to identify yeast or the specific fungus causing the infection.
Treatments: Short-course vaginal therapy (3-7 days of antifungal cream, ointment, tablet, or suppository); One-dose oral fluconazole; Long-course vaginal therapy (daily antifungal for up to two weeks, then once weekly for six months); More than one dose of oral antifungal medication; Boric acid therapy (vaginal capsule, not for oral use).
Tests: Pelvic exam; Vaginal fluid test
Medications_Drugs: miconazole; terconazole; fluconazole; oteseconazole; ibrexafungerp; boric acid

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on patient-reported symptoms; Video recording of wrist movement during putting can aid diagnosis; Neurologic exam may be performed to rule out other causes.
Treatments: Change of grip; Use of a different putter (longer putter or putter with a stabilizing grip); Changing head position and eye focus during putting; Mental skills training (relaxation, visualization, positive thinking); Oral medications; Botulinum toxin injection.
Tests: Neurologic exam
Medications_Drugs: Benzodiazepines; Baclofen; Anticholinergic drugs; Propranolol; OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox); IncobotulinumtoxinA (Xeomin); AbobotulinumtoxinA (Dysport); Botulinum toxin type B (Myobloc)

Diagnosis: Physical exam by an ENT specialist to assess symptoms; Barium swallow X-ray to visualize the digestive tract.
Treatments: Eating softer foods in smaller bites; Endoscopic repair (rigid or flexible endoscope using laser, stapler, or electrocautery); Endoscopic diverticulectomy; Open surgery (incision in the neck to remove the bulge).
Tests: Barium swallow

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on medical history, high gastrin levels (confirmed by blood tests, potentially repeated and including a secretin stimulation test), and the presence of ulcers or gastrin-producing tumors (identified through upper gastrointestinal endoscopy with biopsy and potentially endoscopic ultrasound).  High gastrin levels alone are not definitive as they can be caused by other conditions.  A combination of high gastrin levels with acid production and ulcers detected through endoscopy establishes the diagnosis.
Treatments: Surgical removal of gastrinomas (if feasible); Debulking of liver tumors; Tumor embolization; Radiofrequency ablation;  Injection of drugs into the tumor; Chemotherapy; Liver transplant; Proton pump inhibitors; Octreotide
Tests: Blood tests (gastrin levels, chromogranin A); Secretin stimulation test; Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy with biopsy; Endoscopic ultrasound; CT scans; MRI imaging; Ga-DOTATATE PET-CT scanning
Medications_Drugs: Lansoprazole (Prevacid); Omeprazole (Prilosec, Zegerid); Pantoprazole (Protonix); Rabeprazole (Aciphex); Esomeprazole (Nexium); Octreotide (Sandostatin)
